question_text: A child who underwent ventriculoperitoneal shunt surgery for tubercular meningitis with hydrocephalus, develops polyuria and hyponatremia. What could be the probable cause?
explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of cerebral salt wasting. Both SIADH and cerebral salt wasting cause hyponatremia, but polyuria happens in cerebral salt wasting. Cerebral salt wasting results from hypersecretion of atrial natriuretic peptide. It is seen primarily with central nervous system disorders including brain tumors, head trauma, hydrocephalus, neurosurgery, cerebrovascular accidents, and brain death. It is associated with hyponatremia, polyuria and elevated urinary sodium excretion. Treatment is by restoring intravascular volume with sodium chloride and water. question_text: A patient who presented with acute confusion and vomiting was diagnosed to have SIADH. This condition can be best treated by which of the following methods?
explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of acute symptomatic SIADH and this condition is best treated by the infusion of hypertonic (3%) saline. This mode of treatment also helps in the correction of sodium deficiency that is partly responsible for hyponatremia. The other form of treatment is to help reduce the concentration of body water by giving an AVP receptor-2 antagonist, conivaptan. Conivaptan blocks the antidiuretic effect of AVP and increases urine output. DDAVP is a synthetic analog of AVP and should not be used as it will further increase water retention.
subject: Medicine

question_text: What is the drug of choice for the treatment of chronic SIADH?
explanation: The drug of choice for the treatment of chronic SIADH is tolvaptan. Vaptans are selective V2 receptor antagonists that act by increasing urinary water excretion by blocking the antidiuretic effect of AVP. Treatment options for chronic SIADH include: Restriction of fluid intake to below the level of urine output - This is considered the mainstay of treatment. But it also has certain disadvantages as stated below, and hence adding on a drug like vaptan is necessary in most cases. Tolvaptan Demeclocycline Fludrocortisone Advantages of vaptans over fluid restriction: Fluid restriction is usually a burden to the patient, unreliable, impractical, and slow to work. Increased thirst is a frequently observed characteristic of hyponatremia in SIADH, and is particularly difficult to suppress. Hence, water restriction in SIADH frequently leads to non-compliance in the long run.
subject: Medicine

question_text:
What causes central pontine myelinolysis?
Hyponatremia
explanation: Rapid correction of hyponatremia may result in central pontine myelinolysis. Central pontine myelinolysis is an osmotic demyelination syndrome (ODS), wherein rapid correction of hyponatremia results in water being driven out of the cell which has adapted to a chronic state of hypotonicity, leading to damage to the myelin sheath of these cells. It is characterized by the acute onset of quadriparesis, ataxia, and abnormal extraocular movements. Thyroid Disorders - Clinical Features

question_text: Which of the following is a specific sign for Graves' disease?
explanation: Ophthalmopathy is the specific sign of Graves’ disease. Glycosaminoglycan deposition, lymphoid infiltrates and fatty infiltration are responsible for ophthalmopathy and dermopathy. Grave's disease is an autoimmune disorder due to the production of TSH-receptor stimulating immunoglobulins (TSI) thereby causing hyperthyroidism. It is characterized by the triad of: Thyrotoxicosis Infiltrative ophthalmopathy (exophthalmos) Dermopathy (pretibial myxedema) Ophthalmopathy can sometimes precede or follow thyrotoxicosis, accounting for some cases of euthyroid ophthalmopathy.

question_text: A patient with Graves' disease presents with the following finding. Which statement regarding this condition is false?
options: Acropachy is strongly associated with this condition.
It occurs in more than 50% of patients with Graves' disease.
It occurs almost always in the presence of moderate or severe form of ophthalmopathy.
Skin changes can occur after trauma.
explanation: The given scenario along with the image is suggestive of thyroid dermopathy. It occurs in <5% of patients with Graves’ disease. Thyroid dermopathy is almost always associated with ophthalmopathy. Thyroid dermopathy is most frequently observed over the anterolateral parts of the lower leg. Hence, it is termed pretibial myxedema. Skin changes can occur at other sites, particularly after trauma. The typical lesion is a noninflamed, indurated plaque with a deep pink or purple color and orange peel-textured papules. Thyroid acropachy refers to a form of clubbing rarely observed in Graves’ disease. It is strongly associated with thyroid dermopathy. Thyroid dermopathy usually does not need any active treatment, but if necessary, treatment includes topical, high-potency glucocorticoid ointment under an occlusive dressing or octreotide can be useful in some cases. question_text: A patient from a hilly area was referred with a partial small bowel obstruction confirmed on CECT. Conservative management was tried for a week, but he continued to deteriorate and was taken up for emergency laparotomy. On post-operative day 7, he developed atrial fibrillation. Investigations revealed elevated free T3 and free T4 levels. What is the most probable cause?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of the Jod-Basedow phenomenon, likely due to the administration of an iodine-containing contrast agent during CECT. question_text: Which of the following conditions is not associated with amiodarone therapy?
explanation: Silent thyroiditis is not associated with amiodarone therapy. Amiodarone has the following effects on the thyroid gland: Acute, transient suppression of thyroid function i.e., Wolff-Chaikoff effect Hypothyroidism in patients susceptible to the inhibitory effects of a high iodine load Thyrotoxicosis may be caused by Jod-Basedow phenomenon due to the iodine load, in the setting of multinodular goitre or incipient Graves’ disease. It can also be caused by a thyroiditis-like condition. Painless thyroiditis, or silent thyroiditis, occurs in patients with underlying autoimmune thyroid disease and has a clinical course similar to that of subacute thyroiditis. The condition can occur in up to 5% of women 3–6 months after pregnancy and is then termed postpartum thyroiditis.

question_text: Which of the following statements about amiodarone-induced thyrotoxicosis is false?
options: Type 2 AIT is associated with intrinsic abnormalities of the thyroid gland

question_text: Which of the following statements is true about non-toxic multinodular goitre?
options: It is more commonly observed in women
It does not occur in iodine-deficient regions
Most patients with non-toxic MNG have hypothyroidism
Risk of malignancy is higher than in cases of solitary thyroid nodule
explanation: Multinodular goitre (MNG) is more commonly observed in women. It is common in iodine-deficient regions. Most patients are asymptomatic and euthyroid. Sudden pain may occur due to haemorrhage. TFTs should be performed in all patients to exclude thyrotoxicosis or hypothyroidism. The risk of malignancy due to MNG is similar to that due to solitary nodules. Hoarseness, reflecting the involvement of laryngeal nerves implicate malignancy. Most non-toxic MNGs can be managed conservatively. Levothyroxine if used, should be started at low doses and then increased gradually. Radioiodine therapy is implemented for large goitres as it decreases goitre size and can ablate regions of autonomy.

question_text: What is the major difference between non-toxic and toxic multinodular goitre?
explanation: The major difference between toxic and non-toxic multinodular goiter (MNG) is the presence of functional autonomy in toxic MNG. The pathogenesis of toxic MNG appears to be similar to that of non-toxic MNG. In both types, many nodules are polyclonal whereas others are monoclonal and vary in their clonal origins. Most patients with non-toxic MNG are asymptomatic and euthyroid. However, patients with toxic MNG have subclinical or mild hyperthyroidism.
subject: Medicine

question_text: What is the most common thyroid malignancy?
explanation: Papillary carcinoma is the most common thyroid malignancy. Prevalence of different types of thyroid malignancies: Type of malignan cy Occure nce Papillary 80-90 % Follicular 5-10% Medullary <10% Others 1-2%
subject: Medicine

question_text: The following patients presented with thyroid nodules. Who has the least risk of developing thyroid carcinoma?
options: A 55-year-old woman with no voice abnormalities and nodule size of 3 cms
A 65-year-old woman with vocal cord paralysis and hoarse voice and nodule size of 3.5 cms
A 60-year-old man without any voice abnormalities and nodule size of 2.5 cms
A 43-year-old woman with no voice abnormalities and nodule size of 4.5 cm
explanation: Among the options, the female patient with age between 20 and 65 years and no voice abnormalities and nodule size < 4 cm has the least risk for development of thyroid carcinoma. Risk factors for the development of thyroid carcinoma in patients with thyroid nodules include: Age less than 20 or greater than 65 years Male gender Increased nodule size > 4 cm Vocal cord paralysis and hoarse voice New or enlarged neck mass Family history of thyroid cancer, MEN2, or other syndromes associated with thyroid malignancy (e.g., Cowden’s syndrome, familial polyposis, Carney complex) Nodule fixed to adjacent structures Exposure to radiation in childhood or adolescence Extrathyroidal extension Lateral cervical lymphadenopathy
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following statements is not true about thyroid hormone resistance?
options: Inherited as an autosomal recessive disorder
Characterized by elevated thyroid hormone levels and normal or elevated TSH
Classic forms are caused by mutations in TR- gene
explanation: Thyroid hormone resistance is an autosomal dominant disorder. It is characterized by elevated thyroid hormone levels and inappropriately elevated or normal TSH levels. Classic forms of the disease are attributed to the mutation in TR- gene. Patients with this condition are often asymptomatic, as hormone resistance is partial and compensated by the increase in thyroid hormone levels. In most patients, no treatment is indicated.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Patients with what condition present with normal thyroglobulin levels?
explanation: Serum thyroglobulin levels are normal in patients with thyrotoxicosis factitia, as it is caused by the self-administration of thyroid hormone. Its level is elevated in all other types of thyrotoxicosis. Thyroglobulin (Tg) levels are particularly increased in thyroiditis, implicating destruction of thyroid tissue and release of thyroglobulin. The primary course of action for determining the thyroglobulin levels, however, is in the clinical follow-up of thyroid cancer patients. Following total thyroidectomy and radiofrequency ablation, thyroglobulin levels become undetectable. In the absence of anti-Tg antibodies, measurable levels of Tg are indicative of incomplete ablation or recurrent cancer.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A patient presented with fever and painful neck swelling. She gives a history of sore throat and cough one week ago. Lab investigations revealed elevated T3 and T4 levels and elevated ESR. Which of the following statements about this condition is false?
options: Treatment of choice is supportive care and NSAIDs
Women are generally affected three times more often than men
Both thyrotoxic and hypothyroid phases can be observed
explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of De Quervain’s thyroiditis, and it is not autoimmune in origin. It is subacute granulomatous thyroiditis that occurs secondary to viral infections. Many viruses such as mumps, influenza, coxsackie, adenoviruses, and echoviruses have been clinically implicated in this condition. Peak incidence is observed at 30-50 years and women are generally affected three times more often than men. Clinically, it presents as a painfully enlarged thyroid and is sometimes accompanied by fever. It has three distinct phases: Thyrotoxic phase Hypothyroid phase Recovery phase Treatment includes large doses of aspirin, NSAIDs, steroids and/or beta-blockers to relieve the observable clinical symptoms. Antithyroid drugs do not have any role. In case the hypothyroid phase is prolonged - levothyroxine can be used.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following conditions is not associated with hypothyroidism?
explanation: Graves' disease is not associated with hypothyroidism.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 4-month-old baby presented with a history of constipation, lethargy, and has poor activities. Clinical examination reveals jaundice, hypotonia and there was no palpable goitre. Laboratory investigations revealed low T4 and elevated TSH levels. Which of the following is not true about this condition?
options: Most common cause is inborn defects in the synthesis of thyroid hormone
The developmental abnormalities are more common in girls
High circulating T4 level is needed to normalize TSH
explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of congenital hypothyroidism. The most common cause of this condition is thyroid gland dysgenesis, seen in about 80-85% of cases of neonatal hypothyroidism. In the remaining cases of neonatal hypothyroidism, it is due to inborn defects in thyroid hormone synthesis and rarely due to TSH receptor antibodies. These developmental abnormalities are twice as common in girls. Clinical features include: Prolonged jaundice Umbilical hernia Enlarged tongue Hypotonia Delayed bone maturation Permanent neurological damage results if treatment is delayed. T4 requirements are relatively high during the first year of life. A high circulating T4 level is needed to normalize TSH. Early treatment with T4 results in normal IQ levels by preventing neurodevelopmental abnormalities.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Patients with autoimmune hypothyroidism have a higher predisposition for all except:
explanation: Autoimmune hypothyroidism is usually not associated with type II diabetes mellitus. Genetic risk factors for autoimmune hypothyroidism has been documented with HLA-DR3, HLA-DR4, HLA-DR5. A weak association also exists with CTLA4 gene polymorphism. This may explain the relationship between autoimmune hypothyroidism and type I diabetes mellitus, Addison's disease, pernicious anemia, and vitiligo. Less commonly encountered clinical associations include: Celiac disease Dermatitis herpetiformis Chronic active hepatitis Rheumatoid arthritis Myasthenia gravis Systemic lupus erythematosus Sjogren's syndrome.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Most common symptom seen in patients with hypothyroidism is?
explanation: The most common symptom of hypothyroidism is tiredness and weakness. question_text: An elderly patient presents to the ER with symptoms suggestive of myxedema coma. Which of the following is unlikely to be seen in this patient?
explanation: Hyperthermia is least likely in this patient. Clinical manifestations of myxedema coma include decreased consciousness, seizures and hypothermia. Myxedema coma is a serious condition with a mortality rate of 20-40%. The clinical outcomes are independent of the detected T4 and TSH levels. Clinical features of myxedema crisis include: Impaired cognition, ranging from confusion to somnolence to coma (myxedema coma) Convulsions and abnormal CNS signs. Profound hypothermia (can reach 23°C), hypoventilation, hyponatremia, hypoglycemia, hypoxemia, hypercapnia, and hypotension. Rhabdomyolysis and acute kidney injury.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A patient came to the hospital with complaints of lethargy, increased sleep, and weight gain. Investigations revealed low plasma TSH concentration. However, on the ■administration of TRH, the TSH levels increased. Which of the following conditions is likely in this patient?
options: Hyperthyroidism due to disease in the pituitary
Hypothyroidism due to disease in the pituitary
Hypothyroidism due to disease in the hypothalamus
Hyperthyroidism due to disease in the hypothalamus
explanation: The presenting symptoms of lethargy, increased sleep, and weight gain are suggestive of hypothyroidism. An increase in TSH on administration of TRH confirms the lack of stimulus for TSH secretion from the hypothalamus. Although decreased TSH levels can be seen in hyperthyroidism, clinical features such as lethargy, increased sleep and weight gain are not. This pushes the diagnosis in favor of hypothyroidism. If the disease was in the pituitary, there would be no increase in TSH secretion on administration of TRH (Option B). Normally, the thyrotropin releasing hormone (TRH) is released by the hypothalamus. It stimulates the pituitary gland to release the thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), which in turn stimulates the thyroid gland to produce T3 and T4 hormones. Low TSH levels may be seen in the following cases: Disease Pathogenesis Presentation Hyperthyroidism Feedback inhibition of TSH r elease Symptoms of hyperthyroidis m Primary disease of the pituita ry Decreased release of TSH, th ereby causing a decreased rel ease of thyroid hormones Symptoms of hypothyroidism. question_text:
A middle-aged woman with a history of constipation, dry skin and menorrhagia presents to the ER with altered sensorium, non-pitting edema, hypothermia, bradycardia, and hypotension. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Septic shock
explanation: The given clinical history is typical of a case of hypothyroidism and the diagnosis is myxedema coma, which is a serious complication of hypothyroidism. Myxedema coma is a part of a larger clinical picture of myxedema crisis. Myxedema crisis refers to severe, life-threatening manifestations of hypothyroidism. It is often precipitated by the administration of sedatives, antidepressants, hypnotics, anaesthetics, or opioids. Clinical features of myxedema crisis : Impaired cognition, ranging from confusion to somnolence to coma (myxedema coma). Convulsions and abnormal CNS signs. Profound hypothermia (can reach 23°C), hypoventilation, hyponatremia, hypoglycemia, hypoxemia, hypercapnia, and hypotension. Rhabdomyolysis and acute kidney injury A high mortality rate Other options: Option A: Without a history of or focus of infection, septic shock is unlikely. Option B: Cardiogenic shock would present with symptoms of left heart failure i.e. pitting pedal edema, abdominal distension, prominence of neck veins, and dyspnea. Option D: Hypoglycemia usually presents with sweating, palpitations, and tachycardia Thyroid Disorders - Management
subject: Medicine

question_text: A middle-aged woman who presented with tremors, palpitations, weight loss, and menstrual irregularities is diagnosed with Graves' disease. Which of the following statements would be correct with respect to her thyroid function test?
options: Radioactive Iodine Uptake (RAIU) at 24 hours below normal
explanation: In Graves' disease, the level of serum TSH is low, free T4 is high and serum T3 is high. In patients with thyrotoxicosis, the radioactive iodine uptake (RAIU) at 24 hours is characteristically elevated. Grave’s disease is characterized by thyrotoxicosis caused by thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulins (TSIs) synthesized by lymphocytes in the thyroid gland, bone marrow, and lymph nodes. Thyroid peroxidase (TPO) and thyroglobulin (Tg) antibodies are also seen. This results in excess production of free T3 and free T4 levels and in turn reduces serum TSH levels. RAIU is used to differentiate Grave’s from other thyroid disorders, here there is diffuse high uptake. Measurement of TRab and TPOs is also done to confirm the diagnosis if the diagnosis clinically is unclear.
subject: Medicine

question_text: What is the most common pattern of thyroid hormone levels in a patient with sick euthyroid syndrome?
explanation: The most common hormone pattern observed in sick euthyroid syndrome (SES) is a decrease in total and unbound T3 levels with normal levels of T4 and TSH. This pattern is called low T3 syndrome. SES is caused by an acute severe illness in the absence of underlying thyroid disease. T4 to T3 conversion via peripheral deiodination is impaired leading to a fall in T3 corresponding to the severity of illness. There is an adaptive increase in the level of reverse T3 (rT3). In very sick patients, there can be a dramatic fall in both total T4 and T3 levels. This pattern is called low T4 syndrome and is associated with a poor prognosis.
subject: Medicine

question_text: On thyroid function test analysis, TSH value was much higher than normal with a low free T4. What is the diagnosis?
explanation: An elevated TSH value with low free T4 is suggestive of primary hypothyroidism (Option D). Option A: In subclinical hypothyroidism, free T4 levels remain normal despite elevated TSH. Option B: TSH is low in hyperthyroidism. Option C: The diagnosis of secondary hypothyroidism is made along with a deficiency of other pituitary hormones. TSH levels may be low, normal, or slightly increased. The elevation in TSH levels can be attributed to the secretion of immunoreactive but biologically inactive forms of TSH. To confirm the diagnosis, it is essential to detect a low level of unbound T4. The diagnostic approach to hypothyroidism is given in the flowchart below:
subject: Medicine

question_text: The radio-iodine uptake scan of a patient evaluated for swelling of the thyroid is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given image showing localized overactivity (increased uptake) in the left lobe of the thyroid i.e., hot nodule, with suppression of the remainder of the gland, is suggestive of a hypersecreting adenoma. Other options: Option B: The likelihood of malignancies like papillary Carcinoma thyroid is low (5%) in the case of a hot nodule. Option C: Graves disease shows diffusely increased uptake on a thyroid scan. Option D: Lateral aberrant thyroid presents with swelling of cervical lymph nodes and not thyroid. It is due to skip metastasis from papillary thyroid carcinoma to the ipsilateral cervical lymph nodes. The thyroid scan appearance in different conditions is shown in the image below: Diagnostic isotope studies, such as 99mTc-pertechnetate and iodine-123, are becoming less common in thyroid imaging because some warm swellings (5%) which are actually malignant could be mistaken as benign. Isotope scanning is most valuable when assessing a hyperthyroid patient presenting with a nodule or nodularity in the thyroid. It helps to identify overactivity in the gland, which can differentiate between a toxic nodule that suppresses the rest of the gland and a toxic multinodular goitre with multiple areas of increased uptake.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following drugs can cause the condition shown below?
explanation: The given image shows the absence of scalp hair and skin, along with calvarial defects(skull bone defects), suggestive of aplasia cutis congenita. This is commonly associated with carbimazole and methimazole. These drugs can also cause other defects such as: Choanal atresia Tracheoesophageal fistula Fetal goiter
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following patients cannot undergo radioiodine therapy?
explanation: Lactating mothers cannot undergo radioiodine therapy. Pregnancy and breastfeeding are absolute contraindications of radioiodine therapy. Patients can safely conceive 6 months after undergoing radioiodine treatment. Radioiodine therapy in patients with severe ophthalmopathy can be given with caution along with prednisone to prevent exacerbation of ophthalmopathy.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 25-year-old woman presents with palpitations. She informs you that a urine pregnancy test done one week ago was positive. Her investigations reveal hyperthyroidism. Which of the following antithyroid drugs can be prescribed for her?
explanation: The patient in the given clinical scenario is in the 1st trimester of pregnancy. Propylthiouracil is used in the 1st trimester of gestation because it has lower teratogenic effects than carbimazole. Carbimazole and methimazole are associated with teratogenic effects such as Aplasia cutis congenita Choanal atresia Treacheosopageal fistula Fetal goiter However, propylthiouracil use is limited to the first trimester due to the risk of hepatotoxicity. It is replaced with carbimazole or methimazole in the 2nd and 3rd trimesters of the pregnancy. The lowest effective antithyroid drug dose should be used throughout gestation. This is to maintain the maternal serum-free T4 level in the upper limit of the non-pregnant normal reference range.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A patient undergoing radioactive iodine therapy for a non-toxic multinodular goitre later develops altered sensorium, fever, and vomiting. What is the anti-thyroid drug of choice in this patient?
explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of thyroid storm and propylthiouracil is the drug of choice in this patient. This is due to its inhibitory action on peripheral T4  T3 conversion. PTU is administered in large doses (500–1000 mg loading dose and 250 mg every 4h) administered orally / via nasogastric tube / per rectum. Propranolol is also given to reduce symptoms like tachycardia and other adrenergic manifestations.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A patient presents with a diffusely enlarged thyroid gland. However, she has no features of hyperthyroidism. Which of the following statements about her condition is false?
options: It is also referred to as simple goitre or colloid goitre
Most commonly caused by iodine deficiency
Thyroid function tests should be performed in all patients with goiter
explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of a non-toxic diffuse goitre. Surgery is rarely indicated in this condition, except for cosmetic reasons, tracheal compression or obstruction of the thoracic inlet. It is sometimes called simple goitre - because of the absence of nodules, and colloid goitre - because of the presence of uniform follicles that are filled with colloid. It is most commonly caused by iodine deficiency and is often termed endemic goitre. Most diffuse goitres are benign and asymptomatic. Examination reveals a symmetrically enlarged, non-tender, generally soft gland without palpable nodules. TFTs should be performed in all patients to exclude thyrotoxicosis or hypothyroidism. If markedly enlarged, it can cause tracheal/oesophagal compression. Substernal goitre may obstruct the thoracic inlet leading to a positive Pemberton’s sign i.e., facial congestion on bilateral arm elevation due to venous occlusion.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following statements about silent thyroiditis is true?
options: Glucocorticoids are not indicated for treatment
It is not associated with thyrotoxicosis
It is not associated with hypothyroidism
explanation: Glucocorticoid treatment is not indicated in silent thyroiditis. The condition is called silent thyroiditis, as it is painless. When it occurs 3-6 months after pregnancy, it is termed postpartum thyroiditis. The condition is observed in up to 5% of women and it is 3 times more common in women with Type 1 diabetes mellitus. Typically, patients experience a brief phase of thyrotoxicosis lasting 2-4 weeks, followed by hypothyroidism for 4-12 weeks, and then clinical resolution. Often, only one phase is apparent. In addition to painless goitre, silent thyroiditis can be distinguished from subacute thyroiditis by a normal ESR value and the presence of TPO antibodies. Severe thyrotoxic symptoms can be managed with a brief course of propranolol, a 20–40 mg dose administered three or four times daily. Thyroxine replacement may be needed for treating the hypothyroid phase but should be withdrawn after 6–9 months, to enable patient recovery.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A middle-aged woman with fatigue, depression and weight gain was found to have hypothyroidism. Which of the following statements is false about the treatment of her condition?
options: The replacement dose of thyroid is 1.6 g/kg body weight
Complete relief from symptoms might occur within 3-6 months after initiation of treatment
TSH responses should be determined 2 months following the initiation of treatment or change in dose
Once TSH level is stable, TSH measurement is recommended at annual intervals
explanation: The clinical effects of levothyroxine replacement are slow to appear. Patients may not experience full relief from symptoms until 3–6 months after normal TSH levels are restored. If there is no residual function, the daily replacement dose of levothyroxine is usually 1.6 g/kg body weight (typically 100–150 g), ideally taken at least 30 minutes before breakfast. TSH responses are gradual and should be determined 2 months following the initiation of treatment or change in dose. Once the full replacement is achieved and TSH levels are stable, TSH measurement is recommended at annual intervals. In patients who have developed hypothyroidism following treatment of Graves' disease, lower doses are needed for replacement. This is because there is often underlying autonomous function, necessitating lower replacement doses (typically 75–125 g/d).
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 24-year-old primigravida at 10 weeks of gestational age presents to your OPD. She is on oral levothyroxine supplementation for hypothyroidism. What is the target TSH level to be maintained in this patient?
explanation: The target TSH level to be maintained in the first trimester of pregnancy is <2.5 mIU/L. For second and third trimester the target is <3.0 mIU/L. Thyroid function must be evaluated by testing for TSH levels every 4 weeks in the first trimester and less frequently after 20 weeks. The levothyroxine dose may be increased by 50% during pregnancy. Following delivery, doses of thyroxine are usually restored to that of pre-pregnancy levels.
subject: Medicine

question_text:
An elderly woman with hypothyroidism presents to the ER with decreased consciousness, hypothermia, sinus bradycardia, and hypotension. Her family members reveal that she has not been taking her thyroid medications recently. Investigations reveal elevated TSH levels and reduced T3 and T4 levels. All of the following can be used in the treatment except:
IV levothyroxine
explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of myxedema coma. Hypotonic IV fluids are avoided in the course of treatment of this condition. However, hypertonic saline is used. Hypotonic fluids may exacerbate water retention and dilutional hyponatremia secondary to impaired renal perfusion and inappropriate vasopressin. Treatment of myxedema coma includes: Levothyroxine (T4) can be administered as a single IV bolus of 500 g. Although further doses are strictly not required, it is continued at 50-100 g/day. An alternative mode of treatment is the IV administration of liothyronine (T3) or via NG tubes ith doses ranging from 10-25 g every 8-12 hours in case T4 to T3 conversion in myxedema is impaired. Parenteral hydrocortisone should be administered to treat a condition of impaired adrenal reserve in profound hypothyroidism. Hypertonic saline or IV glucose may be recommended for treatment. External warming is indicated only if the temperature is less than 30oC. Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia
subject: Medicine

explanation: MEN1 is also referred to as Wermer's syndrome.

question_text: Which of the following conditions is not observed in MEN1 syndrome?
explanation: Anterior pituitary tumours are associated with MEN1 syndrome, not posterior pituitary tumors.

question_text: A 35-year-old man presented with abdominal pain, nausea, and diarrhea. He had a history of hyperparathyroidism and a transsphenoidal prolactinoma resection. Which of the following is the most common functional enteropancreatic tumor seen in this condition?
explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of MEN1 syndrome and gastrinoma is the most common functional enteropancreatic tumor in MEN1 / Wermer's syndrome. Enteropancreatic tumors in MEN1 syndrome are: Non-functioning pancreatic tumors (most common overall) Functioning pancreatic tumors : Gastrinoma - 50% (most common among functioning pancreatic tumours) Insulinoma - 30% Glucagonoma VIPoma (least common)

question_text: Which of the following is the most common site of gastrinoma in MEN 1 syndrome?
explanation: Most common site of gastrinoma in MEN 1 syndrome is the first and second part of duodenum. MEN 1 syndrome is characterized by the triad of tumors involving the parathyroids, pancreatic islets, and anterior pituitary. Gastrinoma is the most common pancreatic islet tumor in MEN 1 syndrome and if it is associated with marked gastric acid production and recurrent peptic ulcers, the condition is called Zollinger Ellison syndrome.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 30-year-old man presents to the OPD with complaints of recurrent episodes of weakness, headache, sweating, and fainting after fasting. He tells that the symptoms improve after the consumption of food. There is a history of MEN1 syndrome running in the family. Serum C peptide levels are found to be elevated. What is the definitive treatment of choice in this patient?
explanation: The given clinical scenario along with elevated serum C peptide levels points towards a diagnosis of insulinoma in a MEN1 patient. The definitive treatment of choice in this patient is surgery. Insulinoma is the second most common functioning enteropancreatic tumor in MEN1 syndrome. Investigation of choice is 72-hour fasting glucose and serum insulin levels. These parameters are measured when the patient develops hypoglycemic symptoms during a supervised 72-hour fasting period. The treatment of choice is surgery, ranging from enucleation of a single tumor to pancreatectomy. Non-surgical management of insulinoma includes frequent consumption of carbohydrate-rich meals, octreotide or diazoxide, which are not always successful. Selpercatinib, a kinase inhibitor was recently approved by the FDA. It is used to treat tumours with a mutation in the RET gene. These are non-small cell lung cancer, medullary thyroid cancer, and other types of thyroid cancers in patients with a mutation in the RET gene.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is the most frequently observed cutaneous manifestation of MEN1 syndrome?
explanation: The most frequently observed cutaneous manifestation of MEN1 syndrome is angiofibroma. Cutaneous tumors in MEN1 Syndrome are: Angiofibroma – 85% Collagenoma – 70% Lipoma - 33%

explanation: Secretin study is not done as an annual screening test in patients with MEN1 syndrome. It is a provocative test for the diagnosis of gastrinoma. question_text: What is the most common component of Sipple’s syndrome?
explanation: The most common component of MEN2A syndrome, which is also called Sipple’s syndrome is medullary thyroid cancer.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following features would you not expect to see in a patient with MEN2 syndrome?
explanation: Pituitary adenoma is not a characteristic feature of the symptom complex of MEN2 and its variants, but it is observed in MEN1 and MEN4 syndrome.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following features would you not expect to see in a patient with MEN2B syndrome?
explanation: Meningioma is not commonly seen in MEN2B Syndrome. MEN1 syndrome is associated with meningiomas.
subject: Medicine

question_text: MEN4 syndrome is caused by a mutation in which of the following genes?
explanation: MEN4 is caused by genetic mutations in CDKN1B (cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor), located on chromosome 12. MEN1 is caused due to MEN1 gene mutation on chromosome 11. MEN2 is associated with RET proto-oncogene mutation on chromosome 10.

question_text: Which of the following malignancies would you not expect to see in a patient with MEN4 syndrome?
explanation: Medullary thyroid carcinoma is not associated with MEN4 syndrome, but it is associated with MEN2 syndrome.
subject: Medicine

question_text:
A patient presented with abdominal pain and swelling in his scrotum and was diagnosed to have testicular carcinoma. There is a history of MEN syndrome running in his family. Which of the following conditions is he likely to have?
MEN4
explanation: This patient is likely to have MEN4 syndrome as reproductive organ tumors are a characteristic feature of this condition. Pheochromocytoma
subject: Medicine

question_text: The clinical triad of pheochromocytoma includes all of the following symptoms except:
explanation: The clinical triad of pheochromocytoma includes the following symptoms: Headache Profuse sweating Palpitation (due to tachycardia) Hypertension is the most predominant sign of pheochromocytoma. Though intermittent hypertension is a classical feature, sustained hypertension is also common.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following would you not see in a patient with pheochromocytoma?
explanation: Hypercalcemia is seen in patients with pheochromocytoma, not hypocalcemia. This is due to the production of parathyroid hormone-related peptide (PTHrP) by the tumor.
subject: Medicine

question_text: In a patient with pheochromocytoma, which of the following clinical features is least likely to be present?
explanation: Polyuria, not oliguria is seen in patients with pheochromocytoma. Excess catecholamine levels in this condition can cause polyuria and polydipsia due to hyperglycemia.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is an associated finding that can be seen in patients with pheochromocytoma?
explanation: Café au lait spots are seen in neurofibromatosis 1, which is a pheochromocytoma-associated syndrome. Pheochromocytoma-associated syndromes include the following: Neurofibromatosis type 1 Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 Von Hippel–Lindau syndrome Paraganglioma syndrome
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following parameters can help you diagnose a patient with a malignant pheochromocytoma?
explanation: Malignant pheochromocytoma refers to tumors that have undergone metastasis to lymph nodes or distant sites. They are histologically and biochemically the same as benign ones. Hence, typical histological criteria like cellular atypia, mitotic spindles, and capsular invasion are insufficient to confirm malignancy in pheochromocytomas.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following catecholamines would be elevated in a patient with extra-adrenal pheochromocytoma?
explanation: Norepinephrine is exclusively secreted in patients with extra-adrenal pheochromocytoma. The PNMT (phenylethanolamine-N-methyl transferase) enzyme converts norepinephrine to epinephrine. This enzyme is absent in extra-adrenal sites. Hence, extra-adrenal pheochromocytomas secrete only norepinephrine and cannot secrete epinephrine. On the other hand, adrenal pheochromocytomas can secrete norepinephrine, epinephrine, and dopamine in varying amounts depending on the PNMT levels in the tumor. Extra-adrenal pheochromocytomas or catecholamine-secreting paragangliomas are most commonly found in the abdomen. They commonly arise from the organ of Zuckerkandl.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 31-year-old woman is rushed to the ED with a severe headache and vomiting. Past history includes a total thyroidectomy for thyroid cancer 3 months ago. Her BP is 200/100 mm Hg and pulse is 110/min. On examination, a marfanoid habitus is noted along with the findings shown. Which of the following is likely to be predominantly elevated?
explanation: This clinical scenario with a history of thyroid cancer (likely medullary carcinoma) and the image showing mucosal neuromas points towards MEN2B syndrome. Her current presentation is suggestive of a pheochromocytoma. She is likely to have predominantly elevated levels of epinephrine and its metabolite, metanephrine. This is due to the higher expression of the PNMT enzyme associated with the mutations in MEN2 syndromes (both 2A and 2B). The higher levels of epinephrine result in a more symptomatic presentation. In contrast, low PNMT expression is seen in von-Hippel-Lindau (VHL) syndrome. This leads to a predominant elevation of norepinephrine and normetanephrine levels. It is less symptomatic compared to MEN2 syndrome.
subject: Medicine

question_text: In a suspected case of pheochromocytoma, which of the following would you avoid while making a diagnosis?
explanation: Biopsy and FNAC should be avoided in patients with pheochromocytoma, as it is a highly vascular tumor. CT and MRI have similar sensitivity but T2-weighted MRI with gadolinium contrast is the optimal test for diagnosis. MIBG (metaiodobenzylguanidine) scintigraphy can be used to localize the tumor if both CT and MRI are negative. question_text: Which of the following is the best method for detecting and localization of tumors associated with pheochromocytomas?
explanation: Among the given options, the fluorodopa-PET scan is the best method for detecting and localization of tumors associated with pheochromocytoma. If biochemical testing for pheochromocytoma is positive, an abdominal MRI must be performed first. question_text: A 45-year-old man presented with recurrent episodes of headache, palpitations, and sweating. His blood pressure at presentation was 180/100 mm Hg. Further testing revealed elevated urinary metanephrines. CT abdomen showed a right adrenal mass. What is the drug of choice for the management of this patient?
explanation: This clinical scenario is suggestive of pheochromocytoma. The drug of choice to control blood pressure prior to surgery is oral phenoxybenzamine at 0.5–4 mg/kg of body weight. It is a non-specific -blocker and is preferred due to its long action (3-4 days). Other -blockers like oral prazosin and intravenous phentolamine have a shorter duration of action and can be used to manage paroxysms. IV phentolamine is also used for intra-operative management of BP. -blockers are usually given for 7 days. Following this, -blockers are started, usually 2-3 days preoperatively. -blockers should never be started first because blockade of vasodilatory peripheral -receptors with unopposed -receptor stimulation can lead to a further elevation in blood pressure. question_text: Which of the following should not be used for the initial management, in a patient with pheochromocytoma?
explanation: Beta-blockers like atenolol should never be used as the initial drug or alone in the management of pheochromocytoma. They must be given only after adequate alpha blockade has been established. Blocking beta-receptors may cause unopposed stimulation of alpha-receptors, precipitating a hypertensive crisis. Option A: Prazosin is an alpha-blocker. Option C: Nitroprusside can be used in case of hypertensive emergencies. Option D: Metyrosine inhibits catecholamine synthesis. It can be used when other agents have been ineffective.

question_text: Which of the following is not a part of Averbuch’s chemotherapy protocol?

A patient is diagnosed with malignant pheochromocytoma. Which of the following is used to treat this condition?
Strontium
explanation: 131I-MIBG (metaiodobenzylguanidine) is used for the treatment of malignant pheochromocytoma. Malignant pheochromocytomas occur in 10% of cases and are histologically and biochemically the same as benign ones. explanation: Cushing’s disease, and all other causes of Cushing's syndrome, can result in a hypercoagulable state. This is due to an increase in procoagulant factors and inhibition of fibrinolysis. Cushing's disease is a form of Cushing's syndrome caused by an ACTH-secreting pituitary tumor. The high ACTH levels stimulate melanocytes and cause skin hyperpigmentation. question_text: A 28-year-old woman visits a gynecologist with complaints of irregular and infrequent menstrual cycles. She is also upset that she has gained 12 kg over the past few months. Her face appears as shown in the image below. Her blood pressure at this visit is 144/98 mm Hg and she has multiple purple striae over her abdomen. Which of the following investigations should you advise this patient?
options: Serum testosterone levels and abdominal USG
explanation: The given clinical scenario along with the image showing moon facies with acne and hirsutism are suggestive of Cushing’s syndrome. It can be diagnosed with the help of a single midnight serum cortisol measurement. Option A: Cosyntropin (ACTH) stimulation test is used for the diagnosis of Addison's disease. Options C and D: Serum testosterone, abdominal USG, and LH: FSH ratio, are used to confirm a diagnosis of the polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). Though PCOS can present with similar features, it is not typically associated with moon facies, purple striae, or hypertension.

question_text: You can advise any of the following tests for screening of a patient suspected to be having Cushing's syndrome except:
explanation: Determination of plasma ACTH levels is not advised as a screening test for a patient with Cushing's syndrome. Plasma ACTH determination is done to distinguish between ACTH-dependent and independent causes. It is done after the screening or confirmation of Cushing's syndrome.

question_text: In patients with which of the following conditions would you expect to see the highest basal ACTH level?
explanation: Basal plasma ACTH levels are highest in ectopic ACTH-secreting tumors. Plasma ACTH > 15pg/ml is suggestive of ACTH-dependent Cushing's syndrome due to pituitary or ectopic sources. Basal ACTH in pituitary adenoma can be normal or elevated, whereas in an ectopic source the ACTH production is very high. This occurs because a pituitary adenoma retains some sensitivity to the negative feedback mechanism exerted by cortisol, but ectopic tumors remain unaffected. Plasma ACTH < 5pg/ml is suggestive of ACTH-independent Cushing’s syndrome that can be caused by an adrenal adenoma or exogenous administration of glucocorticoids.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A patient with suspected Cushing's syndrome is found to have elevated ACTH levels. What is the investigation of choice?
explanation: An elevated ACTH level is suggestive of ACTH-dependent Cushing's syndrome. The investigation of choice for ACTH-dependent Cushing's syndrome is MRI brain, to look for the presence of a pituitary tumour. If the MRI brain shows a mass it is suggestive of a pituitary mass of >6 mm in size. However, if the MRI brain does not show a mass it suggests a pituitary tumor of <6mm in size or an ectopic ACTH source. N te: High-dose dexamethasone suppression test and CRH stimulation test are employed t differentiate pituitary from ectopic ACTH syndrome. A definitive cause can be established only by imaging techniques like MRI for pituitary tumors, CT scan of the chest and abdomen for ectopic ACTH sites. Hence MRI is considered the investigation of choice.

question_text: A 56-year-old man chronic smoker presented with flecks of blood in his sputum. He is currently on treatment for COPD and hypertension. His BMI is 31 kg/m² and he has central obesity. His RBS is 261 mg/dl. During further evaluation, he is found to have high ACTH levels that remained high even after administration of high-dose dexamethasone. What is the underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
explanation: Elevated ACTH levels that do not get suppressed by a high-dose dexamethasone test are suggestive of Cushing’s syndrome secondary to an ectopic ACTH-secreting tumor. Considering the patient's smoking history and presentation with hemoptysis, it is likely to be a lung tumor. Ectopic sources of ACTH include small cell lung cancers and pulmonary carcinoid tumors. The most effective treatment strategy is the management of the underlying SCLC or carcinoid. question_text: A 50-year-old woman was diagnosed with ACTH-dependent Cushing's syndrome. As MRI of the pituitary was normal and further testing was unequivocal, she was scheduled for inferior petrosal sinus sampling. It revealed a baseline petrosal:peripheral ACTH ratio > 2. What is the treatment of choice in this patient?
explanation: Cushing’s syndrome with petrosal: peripheral ACTH ratio > 2 at baseline confirms the presence of an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma. The treatment of choice is transsphenoidal pituitary surgery. Radiotherapy is used in case of recurrence of tumors. question_text: Which of the following would not be used to treat patients with Cushing’s syndrome?

question_text: Which of the following is the best adrenolytic agent that can be used in the management of patients with adrenocortical carcinoma?
explanation: Mitotane is used in the management of adrenocortical carcinoma due to its adrenolytic properties. Mitotane is an insecticide derivative. It is effective in the treatment of benign Cushing's also, but is rarely used due to its side effects.

question_text: Which of the following complications is associated with bilateral adrenalectomy?
explanation: Nelson’s syndrome is a rare complication of total bilateral adrenalectomy (TBA). TBA is a procedure used to control hypercortisolism in Cushing's disease (due to ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma) when resection of the primary tumor is not possible. The loss of feedback inhibition of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis following TBA increases CRH. This leads to stimulation of ACTH-secreting corticotroph cells, causing enlargement of the original pituitary tumor or the formation of a new one. Nelson's syndrome is associated with a clinical triad of: Hyperpigmentation Excessive ACTH secretion Corticotroph adenoma Screening is done with fasting plasma ACTH levels and MRI brain is performed at regular intervals. Prophylactic pituitary irradiation may be recommended to prevent its incidence. The primary treatment is transsphenoidal surgery. Patients will also require life-long glucocorticoid replacement, as they do not produce cortisol. The use of steroidogenic inhibitors in the treatment of Cushing's disease has decreased the need for bilateral adrenalectomy these days. Option A: Sheehan’s syndrome refers to postpartum hypopituitarism that is caused by ischemic necrosis of the anterior pituitary as a result of severe postpartum hemorrhage. Option B: Addison's disease occurs due to autoimmune destruction of adrenal glands. Option C: Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome refers to adrenal apoplexy that is caused by fulminant meningococcemia.

question_text:
Which of the following is not a cause of pseudo-Cushing's syndrome?
Obesity
explanation: Malignancy does not cause pseudo-Cushing's syndrome. It may cause ectopic ACTH production, leading to true Cushing’s syndrome. Pseudo-Cushing’s syndrome refers to functional hypercortisolism caused by chronic activation of the HPA axis. It presents with clinical and biochemical features similar to Cushing’s syndrome, making it difficult to differentiate between them. It may occur secondary to the following conditions: Severe major depressive disorder Polycystic ovarian syndrome Insulin-resistant obesity Obstructive sleep apnea Chronic alcoholism End-stage renal disease It usually resolves when the underlying condition is treated. question_text: Addison's disease is commonly associated with
explanation: Primary adrenal insufficiency, also known as Addison’s disease, is most commonly caused by autoimmune adrenalitis. Tuberculous adrenalitis is still a frequent cause of primary adrenal insufficiency in developing countries like India. It is characterized by the loss of glucocorticoid, mineralocorticoid, and adrenal androgen secretion. Glucocorticoid deficiency results in fatigue, lack of energy, weight loss, fever, myalgia, normochromic anemia, and hypoglycemia. Mineralocorticoid deficiency is characterized by nausea, vomiting, low blood pressure, postural hypotension, salt craving, hyponatremia, and hyperkalemia. Adrenal androgen deficiency manifests as a lack of energy, dry itchy skin, loss of libido, and loss of axillary and pubic hair (in women). Hyperpigmentation is seen in primary adrenal insufficiency due to excess proopiomelanocortin-derived peptides. Hyperpigmentation is not seen in secondary adrenal insufficiency. The diagnosis of adrenal insufficiency can be made with the short cosyntropin test (cortisol level <450-500nmol/L sampled 30 to 60 minutes after ACTH stimulation is diagnostic of adrenal insufficiency). Plasma ACTH, plasma renin, and serum aldosterone can help differentiate primary from secondary causes. Primary adrenal insufficiency will show elevated ACTH and a compensatory elevation in renin levels due to decreased aldosterone in the body. In secondary adrenal insufficiency, ACTH is low with normal renin and aldosterone. Treatment includes glucocorticoid, mineralocorticoid, and adrenal androgen replacement. Other options: Option B: Patients with adrenocortical carcinoma present with features of glucocorticoid and adrenal androgen excess, and not adrenal insufficiency. Options C and D: Hypernephroma and medullary carcinoma thyroid are not associated with Addison's disease.

question_text: What is the most common cause of adrenal insufficiency in India?

question_text: A 27-year-old woman is brought to the casualty with severe abdominal pain, vomiting, and diarrhea for the past 3 days. She has been excessively tired and dizzy for the past 2 weeks. options: Serum Na+, K+, saline suppression test
explanation: This clinical scenario is suggestive of adrenal insufficiency. The confirmatory test for diagnosis is the ACTH stimulation test or short cosyntropin stimulation test. Hyponatremia and hyperkalemia are seen. Plasma levels of ACTH, renin and aldosterone are used to differentiate between primary and secondary adrenal insufficiency.

question_text: A 20-year-old woman is being evaluated for adrenal insufficiency. You decide to check her serum levels of ACTH, renin, and aldosterone. Which of the following laboratory findings would prompt you to subsequently order a pituitary MRI?
options: High renin and low aldosterone levels
Low renin and high aldosterone levels
explanation: Pituitary MRI is indicated in secondary adrenal insufficiency which presents with the following parameters: Low-normal ACTH level Normal renin level Normal aldosterone level The following findings are seen in primary adrenal insufficiency: High ACTH levels High renin Low aldosterone levels Pituitary MRIs are not required in primary adrenal insufficiency. The fact that a pituitary MRI is done itself gives a hint towards secondary adrenal insufficiency.

question_text: A 33-year-old man collapses during a family vacation. At the hospital, blood pressure is found to be 86/52 mm Hg, and random blood sugar is 49 mg/dl. His wife says that he has been on treatment for Addison's disease for two years but had forgotten to pack his medication for the trip. What is the drug of choice for this patient?
explanation: This clinical scenario is suggestive of an adrenal crisis triggered by missed medication. In this patient who is a known case of adrenal insufficiency, IV hydrocortisone is the drug of choice. However, in patients with newly diagnosed adrenal insufficiency, dexamethasone is used for the treatment of adrenal crisis. This is because dexamethasone is not measured in cortisol assays and would not interfere with the diagnostic tests, whereas hydrocortisone interferes with cortisol assays. Acute adrenal insufficiency requires the immediate initiation of the following therapeutic strategies: Rehydration - saline infusion at an initial rate of 1 L/h with continuous cardiac monitoring. Glucocorticoid replacement - bolus injection of 100 mg hydrocortisone, followed by the maintenance dose of 100–200 mg over 24h. Mineralocorticoid replacement - initiated once the daily hydrocortisone dose has been reduced to <50 mg as higher doses of hydrocortisone have sufficient mineralocorticoid action.

question_text: A patient who presented with an adrenal crisis is undergoing treatment with dexamethasone. Which of the following abnormalities will not improve with this treatment?
explanation: Hyperkalemia will not improve following administration of dexamethasone. Dexamethasone is a long-acting steroid with glucocorticoid action. It has no effect on hyperkalemia, which is mediated by mineralocorticoids. Hyponatremia is chiefly due to mineralocorticoid deficiency, however, hypocortisolism causes hyponatremia due to loss of feedback inhibition of ADH resulting in SIADH (syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion). Hypocortisolism can also cause postural hypotension as cortisol regulates vascular tone by potentiating the effects of vasoconstrictors. Thus on administration dexamethasone hyponatremia and postural hypotension will improve as dexamethasone has glucocorticoid action but hyperkalemia will not improve. Dexamethasone is used in patients with newly diagnosed adrenal insufficiency as it does not interfere with serum cortisol measurement. question_text: Which of the following is incorrect with respect to Addisonian pigmentation?
options: Does not affect the oral mucosa
explanation: Addison's disease causes patchy hyperpigmentation of the oral mucosa. Hyperpigmentation is also present in areas of increased friction including: Palmar creases Dorsal aspect of the foot Nipples and the axillary region

question_text: What is the most common cause of mineralocorticoid excess?
explanation: Bilateral adrenal hyperplasia is the most common cause of mineralocorticoid excess. It causes primary hyperaldosteronism. Other causes of primary hyperaldosteronism are: Conn’s syndrome – Unilateral adrenal adenoma Glucocorticoid-remediable hyperaldosteronism (< 1%) Other causes of mineralocorticoid excess are as follows: Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) Syndrome of apparent mineralocorticoid excess (SAME) Adrenocortical carcinoma Progesterone-induced hypertension Cushing’s syndrome Liddle’s syndrome is due to a mutation of ENaC subunits. This results in reduced degradation of ENaC channels, causing prolonged mineralocorticoid action.

question_text: Which of the following clinical features will you not expect to see in a patient with Conn's syndrome?
explanation: In Conn’s syndrome, even though there is volume expansion, an underlying salt-escape mechanism leads to the absence of pedal edema. The volume expansion due to hypernatremia leads to right heart dilatation that stimulates the release of atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP). This leads to compensatory diuresis and lack of edema despite sodium retention. Features of primary hyperaldosteronism: Hypokalemia Hypertension Metabolic alkalosis Polyuria (due to ANP) Polydipsia (consequence of polyuria) Muscle weakness

question_text: A 39-year-old man is referred for evaluation of severe hypertension that has not improved despite being on 3 anti-hypertensive drugs. The presence of decreased plasma renin activity in this patient would point to which of the following diagnoses?
explanation: Conn syndrome is a cause of primary hyperaldosteronism that presents with hypertension and low levels of renin. Elevated aldosterone levels cause negative feedback in the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) and results in decreased renin production.

question_text: Which of the following is the best initial investigation in a patient with hypokalemic hypertension?
explanation: Hypokalemic hypertension is suggestive of hyperaldosteronism. The screening test of choice is a measurement of plasma renin and aldosterone levels to calculate the aldosterone-renin ratio (ARR). ARR must be estimated in patients with hypertension and any one of the following features: Drug resistance Hypokalemia Adrenal mass Onset before 40 years of age Prior to the determination of ARR, hypokalemia correction must be done. If the patient is on spironolactone, it must be stopped 4 weeks prior to testing. Other blood pressure medication may be continued. ARR screen is considered positive when: ARR > 750 pmol/L : ng/mL per hour Aldosterone > 450 pmol/L Option A: ACTH stimulation test is used for the diagnosis of Addison’s disease. It presents with hypotension and hyperkalemia. Options B and C: If ARR is positive, CT abdomen and adrenal vein sampling are used for confirmation of the diagnosis.

question_text:
Which of the following tests is not performed in patients with an elevated aldosterone-renin ratio?
Saline infusion test
explanation: An elevated aldosterone-renin ratio (ARR) is indicative of primary hyperaldosteronism. Metyrapone stimulation test is used in the diagnosis of adrenal insufficiency, not hyperaldosteronism. A failure of suppression of aldosterone levels below 140 pmol/L indicates autonomous aldosterone production, which is the hallmark of primary hyperaldosteronism. This principle is used in the following tests: Saline infusion test - IV administration of 2L of physiological saline over 4 hours Oral sodium loading test - oral sodium given over 3 days Fludrocortisone suppression test - given IV over 4 days These tests may be used to confirm the diagnosis in patients with elevated ARR, but are not necessary in cases of overt hypokalemic hypertension, strongly positive ARR, and high aldosterone. question_text: Which of the following is not a clinical feature of diabetes mellitus?
explanation: Weight loss is a clinical feature of diabetes mellitus, not weight gain. Diabetes mellitus refers to a group of common metabolic disorders that result in hyperglycemia. It causes the following classical triad of symptoms: Polyuria - due to osmotic diuresis Polydipsia - triggered by the resulting hypovolemia Weight loss - due to catabolic state Note: Obesity is a risk factor, not a symptom of type 2 diabetes mellitus and plays a role in its pathogenesis. Increase in the adipocyte mass leads to an increase in the level of circulating free fatty acids. Free fatty acids impair glucose utilization in skeletal muscles, promote glucose production by the liver, and impair beta-cell function.

question_text:

Which of the following statements is true about this condition?
options: Antibodies against zinc transporters may be present
It is associated with a strong family history
Insulin-resistance is the hallmark for pathogenesis
explanation: This clinical scenario is suggestive of type 1 diabetes mellitus. It is an autoimmune disease associated with the following immunologic markers: Antibodies against zinc transporter (ZnT-8) Islet cells antibodies (ICA) Anti-glutamic acid decarboxylase antibodies (GAD) Insulin autoantibodies (IAA)

question_text: Which chromosome contains the major susceptible gene for type 1 diabetes mellitus?
explanation: The major susceptibility gene for type 1 diabetes mellitus is located in the HLA region of chromosome 6. Type I diabetes mellitus occurs in genetically susceptible individuals and is usually triggered by infections. The HLA complex is most commonly involved. The common HLA associations include: Causative - HLA-DQA1*0501 and DQB*0201 Protective - HLA-DQA1*0102, DQB1*0602, DRB1*1501 Other genomic associations of type I diabetes mellitus include the CTLA-4 gene and IL-2 receptor. Type 2 diabetes mellitus is associated with mutations in the calpain-10 gene on chromosome 2. It results in insulin resistance.

question_text: Which of the following mechanisms is predominantly responsible for an increase in the fasting plasma glucose level of patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus?
explanation: In type 2 diabetes mellitus increased fasting blood sugar is predominantly due to increased hepatic gluconeogenesis. In the postprandial period, there is a rise in peripheral blood glucose levels. Due to insulin resistance in type 2 diabetes mellitus, there is reduced peripheral uptake of glucose by insulin-sensitive tissues like the liver and skeletal muscles. This results in reduced glucose utilization by skeletal muscles as well as reduced glycogenesis in the liver and skeletal muscles. This results in increased postprandial plasma glucose levels. Increased hepatic glucose output predominantly accounts for increased FPG levels, whereas decreased peripheral glucose utilization results in postprandial hyperglycemia.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 22-year-old woman presents with fatigue and weight loss for the past 6 months. She tells you that her father is also a diabetic. Further evaluation reveals the following. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: This clinical scenario is suggestive of maturity-onset diabetes of the young (MODY). MODY is a monogenic form of diabetes mellitus that is transmitted in an autosomal dominant fashion. It affects young adults < 25 years of age. It occurs due to reduced insulin secretion. Etiological factors of type 1 and 2 diabetes such as insulin resistance, obesity, and antibodies are not associated with this condition. Stable hyperglycemia is usually seen, hence complications like diabetic ketoacidosis are uncommon. Macrovascular complications like hyperlipidemia or hypertension are not seen. It is treated with sulfonylureas. Latent autoimmune diabetes in adults (LADA) is a form of type 1 diabetes that occurs between 30-50 years of age.
subject: Medicine

question_text: All of the following are true about maturity-onset diabetes of the young (MODY) except:
options: MODY 4 is the most common form
explanation: MODY 3 is the most common form of maturity-onset diabetes of the young (MODY), accounting for two-thirds of all the cases. MODY is a monogenic form of diabetes mellitus that is transmitted in an autosomal dominant fashion. It affects young adults <25 years of age. There are a total of 11 types of MODY based on mutations involves. Some of the affected genes include: Types 1,3,5: HNF (Hepatocyte nuclear transcription factor) mutation Type 2: Glucokinase mutation Type 4: IPF 1 (Insulin Promotor Factor-1) mutation These mutations result in impaired glucose-induced insulin secretion resulting in insulinopenia.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following would cause type 1 diabetes in an adult patient?
explanation: Type 1 diabetes mellitus in an adult is suggestive of latent autoimmune diabetes in adults (LADA). LADA is common in thin-built adults between 30-50 years and is associated with autoantibodies. As the progression of the disease is less rapid than in children, clinical features may mimic type 2 diabetes. However, patients usually require insulin treatment within 5 years. Option A: Patients with latent diabetes become diabetic under stressful conditions. However, upon removal of stress, they become non-diabetic. Option B: MODY or maturity-onset diabetes of the young is a monogenic form of diabetes that occurs < 25 years. There is impaired insulin secretion, but no antibodies. Option C: Brittle diabetes is seen in children with type 1 DM. It presents with wide fluctuation in blood sugar levels.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Patients with all of the following conditions can develop diabetes mellitus except:
explanation: Fragile X syndrome is not associated with diabetes mellitus. Genetic syndromes associated with diabetes include: Prader-Willi syndrome Friedreich’s ataxia Wolfram’s syndrome Down’s syndrome Klinefelter’s and Turner’s syndrome Huntington’s chorea Laurence-Moon-Biedl syndrome Myotonic dystrophy Porphyria Diseases of the exocrine pancreas causing diabetes: Hemochromatosis Pancreatitis Neoplasia Cystic fibrosis Endocrinopathies causing diabetes: Acromegaly Cushing’s syndrome Glucagonoma Pheochromocytoma Hyperthyroidism
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following patients can be diagnosed with diabetes mellitus?
options: A patient with RBS of 210 mg/d
A patient with FBS of 125 mg/dl and 2-hour PPBS of 199 mg/d
A patient with symptoms of diabetes and RBS of 192 mg/d
explanation: The patient with HbA1c  6.5 % can be diagnosed with diabetes mellitus as this is an independent criterion for diagnosis.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 46-year-old man presents to his physician for a routine health evaluation. He is concerned that he might have diabetes as his three brothers have all been diagnosed with diabetes. He does not have any complaints. Which of the following tests can be employed in this patient?
explanation: HbA1c and fasting blood glucose are used for screening diabetes mellitus in asymptomatic individuals. HbA1c refers to glycated hemoglobin and it serves as a long-term indicator for blood glucose levels (8 to 12 weeks). Normal < 5.7 % Abnormal glucose homeostasis: 5.7 to 6.4 % Diabetes mellitus:  6.5% HbA1c also serves as a prognostic indicator for glycemic control.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following can be termed impaired glucose tolerance?
options: Fasting blood glucose levels between 100 and 125 mg/dL
Random blood glucose levels between 140 and 199 mg/dL
Blood glucose levels between 140 and 199 mg/dL following oral glucose tolerance test
Fasting blood glucose levels between 100 and 199 mg/dL
explanation: Impaired glucose tolerance is defined as blood glucose levels between 140-199 mg/dL following an oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT). Impaired fasting glucose is when the fasting blood glucose is between 100 to 125 mg/dL.
subject: Medicine

question_text: You are counselling an asymptomatic middle-aged woman regarding screening for diabetes mellitus. Based on the ADA recommendations, what will you tell her?
options: All individuals > 35 years must undergo screening every 3 years
All individuals > 50 years must undergo screening every 5 years
Oral glucose tolerance test would be performed
Random blood glucose levels would be checked
explanation: The ADA recommends screening for type 2 diabetes mellitus in all asymptomatic individuals > 35 years every 3 years. The tests used for screening are: HbA1c levels Fasting blood glucose levels Individuals can be screened earlier if they are overweight with BMI >25 kg/m2 and have one of the following risk factors: Family history of diabetes History of cardiovascular diseases History of gestational diabetes mellitus or delivery of a baby > 4 kg Obesity (BMI 25 kg/m2) Physical inactivity Hypertension (140/90 mm Hg) HDL cholesterol < 35 mg/dL Triglycerides >250 mg/dL Polycystic ovarian syndrome or acanthosis nigricans Note- If an individual has a test result near the margins of the diagnostic threshold, a close follow-up should be done and repeat the test in 3–6 months.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A middle-aged woman has been diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus. Her HbA1c level is 11.1%. What is the initial drug of choice?
explanation: Insulin is the best initial drug of choice when HbA1c is > 9% at diagnosis. Insulin is used in the treatment of type 2 diabetes in the following cases: Inadequate glycemic control with 2 or more oral agents HbA1c > 9% at diagnosis In patients with HbA1c < 9%, metformin is the drug of choice.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 45-year-old woman was brought to the emergency department by her relatives after she suffered a brief, seizure-like episode. They tell you that she is taking an oral medication for diabetes. On examination, the patient was disoriented, and CBG was 45 mg/dl. Which of the following drugs most likely played a role in the patient’s current presentation?
explanation: Repaglinide is an insulin secretagogue and hence poses the risk of causing hypoglycemia. Drugs that can cause hypoglycemia (insulin secretagogues): Sulfonylureas Meglitinides: Nateglinide, Repaglinide The following drugs are not directly responsible for stimulating insulin secretion and hence do not cause hypoglycemia: Metformin Alpha-glucosidase inhibitor Pioglitazone DPP-4 inhibitor: Sitagliptin Management of diabetes mell itus Intervention Advantages Disadvantages Management of diabetes mell itus Management of diabetes mell itus Management of diabetes mell itus Lifestyle changes Reduced complications and mortality Insufficient for most patients within 1st year Metformin Weight neutral GI side effectsContraindicate d when GFR < 45 ml/min Insulin Rapidly effectiveLowers HbA 1c more than other drugs (by 1.5-3%) Weight gainHypoglycemia GLP-1 agonists Weight lossReduces cardiova scular complications GI side effects Pramlintide Weight lossLowers postprand ial glucose GI side effectsHypoglycemia when used with insulin Sulfonylureas Rapidly effective Weight gainHypoglycemia Thiazolidinediones Lowers insulin requirements Weight gain, edema, CHF, fr actures Meglitinides Rapidly effective Weight gainHypoglycemia SGLT-2 inhibitors Weight lossBetter cardiovasc ular and renal outcomes UTI, vulval candidiasisDehyd rationEuglycemic DKA DPP-4 inhibitors Weight neutral Angioedema, urticaria Alpha-glucosidase inhibitors Weight neutral GI flatulenceRise in LFT

question_text: All of the following drugs can be used in the treatment of patients with type 1 diabetes except:
explanation: Metformin can only be used in the treatment of type 2 diabetes mellitus. Drugs that can be used for treating both type 1 and type 2 diabetes mellitus include the following: Acarbose - reduces the breakdown of starch into sugar in the GI tract and lowers the postprandial glucose rise in both types. Pramlintide - an injectable drug that enhances amylin secretion leading to reduced glucagon evels Insulin
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 40-year-old male patient with type 2 diabetes mellitus is now diagnosed with hypertension. Which of the following antihypertensive drugs will you not prefer in this patient?
explanation: Hydrochlorthiazide belongs to the thiazide group of diuretics, that can cause dyslipidemia and hyperglycemia. Hence they are not preferred for use in diabetic hypertensives. The antihypertensive drug of choice in diabetes mellitus include angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACE-I) or angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs).
subject: Medicine

question_text: A type 2 diabetic patient who was recently started on treatment complains of frequent urination, fever, and burning micturition. Which of the following drugs is most likely responsible for these symptoms?
explanation: This clinical scenario is suggestive of a urinary tract infection (UTI). This adverse effect occurs as a result of dapagliflozin use. The group of sodium-glucose co-transporter-2 or SGLT-2 inhibitors includes drugs like dapagliflozin and canagliflozin. These drugs prevent glucose reabsorption in the renal tubules and cause loss of sodium and glucose. UTI - due to glucosuria Dehydration - due to natriuresis and volume loss Euglycemic diabetic ketoacidosis - low blood glucose levels due to glucosuria can reduce insulin release SGLT-2 inhibitors must be temporarily discontinued for 3-4 days before any scheduled surgery to avoid potential risk for diabetic ketoacidosis.
