question_text: A 65-year-old man is hospitalized with pneumonia. He is a known patient of type 2 diabetes. During the hospital stay, his appetite is poor and his oral intake is irregular. The physician decides to administer rapid-acting insulin based on high blood sugar values. Which of the following would he use?
explanation: This clinical scenario describes the sliding scale method. Rapid-acting insulins such as glulisine are used. Sliding scale refers to the administration of insulin as a bolus dose based on the blood sugar level before the meal. Using this principle, the insulin dose is titrated every time according to pre-meal glucose levels to determine insulin requirement. Hence, rapid-acting insulin is preferred. This method requires a fixed carbohydrate intake at every meal. It is used for the short-term management of hospitalized patients, especially when the frequency or quantity of food intake is very variable. It does not deliver insulin in a physiological manner, hence is not a preferred long-term strategy for glycemic control.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is incorrect about Afrezza?
options: It is available as a powder for inhalation
explanation: Afrezza is an inhalational form of insulin that can cause hypoglycemia. It is a rapid-acting form of insulin that is administered at the beginning of each meal. Peak levels are achieved 12-15 minutes later. Adverse effects include hypoglycemia, cough, throat pain, or irritation. It may cause acute bronchospasm in patients with asthma, COPD, as well as active smokers. Hence, it is contraindicated in these condition.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 60-year-old man presents to the casualty with confusion, vomiting, and abdominal pain. His blood sugar levels are 421 mg/dl and urine ketones are 3+. He is started on IV normal saline and insulin infusion. Which of the following should he be monitored for?
explanation: This clinical scenario is suggestive of diabetic ketoacidosis, which is treated with insulin infusion. Insulin causes an intracellular shift of K+ ions resulting in a decreased extracellular K+ ion concentration. This results in hypokalemia. Non-diabetic clinical applications of insulin include: Treatment of hyperkalemia To determine the functions of the anterior pituitary To examine the completion of truncal vagotomy
subject: Medicine

question_text: Dawn phenomenon is clinically suspected when a patient shows which of the following findings?
options: Early morning hyperglycemia with hypoglycemia at 3 am
Early morning hypoglycemia with normal blood glucose levels at 3 am
Early morning hyperglycemia with normal blood glucose levels at 3 am
Early morning hypoglycemia with hyperglycemia at 3 am
explanation: Dawn phenomenon refers to normal blood glucose levels at 3 am followed by early morning hyperglycemia. This occurs due to an early morning surge in plasma growth hormone and cortisol levels, which have an insulin-antagonistic action. In normal individuals, this is countered by increased early morning insulin secretion. However, in diabetic patients, insulin secretion is disrupted which results in the unopposed action of growth hormone. Hence, there will be resulting hyperglycemia.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A patient is said to have developed insulin resistance when the required insulin dosage is which of the following?
explanation: When a patient needs > 200 units of insulin per day, they are said to have developed insulin resistance. Some causes of insulin resistance are as follows: Werner syndrome Lipodystrophy syndrome Ataxia-telangiectasia Polycystic ovarian disease Insulin resistance can present as non-alcoholic fatty liver disease.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 12-year-old child who is known to have type 1 diabetes mellitus presents with confusion and drowsiness. Her mother says that she seems to be breathing very fast. On examination, mucous membranes are dry and blood pressure is 70/50 mm Hg. Random blood glucose is 415 mg/dl and urine ketones are 4+. What is the next best step in management?
options: 2-3 L of normal saline over 1-3 hours
Insulin bolus of 0.1 units/kg given IV
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) and the first step is to assess the arterial blood gas (ABG) levels. This precedes correction of fluid balance, as assessment of the current status of the patient is necessary before beginning treatment. A baseline pH and electrolyte level must be obtained. Diabetic ketoacidosis is the most serious complication of type 1 diabetes mellitus. The symptoms include dehydration, nausea, vomiting, confusion, drowsiness, and coma in severe cases. In DKA, the insulin-to-glucagon ratio is decreased which promotes gluconeogenesis, glycogenolysis, and ketone body formation in the liver. Ketone bodies exist as ketoacids at physiological pH which are neutralized by bicarbonate. As bicarbonate stores are depleted, metabolic acidosis ensues. Increased lactic acid production also contributes to the acidosis. The diagnostic biochemical criteria for DKA includes: Hyperglycemia (>250 mg/dL) Venous pH <7.3 Plasma/serum bicarbonate <15-18 mmol/L Increased anion gap Ketonemia (beta-hydroxybutyrate [BOHB] >3 mmol/L) and ketonuria Signs of ketoacidosis: Kussmaul breathing (deep, heavy, non-labored rapid breathing) Fruity breath odor (acetone) Prolonged Q-T interva Diminished neurocognitive function Coma
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is responsible for the elevated levels of TG and VLDL in diabetes mellitus?
options: Increased activity of lipoprotein lipase and decreased activity of hormone sensitive lipase
Increased activity of hormone sensitive lipase and decreased lipoprotein lipase activity
Increase in peripheral function of LDL receptors
Increased in activity of hepatic lipase
explanation: The elevated levels of triglycerides (TG) and very low-density lipoproteins (VLDL) in diabetes mellitus (DM) are due to decreased activity of lipoprotein lipase (LpL) and increased activity of hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL). Insulin normally has an inhibitory action on HSL and induces LpL on capillary walls. There is an absolute or relative deficiency of insulin in DM. In DM, the activity of LpL is decreased and HSL is increased. The increased activity of HSL results in increased mobilisation of fat stores towards lipolysis releasing fatty acids. These fatty acids are partly cleared by the liver, resulting in increased synthesis of VLDL and TG, resulting in dyslipidemia. They can accumulate in the liver, resulting in steatosis (non-alcoholic fatty liver disease). The reduced activity of LpL prevents the clearing of TG and VLDL in the bloodstream and their levels remain elevated.
subject: Medicine

question_text:
In a PHC, which of the following initial screening tests are used to diagnose diabetes?
1 and 2
explanation: Fasting blood sugar >126 mg/dL and 2-hour postprandial blood sugar >200 mg/dl can be used as screening tests for diabetes in a primary health center (PHC). HbA1c estimation is usually unavailable for screening at many PHCs due to low resources. In India, facilities for HbA1c estimation are usually available only at tertiary centers. Random blood sugar >200 mg/dL can be used for diagnosis only if the patient presents with symptoms of diabetes, hence it is not a useful screening test. Diabetes Mellitus: Complications and their Management
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is not a feature of diabetic ketoacidosis?
explanation: In diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), serum bicarbonate is usually < 15. Serum HCO3 > 15 meq/L is suggestive of alcoholic ketoacidosis. DKA is an acute complication of type 1 diabetes mellitus. It is usually precipitated by absolute or relative insulin deficiency caused by increased metabolic demand (infections) or insulin noncompliance. The common symptoms include nausea, vomiting, and severe abdominal pain. The common signs include Kussmaul breathing, fruity odor of the breath, dehydration, tachycardia, hypotension, and delirium. The diagnosis of DKA is made based on the following parameters: Hyperglycemia > 250 mg/d Ketosis or ketones in urine Metabolic acidosis with pH < 7.3 HCO3 < 15-18 mEq/L High anion gap due to ketoacids and lactic acidosis Hyponatremia is seen as a result of hyperglycemia (osmotic shift causes dilutional hyponatremia). Normal sodium levels on admission indicate severe dehydration. Despite a total-body potassium deficit, the serum Potassium at presentation may be mildly elevated, secondary to the acidosis and volume depletion.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 19-year-old woman with a history of type 1 diabetes is brought to the ER with confusion, vomiting, and abdominal pain. Investigations show blood glucose of 520 mg/dl and urine positive for ketone bodies. Which of the following is the drug of choice?
explanation: The drug of choice for controlling hyperglycemia in a patient with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) is short-acting insulin, preferably regular insulin. Intermediate (such as lente insulin and NPH), long-acting insulins, and oral hypoglycemic agents are never used in the initial management of DKA. The mainstay of treatment is the administration of normal saline followed by infusion of short-acting insulin. The precipitating event must be identified and treated. Careful monitoring of K+ levels and replacement in the later stages is required, as insulin therapy causes hypokalemia.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is the leading cause of death in children with diabetic ketoacidosis?
explanation: Cerebral edema is the leading cause of mortality in children with diabetic ketoacidosis. The osmolar gradient generated due to the high blood glucose level results in water shift from the intracellular fluid (ICF) to the extracellular fluid (ECF) space and leads to the contraction of cell volume. Correction with insulin and intravenous fluids can result in a rapid reduction in effective osmolarity, reversal of the fluid shift, and result in cerebral edema. Complications of diabetic ketoacidosis include: Cerebral edema – especially in children Cardiac arrhythmia - due to electrolyte imbalance Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) Venous thrombosis Acute gastric dilation Acute kidney injury Intestinal necrosis Acute pancreatitis Mucormycosis
subject: Medicine

question_text: A patient with diabetic ketoacidosis has severe abdominal pain. Which of the following is the recommended test to rule out acute pancreatitis?
explanation: In diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), severe abdominal pain can mimic acute pancreatitis. Serum lipase is the best test to rule out this condition. It must then be confirmed by imaging (USG or CT abdomen). Serum amylase is an unreliable indicator as DKA is associated with hyperamylasemia of salivary origin. Serum and urine trypsinogen may be elevated in early pancreatitis but are not used for diagnosis. Fecal elastase is elevated in chronic pancreatitis.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 15-year old boy presents with persistent vomiting for one day. Laboratory investigations reveal the following. What is the best sequence of management?
options: Start IV fluids, administer IV regular insulin, and then correct hypokalemia
Start IV fluids, administer subcutaneous bolus of insulin and correct hypokalemia concurrently
Start IV fluids and correct hypokalemia first, then administer IV regular insulin
Administer IV regular insulin with KCl first , then start IV fluids once the K+ level is corrected
explanation: This clinical scenario is suggestive of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). On confirming the diagnosis, IV fluids must be started. If the initial serum potassium < 3.3 meq/L, insulin should be administered only after the correction of hypokalemia. This is because treatment with insulin and fluids can worsen hypokalemia by the following mechanisms: Insulin causes the shift of K+ ions into cells Resolution of the acidosis also promotes K+ entry into cells Urinary loss of K+ salts of organic acids
subject: Medicine

question_text: Distinguishing features between hyperglycemic hyperosmolar state and diabetic ketoacidosis include all of the following except:
explanation: Hypotension and tachycardia are common features of both hyperglycemic hyperosmolar state (HHS) and diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). In DKA, insulin deficiency and an increase in counter-regulatory hormones lead to shunting of free fatty acids to form ketone bodies. The ketoacids increase the anion gap and cause low pH. In HHS, there is still some insulin available. Hence, there are no ketones formed, and the patient has normal pH and pCO2.
subject: Medicine

question_text:
An elderly man is brought to the hospital with confusion and drowsiness. His son says that he has been urinating more frequently than normal and eating very little over the past 1 week.
Capillary blood glucose is 800 mg/dl. Which of the following would not be seen in this patient?
explanation: This clinical scenario is suggestive of hyperglycemic hyperosmolar state (HHS). Kussmaul's breathing is not a feature of HHS. HHS is commonly seen in older adults suffering from type 2 diabetes mellitus. Patients can present with the following features: Polyuria Polydipsia Lethargy Altered sensorium, coma Seizures Severe dehydration The following lab values are seen: Blood glucose of 600-1200 mg/d Serum osmolality > 350 mOsm/L Prerenal azotemia due to dehydration Pseudohyponatremia may be seen due to hyperglycemia Normal pH and ketones The mainstay of management is fluid replacement, IV regular insulin, along with potassium replacement. Heparin can be given prophylactically as volume contraction can increase the risk of venous thrombosis.
subject: Medicine

question_text: What is the most common pattern of dyslipidemia associated with diabetes mellitus?
explanation: Dyslipidemia commonly occurs as a complication of type 2 diabetes mellitus. The most common pattern is as follows: Increased triglyceride levels - due to increased glucose and free fatty acids, decreased lipolysis of VLDL. Decreased HDL levels Though diabetes does not increase LDL levels, there is increased atherogenicity as the existing LDL molecules are more easily glycated and susceptible to oxidation.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Dyslipidemia is more commonly associated with which of the following?
options: Maturity onset diabetes of the young
explanation: Dyslipidemia is more commonly associated with type 2 diabetes mellitus. It is less common in type 1 and gestational diabetes. Maturity onset diabetes of the young (MODY) is not associated with dyslipidemia. Note: Saroglitazar is a more advanced drug that reduces blood sugar and lipid levels in diabetic patients. It acts on PPAR alpha and gamma receptors.
subject: Medicine

question_text: You have started a 40-year-old man on treatment for type 2 diabetes mellitus and dyslipidemia. Which of the following is not an appropriate target for this patient?
explanation: According to the ADA guidelines, a treatment goal of postprandial plasma glucose < 180 mg/dL must be followed in adults with diabetes. In younger individuals or those with other cardiovascular risk factors, the target blood pressure is < 130/80 mm Hg. Although not a treatment goal, the ADA also recommends triglyceride levels be maintained at < 150 mg/dl. Note: Saroglitazar is a more advanced drug that reduces blood sugar and lipid levels in diabetic patients. It acts on PPAR alpha and gamma receptors.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A middle-aged patient with type 2 diabetes is diagnosed with essential hypertension. What is the antihypertensive drug of choice?
explanation: The drug of choice in this diabetic patient with hypertension is losartan. Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACE inhibitors) or angiotensin receptor blockers (ARB) are the first-line drugs in diabetic hypertensives. Among ARBs, the drug of choice is telmisartan (acts on PPAR receptor). They reduce both macrovascular and microvascular complications and have a nephroprotective effect. However, they are contraindicated in chronic kidney disease as they can cause a further decline in GFR.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is the earliest manifestation of diabetic nephropathy?
explanation: The earliest manifestation of diabetic nephropathy is an increase in the glomerular filtration rate (GFR). It occurs as a result of glomerular hyperperfusion and renal hypertrophy. The following sequence of changes are seen in diabetic nephropathy: Increased GFR Incipient diabetic nephropathy - microalbuminuria (30–300 mg/day albumin) Diagnostic marker to detect early diabetic nephropathy Indicator of long-term cardiovascular disease Overt diabetic nephropathy - macroalbuminuria ( >300 mg/day albumin) End-stage renal disease
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 15-year-old boy has been on treatment for type 1 diabetes mellitus since the age of 10 years. His physician decides to begin screening for diabetic nephropathy. Which of the following is not always a reliable indicator of this condition?
explanation: Albumin of 30-300 mg/day refers to microalbuminuria. It can be unreliable in the diagnosis of diabetic nephropathy. It is not required to diagnose nephropathy as it is very variable. Non-albuminuric diabetic nephropathy may occur in some patients and regression of albuminuria may be seen in type 1 diabetics. Diabetic nephropathy can be diagnosed if the following are satisfied: Reduced GFR (< 60 mL/min/1.73 m2) with or without persistent albuminuria (> 30 mg/day or urine PCR > 30 mg/g) Long duration of diabetes or established diabetic retinopathy Other etiologies are ruled out Long duration in type 1 diabetes refers to 5 years after diagnosis. On the other hand, patients with type 2 diabetes are exposed to hyperglycemia and prediabetes for a long time even before diagnosis. Hence, at the time of diagnosis, patients with type 2 diabetes are considered to have had the disorder for a duration sufficiently long to produce kidney disease. However, a clinical diagnosis of diabetic nephropathy can be made in patients with established retinopathy, even if the duration of diabetes is short.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following statements about diabetic nephropathy is true?
options: Pancreatic transplantation can improve proteinuria at an early stage
Strict glycemic control is unlikely to prevent microalbuminuria
Dietary protein restriction can benefit diabetic patients with albuminuria
Microalbuminuria is not an indicator of long-term cardiovascular morbidity
explanation: Pancreatic transplantation can help improve proteinuria at an early stage. Successful pancreatic transplantation can have the following effects: Prevention of diabetic nephropathy and regression of albuminuria in early stages. Stabilization and improvement of diabetic neuropathy and retinopathy Increase in HDL with reduction in LDL and triglycerides Option B: Strict glycemic control can prevent or revert microalbuminuria. Option C: The ADA does not suggest restrictions of protein intake in diabetic patients with albuminuria because studies have failed to prove its benefits. Option D: Microalbuminuria is an indicator of long-term cardiovascular morbidity.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 50-year-old man with type 2 diabetes mellitus is found to have a 24-hour urinary albumin of 250 mg. Which of the following drugs may be prescribed to reduce the progression of this condition?
explanation: Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACEI) inhibitors or angiotensin-receptor blockers (ARB) are recommended to reduce the progression of diabetic nephropathy. It has the following effects: Reduction of albuminuria Reduces the associated decline in GFR The mainstay of management of diabetic nephropathy includes control of blood sugar and blood pressure, inhibitors of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone(RAAS) system, and inhibitors of SGLT2 to halt the progression of the disease. RAAS inhibitors include ACE inhibitors, ARBs, or direct renin inhibitors.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A pathologist is studying a renal biopsy sample from a patient with suspected diabetic nephropathy. Which of the following biopsy findings is pathognomonic for this condition?
explanation: The characteristic lesion of diabetic nephropathy is nodular or intercapillary glomerulosclerosis, also called Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules. It is pathognomonic for this condition. The following image shows Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules. Other non-specific findings seen on biopsy include: Glomerular basement membrane (GBM) thickening - highly sensitive Diffuse glomerulosclerosis - most common pattern, due to diffuse mesangial thickening Fibrin cap - accumulation of hyaline material within the capillary loop Capsular drop - accumulation of hyaline material attached to the Bowman's capsule Armani-Ebstein reaction - collection of glycogen clumps within the renal tubules due to tubular injury Renal biopsy is done to rule out other causes of renal failure. The indications for renal biopsy in diabetic nephropathy are: Absence of diabetic retinopathy Absence of edema Absence of frothing and proteinuria Absence of hypertension Presence of microscopic hematuria or features of nephritic syndrome
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following types of renal tubular acidosis can develop in individuals with diabetes mellitus?
explanation: Type IV renal tubular acidosis (RTA) may occur in individuals with diabetes mellitus types 1 and 2. Type IV RTA occurs due to hyporeninemic hypoaldosteronism. Low plasma renin activity is common in diabetic patients due to: Impaired conversion of prorenin to renin Volume expansion in diabetic nephropathy suppresses renin release These individuals have a tendency to develop hyperkalemia and acidemia, which can be exacerbated by the use of ACEI and ARBs. Hence, these drugs should be avoided.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 45-year-old man has been diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus. When should you refer him to an ophthalmologist?
options: Immediately at the time of diagnosis
explanation: Patients with type 2 diabetes should undergo a comprehensive ophthalmological examination to screen for diabetic retinopathy at diagnosis, followed by an annual examination of the fundus. In patients with type 1 diabetes mellitus, screening for retinopathy is recommended 3 to 5 years after diagnosis. Annual fundal examination is recommended thereafter.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following patients would you screen for diabetic retinopathy?
explanation: Screening for diabetic retinopathy is done at 3-5 years following diagnosis in type 1 diabetes mellitus, whereas, patients with type 2 diabetes must be screened at the time of diagnosis. As type 2 diabetes mellitus often has a long asymptomatic period of hyperglycemia before clinical diagnosis, these patients are more likely to have complications at the time of diagnosis itself. Retinopathy develops in nearly 50-80% of patients by 20 years of diagnosis. The presence of diabetic retinopathy often correlates with pathological findings of diabetic nephropathy.
subject: Medicine

question_text: What is the most common clinical presentation of diabetic neuropathy?
explanation: The most common form of diabetic neuropathy is distal symmetric polyneuropathy. It presents with distal sensory loss and pain in a stocking-and-glove distribution and is a risk factor for foot ulceration. Autonomic neuropathy is a common complication and results in the following features: Postural hypotension Silent myocardial infarction Hypoglycemia unawareness Erectile dysfunction Overflow incontinence Gastroparesis Enteropathy with constipation or diarrhea Mononeuropathy of peripheral (median, ulnar, radial) and cranial (oculomotor) nerves is also seen, as well as mononeuritis multiplex. Diabetic polyradiculopathy is characterized by severe pain along the distribution of one or more nerve roots.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following findings in a diabetic patient is self-limiting?
explanation: Amyotrophy refers to weakness of hip extensors and flexors secondary to polyradiculopathy involving the lumbar plexus and femoral nerve. It is associated with severe pain along the distribution of the nerve roots. It is self-limiting and resolves over 6-12 months. Strict glycemic control can reduce the incidence and prevent the progression of macular edema, peripheral neuropathy, and macroalbuminuria. However, once developed, they cannot be reversed. Intermittent microalbuminuria with normal GFR can be reversed with strict glycemic control.
subject: Medicine

question_text: You are evaluating a 65-year-old diabetic woman who has been admitted following a seizure. On admission, she was unconscious, and random blood glucose at admission was 37 mg/dl. The hypoglycemia was corrected and she regained consciousness. The woman says that she had felt normal and had no other symptoms prior to the onset of seizures. What is the likely cause of this presentation?
options: Medication change from metformin to insulin
explanation: This clinical scenario is suggestive of silent hypoglycemia in a diabetic patient. The most likely cause is autonomic neuropathy. Hypoglycemia presents with symptoms like palpitation, tremors, and sweating as a result of sympathetic stimulation. These symptoms are protective and provide advance warning before progression to neuroglucopenia. However, in autonomic neuropathy, there is a reduced release of counterregulatory hormones like catecholamines. Hence, the classical symptoms of hypoglycemia do not occur and the patient directly presents with features of neuroglucopenia. This is called hypoglycemia unawareness. The use of beta-blockers can also cause hypoglycemia unawareness.
subject: Medicine

question_text: You are counselling a patient with longstanding, poorly-controlled diabetes mellitus. Advising tight glycemic control in this patient would not improve which of the following?
explanation: In patients with longstanding diabetes mellitus, tight glycaemic control is beneficial for microvascular complications. However, it has no effect on macrovascular complications like peripheral vascular disease (PVD), myocardial infarction, and stroke. Good glycemic control improves microvascular complications through primary and secondary prevention. It reduces the incidence of complications as well as stabilizes and prevents further progression in affected individuals. Intermittent microalbuminuria with normal GFR can even be reversed with tight glycemic control. Complication % risk reduction with tight gl ycemic control Retinopathy 47 % Microalbumin uria 39 % Nephropathy 54% Neuropathy 60 %
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which among the following statements explains Legacy effect and metabolic memory?
explanation: Legacy effect or metabolic memory can be observed in relation to glycemic control during early disease in patients with diabetes mellitus. Intensive glycemic control during the early stages of the disease has a positive effect on long-term microvascular and macrovascular complications (statement 1) even if this intensive glycemic control is not maintained long term. Similarly, uncontrolled blood glucose levels in the early stages causes an increased risk of these complications (statement 5). This phenomenon is called legacy effect and is attributed to metabolic memory. In patients with longstanding diabetes, intensive glycemic control at later stages can improve microvascular complications but has no effect on macrovascular complications.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A patient with chronic diabetes presents to the OPD for his annual checkup. A small painless ulcer is noted over his right foot. His BMI is 33 kg/m2. All of the following factors can be implicated in the causation of his foot ulcer except:
explanation: Venous stasis is not a cause of diabetic foot ulcers and gangrene. They are usually caused by a combination of three factors: Ischemia - secondary to atheroma Peripheral neuropathy - leads to trophic skin changes Immunosuppression - due to excess sugar deposition in tissues, predisposing diabetic patients to infection Common sites of ulcers include: Great toe Metatarsophalangeal areas.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 25-year-old diabetic woman presents to the OPD with the following skin lesions. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given image showing irregular plaques with yellowish discoloration and telangiectasias are suggestive of necrobiosis lipoidica diabeticorum. It is an inflammatory granulomatous disorder of the skin due to collagen degeneration and lipid deposition. It is usually seen in young women with diabetes mellitus. The lesions usually begin in the pretibial region. It begins as papules that gradually enlarge and darken to form erythematous plaques with irregular margins, atrophic centers, and central ulceration. Option A: Necrolytic migratory erythema is a feature of glucagonoma. It is a waxing and waning rash that appears as shown below. Option B: Diabetic dermopathy or shin spots are commonly seen in elderly men. It presents as pigmented pretibial papules as shown below. Option D: Granuloma annulare presents with small papules arranged in an annular pattern. There is no yellowish discoloration or telangiectasias, as shown below.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Patients with diabetes mellitus are at a higher risk of developing all of the following infections except:
explanation: Emphysematous appendicitis is not a complication of diabetes mellitus. The potentially fatal infectious complications of diabetes include: Malignant otitis externa Rhinocerebral mucormycosis Emphysematous pyelonephritis Emphysematous cholecystitis
subject: Medicine

question_text:
A morbidly obese diabetic woman is not responsive to metformin therapy. She has a history of pancreatitis and family history of bladder cancer. She does not want to take injections.
Which of the following would be suitable to reduce her glucose levels?
explanation: Among the given options, canagliflozin (Option C) is the most suitable treatment. It is an oral drug belonging to the class SGLT-2 inhibitors and causes weight loss. Although it increases the risk of urogenital infections, it has no risk of pancreatitis or bladder cancer. Option A: Sitagliptin, a DPP-IV inhibitor, is associated with the risk of acute pancreatitis. Option B: Pioglitazone, a thiazolidinedione, can increase the risk of bladder cancer and can cause weight gain and congestive cardiac failure. Option D: Liraglutide is an injectable GLP-1 receptor agonist. Pancreatitis is a serious adverse effect of this drug. Hence, it is contraindicated in individuals with a history of pancreatitis and should be permanently discontinued if pancreatitis develops.
subject: Medicine

question_text:
Which of the following anti-diabetic drugs should be stopped in a patient with a creatinine of
5.6 mg/dL?
Metformin
explanation: Metformin should be stopped in case of elevated creatinine levels (renal insufficiency) > 1.5 mg/dl in men and >1.4 mg/dl in women. Metformin acts by reducing hepatic glucose production and improves peripheral glucose utilization. Lactic acidosis and Vitamin B12 deficiency are specific adverse effects of metformin. It is not used in patients with a glomerular filtration rate <30 mL/min (moderate renal insufficiency), acidosis, unstable congestive cardiac failure, liver disease, severe hypoxemia, and patients undergoing contrast studies. Reproductive Endocrinology
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is not a feature of 11-beta-hydroxylase deficiency?
explanation: 11-beta-hydroxylase deficiency is associated with metabolic alkalosis, not metabolic acidosis. It is a rare form of congenital adrenal hyperplasia that presents with the following features: Glucocorticoid deficiency: Hypoglycemia Hyperpigmentation around the genitals due to excess adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) secretion Mineralocorticoid excess: Hypokalemia Hypertension Metabolic alkalosis Adrenal androgen excess Virilization in females Precocious puberty in males
subject: Medicine

question_text: A neonate with ambiguous genitalia undergoes karyotyping and is confirmed to have a 46XY genotype. His blood pressure is 140/80 mm Hg and serum potassium is 1.9 mEq/L. Which of the following is responsible for these findings?
explanation: This clinical scenario with ambiguous genitalia in a male neonate is suggestive of 17 alpha-hydroxylase deficiency. It causes hypertension and hypokalemia due to the accumulation of 11-deoxycorticosterone, which is a mineralocorticoid causing sodium retention. 11-hydroxylase deficiency also leads to the accumulation of 11-deoxycorticosterone.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following abnormalities will you see in a child with salt-wasting congenital adrenal hyperplasia?
explanation: Hypoglycemia is a feature of salt-wasting congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH). It is due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency. It results in hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and hypotension. Males typically present with salt-wasting crises as they often go undiagnosed at birth due to the presence of normal genitalia.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is the drug of choice for the prenatal treatment of congenital adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency?
explanation: The drug of choice for the prenatal treatment of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency is dexamethasone, as it readily crosses the placenta. It is an experimental approach aimed at reducing the virilization of 46XX fetuses by suppressing fetal adrenal steroid and androgen secretion. It may be considered when there is a high risk of CAH due to strong family history. It is effective only when started before 4 weeks of gestation. Hydrocortisone is given in the children at divided doses of 1–1.5 times the normal cortisol production.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A female neonate is noted to have ambiguous genitalia at birth. Further testing reveals elevated 17-(OH)-progesterone levels and a blood glucose of 40 mg/dl. What treatment will you recommend?
explanation: Ambiguous genitalia, elevated 17-(OH)-progesterone, and hypoglycemia are suggestive of 21-hydroxylase deficiency. The drug of choice is hydrocortisone. Hydrocortisone acts as a potent glucocorticoid with mineralocorticoid action and thus increases salt absorption from the kidneys as well. Betamethasone, beclomethasone, and dexamethasone have negligible effects as mineralocorticoids.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is incorrect about galactorrhea?
explanation: Galactorrhea or pathological production of milk is not associated with lactation, which is a physiological condition. Galactorrhea is the inappropriate discharge of milk-containing fluid from the breast. It may be unilateral or bilateral. It is associated with acromegaly and hyperprolactinemia. Treatment is with dopamine agonists like bromocriptine or cabergoline if it is due to hyperprolactinemia.
subject: Medicine

question_text: In a patient with gynecomastia, you will order all of the following tests except:
explanation: Determination of prolactin level is not useful in patients with gynecomastia. For the diagnosis of gynecomastia, serum levels of the following hormones must be checked: Testosterone LH FSH Estradio hCG
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 32-year-old man is being evaluated for gynecomastia. Laboratory investigations reveal low levels of serum testosterone and luteinizing hormone. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: This clinical scenario of gynecomastia with low LH and testosterone is suggestive of a sertoli cell tumor. Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism is also a possible diagnosis with the above clinical presentation and must be ruled out before diagnosing a Sertoli cell tumor. The differential diagnosis of gynecomastia is as follows: High LH and low testosterone Testicular failure Low LH and low testosterone Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism Sertoli cell tumor - increased primary estrogen production High LH and high testosterone Androgen-resistant state GnRH-secreting tumor
subject: Medicine

question_text: A mother brings her 17-year-old daughter to the gynecologist as she has not started menstruating yet. Examination reveals well-developed breasts and the absence of pubic and axillary hair. Pelvic examination reveals a short, blind-ended vagina. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of complete androgen insensitivity syndrome. Clinical features: Female phenotype Normal breast development Blind-ended vagina with absent uterus and ovaries Presence of testes in the abdomen or inguinal region Scanty pubic and axillary hair Primary amenorrhea in late adolescence Option A: In Turner’s syndrome, breasts are infantile. Option B: Stein Leventhal syndrome or polycystic ovarian disorder presents with hirsutism and anovulatory menstrual cycles. Option C: Premature ovarian failure presents with secondary amenorrhea.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A baby girl is referred to a pediatric surgeon for suspected bilateral inguinal hernias. Further evaluation reveals the masses to be testes in the inguinal canal. Which karyotype would you expect to find in this child?
explanation: This clinical picture is suggestive of androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS). Affected children have a male karyotype or 46 XY with a female phenotype. 46XY individuals with complete AIS (formerly called testicular feminization syndrome) have the following features: Female phenotype Normal breast development Blind-ended vagina with absent uterus and ovaries Scanty pubic and axillary hair Most patients present with Inguinal masses in infancy - Due to undescended testes or hernias containing testes Primary amenorrhea in late adolescence Gonadectomy is a recommended course of treatment due to the possible risks of malignancy.
subject: Medicine

question_text: An 18-year-old boy is brought to the casualty with minor burns following a house fire. He tells you that he did not even smell the smoke. Further probing reveals a history of bilateral orchidopexy at the age of 7. Examination findings include eunuchoid habitus, prepubertal testes, and microphallus. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: Anosmia and absent secondary sexual characteristics in this patient are suggestive of Kallman syndrome. It is an X-linked disorder that causes isolated hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism due to defective development of the olfactory bulb. This results in: Defective migration of GnRH-producing neurons that originate from the olfactory epithelium Aplasia or hypoplasia of olfactory bulb The clinical features include: Cryptorchidism Absent or delayed pubertal changes due to GnRH deficiency Anosmia or hyposmia Options A and B: Klinefelter syndrome is a cause of primary or hypergonadotrophic hypogonadism. Option D: Hyperprolactinemia can cause hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism, but is also associated with gynecomastia, galactorrhea, and bitemporal hemianopia.
subject: Medicine

question_text: What is the most common cause of hypergonadotropic hypogonadism in males?
explanation: The most common cause of hypergonadotrophic hypogonadism in males is Klinefelter’s syndrome It occurs in males with a 47 XXY karyotype and is associated with testicular dysfunction and male infertility. Causes of hypergonadotrophic hypogonadism in males and females: Congenita Klinefelter's syndrome Turner's syndrome Swyer's syndrome Premature ovarian failure associated with fragile X syndrome and galactosemia Acquired Mumps orchitis Testicular torsion, trauma Liver cirrhosis Ketoconazole Premature ovarian failure
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following will you recommend in all patients with androgen insensitivity syndrome?
explanation: Gonadectomy is clinically recommended in all patients with androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS) or testicular feminization syndrome due to the risk of malignancy arising from the abnormally located testes. Options B, C, D: These treatment options may be offered to patients with AIS, but it depends on personal preference and whether they identify as males or females.
subject: Medicine

question_text:
A 19-year-old patient is being evaluated for primary amenorrhea. Laboratory investigations reveal decreased estrogen, FSH, and LH. What is the likely diagnosis?
Asherman syndrome
explanation: Decreased levels of estrogen, FSH, and LH are suggestive of hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism, which is caused by Kallman syndrome. It is an X-linked disorder (KAL gene) that causes isolated hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism and anosmia. Causes of hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism: Congenita Kallman's syndrome Isolated hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism (IHH) Prader-Willi syndrome CHARGE syndrome Acquired Pituitary tumors, apoplexy Hyperprolactinemia Anorexia nervosa, excess exercise Irradiation Infection Trauma Option A: Asherman syndrome causes secondary amenorrhea due to intrauterine synechiae. Option B: Müllerian agenesis presents with primary amenorrhea with normal levels of a hormones. Option D: Turner's syndrome causes primary amenorrhea due to hypergonadotrophic hypogonadism. Disorders of Parathyroid and Calcium Homeostasis

question_text: Hypercalcemia is associated with all of the following medical conditions except:
explanation: Hypercalcemia is associated with all of the following conditions except hypothyroidism. Hyperthyroidism is however associated with hypercalcemia. Other options: Multiple myeloma is a hemotological malignancy associated with hypercalcemia. Hyperparathyroidism is associated with sub-periosteal bone resorption resulting in hypercalcemia. Sarcoidosis is associated with hypercalcemia due to increased activity of 1 alpha hydroxylase activity in the macrophages.

question_text: Which of the following can cause hypercalcemia in a patient?
explanation: Vitamin A intoxication can cause hypercalcemia. This is due to high bone turnover. Ingestion of 50,000–100,000 units of Vitamin A daily can increase calcium levels up to 12–14 mg/dL. Note: Vitamin D intoxication also leads to hypercalcemia.

question_text: A 66-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after being found unconscious by her neighbors. She is found to have marked dehydration and serum calcium levels of 16 mg/dl. All of the following can cause this presentation except:
explanation: This clinical scenario with severe hypercalcemia (> 14.8 mg/dl) is suggestive of a hypercalcemic crisis. Pancreatitis causes hypocalcemia, not hypercalcemia. Hypercalcemic crisis is often caused by malignancies due to an acute rise in calcium levels following bone resorption due to metastases. It is a medical emergency that presents with polyuria, severe dehydration, gastrointestinal symptoms, and altered consciousness. It can lead to cardiac arrest and coma.

question_text: Which of the following is not seen in patients following excessive intake of calcium?
explanation: Excess calcium ingestion is not associated with restrictive cardiomyopathy. It results in milk-alkali syndrome, commonly associated with excessive intake of absorbable antacids such as milk or calcium carbonate. In susceptible individuals, there is a loss of negative feedback, leading to excess calcium absorption when there is excess intake. It results in the following triad of clinical features: Hypercalcemia Alkalosis - due to HCO3 reabsorption caused by PTH suppression, natriuresis, and water depletion. Renal failure - due to damage to renal tubules. It is reversible once ingestion of antacid is stopped. However, in severe cases, a chronic form called Burnett’s syndrome can develop. It is associated with irreversible renal damage.

question_text: What is the most common cause of primary hyperparathyroidism?
explanation: Parathyroid adenomas are the most common cause of primary hyperparathyroidism. Causes of primary hyperparathyroidism: Parathyroid adenomas: These maybe Solitary (more common) Multiple Part of MEN-1, MEN-2A or MEN-4 Chief cell parathyroid hyperplasia Parathyroid gland carcinoma Lithium use Hyperparathyroidism-jaw tumor (HPT-™T) syndrome

question_text: Which of the following sets of lab values will be seen in a patient with secondary hyperparathyroidism?

question_text: Calcitonin levels are increased in:
explanation: Calcitonin levels are increased in hyperparathyroidism. Due to elevated parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels in hyperparathyroidism, there is osteoclast activation. This leads to increased calcium levels in plasma. As a response to this, there is an increase in the level of calcitonin to regulate the high calcium levels. Calcitonin is secreted by the parafollicular C-cells of the thyroid gland. Its principal effects are to lower serum calcium and phosphate by its action on bone and kidney. In bone, calcitonin inhibits osteoclasts and reduces bone resorption. In the kidney, it inhibits the reabsorption of both calcium and phosphate. Other options Option A: In hyperthyroidism, the direct effect of thyroid hormones can lead to bone resorption and mild hypercalcemia. However, hyperparathyroidism is a better answer. Options B and D: Hypoparathyroidism and Cushing’s syndrome will have low serum calcium and hence, will not have increased calcitonin levels.

question_text: The spinal x-ray of a patient with elevated ALP levels is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The above x-ray shows a rugger jersey spine which is a distinct feature of hyperparathyroidism. It is associated with elevated ALP. It refers to the prominent hyperdensities at the endplates of successive vertebrae, which mimics the striped appearance of a rugby jersey. Option A: Paget's disease causes cortical thickening, which results in increased opacity on all sides of the vertebral body. These are called picture frame vertebrae. Option C: Osteopetrosis presents with normal ALP levels. It results in sclerotic endplates of vertebrae that are termed sandwich vertebrae. Though this finding is similar to rugger jersey spine, it is denser and more sharply defined than rugger jersey spine. In addition, there is sclerosis of inner margins of vertebral bodies, resulting in a bone within a bone appearance. Option D: Ankylosing spondylitis produces a bamboo spine appearance due to fusion of vertebral bodies.

question_text: A middle-aged woman presents with worsening pain and an inability to bear weight on her left leg. She says that she had banged her leg against a chair 3 days ago. X-ray reveals a fracture of her left tibia. In view of this finding, a skeletal survey was performed and reveals the following additional finding. What is the likely cause?
explanation: This clinical scenario is suggestive of a pathological fracture of the tibia. The given x-ray shows brown tumors or osteitis fibrosa cystica, which are characteristic of hyperparathyroidism.

question_text: This x-ray finding in a patient is characteristic of which of the following conditions?
explanation: The arrows in this x-ray point to arrow-headed fingers or the spade phalanx sign. It is pathognomonic of acromegaly. Acromegaly is the result of excessive growth hormone (GH) production, most commonly from a macroadenoma of the pituitary. There is osseous enlargement, presenting with spade-like hands and widening of the terminal phalangeal tufts, giving an arrow-head appearance. Other features in the hand include: Widened joint spaces (due to cartilage hypertrophy) Generalized osteoporosis and cystic changes in the carpal bones Option A: Hyperparathyroidism causes subperiosteal bone resorption, which is marked along the radial aspect of the middle phalanges of the index and middle fingers. Option B: Down's syndrome can cause hypoplasia of the middle phalanx of the 5th finger. Option C: Psoriasis causes a pencil-in-cup appearance of the distal phalanx.

question_text: Which of the following is not used to treat a patient with hypercalcemia due to primary hyperparathyroidism?
explanation: Glucocorticoids have no effect on the serum calcium concentration in primary hyperparathyroidism and normal individuals. They are effective in the treatment of hypercalcemia when associated with the following conditions: Malignancy Vitamin D intoxication Sarcoidosis Initial medical management of hypercalcemia involves the following: Normal saline (200-500 ml/hour): It is the mainstay treatment to correct dehydration, and titrated to maintain a urine output of >100 ml/hour Pamidronate or zoledronate: These are bisphosphonates and are considered as the drug of choice in primary hyperparathyroidis Cinacalcet: This is a calcimimetic that increases the affinity of the glands to extracellular calcium, thereby decreasing parathyroid hormone secretion Denosumab: This inhibits RANK-ligand, which acts on osteoclasts Calcitonin: This is an activated vitamin D analog that may be used to reduce calcium levels. It should be used within the first 24 hours Forced diuresis refers to aggressive fluid hydration with loop diuretic administration. Although this is an effective method to reduce calcium levels, it requires careful monitoring for adverse effects like fluid overload, hypokalemia, and hypomagnesia. Due to this reason as well as the availability of more effective treatment modalities, forced diuresis is not preferred any longer. The definitive management of primary hyperparathyroidism is the surgical removal of the parathyroid gland.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is used in the treatment of hypercalcemia due to Vitamin D toxicity?
explanation: In patients with hypercalcemia due to vitamin D toxicity, glucocorticoids like dexamethasone are the preferred therapy as they decrease 1,25 (OH2) vitamin D (calcitriol) production. This results in reduced intestinal calcium absorption and increased urinary excretion of calcium. Hydroxychloroquine, chloroquine, and ketoconazole may also decrease calcitriol production and are used occasionally. But the preferred therapy is steroids. Vitamin D toxicity presents acutely with features of hypercalcemia such as confusion, polyuria, polydipsia, anorexia, vomiting, and muscle weakness. Chronic intoxication may cause nephrocalcinosis, bone demineralization, and pain. Lab features include elevated 25 (OH) vitamin D, high calcium, and suppressed PTH. Dexamethasone can also be used in the treatment of hypercalcemia caused by the humoral hypercalcemia of malignancy (due to PTHr) and sarcoidosis.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A patient is brought to the emergency department with confusion, drowsiness, and multiple episodes of vomiting. His family members say that he was diagnosed with bipolar disorder several years ago and has been on medication ever since. Further evaluation reveals a serum calcium level of 16 mg/dl. What should be the next step in the management of this patient?
explanation: This clinical scenario is suggestive of a hypercalcemic crisis. The next best step in management is saline hydration. Typically 200-500 ml/hour fluids are given to correct dehydration and titrated to maintain a urine output of >100 ml/hour. Hypercalcemic crisis is a medical emergency associated with serum calcium >14 mg/dl. It is often caused by conditions causing an acute rise in calcium levels such as malignancies or lithium overdose. It presents with oliguria, severe dehydration, gastrointestinal symptoms, and altered consciousness. It can lead to cardiac arrest and coma. Initial medical management of hypercalcemia involves the following: Fluids are the mainstay treatment Bisphosphonates Cinacalcet Denosumab Calcitonin

question_text: Which of the following statements is incorrect with respect to hypocalcemia?
explanation: Hypocalcemia is a feature of secondary hyperparathyroidism (SHPT). Hypocalcemia refers to total serum calcium 8.4 mg/dl. The causes include: Low PTH Hypoparathyroidis High PTH (SHPT) Chronic kidney disease Vitamin D deficiency Pseudohypoparathyroidis Hyperphosphatemia Loop diuretics, calcitonin, bisphosphonates Massive blood transfusions Hyperventilation Hypomagnesemia - Mg is essential for PTH release Severe hypermagnesemia - higher Mg levels suppress PTH secretion Hypocalcemia causes tetany or increased neuromuscular excitability. question_text: The following sign is elicited in a patient. What is it called?
explanation: The above image indicates Trousseau's sign or carpopedal spasm classically seen in patients with hypocalcemia. Trousseau's sign is elicited by making the forearm ischemic by applying a sphygmomanometer cuff to the arm and keeping the pressure above systolic blood pressure (SBP) for 5 minutes. The hand goes into a painful carpopedal spasm and assumes the accoucheur’s hand position. Hypocalcemia results in tetany or increased neuromuscular irritability. It leads to paresthesia and tingling of extremities and perioral area. Severe hypocalcemia can cause seizures. Option A: Chvostek's sign is also seen in hypocalcemia. Tapping the facial nerve in front of the tragus will cause spasms of the facial muscles. Option C: Tinel's sign is seen in carpal tunnel syndrome. It refers to a tingling sensation on tapping over the median nerve. Option D: Troisier's sign refers to left supraclavicular lymphadenopathy in metastatic abdominal malignancy.
subject: Medicine

question_text:
Which of the following agents cannot be used to manage a patient with chronic hypocalcemia?
Etidronate
explanation: Etidronate is not used in the management of hypocalcemia. It is a bisphosphonate used in the management of hypercalcemia. The goal in the management of hypoparathyroidism is to restore the calcium-phosphate balance. The mainstay is calcium and vitamin D supplements. Other underlying conditions must also be treated. Instead of loop diuretics, thiazides can be administered on a low sodium diet as they enhance urinary calcium reabsorption. Obesity
subject: Medicine

question_text: The hormone leptin is derived from which of the following?
explanation: Leptin is an adipocyte-derived hormone. It acts through brain circuits (predominantly in the hypothalamus) to influence appetite, energy expenditure, and neuroendocrine function. High leptin levels reduce appetite and increase energy expenditure. The arcuate nucleus in the hypothalamus plays an important role in the regulation of appetite.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 25-year-old woman has been fasting all day as part of a new diet. Which of the following is a gut peptide that will be increased in this woman?
explanation: In the fasting state, high levels of ghrelin are seen. It is a gut-peptide produced in the stomach and stimulates hunger and appetite.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 16-year-old boy ate two pieces of cake, a sandwich, and two scoops of ice cream at his friend's birthday party an hour ago. Levels of which of the following are likely to be high in this boy?
explanation: This boy is likely to have high levels of -Melanocyte-stimulating hormone (-MSH). It is a hypothalamic peptide that decreases appetite and hence would be increased in the fed state.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is a key transcription factor involved in the differentiation of mesenchymal preadipocytes to adipose cells?
explanation: One of the key transcription factors involved in the differentiation of mesenchymal preadipocytes to adipose cells is the peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor  (PPAR). It is a nuclear receptor that also binds the thiazolidinedione class of insulin-sensitizing drugs used in the treatment of type 2 diabetes mellitus. Note: Saroglitazar has a dual action on PPAR and PPAR■ receptors. It reduces blood sugar and lipid levels in diabetic patients.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding adiponectin?
options: Its levels are increased in obesity
explanation: Adiponectin levels are reduced in obesity. It is an abundant adipose-derived protein with the following characteristics: Its levels are reduced in obesity It enhances insulin sensitivity and lipid oxidation Has vascular-protective effects On the other hand, resistin and RBP4 levels, which are also secreted by adipocytes, may induce insulin resistance.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 2-year-old girl is referred to an endocrinologist with severe obesity and insatiable hunger despite adequate nutrition. Due to the early-onset severe obesity, genetic testing was done and revealed inactivating mutations in the leptin gene. Which of the following neuroendocrine abnormalities is this child most likely to develop?
explanation: The most prominent neuroendocrine abnormality seen in obese individuals with inactivating mutations in the leptin (ob gene) or leptin receptor (db gene) is hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. Leptin mutations are responsible for a rare form of obesity that runs in families. These mutations prevent leptin from delivering satiety signals. Hence, the brain perceives starvation despite adequate nutrition. It results in morbid, early-onset obesity. Mutations in the following genes can cause obesity in humans: Lep (ob) LepR (db) POMC PC-1 MC4R
subject: Medicine

question_text: Genetic mutations causing pro-opiomelanocortin (POMC) deficiency presents with all of the following except:
explanation: Cachexia is not a feature of mutations of the pro-opiomelanocortin (POMC) gene. It is associated with the following characteristics: Absence of -MSH Severe obesity - -MSH inhibits appetite in the hypothalamus Pale skin and red hair Absence of ACTH Secondary adrenal insufficiency
subject: Medicine

question_text: The production of which of the following hormones is increased in obesity?
explanation: Insulin levels are increased in obesity. It stimulates the synthesis of fatty acids and TAG and decreases the rate of lipolysis. Thyroxine, growth hormone, and adiponectin have lipolytic effects, hence their levels are reduced in obesity. Hyperinsulinemia and insulin resistance are consistent features of obesity. Insulin resistance is more strongly linked to intra-abdominal fat than to fat in other areas. Adiponectin (Option D) is an anti-inflammatory cytokine that is produced by adipocytes. It performs vital functions that are reduced in obesity - like, increasing insulin sensitivity and the inhibition of gluconeogenic enzymes. It also enhances fatty acid oxidation. Insulin resistance in obesity occurs as a result of the following: Insulin receptor downregulation Increased FFA (free fatty acids) and capable of impairing insulin action Intracellular lipid accumulation Circulating peptides produced by adipocytes such as TNF-, IL-6, RBP4, and resistin modify insulin action.
subject: Medicine

question_text: In a child with obesity, hypogonadism, and mental retardation, which of the following would you not suspect ?
explanation: Children with Angelman syndrome present with mental retardation but do not have obesity and hypogonadism. It occurs due to the deletion of band q12 of the maternal chromosome 15. The following syndromes present with obesity, hypogonadism, and mental retardation Prader-Willi syndrome - deletion of band q12 of the paternal chromosome 15. Laurence-Moon-Bardet-Biedl syndrome Carpenter syndrome Cohen syndrome The following image shows a child with Prader-Willi syndrome.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Obesity is not seen in patients with which of the following conditions?
explanation: Sipple syndrome is characterized by pheochromocytoma which is associated with weight loss. Obesity is seen in the following syndromes: Cushing's syndrome Prader-Willi syndrome Pickwickian syndrome Hypothyroidism Insulinoma Craniopharyngioma and other hypothalamic disorders Laurence-Moon-Bardet-Biedl syndrome Carpenter syndrome Cohen syndrome
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 40-year-old woman is being evaluated for high blood glucose levels. On examination, acanthosis nigricans is noted, and her BMI is 34 kg/m². How would you classify her weight?
explanation: According to the WHO classification, a BMI of 34 kg/m² would be classified as class I obesity. The revised BMI classification for Asians/Indians is as follows: Underweight - BMI < 18.5 kg/m2 Normal or lean - BMI 18.5–22.9 kg/m2 Overweight - BMI 23.0 –24.9 kg/m2 Obese BMI 25 kg/m2 Note: As the question does not specify Asian/Indian, the answer is given according to WHO classification. question_text: A known patient of type 2 diabetes mellitus on oral medication presents to your OPD for review. His blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg and his BMI is 28.4 kg/m². His fasting glucose is 118 mg/dl and postprandial glucose is 154 mg/dl. He consumes a low-calorie diet and exercises regularly. How will you manage his obesity?
options: Start him on a more intense diet and exercise regimen
Anti-obesity drugs in combination with proper diet and exercise
Anti-obesity drugs alone as lifestyle changes have not been effective
explanation: This obese man with a BMI of 28.4 kg/m² along with comorbidities must be managed with anti-obesity drugs as an ad™unct to comprehensive lifestyle modifications. The recommendations for management of obesity are as follows: Diet, exercise, behavioral therapy: BMI - 25-29.9 with comorbidities BMI  30 Ad™unctive pharmacotherapy: BMI - 2š-29.9 with comorbidities BMI  30 Bariatric surgery: BMI - 35-39.9 with comorbidities BMI  40
subject: Medicine

question_text:
Which of the following anti-obesity drugs is a selective 5-HT2C receptor agonist?
Orlistat
explanation: Lorcaserin is a selective 5-HT2C receptor agonist with a functional selectivity ~15 times that of 5-HT2A receptors and 100 times that of 5-HT2B receptors. Hyperbilirubinemias and Tests of Liver Function
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 4-month-old child was brought with a history of recurrent episodes of jaundice. Blood investigations were suggestive of hereditary spherocytosis. Which of the following liver function test findings is likely to be seen here?
explanation: The given clinical scenario describes recurrent hemolysis in a patient with hereditary spherocytosis leading to jaundice. In hemolytic conditions, only the unconjugated/ indirect bilirubin is raised and conjugated/direct bilirubin remains normal i.e. <15% of total bilirubin. Bilirubin is synthesized from heme which is released primarily from the breakdown of old RBCs. This bilirubin is in its unconjugated form. It enters the circulation and reaches the liver. It is converted to conjugated bilirubin which is then secreted into the biliary tree. Therefore, in a healthy person, most of the circulating bilirubin is unconjugated/indirect bilirubin. Hence, the normal liver function tests show indirect bilirubin >85% and direct/conjugated bilirubin <15% of the total bilirubin. The normal bilirubin values are as follows: Total bilirubin levels - 1 to 1.5 mg/dL Direct bilirubin - <0.3 mg/dL
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 2-week-old baby presented with yellowish discoloration of the skin. Investigations revealed markedly elevated direct bilirubin levels. Which of the following conditions should be suspected in the newborn?
explanation: The raised direct bilirubin levels indicate conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Among the given options, biliary atresia causes conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Biliary atresia is a disorder characterised by destruction or absence of bile ducts in a newborn. It leads to obstruction to the flow of bile thereby causing leaking of conjugated bilirubin into the circulation. Option B: Physiological jaundice of the newborn occurs due to immaturity of the newborn's liver. It is not able to conjugate the excess bilirubin produced after birth. It leads to unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Option C: Breast milk may contain certain factors that inhibit the conjugation of bilirubin leading to unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Option D: Hemolytic disease of the newborn causes excess production of bilirubin due to hemolysis leading to unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Investigations performed in a patient with recurrent jaundice gave the following results. What is the possible cause of jaundice in this patient?
explanation: The presence of urinary bilirubin and increased total bilirubin indicates conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Among the given options, Dubin Johnson syndrome causes conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Only conjugated bilirubin can appear in the urine because it is water-soluble and filterable by the kidney. Unconjugated bilirubin is water-insoluble and bound to albumin, hence it cannot be filtered by the kidney. Causes of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia: Increased bilirubin production- Hemolytic anemias Hematomas Impaired bilirubin uptake and conjugation- Gilbert syndrome Crigler Najjar syndrome Drugs - Probenecid, Rifampin Causes of conjugated hyperbilirubinemia: Hereditary cholestatic syndromes Dubin Johnson syndrome Rotor syndrome Biliary obstruction
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is a cause of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia?
options: Stone in the common bile duct
explanation: Probenecid causes impaired hepatic uptake of bilirubin which leads to unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Amoxicillin-clavulanate, acute hepatitis and stone in the common bile duct are causes that lead to mixed hyperbilirubinemia (both conjugated and unconjugated bilirubin elevated) or predominantly conjugated hyperbilirubinemias. Levels of conjugated and unconjugated bilirubin are useful in determining pre-hepatic causes of jaundice but are not useful in differentiating between intrahepatic and post-hepatic causes of jaundice.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 24-year-old woman presents with jaundice. She had been on OCPs for the past month. Her LFT and liver biopsy findings are given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Dubin Johnson syndrome (DJS). The LFT describes conjugated hyperbilirubinemia with normal liver enzyme levels. The given image of microscopic examination of liver biopsy shows an accumulation of dark melanin-like pigment in the hepatocytes which is seen in this condition. DJS is an autosomal recessive condition causing defective expression of MRP 2 protein which is important for the biliary excretion of conjugated bilirubin. The patient has icterus but is otherwise asymptomatic. DJS also impairs biliary excretion of various compounds like epinephrine metabolites. The dark melanin-like pigment is derived from these metabolites causing the liver to appear black. Rotor syndrome is also an autosomal recessive condition causing conjugated hyperbilirubinemia but it does not present with pigmentation of the liver. Gilbert and Crigler-Najjar syndromes are characterized by unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.
subject: Medicine

question_text: What is the defect seen in patients with Rotor syndrome?
options: Mutation in organic anion transport protein
explanation: Rotor syndrome occurs due to mutation in OATP (organic anion transport protein) 1B1 and 1B3. Rotor syndrome is an inherited autosomal recessive disorder with conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. It is a benign disorder with mild elevation of bilirubin levels. It is similar to Dubin Johnson syndrome but the liver does not show any black pigmentation. No treatment is required for these patients.
subject: Medicine

question_text: While evaluating a patient with jaundice, all of the following investigations would help you to differentiate between Dubin Johnson syndrome and Rotor syndrome except:
explanation: Serum bilirubin levels are not helpful in differentiating between Dubin Johnson syndrome (DJS) and Rotor's syndrome as both these conditions present with mild elevation of serum bilirubin. These two conditions can be differentiated as follows: Test Rotor Syndrome Dubin Johnson syndrome Oral cholecystography Gall bladder is visualized Gall bladder not visualisedIm paired ability to concentrate t he contrast material into bile Total urinary coproporphyrin Elevated NormalIncreased excretion o f coproporphyrin 1 and decre ased excretion of coproporph yrin 3 Bromsulphalein (BSP) cleara nce test Delayed clearance of BSPNo reflux Rise in plasma levels of BSP after 90 minutes of injection Reflux of BSP from hepatocyt es

question_text: In a patient with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, which feature helps confirm the diagnosis of Crigler- Najjar syndrome?
explanation: Kernicterus is seen in Crigler-Najjar syndrome but not in Gilbert syndrome. Gilbert syndrome does not cause a significant elevation in unconjugated bilirubin to cause kernicterus. Crigler-Najjar syndrome and Gilbert syndrome are both caused by various mutations in the UGT1A1 gene. This leads to decreased activity of bilirubin UDP-glucuronosyltransferase enzyme leading to unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Both are predominantly inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern. These syndromes present with jaundice in infants. The unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia in these syndromes is not associated with any hemolysis. All the other liver function tests are usually normal. Crigler Najjar syndrome may lead to kernicterus causing severe brain damage. Liver transplantation is required without which the infant may not survive beyond 1-2 years of age. Whereas, Gilbert syndrome is a benign asymptomatic condition that does not need any intervention.
subject: Medicine

question_text: An infant presented with yellow discolouration of the skin, poor feeding, and seizures. Investigations revealed total bilirubin- 40 mg/dL and unconjugated bilirubin- 34 mg/dL. Phenobarbitone was administered while blood was being arranged for an exchange transfusion. However, there was no improvement. What is the most probable diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario with poor feeding and seizures is indicative of kernicterus. This accompanied with unconjugated hyperbilrubinemia is highly suggestive of Crigler-Najjar syndrome type 1. No improvement in bilirubin levels following the administration of phenobarbital further supports the diagnosis. Crigler-Najjar syndrome is of two types with type 1 having absent/trace enzyme activity and type 2 having <10% of the normal enzyme activity. Hence, type 1 is far more severe and leads to kernicterus and neurological damage. Type 2 may also lead to kernicterus occasionally. Kernicterus occurs because the unconjugated bilirubin is lipid-soluble and hence crosses the blood-brain barrier. Phenobarbital is an enzyme inducer. Its administration can be used to differentiate between type 1 and type 2 Crigler-Najjar. Enzyme induction by phenobarbital leads to improved conjugation of bilirubin leading to a reduction in total bilirubin level in type 2 Crigler-Najjar syndrome. No improvement is seen in type 1 as the enzyme activity is absent and therefore cannot be induced. Inherited unconjugated hyperbilirubinemias (Autosomal Recessive) include: Note: Rotor syndrome causes conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Crigler-Najjar type I Crigler-Najjar type II Gilbert Syndrom e UDP-GT Activity Absent Markedly reduced Reduced Serum bilirubin 20 - 45 mg/dl <20 mg/dl Generally <3 mg/ dl Pheno-barbital effect on seru m bilirubin No effect Reduction Reduction Outcome Kernicterus Usually benign, kernicterus i s rare Benign Prevalence Rare Rare Common The normal serum bilirubin (between 1 and 1.5 mg/dL) present in serum represents a balance between input from the production of bilirubin and hepatic/biliary removal of the pigment. Isolated elevation of the bilirubin: Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia- >15% conjugated bilirubin Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia- <15% conjugated bilirubin

question_text: An 8-year-old child presents with jaundice and easy fatiguability. He had a history of ear infection which was treated with amoxicillin-clavulanic acid. Investigations done are shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hemolytic jaundice. It can present with the following features: Low hemoglobin Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia Pigment gall stones - excess bilirubin in bile Development of cholestasis when the gall stones obstruct the flow of bile. This would result in the elevation of conjugated bilirubin and LFTs show a cholestatic picture. Hepatic and obstructive causes of jaundice are not likely as the other liver function tests are normal. The various causes of jaundice can be differentiated as follows: Inherited hyperbilirubinemias like Gilbert syndrome are suspected when there is no associated hemolysis. It is unlikely in this patient because there are clear hemolytic features. question_text: Which of the following conditions is associated with increased activity of 5’- nucleotidase?
explanation: 5■-nucleotidase is usually elevated in cholestasis. Enzymes elevated in cholestasis are : Alkaline phosphatase (ALP) 5■-nucleotidase -glutamyl transpeptidase (GGT)

question_text: Which among the following is the most specific indicator of liver cell injury?
explanation: Among the given options, alanine aminotransferase is the most specific indicator of liver cell injury. Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) and aspartate aminotransferase (AST) are indicators of liver cell injury. This is because ALT is found primarily in the liver, whereas, AST is found in the liver, cardiac muscle, skeletal muscle, kidneys, brain, pancreas, etc. GGT and ALP are enzymes that primarily reflect cholestasis.
subject: Medicine

question_text: In a patient with acute viral hepatitis, what level of serum transaminases will you expect?
explanation: In a patient with acute viral hepatitis, serum transaminases are elevated to >1000 IU/L The normal levels of serum transaminases are 10-40 IU/L. Marked elevation of serum transaminases >1000 IU/L is seen in conditions with extensive hepatocellular injury. These include: Viral hepatitis Ischemic injury to the liver in conditions like acute heart failure Toxin/drug-induced liver injury Minor elevations of serum transaminase levels up to 300 IU/L are non-specific and can be found in any liver disease.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 64-year-old man with jaundice and abdominal pain was found to have an ALP level of 200 mg/dL. His LFT reports from a month ago had shown an ALP level of 50 mg/dL. What is your inference?
options: Could be due to fatty meal intake
explanation: A 4 fold rise of serum ALP (alkaline phosphatase) is suggestive of cholestatic liver disease. However, serum ALP levels cannot differentiate between extrahepatic and intrahepatic cholestasis. The normal range for serum ALP is considered 40-125 IU/L. Serum alkaline phosphatase is found in the liver, bone, small intestines, and placenta. Hence, a mild increase in ALP, i.e., 1 - 1.5 times normal, can be seen in these conditions: Following a fatty meal intake - influx of intestinal alkaline phosphatase into the blood. Hence, the patient is advised to fast before the blood sample is collected for the test. In pregnancy - placental ALP In children - rapid bone growth In elderly people over 60 years of age ALP can be raised even in conditions like metastatic bone disease, inflammatory bowel disease, Hodgkin's lymphoma, etc. Hence, it needs to be correlated with raised levels of gamma-glutamyltransferase (GGT) and 5' nucleotidase which are more specific for liver disease.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following statements regarding liver enzymes is true?
options: ALT is raised to >1000 IU/L in cirrhosis
Absolute levels of aminotransferases correlate with the prognosis
AST:ALT ratio <1 is seen in nonalcoholic fatty liver disease
AST:ALT ratio >1 is seen in chronic viral hepatitis
explanation: AST:ALT ratio <1 is seen in NAFLD (nonalcoholic fatty liver disease). The AST:ALT ratio can be interpreted as follows: Option A: Patients with cirrhosis have only mildly elevated or even normal levels of serum transaminases. Option B: Absolute levels of aminotransferases are not used for predicting prognosis. This is because there is a poor correlation between the degree of liver cell damage and the levels of aminotransferases. So, AST>AL T. >3:1 Highly suggestive of alcoholic liver disease.
