question_text: Liver function tests of a patient show isolated elevation of gamma-glutamyltransferase with other liver enzymes within normal limits. All of the following drugs could be responsible for this finding except:
explanation: Among the given options, penicillin does not lead to elevated gamma-glutamyltransferase (GGT) levels. GGT is a microsomal enzyme. Hence, drugs that are microsomal enzyme inducers can lead to an increase in GGT levels. However, other liver enzyme levels will be normal. Therefore, an isolated rise in GGT level does not indicate cholestatic liver disease. Drugs that increase levels of GGT are: Barbiturates Carbamazepine Ethanol Griseofulvin Rifampicin Phenytoin
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following statements regarding prothrombin time is false?
options: Indicates prognosis in acute liver disease
Indicates prognosis in chronic liver disease
Measures factors II, V, VIII, X
Measures factors II, V, VII, X
explanation: Prothrombin time (PT) can help in estimating the levels of factors II, V, VII, and X. PT evaluates the extrinsic and the common pathway of coagulation. Factor VII is required in the extrinsic pathway and factors II, V, X are required in the common pathway. Coagulation factors are produced by the liver (except factor VIII) and they have a short half-life. Hence, they indicate the synthetic function of the liver and are very useful in assessing acute hepatic dysfunction. Factor VIII is produced by vascular endothelial cells. Prolonged PT that is not corrected by vitamin K administration indicates poor prognosis in both acute and chronic liver disease.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which among the following is a marker of chronic liver disease?
explanation: Serum albumin is a marker of chronic liver disease because it is synthesized by the hepatocytes and has a long half-life of 18–20 days. Serum albumin is not a good indicator of acute or mild hepatic dysfunction. Hypoalbuminemia is more common in chronic liver disorders such as cirrhosis and usually reflects severe liver damage. In hepatitis, albumin levels <3 g/dL should raise the possibility of chronic liver disease. Prothrombin time is used to assess acute parenchymal liver disease. 5' nucleosidase is elevated in cholestasis. Elevation of ALP (<3 fold) is not specific to liver diseases.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following can be seen in a patient with chronic liver disease?
explanation: Chronic liver disease is associated with hypergammaglobulinemia. Chronic liver diseases with hypergammaglobulinemia include autoimmune hepatitis, primary biliary cirrhosis, and alcoholic liver disease. The liver produces all globulins except gamma globulin which are produced by B cells. In chronic liver diseases like liver cirrhosis, there is impaired reticuloendothelial function in hepatic sinusoids. Hence the liver fails to clear the bacterial antigens. This causes an increased production of gamma globulin.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is not a marker for liver fibrosis?
explanation: Telopeptide is not a marker for liver fibrosis. It is a marker for bone resorption. Various non-invasive markers to detect hepatic fibrosis are given below: Non-invasive test for fibrosis Components tested Fibrotest/FibroSure 2-macroglobulinHaptoglobi nApolipoprotein A-1GGTTota l bilirubin Enhanced Liver Fibrosis (EL F) assay Hyaluronic acidProcollagen p eptide III(PIIINP)Tissue inhi bitor of metalloproteinase(TI MP) Transient elastography (Fibr oScan) Ultrasound waves are used to measure liver stiffness Non-invasive test for fibrosis Components tested Non-invasive test for fibrosis Components tested Fibrospect II Hyaluronic acidAlpha 2 macr oglobulinTissue inhibitor of metalloproteinase 1 (TIMP 1)

question_text:
In which of the following patients planned for a liver biopsy, would you not be required to use the transjugular approach?
A patient with prolonged INR
explanation: Liver biopsy can be performed in a patient with splenomegaly via the percutaneous approach. When the percutaneous approach is not advisable, liver biopsy can be performed via the transjugular approach. In this approach, a cannula is inserted via the jugular vein which is then passed into hepatic veins through which the biopsy sample is taken. Therefore, any bleeding resulting from the procedure will drain into the hepatic veins. Indications of transjugular liver biopsy: Percutaneous approach contraindicate Significant ascites Prolonged INR Coagulopathies Difficulty in accessing the liver via the percutaneous route Morbid obesity Alcoholic Liver Diseases and Non-Alcoholic Fatty Liver Disease
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is the most common cause of cirrhosis in India?
explanation: Alcoholic liver disease is the most common cause of cirrhosis in India. The most common cause of cirrhosis worldwide is chronic viral hepatitis - Hepatitis C and B. NASH is expected to overtake it in the near future.
subject: Medicine

question_text: What is the minimum amount of ethanol a man must have consumed for him to be at increased risk for alcoholic liver disease?
explanation: The minimum amount of ethanol that leads to an increased risk of developing alcoholic liver disease is 28g/day. In women, the minimum is 14g/day. The risk factors for alcoholic liver disease are: Quantity of alcohol consumption - The risk of developing alcoholic liver disease increases when alcohol consumption is >14 drinks/ week in men and >7drinks/week in women. A standard drink contains 14g of ethanol which is present in - 120 mL of wine 350ml of beer 45ml of spirits (gin, rum, whiskey, vodka, tequilla) Gender - Women have increased susceptibility to alcoholic liver disease Hepatitis C infection - Increases the severity and decreases survival in alcoholic liver disease Genetics - A variation in patatin-like phospholipase domain-containing protein 3 (PNPLA3) gene confers an increased risk of progressive liver disease
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 45-year-old chronic alcoholic presents with right upper quadrant abdominal pain and nausea. His ultrasound abdomen revealed grade 2 fatty liver. Which among the following findings is unlikely to be seen in his condition?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of alcoholic liver disease. It is usually characterized by an AST: ALT > 2. This is because there is a deficiency of pyridoxal 5'- phosphate that is a cofactor for the enzymatic activity of ALT. Therefore, ALT levels fail to rise and there is a reversal of the AST: ALT ratio. Prothrombin time (PT) is prolonged due to the deficiency of coagulation factors and, usually, does not respond to the administration of parenteral vitamin K. Platelet counts are often reduced early in the disease, which is reflective of portal hypertension with hypersplenism. Elevated ALP levels are seen due to enzymatic induction by alcohol and mild cholestasis.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is unlikely to be seen in patients with Zieve's syndrome?
explanation: Zieve's syndrome is not associated with thrombocytosis. Zieve's syndrome is a rare syndrome occurring due to severe alcoholic hepatitis characterized by a triad of: Cholestatic jaundice Hemolytic anemia Transient hyperlipidemia It resolves with abstinence from alcohol.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is the most specific marker for alcoholism?
explanation: GGT (Gamma Glutamyl Transferase) is the most specific marker of alcoholism among the given options. The markers with >60% sensitivity and specificity for heavy alcohol use are gamma-glutamyl transferase (>35 u) and carbohydrate-deficient transferrin (CDT), the combination of the two is likely to be more accurate than one. An isolated elevation in serum GGT or GGT elevation out of proportion to that of other enzymes (such as the ALT and ALP) may be an indicator of alcohol abuse or alcoholic liver disease. ALT (option A) is usually elevated in acute hepatocellular conditions such as hepatitis. Alanine aminotransferase is predominantly found in the liver, hence a more specific marker of liver injury. A ratio of AST/ALT > 2:1 indicates the possibility of alcoholic liver disease and > 3:1 ratio is highly indicative of this condition. In alcoholic liver disease, ALT levels are often normal. ALP (option C) is elevated in cholestasis, ■■is also elevated when there is rapid bone growth like in children and adolescents because of bone alkaline phosphatase and in normal pregnancies due to placental alkaline phosphatase. LDH (option D) elevation is nonspecific.
subject: Medicine

question_text: You are using a CAGE questionnaire to screen a patient for alcohol abuse. Which of these is not the correct expansion of this questionnaire?
options: C - drink to calm your nerves
A - criticism over drinking annoys you
E - had a drink as eye opener
explanation: C stands for feeling the need to cut down your drinking in the CAGE questionnaire. The CAGE questionnaire is used for identifying alcohol abuse. It can be expanded as below: C - Have you ever felt you ought to cut down on your drinking? A - Have people annoyed you by criticizing your drinking? G - Have you ever felt guilty or bad about your drinking? E - Have you ever had a drink first thing in the morning to steady your nerves or get rid of a hangover (eye-opener)? One 'yes' response raises a suspicion of an alcohol use problem and more than one is a strong indication of abuse or dependence.
subject: Medicine

question_text: What parameters are used in calculating discriminant function?
options: Prothrombin time, ascites and hepatic encephalopathy
explanation: Discriminant function (DF) is calculated using prothrombin time and bilirubin level. It is also known as the Maddrey score and it assesses the severity and mortality risk in alcoholic hepatitis. DF = 4.6 X (the prolongation of the prothrombin time above control [seconds]) + serum bilirubin (mg/dL) DF  32 indicates severe disease and is an indication for starting glucocorticoids.

explanation: Alcoholic cirrhosis is characterized by mixed micro-and macronodular. If a mixed pattern is not an option, the best choice is micronodular cirrhosis. question_text: Prednisolone therapy for alcoholic hepatitis can be started in a patient with all of the following except:
explanation: SOFA score >2 indicates sepsis and glucocorticoids are avoided in septic patients. Glucocorticoids are indicated in severe alcoholic hepatitis which is defined as: Discriminant Function (DF)  32 Model for End-stage Liver Disease (MELD) score  21 Glasgow alcoholic hepatitis score  9 Presence of hepatic encephalopathy Prednisolone is given at a dose of 32 mg orally daily for 4 weeks and then slowly tapered off. question_text: A 34-year-old man presents with yellowish discoloration of the skin, abdominal pain, and fever. He reports consuming one-quarter of whisky every day for the past 10 years. He is a known case of chronic kidney disease. His lab reports are given below. Which of the following is used in his treatment?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of severe alcoholic hepatitis. Since the patient is a known case of chronic kidney disease, pentoxifylline is used in his treatment. Severe alcoholic hepatitis is defined by a discriminant function  32. In the given scenario, DF = 4.6 X (the prolongation of the prothrombin time above control [seconds]) + serum bilirubin (mg/dL) = 4.6 x (16-11) + 11 = 34. Thus, the patient cannot be managed by nutritional support alone. Pentoxifylline is a TNF alpha inhibitor used either by itself or along with glucocorticoids in the treatment of severe alcoholic hepatitis. It is preferred in patients with kidney diseases and conditions where glucocorticoids are contraindicated. Glucocorticoid therapy is avoided in: Active GI bleeding requiring blood transfusions Active infection requiring antibiotic treatment Preexisting chronic renal disease with a serum creatinine level greater than 2 mg/dL Pancreatitis Obvious contraindications to glucocorticoid therapy

question_text: Which of the following statements is not true about nonalcoholic fatty liver disease?
options: Results from fat accumulation in more than 5% of hepatocytes
Strongly associated with obesity and insulin resistance
Associated with reduced serum ferritin levels
Diagnosis of NASH requires presence of inflammation
explanation: Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is associated with increased levels of serum ferritin. Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is defined as hepatic steatosis in the absence of any secondary cause for fat accumulation. Histologically, this requires fat accumulation in more than 5% of hepatocytes and it can be divided into: Nonalcoholic fatty liver (NAFL)- steatosis without inflammation Nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) - steatosis with inflammation NAFLD is strongly associated with obesity and insulin resistance. Its diagnosis requires demonstration of hepatic steatosis and exclusion of significant alcohol consumption and other causes of hepatic fat accumulation.
subject: Medicine

question_text:
A non-diabetic patient has been diagnosed with nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH). Which of the following is the first-line therapy for it?
Vitamin A
explanation: The first-line therapy for nondiabetic patients with nonalcoholic steatohepatitis(NASH) is vitamin E. explanation: The most common route of the spread of hepatitis E is feco-oral. Hepatitis E virus is the most common cause of acute hepatitis in adults, especially in endemic countries like India. question_text: Which of the following statements is true regarding hepatitis E?
options: Can be fatal in pregnant women
Can cause chronic hepatitis in immunocompetent
Most common route of spread is vertical transmission
explanation: Fatality due to Hepatitis E is highest in pregnant women. In the general population, hepatitis E can lead to fatal fulminant hepatitis in only 1–2% of cases. However, in pregnant women, this is raised to 20% of cases. HEV does not have a carrier state and can cause chronic hepatitis only in immunocompromised individuals. question_text: Which of the following is associated with the highest risk of developing fulminant hepatitis?
explanation: Acute viral hepatitis caused by the hepatitis D virus is associated with the highest risk of developing fulminant hepatitis. However, fulminant hepatitis is most commonly caused by hepatitis E, especially in endemic countries such as India. This is due to the greater prevalence of hepatitis E infections compared to hepatitis D.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A pregnant woman comes to your clinic for her first antenatal checkup in her 3rd trimester. Laboratory workup reveals that she is HBsAg positive and HBeAg positive. What is the chance of vertical transmission of hepatitis B to the child?
explanation: The chance of vertical transmission of hepatitis B from a mother who is HBsAg positive and HBeAg positive is >90%. In contrast, when the mother is HBsAg positive but HBeAg negative or HBsAg positive with Anti Hbe, the risk of vertical transmission is low. To prevent vertical transmission of HBV, HBsAg positive pregnant women with high HBV DNA titres should receive tenofovir prophylaxis from the 28th week of pregnancy until birth. Infants born to these women are given hepatitis B immunoglobulin along with the first dose of the hepatitis B vaccine. The presence of HBeAg indicates active replication of HBV. Therefore, HBeAg is the qualitative marker of infectivity. HBV DNA titre is the quantitative marker of infectivity. question_text: What is the first marker to rise in a patient with acute hepatitis B?
explanation: The first virologic marker to rise in acute hepatitis B is HBsAg i.e., Hepatitis B surface antigen. It is detectable in serum within 1–12 weeks of infection. Usually, HBsAg becomes undetectable 1–2 months after the onset of jaundice. If it persists beyond 6 months, it indicates chronic hepatitis B. However, very rarely, patients may have an HBsAg negative status even during active infection due to infection with escape mutant HBV. These escape mutants have mutations within the S gene and they are known to be responsible for occult hepatitis B infections.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which serological marker can be used to diagnose acute hepatitis B in the window period?
explanation: The diagnosis of acute hepatitis B in the window period or serological gap can be made by the detection of the anti-HBc antibody. The window period is the period between the disappearance of HBsAg to anti-HBs seroconversion. During this window period, anti-HBc is the only detectable antibody.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 35-year-old male patient presented with right upper quadrant abdominal pain and jaundice. His lab reports are given below. What is the likely causative organism for his condition?
explanation: Increased viral load and negative HBeAg suggest a pre-core mutant variety of hepatitis B virus. These strains have mutations in the pre-core region of the C gene, leading to a stop codon that prevents HBeAg synthesis. These strains can be detected in the serum by HBV DNA analysis. Infection with hepatitis B mutants is difficult to treat and causes infections of prolonged duration. They have a higher risk of progressing to liver cirrhosis. question_text: The lab report of a 40-year-old man is shown below. What is the most likely cause for this serological picture?
options: Hepatitis B in the remote past
explanation: The given lab findings are most likely to be in patients who had hepatitis B in the remote past i.e., patients in late convalescence period. In such conditions, the patient will have positive IgG anti-HBc and negative HBsAg.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A patient with acute hepatitis B has recovered from the infection. Identify the serological marker marked in the image:
explanation: The serological marker marked in the image which becomes detectable early in the infection and remains elevated for a long period after recovery from the infection is an anti-HBc antibody. Anti-HBc is demonstrable in serum within the first 1–2 weeks after the appearance of HBsAg. It precedes detectable levels of anti-HBs by weeks to months. I M anti-HBcAg antibody is seen early in the infection for about 6 months and indicates a recent infection. IgG anti-HBcAg antibody is seen later, after 6 months, and indicates remote infection.
subject: Medicine

question_text: An intern sustained a needle-prick injury while establishing an IV line on a patient in the casualty. The patient was subsequently found to be HBsAg positive. The presence of which of the following markers in the intern would reliably indicate an early infection?
explanation: The most reliable indicator of recent HBV infection is IgM anti-HBc in serum. However, the first virologic marker to rise in acute hepatitis B is HBsAg i.e. surface antigen. HBsAg is detectable in serum within 1–12 weeks of infection. Anti-HBc is demonstrable in the serum about 1-2 weeks after this, and may sometimes persist in the serum even longer than an anti-HBs antibody. IgM anti-HBcAg is seen early in the infection and persists for about 6 months. It indicates a recent infection. IgG anti-HBcAg antibody is seen later i.e. after 6 months and indicates remote infection. HBcAg is not detectable in the serum of patients with HBV infection as it is present intracellularly. Note: The risk of transmission of HBV from percutaneous routes (eg., needle prick) is about 6-30% and it is about 100 times more infectious than HIV.
subject: Medicine

question_text: During your casualty rotation, you accidentally injure yourself while suturing a patient. ’ou had taken the full schedule of hepatitis B vaccination during your first year of medical school. Which of the following markers will you get measured to determine the need for HBIG administration?
explanation: The need for administration of hepatitis B hyperimmune globulin (HBIG) in a previously vaccinated individual can be determined based on anti-HBsAg levels. It is the marker for determining the efficacy of hepatitis B vaccination. The complete hepatitis B vaccine schedule consists of three intramuscular doses at 0, 1, and 6 months. Post Exposure Prophylaxis: The prophylaxis can be done using the hepatitis B vaccine or hepatitis B immunoglobulin (HBIG). question_text: Which of the following markers can be used to differentiate between hepatitis D superinfection and coinfection?
explanation: I M anti-HBc can be used to differentiate between hepatitis D coinfection and superinfection in patients with HBV infection. question_text: A male patient presents with complaints of jaundice, loss of appetite, and weight loss for the past several months. After a full laboratory workup, a liver biopsy was performed which appeared as shown in the given image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given histopathological image shows ground-glass hepatocytes which are a hallmark of chronic hepatitis B infection. These ground-glass hepatocytes are liver parenchymal cells that have an eosinophilic, granular, and glassy appearance on light microscopy. This appearance is due to the accumulation of HBsAg (hepatitis B surface antigen) in the smooth endoplasmic reticulum. question_text: Which of the following pairs of viral hepatitis and its management is incorrectly matched?
options: Acute viral hepatitis E - Supportive care
Acute viral hepatitis B - Antiviral therapy
Acute viral hepatitis A - Supportive care
Acute viral hepatitis C - Antiviral therapy
explanation: Antiviral therapy is not indicated in acute hepatitis B infection. It is only indicated in chronic hepatitis B. The majority of acute hepatitis (A, B, and E) infections are self-limiting, resulting in viral elimination and complete healing within 6 months. Hence, they need only supportive management. Only 5% of acute hepatitis infections become chronic. In acute hepatitis C infection, recovery is rare, and the risk of progression to chronic hepatitis is high(85%). Thus antiviral therapy is started irrespective of the disease stage.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is an indication for antiviral therapy in chronic hepatitis B infection?
options: HbeAg negative with HBV DNA <2000 IU/L
ALT > 2 times upper limit of normal
Normal Fibroscan report with ALT < 2 ULN
explanation: ALT > 2 times upper limit of normal is an indication for antiviral therapy in chronic hepatitis B infection. The decision to initiate antiviral therapy is primarily based on the presence or absence of cirrhosis, and parameters such as HBeAg, alanine aminotransferase (ALT) level, and HBV DNA level. The following are the indications for starting antivirals in chronic hepatitis B: Patients without cirrhosis HBeAg + with HBV DNA >20,000 IU/mL and ALT level >2 times the upper limit of normal HBeAg -ve with HBV DNA >2000 IU/mL and ALT level >2 times the upper limit of normal Patients with compensated cirrhosis and an HBV DNA >2000 IU/mL Patients developing acute liver failure or decompensated cirrhosis Recommended first-line antiviral drugs: Entecavir Tenofovir alafenamide Tenofovir disoproxil fumarate Pegylated interferon alfa can also be used. Treatment is aimed at HBeAg seroconversion, but most patients may need to continue antiviral therapy indefinitely.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 32-year-old man presented with complaints of fatigue for the past 1 month. His lab reports are given below. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
explanation: HBeAg negative and HBV DNA <2000 IU/mL is suggestive of HBV carrier. Serial monitoring of both biochemical and virological parameters is done for such patients. Indications for starting antiviral therapy in chronic hepatitis B are: Patients without cirrhosis HBeAg + with HBV DNA >20,000 IU/mL and ALT level >2 times the upper limit of normal HBeAg -ve with HBV DNA >2000 IU/mL and ALT level >2 times the upper limit of normal Patients with compensated cirrhosis and an HBV DNA >2000 IU/mL Patients developing acute liver failure or decompensated cirrhosis

question_text: Which of the following is recommended as first-line therapy in a patient with chronic hepatitis B?
explanation: First-line drugs used for the treatment of chronic hepatitis B include entecavir and tenofovir. Second-line drugs for this condition include: Lamivudine Adefovir Telbivudine Pegylated interferon can also be used in its treatment.

question_text: In which of the following populations should surveillance for hepatocellular carcinoma be done?
explanation: Surveillance for hepatocellular carcinoma is recommended for Asian male HBV carriers over the age of 40 years. The most common etiological factor for hepatocellular carcinoma in the world is the hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection. Surveillance programs have been implemented to screen for HCC in high-risk individuals because it is more cost-effective than the treatment of HCC. Surveillance for hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is recommended in: HBV carriers with cirrhosis Patients with high serum levels of HBV DNA and ongoing liver injury HBV carriers born in Africa and over the age of 20 Asian male HBV carriers over age 40 Asian female HBV carriers over age 50 HBV carriers with a family history of HCC Note: The CDC recently updated its guidelines for Hepatitis B screening. The report includes screening for all adults >18 years old using the triple-panel test (HBsAg, Anti-HBs, total anti-HBc) and expanded risk-based testing in certain high-risk populations.

question_text: A 35-year-old male comes to the OPD with intermittent jaundice for the past 2 months. ’ou suspect acute viral hepatitis. Which of the following will you not evaluate in this patient?
explanation: I M anti-HBe is not one of the markers that are evaluated in a suspected case of acute viral hepatitis. Investigations done in suspected acute viral hepatitis are: IgM anti-HAV - to detect acute hepatitis A infection which is the most common cause of acute hepatitis in children HBsAg and IgM anti-HBc - to detect acute hepatitis B infection, where HbsAg is the first marker to rise and IgM anti-HBcAg is the most reliable marker of acute infection Anti HCV - to evaluate for acute hepatitis C infection IgM anti-HEV (rarely)- to detect acute hepatitis E infection which is one of the causes of acute viral hepatitis in adults.

question_text:
A 40-year-old male chronic smoker presents to the AIIMS OPD with fever, fatigue, yellow-colored urine, and clay-colored stools. For the past few days, he has developed an aversion to cigarette smoking. On examination icterus was present. What investigations
would you advise to rule out acute viral hepatitis? Liver function test results are given below:
options: HBsAg, IgM antiHBc, AntiHDV, AntiHCV, Anti HEV
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of jaundice. The tests that should be done in this patient to rule out acute viral hepatitis include: Anti-HAV HBsA IgM anti-HBc Anti-HCV We mainly test for hepatitis A, B, and C. Tests for hepatitis D and E are not used routinely. Hepatitis D only occurs concurrently with Hepatitis B, either as a co-infection (when it is clinically indistinguishable from HBV infection) or superimposed on chronic HBV infection. In the latter scenario, it presents as a sudden worsening of the patient’s condition. IgM anti-HDV, IgG anti-HDV, and HDV RNA assays are useful for diagnosis when hepatitis D is suspected. Hepatitis E is not tested as the majority of patients who acquire hepatitis E virus (HEV) infection spontaneously clear the virus. Acute hepatic failure is more likely in those who are pregnant and in those who are malnourished or have preexisting liver disease. Chronic HEV has been described almost exclusively in immunocompromised hosts (e.g., organ transplantation). The diagnosis of acute HEV is typically based upon the detection of IgM antibodies to HEV. Both false positives and negatives are common with available assays and are thus, not very reliable. Thus, additional serologic testing or HEV RNA testing should be performed to confirm the diagnosis and not be useful as a screening test. question_text: Which of the following groups of individuals need not be screened for Hepatitis C infection?
options: Patients with unexplained elevation of aminotransferase levels
Patients who have undergone long-term haemodialysis
Household contacts of patients with hepatitis C
explanation: HCV screening is not indicated for household contacts of persons with hepatitis C. However, hepatitis B virus screening is recommended in household contacts of HBV-infected persons. Indications of HCV infection screening: Persons with a history of using injection drugs Persons with HIV infection Long term hemodialysis Persons with an unexplained elevation of aminotransferases Recipient of blood or organs from a donor found to be positive for hepatitis C Children born to women with Hepatitis C Health care, public safety, and emergency medical personnel following needle injury or mucosal exposure to HCV contaminated blood Sexual partners of persons with Hepatitis C

question_text: Which of the following is unlikely to be seen as an extrahepatic manifestation in patients with hepatitis C infection?
explanation: Polyarteritis nodosa is not characteristically associated with hepatitis C infection. However, it is a common extrahepatic manifestation of hepatitis B viral infection.
subject: Medicine

question_text:
A 35-year-old man who presented with weight loss and abdominal discomfort is diagnosed with chronic hepatitis C . All the following factors can determine the progression of liver
disease in this patient except:
explanation: While HCV RNA is considered the gold standard for establishing a diagnosis of hepatitis C, it has no role in determining the progression of liver disease in patients with chronic hepatitis C. The likelihood of progression of liver disease in patients with chronic hepatitis C is increased by: Longer duration of infection - most important determinant Older age Obesity - patients with a high body mass index are at an increased risk of developing fibrosis Diabetes mellitus and insulin resistance Concomitant liver disorder (eg., alcoholic liver disease, chronic hepatitis B, hemochromatosis) Concomitant HIV infection. The best prognostic indicator in chronic hepatitis C is the rate of fibrosis and baseline inflammation seen in liver histology.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 47-year-old man presented with generalized weakness, fatigue, and fever. His lab investigations are given below. What is the preferred treatment regimen for this patient?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hepatitis C for which the preferred treatment regimen is velpatasvir 100 mg and sofosbuvir 400 mg. The goal of treatment is a sustained virologic response (SVR), which is defined as the absence of a virus in the blood (undetectable HCV RNA), 12 weeks after completion of treatment. This can be achieved by the use of pan-genotypic directly acting antiviral drugs, irrespective of the disease stage.
subject: Medicine

question_text:
Which of the following is not a non-structural protein 5A inhibitor used in the treatment of patients with hepatitis C infection?
Sofosbuvir
explanation: Sofosbuvir is not an NS5A inhibitor but is an NS5B nucleoside/nucleotide polymerase inhibitor. The directly acting antivirals used in the treatment of Hepatitis C infection include: Autoimmune Disorders of Hepatobiliary System
subject: Medicine

question_text: Autoimmune hepatitis is suspected in a woman presenting with fatigue, pruritus, and arthralgia. She has a past history of Hashimoto's thyroiditis. Which of the following is not part of the simplified scoring system for the given condition?
explanation: Presence of viral markers is not a part of the simplified scoring system for diagnosis of autoimmune hepatitis. The simplified scoring system includes four variables. They are: Autoantibodies Elevated serum IgG level Typical compatible histologic features Absence of viral hepatitis markers The clinical presentation in autoimmune hepatitis is variable and shares features with acute and chronic hepatitis of other aetiologies. They usually present with an insidious onset of non-specific symptoms such as fatigue, anorexia and eventually jaundice. It can then progress to extensive liver necrosis and liver failure. Autoimmune hepatitis is associated with several autoimmune diseases such as: Rheumatoid arthritis Systemic lupus erythematosus Thyroiditis and Grave's disease Haemolytic anemia
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following drugs is associated with Autoimmune hepatitis (AIH)?
explanation: Minocycline is associated with the development of drug-induced AIH. Other drugs associated with AIH include nitrofurantoin, methyldopa, diclofenac, and possibly statins.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 20-year-old lady is suspected to have autoimmune hepatitis. Which of the following antibodies is unlikely to be present in her serum?
explanation: cANCA is not seen in autoimmune hepatitis. It is positive in Wegner's granulomatosis. pANCA is what is seen in autoimmune hepatitis. There are 2 types of autoimmune hepatitis: Type I (classic) autoimmune hepatitis is often seen in young women. It is linked to HLA-DR3 or HLA-DR4. It responds well to steroids and has a better prognosis. The autoantibodies that are seen in type I are: ANA - antinuclear antibodies ASMA - anti-smooth muscle actin pANCA - perinuclear anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic anti-SLA - anti-soluble liver antigen Type II autoimmune hepatitis is often seen in children. It is linked to HLA-DRB1 or HLA-DQB1. It usually leads to fibrosis, cirrhosis and liver failure. The autoantibodies that are seen in type II are: Anti-LKM 1 - anti-liver kidney microsomes Anti-liver cytosol 1
subject: Medicine

question_text: Match the following:
explanation: Anti LKM 1- Autoimmune hepatitis II Anti SLA - Autoimmune hepatitis I Anti LKM 2 - Drug-induced hepatitis Anti LKM 3 - Chronic hepatitis D
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 24-year-old woman presenting with abdominal pain is diagnosed with autoimmune hepatitis. The mainstay of management in this patient is:
explanation: The mainstay of management in autoimmune hepatitis is glucocorticoid therapy. Glucocorticoids are started at high doses and tapered down to a low maintenance dose. The dose of glucocorticoids is often reduced by combining with azathioprine. The benefits of glucocorticoid + azathioprine combination therapy are: Reduction in the duration of therapy. Avoid life-threatening complications of steroids (e.g., cushingoid features, hypertension, diabetes, osteoporosis).
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 23-year-old female patient with a diagnosis of autoimmune hepatitis did not respond well to glucocorticoids. Which among the following is false regarding her further management options?
explanation: Liver transplant is not contraindicated in refractory autoimmune hepatitis even though the risk of recurrence is high. The medical management of refractory autoimmune hepatitis include: High dose glucocorticoids Glucocorticoids + high dose azathioprine Addition of cyclosporine, tacrolimus, or mycophenolate mofetil.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A young lady has been on treatment for autoimmune hepatitis for 2 weeks, she has now come for follow-up investigations. Which of the following suggests a poor prognosis in this patient?
explanation: Persistently increased serum bilirubin after 2 weeks of therapy suggests a poor prognosis. Early signs of poor prognosis include: Failure of serum bilirubin to reduce after 2 weeks of therapy. Early signs of good prognosis include: An increase in serum albumin. A decrease in serum bilirubin, globulins and aminotransferases. Improvement of symptoms. Histopathologic improvement can often take months to years.
subject: Medicine

question_text: The most common symptom of primary biliary cholangitis (PBC) is
explanation: The most common symptom of primary biliary cholangitis(PBC) is fatigue. Primary biliary cholangitis(PBC) is a granulomatous autoimmune condition characterized by the destruction of interlobular hepatic bile ducts. Most patients with PBC are asymptomatic at the time of the diagnosis. Fatigue and pruritus are both common presenting symptoms. However, the most common symptom is fatigue. Other symptoms and signs are - Right upper quadrant pain Hyperpigmentation Xanthomas and xanthelasma Jaundice Hepatosplenomegaly.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 44-year-old woman with rheumatoid arthritis is now diagnosed with primary biliary cholangitis. Which of the following is false regarding her lab values?
explanation: Anti-LKM 2 antibodies are not seen in primary biliary cholangitis. They are seen in drug-induced hepatitis. The laboratory findings of primary biliary cholangitis include : Liver function tests Elevated ALP Elevated GGT and 5'- nucleotidase Elevated ALT and AST Serology - Antimitochondrial antibodies - positive in ˜5% of patients. These are mostly directed against the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex. Antinuclear antibodies Elevated HDL, LDL, and ™LDL Elevated serum IgM Hyperbilirubinemia is seen once cirrhosis has developed.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A patient with a diagnosis of primary biliary cholangitis has been taking ursodeoxycholic acid (UDCA) twice daily. She now presents with ascites and variceal bleeding. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
options: Add obeticholic acid to the treatment
explanation: The presence of ascites and variceal bleeding suggest decompensated liver disease and the appropriate treatment is liver transplantation. The first-line drug in primary biliary cholangitis is ursodeoxycholic acid (UDCA). It only slows the rate of progression of the disease. It does not provide any symptomatic benefit or cure the disease. Obeticholic acid is another drug used in PBC as monotherapy or in combination with UDCA. It is a farnesoid X receptor agonist. Liver transplantation is considered when there are signs of decompensation or portal hypertension such as ascites, variceal bleeding, encephalopathy, coagulopathy, or malnutrition.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A middle-aged woman presented with fatigue, pruritis, and xanthomas over the elbows. A biopsy of her bile duct revealed florid duct lesions. What is the diagnosis?
explanation: Florid duct lesion is characteristic of primary biliary cholangitis (PBC). It is the lymphocytes and plasma cells all centered around bile ducts. Primary sclerosing cholangitis has the characteristic "onion-skin" concentric fibrosis surrounding the bile ducts.
subject: Medicine

question_text:
Which of the following statements about primary sclerosing cholangitis is false?
Affects both intra and extrahepatic bile ducts
options: Liver biopsy definitively establishes the diagnosis
explanation: Liver biopsy does not establish the diagnosis in primary sclerosing cholangitis. The diagnosis requires imaging with MRCP. Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) is a chronic progressive disorder characterized by inflammation and fibrosis of intra and extrahepatic biliary ducts resulting in strictures and cholestasis. The cause is unknown. Most patients have underlying ulcerative colitis. It has an association with HLA DRw52. Patients present with symptoms of cholestasis such as fatigue and pruritus. The laboratory findings include: Liver function tests - Elevated ALP and aminotransferases. Increased serum IgM levels Positive p-ANCA MRCP is the investigation of choice. It shows multiple strictures in intra and extrahepatic bile ducts. Liver biopsy reveals a concentric "onion skin" fibrosis. This is however not pathognomic of PSC. There is no definitive treatment. It involves the administration of UDCA and liver transplantation. PSC can lead to the development of cholangiocarcinoma The image below shows onion-skin fibrosis in PSC. Acute Liver Failure and Liver Transplantation
subject: Medicine

question_text: In acute liver failure, encephalopathy occurs within of the development of clinical symptoms.
explanation: In acute liver failure, encephalopathy occurs within 4 weeks of the development of the clinical symptoms. Acute liver failure is the rapid worsening of the liver function in patients without cirrhosis or any preexisting liver disease. The patient initially suffers from an acute injury to the liver by viruses, drugs, etc. Following this, the function of the liver rapidly worsens and patient develops coagulopathy and encephalopathy within 4 weeks of the development of jaundice or other clinical symptoms.
subject: Medicine

question_text: What is the most common cause of acute liver failure in India?
explanation: The most common cause of acute liver failure (ALF) in India is a viral infection. Among the viruses, hepatitis E virus is the most common cause of acute liver failure. In developed countries, acetaminophen overdose is the most common cause of acute liver failure.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A small child was rushed to the ED by his parents. He had accidentally consumed wild mushrooms while they were trekking. Examination showed features of encephalopathy and his liver function tests were deranged. Which of the following is least likely to be seen in this condition?
explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of Amanita phalloides (wild mushrooms) toxicity causing acute liver failure. Hypoglycemia is seen in acute liver failure and not hyperglycemia. It occurs due to impaired gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis. Features of acute hepatic failure are: Hepatic encephalopathy and cerebral edema- There are increased levels of ammonia (neurotoxin) in the body as a result of decreased elimination by the liver. Coagulopathy- There is a decrease in the synthesis of coagulation factors leading to the elevated prothrombin time and INR. Increased risk of infections- It occurs as a result of decreased reticuloendothelial activity, decreased synthesis of complements, acute phase reactants, etc. Renal failure- This is more commonly seen in drug/toxin-induced hepatic failure. Metabolic complications like hypoglycemia, hyponatremia, hypokalemia, hypophosphatemia, hypomagnesemia.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A patient is said to have hyperacute liver failure if encephalopathy occurs within?
explanation: Hyperacute liver failure is defined as the development of encephalopathy within 7 days of the appearance of symptoms. Acute liver failure can be subcategorized into three groups depending on the time interval between the onset of jaundice and encephalopathy. Hyperacute- encephalopathy develops within 7 days or less than 7 days Acute- encephalopathy develops between 8-28 days Subacute- encephalopathy develops between 28 days to 6 months Patients with hyperacute liver failure are more likely to develop coagulopathy and cerebral edema, but most of the patients will recover without the need for liver transplantation. On the other end, patients with subacute liver failure have less severe coagulopathy and cerebral edema, but most of them will need liver transplantation.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A young patient with Hepatitis E virus infection develops acute liver failure. Which of the following scores can be used in assessing the prognosis of this patient?
explanation: In a patient with acute liver failure, MELD score and King's College Hospital criteria can be used to assess the prognosis. Option A: Pitt score is used used to predict mortality in patients having bloodstream infections. Option B: The child-Pugh score is used to assess the severity of cirrhosis. Option D: Maddrey's Discriminant Function (MDF) score suggests which patients with alcoholic hepatitis may have a poor prognosis and benefit from steroid administration.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A young patient is admitted to the hospital after ingestion of a large number of acetaminophen tablets. To predict the prognosis using King's College hospital criteria in this patient, which of the parameters are not used?
explanation: Serum bilirubin is not included in King's College Hospital criteria in acute liver failure due to paracetamol overdose. The King's College Hospital Criteria is a prognostic tool for patients with acute liver failure (ALF). The criteria is divided into acetaminophen and non-acetaminophen causes of liver failure. Liver transplantation is indicated in acetaminophen-induced ALF if there is a presence of Either pH <7.3 Or all of the following Prothrombin time >100 sec or INR >6.5 Serum creatinine level >3.4 mg/dL (300 mol/L) or anuria Grade 3-4 encephalopathy Liver transplantation is indicated in non-acetaminophen causes of ALF if there is a presence of Either prothrombin time >100 sec or INR >6.7 Or any three of the following Unfavorable etiology (seronegative hepatitis or drug reaction) Age <10 or >40 yr Acute or subacute category (duration of jaundice >7 days) Serum bilirubin level >17.5 mg/dL (300 mol/L) Prothrombin time >50 sec or INR >3.5
subject: Medicine

question_text: For patients with acute liver failure, which of the following is not an absolute contraindication for liver transplantation?
explanation: Portal vein thrombosis is not an absolute contraindication to liver transplantation. This is because portal vein thrombosis can be overcome by constructing a graft from the donor liver portal vein to the recipient’s superior mesenteric vein. Absolute contraindications of liver transplantation are: Uncontrolled extra-hepatobiliary infection or untreated sepsis Uncorrectable life-limiting congenital anomalies Active substance or alcohol abuse Malignancies- Hepatocellular carcinoma with metastatic spread, incurable malignancies outside the liver, cholangiocarcinoma AIDS Advanced cardiopulmonary disease Note: Milan criteria- Patients with primary hepatocellular malignancy can be considered for liver transplantation if there is: A single lesion 5 cm. Up to three separate lesions all <3 cm without any evidence of gross vascular invasion, nodal or distant metastases.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which among the following is the most common indication of liver transplantation in children?
explanation: Biliary atresia is the most common indication of liver transplantation in children. Indications of liver transplant in children: Biliary atresia Neonatal hepatitis Congenital hepatic fibrosis Alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency Wilsons disease Glycogen storage disorders Lysosomal storage disorders The most common indication of liver transplant in an adult is the cirrhotic liver. Cirrhosis may be the consequence of viral hepatitis, autoimmune hepatitis, chronic use of alcohol, or biliary cirrhosis.
subject: Medicine

question_text: When should a liver transplant assessment be considered in a patient with cirrhosis of the liver?
options: When he develops spontaneous bacterial peritonitis
When he has ascites which responds to diuretics
explanation: Liver transplant assessment should be considered in a patient with cirrhosis of the liver when he develops spontaneous bacterial peritonitis. Cirrhosis is the most common indication of liver transplantation in adults. However, not all cases of cirrhosis require liver transplantation. It is considered When the patient either develops the complication of cirrhosis like: Persistent hepatic encephalopathy Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis Portal hypertensive bleeding Diuretic resistant ascites Hepatorenal syndrome Or has a poor liver function MELD score > 12 Child-Pugh grade C
subject: Medicine

question_text: A surgeon has removed a part of the liver from the live donor and has stored it in the University of Wisconsin (UW) solution. Which of the following is not a component of this solution?
explanation: Mannitol is not a component of the University of Wisconsin (UW) solution. It is the most commonly used preservation solution during the transplantation of the liver and kidneys. The organ can be stored in this solution for up to 20 hours. Components of UW solution are: Lactobionate- Prevents cellular swelling and reperfusion injury Raffinose and hydroxyethyl starch- Prevents endothelial injury Glutathione and allopurinol- free radical scavengers Adenosine- required for regeneration of ATP
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is a false statement regarding liver transplantation (LT)?
options: The ideal graft weight to recipient weight ratio (GRWR) in living donor transplant is >0.8 %.
In domino LT, liver grafts with metabolic diseases is used as they are structurally and functionally normal.
Extended criteria donors and paired-exchange < decrease waitlist mortality.
Reduced size < involves dividing the whole liver into right lobe for an adult patient and left lateral segments for pediatric patients.
explanation: The false statement regarding liver transplantation is option D. Reduced-size liver transplantation involves the resection of a full-size liver to appropriately fit in the abdominal cavity of small adults/adolescents. It is reserved only for urgent transplantation. On the contrary, split < involves dividing the whole donor liver into a left lateral segment (segments II and III) for a pediatric patient and a right lobe (segments I, IV-VIII) for an adult patient. Option A: The required graft volume in a living donor transplant is measured by graft weight to recipient weight ratio (GRWR) or ratio of graft volume (GV) to recipient standard liver volume (SLV). The ideal GRWR is >0.8 % or GV/SLV is > 35%. The remnant donor liver mass is kept at >30% for safe regeneration. Option B: Domino liver transplant involves transplanting a liver from a donor with metabolic disease (eg: familial amyloid polyneuropathy) to a recipient with end-stage liver disease (eg: hepatocellular carcinoma). The donor also receives an < (healthy donor) and is prioritized over the end-stage liver disease recipient. As a liver with metabolic diseases is structurally and functionally normal, it can prolong the recipient’s life by at least 15-20 years as they will not develop the metabolic disease immediately. Option C: Extended criteria donors/ECDs (liver grafts extracted from donors after circulatory death) and paired-exchange technique are used to decrease waitlist mortality. However, ECDs have poor graft function due to prolonged hypoxia and are associated with higher infection transmission and biliary complications.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Auxiliary liver transplantation is beneficial in which of the following conditions:
explanation: Auxiliary liver transplantation is beneficial in acute liver failure. Auxiliary liver transplantation involves implanting a healthy liver graft heterotopically or orthotopically while leaving the whole or part of the native liver intact. The auxiliary partial orthotopic < (APOLT) technique is used in patients with acute liver failure and metabolic diseases (primary hypercholesterolemia, glycogen storage disorders, organic acidemia, etc). In acute liver failure, this technique helps in native liver regeneration and immunosuppression withdrawal. In children with metabolic liver diseases, this technique helps in future gene therapy. Options B, C, and D are chronic liver diseases not suitable for auxiliary liver transplantation.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following sentences is true regarding split liver transplantation?
options: It is done in living donor
Left lateral lobe is donated to the paediatric recipient
It is the most common type of liver transplant
Caudate lobe is donated to the adult recipient
explanation: In a split liver transplant, the left lateral lobe is donated to the pediatric recipient. Split liver donation: This method is done when the liver from the deceased donor is suitable for transplant in an adult as well as a pediatric recipient. The liver is split into two. The left lateral segment (2 and 3) is donated to the pediatric recipient, left medial and right segments (4, 5, 6, 7, and 8) is donated to the adult recipient.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A patient who underwent liver transplantation is started on tacrolimus for immunosuppression. His family physician prescribed him fluconazole for the treatment of a fungal infection. This will lead to
options: No effect on both the drugs
explanation: In a patient who is on tacrolimus, the addition of fluconazole may lead to toxicity of the tacrolimus. Tacrolimus and cyclosporine are calcineurin inhibitors and are the common agents used for the immunosuppression following liver transplantation. They are metabolized by the CYP3A enzyme. Fluconazole can inhibit this enzyme and lead to increased levels of tacrolimus and cyclosporine.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A patient presented with fever and pain abdomen. He had undergone liver transplantation a month ago and is taking immunosuppressants. On examination, abdominal guarding was present and on auscultation, no bowel sounds were heard. Doppler showed hepatic artery thrombosis. Which of the following medications is he most likely on?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of peritonitis due to hepatic artery thrombosis. Sirolimus is known to cause hepatic artery thrombosis in liver transplant recipients. Sirolimus is an mTOR inhibitor and prevents T cell activation. It is not used commonly in liver transplant recipients because of the increased frequency of hepatic artery thrombosis in the first month posttransplantation. However, they can be used in patients with calcineurin inhibitor-related nephrotoxicity.
subject: Medicine

question_text: All of the following complications can be seen in patients with liver transplantation except
explanation: Patients with liver transplantation are more likely to develop B cell lymphomas and not T cell lymphoma. Complications of liver transplantation Rejection of the transplanted liver Hepatic artery thrombosis Posttransplantation lymphoproliferative disorders- It can range from a mild polyclonal proliferation of B cells to B cell lymphomas. Congestive heart failure and arrhythmias Increased susceptibility to infections as a result of immunosuppression Renal dysfunction due to acute tubular necrosis or nephrotoxicity of the tacrolimus and cyclosporine Seizures are commonly associated with cyclosporine or tacrolimus toxicity.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A liver biopsy is performed in a patient who is suspected to have acute rejection following liver transplantation. Which of the following findings in the biopsy will confirm the presence of acute rejection?
explanation: The presence of endotheliitis confirms the presence of acute rejection of the liver transplant. Rejection following liver transplantation can be acute or chronic. Patients usually present with Malaise Fever Right upper quadrant pain Laboratory investigations will show Elevated levels of serum bilirubin Aminotransferases Gamma-glutamyl transpeptidases Liver biopsy- for confirming the diagnosis and planning the treatment Liver biopsy of the acute rejection is characterized by the presence of mixed portal cellular infiltrate, bile duct injury, and endothelial inflammation (endotheliitis). Chronic rejection is characterized by the presence of focal parenchymal necrosis, mononuclear cell infiltration, progressive cholestasis, and fibrosis. In some patients, this process will lead to the loss of intrahepatic bile ducts, which is called vanishing bile duct syndrome.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 40-year-old male patient developed fever, malaise, and anorexia after a month of liver transplantation. On evaluation, he has leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, and deranged liver function tests. Which of the following organisms is most likely to have caused this?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of post-solid transplant infection most likely due to cytomegalovirus(CMV). It is the most common cause of post-solid organ transplants in India. Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), herpes, and varicella are also known to cause infection post-solid organ transplantation but to a lesser extent. CMV disease in recipients can present with fever, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, malaise, and arthralgia. They usually present within 1-4 months after transplant. The diagnosis of CMV infection is established by nucleic acid testing (NAT) using the polymerase chain reaction (PCR). Management includes the use of anti-viral drugs like ganciclovir, valganciclovir, foscarnet, cidofovir and intravenous immunoglobulins.
subject: Medicine

question_text:
Which of the following primary diseases has the higher chance of recurrence, after liver transplantation?
Sclerosing cholangitis
explanation: Among the given options, autoimmune hepatitis has the highest chance of recurrence after liver transplantation. Although some cases of sclerosing cholangitis and primary biliary cirrhosis recur, data for recurrence of autoimmune hepatitis is more supportive. Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency does not recur after liver transplantation. Hemochromatosis and Wilson's disease

question_text: What is the most common gene mutation associated with hemochromatosis?
explanation: The most common mutation seen in hemochromatosis is a cysteine to tyrosine substitution at position 282 (C282Y) in the HFE gene. HFE mutations are the most common cause of hereditary hemochromatosis and are inherited as an autosomal recessive trait.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Patients with which of the following conditions are unlikely to develop iron overload?
explanation: Thalassemia minor does not result in iron overload. Secondary hemochromatosis or iron overload is characterized by the deposition of iron in parenchymal cells.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following clinical manifestations of hemochromatosis is incorrectly matched with its mechanism of onset?
explanation: Sexual dysfunction (decreased libido, impotence, amenorrhea) in hemochromatosis occurs as a result of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. This is due to iron deposition in the pituitary gland, not testes. Iron deposition occurs in the following sites: Organ Manifestation Liver Hepatomegaly Skin Slate-grey or bronze skin hyp erpigmentation:increased me lanin synthesisdue to iron de position Pancre as pancreatic diabetes/type 3C d iabetes Pituita ry Hypogonadotropic hypogona dismSecondary hypothyroidi sm Heart Dilated cardiomyopathyCong estive heart failureArrhythmi as Joints Arthropathy is due to:Iron de positionCalcium pyrophosph ate deposition (pseudogout)

question_text: A 7-year-old boy undergoes genetic testing as his brother has been diagnosed with hereditary hemochromatosis. He is found to be homozygous for the C282Y mutation. Which of the following is the strongest indicator that he will develop symptoms of the disease?
explanation: Serum ferritin > 1000 g/L is the strongest predictor of disease expression among individuals homozygous for the C282Y mutation. Many patients with C282Y mutations are initially asymptomatic and do not show features of iron overload. In such patients, serum ferritin can indicate whether they are likely to develop the disease as ferritin levels reflect the total iron stores. As ferritin levels may be high following inflammatory conditions, combined measurement of ferritin and transferrin saturation is done in a practical setting to avoid false positives. It is also repeated once inflammation subsides. If these tests are abnormal, genetic testing for HFE mutations is done.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 47-year-old diabetic man is worried as the skin over his face, neck, and dorsum of hands has turned greyish over the past two months. He also complains of abdominal and joint pain. On examination, gynecomastia and hepatomegaly are noted. What is the treatment of choice for this condition?
explanation: This clinical scenario is suggestive of hemochromatosis. The treatment of choice is the removal of excess iron by phlebotomy. Phlebotomy is an inexpensive, convenient, and safe method of treatment. In this process, 500 mL of blood is removed 1-2 times weekly which removes 200-250 mg of iron. Weekly phlebotomy should be continued until the serum ferritin level is 100 g/L and every 3 months thereafter. It is contraindicated in severe anemia and hypoproteinemia. Chelating agents bind to iron to form complexes that get excreted and are the drugs of choice. Drugs such as deferoxamine and deferasirox are commonly used. However, they are less effective and more expensive than phlebotomy. Liver transplantation is indicated either in end-stage liver disease or in refractory cases. Supportive management includes avoiding iron-containing substances such as red meat, multi-vitamin tablets, etc. Alcohol should be completely avoided as it can aggravate the disease.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 30-year-old man with hereditary hemochromatosis has been started on weekly phlebotomy. All of the following features will improve with this treatment except:
explanation: In hemochromatosis, removal of excess iron through phlebotomy has no effect on arthropathy and hypogonadism.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is incorrect about Wilson's disease?
options: AP1S1 gene is essential for normal functioning
Siblings of affected children have 1 in 4 risk of the disease
explanation: Wilson’s disease is caused due to a loss-of-function mutation in the ATP7B gene on Chr.13q. The gene encodes a copper transporting ATPase (ATP7B) which has 2 functions: Maintains copper in bound form by binding copper to apoceruloplasmin Helps excrete free copper in bile. Thus, an ATP7B deficiency leads to excess deposition of free copper within tissues. It is an autosomal recessive condition. So, siblings of affected children have a 1 in 4 chance. Intracellular trafficking of ATP7B (Wilson's disease) and ATP7A (Menke's disease) genes are regulated by an adaptor protein encoded by the AP1S1 gene. Mutations in this gene result in a syndrome with features of both Wilson's and Menke's diseases. It is called MEDNIK syndrome: Mental retardation Enteropathy Deafness Neuropathy Ichthyosis Keratodermia.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following are true regarding KF ring?
explanation: Among the given options only statements 1 and 5 are true. Kayser-Fleischer (KF) rings are seen in almost all patients of Wilson's disease with neurological involvement. It initially appears as a crescent in the superior pole of Descemet's membrane and gradually extends inferiorly, eventually becoming circumferential in shape. KF rings occur due to copper deposition in the descemet's membrane. It is golden-brown to greenish-brown in color and can be best seen by slit-lamp examination. The image below shows a KF ring : While it is a characteristic sign of Wilson’s disease (statement 2), it can also be seen in: Primary biliary cholangitis Primary sclerosing cholangitis Cholestasis KF rings are present in almost 95% of patients of Wilson's disease with neurological/psychiatric symptoms compared to around 65% of those with hepatic presentations (statement 4). They disappear on treatment with copper-chelating agents like d-penicillamine (while desferrioxamine is an iron chelating agent) and reappear with disease progression (statement 3).
subject: Medicine

question_text: In patients with Wilson's disease, Kayser-Fleischer rings are most commonly associated with:
explanation: The presence of the Kayser-Fleischer (KF) ring in Wilson's disease is most commonly associated with neuropsychiatric manifestations such as dystonia. In majority of the cases, neuropsychiatric manifestations follow hepatic manifestations. It is due to the deposition of free copper in the basal ganglia (leading to bilateral degeneration and atrophy) and cortex. The features include: Dysarthria (most common): Irregular word spacing, hypophonic or spastic speech Dystonia: Vacuous smile i.e mask-like face with an open mouth Parkinsonism: Bradykinesia, postural instability, rigidity Subcortical dementia: Slow mental processing, memory loss Psychiatric symptoms: Loss of emotional control, depression, hyperactivity Decreased scholastic performance: Deterioration in handwriting, clumsiness Autonomic symptoms: Excessive sweating and salivation, sexual dysfunction Wing beating tremors (seen in advanced disease): High amplitude tremor that is prominent with arms abducted, elbows flexed and palms facing downward.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 22-year-old woman is being evaluated in the emergency department for a 3-day history of dark-colored urine and abdominal distension. On examination, she is conscious and oriented. Icterus is present. The following investigations are done. Which of the following would you suspect?
explanation: The given laboratory values indicate hepatic disease and hemolytic anemia (low Hb with high reticulocyte count). These lab findings along with clinical features point to a diagnosis of Wilson's disease. The clinical features of Wilson’s disease include: Option A: Hemochromatosis presents with clinical features of iron overload. Serum ferritin and total iron are elevated. Option B: Acute viral hepatitis presents with positive HbsAg, whereas anti-Hbs IgG indicates past infection. There is tender hepatomegaly with very high levels of transaminases (>1000 IU/L). Option C: Primary biliary cirrhosis presents with jaundice, severe itching, and pale stools. There are high levels of direct bilirubin, ALP, and positive anti-mitochondrial antibodies. question_text: A child presents with hepatitis and progressive neurological degeneration. A picture of his eye has been provided below. Among the following options, what would be the initial step regarding the investigations done for this child's diagnosis?
explanation: The clinical features of hepatitis, progressive neurological degeneration, and the Kayser-Fleischer (KF) ring seen in the image are suggestive of Wilson's disease. The initial step regarding investigations done for the diagnosis is the measurement of serum ceruloplasmin levels. Kayser-Fleischer (KF) ring is a golden to greenish-brown ring of deposition of copper in the Descemets membrane of the peripheral cornea. Patients with neurological manifestations manifest with KF ring in >95% of cases. Lab investigations in Wilson's disease would show: The gold standard technique for diagnosis of Wilson’s disease is percutaneous needle liver biopsy for measurement of hepatic copper levels >200 g/g of dry weight. Lab markers Change in Wilson's diseas e Reason Serum ceruloplas min  ATP7B deficiency results in r educed bound copper 24h urinary coppe r  (>100 g/24h) Excess free copper excreted i n urine Total serum coppe r  Due to marked reduction in c eruloplasmin Option B: The role of total serum copper in the diagnosis of Wilson's disease is limited. Measurement of serum ceruloplasmin and urinary copper is preferred. Option C: ATP7B enzyme assays have shown promise in early studies as a neonatal screening test for Wilson's disease. However, it is not yet part of routine clinical practice. Option D: Karyotyping is done for every asymptomatic 1st and 2nd degree relative of a patient with Wilson’s disease. This helps differentiate the carriers (heterozygous) from the patients (homozygous) and can lead to early initiation of treatment before the onset of symptoms.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following findings would be seen in a patient with Wilson's disease?
explanation: The following findings will be seen in a patient with Wilson's disease: Decreased total serum copper Decreased serum ceruloplasmin Increased urinary copper Normally, >90% of copper exists in bound form and <10% in free form. In Wilson’s disease, despite elevated levels of free copper, the marked reduction in ceruloplasmin results in a net reduction of total serum copper i.e., total serum copper =free copper + ceruloplasmin Lab markers Change in Wilson's diseas e Reason Serum ceruloplas min  ATP7B deficiency results in r educed bound copper 24h urinary coppe r  Excess free copper excreted i n urine Lab markers Change in Wilson's diseas e Reason Total serum coppe r  Due to marked reduction in c eruloplasmin
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 15-year-old boy is brought with complaints of abnormal posture. His scholastic performance used to be above average but has deteriorated over the last 3 months. Dystonia and increased muscle tone are noted on clinical examination. The following picture is seen on ophthalmic examination. What is the gold standard for the diagnosis of this condition?
explanation: This clinical scenario and image showing Kayser-Fleischer (KF) ring with sunflower cataract are suggestive of Wilson's disease. The gold standard for diagnosis is the estimation of liver copper following biopsy. A copper level of >200 g/g dry liver tissue is diagnostic for Wilson's disease. It is measured using neutron activation analysis or atomic absorption spectrometry. Sunflower cataract is a rare finding of Wilson’s disease. It occurs due to the deposition of copper in the center of the lens.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A pathologist is preparing a tissue sample from the liver biopsy of a patient with Wilson's disease. What stain will he use?
explanation: In Wilson’s disease, liver biopsy samples are stained using rubeanic acid to visualize the cytoplasmic copper. Another stain used for copper is the rhodanine stain. However, copper staining is not reliable for diagnosis and a quantitative copper assay must be performed. The given image shows the staining of copper by rubeanic acid.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 17-year-old girl was brought with involuntary, writhing movements of her limbs. On examination, she is anicteric with dystonia and hyperreflexia. Investigations revealed mildly elevated transaminases and low serum ceruloplasmin levels. Which of the following is the safest drug that can be initiated for this patient?
explanation: This clinical scenario is suggestive of Wilson's disease with predominantly neurological features. The safest drug that can be initiated for this patient is trientine. This is because D-penicillamine can worsen neurological symptoms and would not be tolerated by this patient. The copper chelating agents, D-penicillamine and trientine are the first-line drugs in the management of Wilson's disease. D-penicillamine is the recommended drug due to its availability and cost-effectiveness compared to trientine. However, D-penicillamine can precipitate various adverse effects including aplastic anemia, myasthenia gravis and membranous nephropathy. It can also worsen neurological symptoms. Hence, trientine is administered in those who cannot tolerate D-penicillamine. Elemental zinc is commonly used as a maintenance therapy along with chelating agents. It can also be used as first-line therapy in pregnancy. Tetrathiomolybdate is currently under phase 2 clinical trials. It has been identified to be effective in patients with neuropsychiatric manifestations but is not approved for clinical use. Liver transplantation is the definitive treatment for advanced liver disease.
subject: Medicine

question_text: For a patient with Wilson's disease, you would administer pyridoxine along with which of the following drugs?
explanation: Penicillamine should always be co-administered with pyridoxine (25 mg/day) as it is an antagonist to pyridoxine.
subject: Medicine

question_text: The Nazer’s prognostic index for Wilson’s disease includes all of the following parameters except:
explanation: ALT is not a part of Nazer’s prognostic index. Nazer’s prognostic index is used to establish disease severity in Wilson’s disease patients who present with hepatic decompensation.
subject: Medicine

question_text:
Low serum copper levels attributed to ATP7A gene is due to:
Dubin-Johnson syndrome
explanation: Low serum copper level attributed to the ATP7A gene is due to Menke's disease (Option C). Menke's disease or Menke-Kinky hair syndrome is an X-linked recessive condition occurring due to a mutation in the ATP7A gene on chromosome X. This causes impaired transport of dietary copper from the small intestine to the liver leading to low levels of copper-containing enzymes. It presents within 3 years of age and is characterized by: Depigmented kinky hair Failure to thrive Neurodegenerative symptoms like loss of developmental milestones, truncal hypotonia, epilepsyLoose, wrinkled skin Multiple fractures Poor visual acuity Recurrent infections. Lab investigations show low serum copper (<65 g/dL) and low ceruloplasmin(<20 mg/dl). The disease is fatal as it has no curative treatment. But, administration of L-histidine and copper chloride injections may be beneficial, if started early. Aceruloplasminemia is an autosomal recessive disease characterized by tissue iron overload, mental deterioration, microcytic anemia, and low serum iron and copper concentrations. Option B: Low serum copper and low ceruloplasmin is also seen in Wilson’s disease, but is associated with the gene defect ATP7B on chromosome 13. It is an autosomal recessive disorder of copper metabolism with features of hepatolenticular degeneration and Kayser Fleischer ring. Option A: Dubin Johnson Syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by impaired canalicular excretion of bilirubin due to mutation in MRP-2 protein leading to conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Option D: Gilbert’s Syndrome is characterized by decreased UDP glucuronyl transferase activity leading to unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, which can be autosomal recessive or dominant. Cirrhosis and Complications
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following conditions is unlikely to lead to cirrhosis in a patient?
explanation: Hepatitis A infection is an acute self-limiting condition that does not lead to cirrhosis. Cirrhosis is a late stage of chronic liver disease pathologically characterized by hepatic fibrosis, distortion of hepatic architecture, and formation of regenerative nodules. The causes of cirrhosis are: Chronic viral hepatitis - Hepatitis B and C Alcoholic liver disease Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease Autoimmune hepatitis Biliary cirrhosis - Primary biliary cholangitis Primary sclerosing cholangitis Cardiac cirrhosis Inherited metabolic liver diseases - Cystic fibrosis Hemochromatosis Wilson's disease 1 Antitrypsin deficiency Cryptogenic cirrhosis Drugs - methotrexate, isoniazid
