question_text: While examining a chronic alcoholic patient, you notice the given finding. Which of the following is false regarding it?
options: Occurs due to alterations in the metabolism of estrogen
Presence of even 1 lesion is abnorma
Commonly seen over the superior vena cava territory
Compression results in blanching followed by reappearance after release
explanation: The given image shows spider telangiectasia and the presence of >2 to 3 of these are considered abnormal. Spider telangiectasias are dilated arterioles with a prominent central arteriole with radiating vessels appearing in the shape of a spider. They are generally seen in the superior vena cava territory. Compression results in blanching followed by reappearance after the release of pressure. They occur due to a hyperestrogenic state which is caused by defective estrogen metabolism in liver cirrhosis. Clinical features seen in cirrhosis include: Spider telangiectasias Palmar erythema Terry's nails - pallor of the proximal nail bed Clubbing Gynaecomastia Caput medusae - dilated abdominal veins. Parotid enlargement The image below shows Terry's nails.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Clinically significant portal hypertension is defined as a hepatic venous pressure gradient greater than mm Hg.
explanation: Clinically-significant portal hypertension is defined as hepatic venous pressure gradient (HVPG) 10 mm Hg. HVPG is the difference between the wedged hepatic venous pressure (WHVP) and the free hepatic venous pressure (FHVP). It represents the pressure difference between the portal vein and IVC. Interpretation of HVPG values: HVPG v alue Interpretation 1-5 mm Hg Normal >5 mm Hg Portal hypertension 10 mm Hg Clinically significant portal h ypertension, varices can deve lop 12 mm Hg Risk of variceal bleeding and ascites
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is a posthepatic cause of portal hypertension?
explanation: Budd-Chiari syndrome is a posthepatic cause of portal hypertension. Budd Chiari syndrome is a congestive hepatopathy characterized by the obstruction of hepatic venous outflow. The most common cause is due to hepatic vein thrombosis. Obstruction of two or more major hepatic veins causes Budd-Chiari syndrome. It is characterized by hepatomegaly, ascites, and abdominal pain.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following drugs is used to reduce the intrahepatic resistance in portal hypertension?
explanation: Carvedilol is used to reduce the intrahepatic resistance in portal hypertension. The pharmacologic management of portal hypertension includes: Drugs that reduce the portal blood flow Non-selective  blockers - Propranolol and nadolol are preferred Somatostatin and its analogs - Octreotide, lanreotide, and vapreotide Vasopressin and analogs - Terlipressin Drugs that decrease the intrahepatic resistance Carvedilol - due to its  blockade property
subject: Medicine

question_text: Ascitic tap done on a patient with abdominal distention revealed a SAAG of 1.4g/dL. What is the likely cause of his ascites?
explanation: The serum ascites albumin gradient of 1.1g/dL is suggestive of portal hypertension. SAAG helps distinguish ascites caused by portal hypertension from other causes of ascites.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A patient presented with massive abdominal swelling. Paracentesis fluid was sent for lab analysis and results show serum protein to be 3g/dL and ascitic fluid protein to be 1g/dL. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The likely diagnosis in the given clinical scenario with serum-ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) >1.1g/dL [calculated as serum albumin level - ascitic fluid albumin level, which in this case is 3-1=2g/dL] and ascitic fluid protein <2.5 g/dL is late Budd Chiari syndrome. Serum-ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) can be used to differentiate between ascites due to portal hypertension and non-portal hypertensive ascites. It represents the pressure within the hepatic sinusoids and correlates with the hepatic venous pressure gradient. It is given by the formula: SAAG = Serum albumin level - Ascitic fluid albumin level Interpretation of SAAG: SAAG 1.1 g/dL indicates that the ascites is due to increased pressure in the hepatic sinusoids. It reflects the presence of portal hypertension. SAAG <1.1 g/dL indicates that the ascites is not related to portal hypertension. It may be due to infection or malignancy. In cases with high-SAAG (1.1), ascitic protein level analysis further helps in identifying the etiology: 2.5 g/dL indicates that the hepatic sinusoids are normal and are allowing the passage of protein into the ascites as in early Budd-Chiari syndrome. <2.5 g/dL indicates that the hepatic sinusoids have been damaged and scarred and no longer allow passage of protein as in late Budd-Chiari syndrome
subject: Medicine

question_text: A patient is said to have refractory ascites if the ascites does not resolve even after:
explanation: Refractory ascites is defined as the inability to mobilize ascitic fluid despite: Compliance with dietary sodium restriction Administration of maximum doses of diuretics - 400mg of spironolactone per day and 160mg of furosemide per day
subject: Medicine

question_text: What is the minimum absolute neutrophilic count that should be present in the ascitic fluid to diagnose a patient with spontaneous bacterial peritonitis?
explanation: The diagnosis of spontaneous bacterial peritonitis(SBP) is made when the fluid sample has an absolute neutrophil count >250/L. SBP is the spontaneous infection of the ascitic fluid without an intraabdominal source. Infection with E.coli and other gut bacteria is most commonly seen. However, gram-positive bacteria like Streptococcus viridans, Staphylococcus aureus, and Enterococcus sp., can also be found. Abdominal paracentesis is the investigation of choice. It can be managed with antibiotic therapy.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A cirrhotic patient admitted for ascites complained of abdominal pain on the 2nd day of his hospital stay. On examination, he was febrile. His lab reports are given below. Which of the following is false about his condition?
options: E.coli is the most commonly isolated organism
Prophylaxis against this condition is recommended in upper GI bleed
Third generation cephalosporins are used for treatment
Weekly antibiotic prophylaxis is recommended to prevent recurrence
explanation: The given clinical scenario along with ANC  250 cells/l in ascitic fluid is suggestive of spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP). Daily antibiotic prophylaxis is recommended in patients who have had an episode of SBP to prevent a recurrence. SBP is the spontaneous infection of the ascitic fluid without an intraabdominal source. The most common causative organisms are E.coli and other gut bacteria. The diagnosis of SBP is made when the ascitic fluid has an absolute neutrophil count >250/l. According to the latest recommendations, weekly antibiotic prophylaxis is no longer recommended. For patients with low protein ascites (<1.5 g/dL [15g/L]) along with either impaired renal function or liver failure, we use prolonged outpatient trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (one double-strength tablet daily). Alternatives include ciprofloxacin 500 mg per day or norfloxacin 400 mg per day. For patients on chronic trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole therapy, renal function should be monitored by checking serum electrolytes, blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine every one to six months depending on the stability of patient. If there is worsening renal function, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole should be discontinued.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following cannot be used to predict the risk of bleeding of oesophageal varices?
explanation: The risk of bleeding in a patient with oesophageal varices cannot be predicted based on the number of varices present. The factors that are used to predict the risk of variceal bleeding are: Severity of cirrhosis (Child’s class, MELD score) History of a previous variceal bleed Location of the varices - varices with a thinner layer of supporting tissue are likely to bleed more Size of the varices - larger varices have a higher risk of bleeding Endoscopic appearance of varices - Presence of red wale sign, hematocystic spots, diffuse erythema, and cherry red spots are associated with increased risk of bleeding Variceal pressure
subject: Medicine

question_text: In a patient with which of the following conditions would you not recommend a transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt?
explanation: Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) is not recommended in hepatic encephalopathy as it can aggravate its symptoms. TIPS creates a low-resistance channel between the hepatic vein and an intrahepatic branch of the portal vein. It uses a percutaneous approach under angiographic guidance. This reduces portal pressure. It is used in the management of: Oesophageal varices - in patients who fail medical or endoscopic management and have a poor surgical outcome Refractory ascites Gastric varices Ectopic varices Portal hypertensive gastropathy Hepatorenal syndrome Budd Chiari syndrome
subject: Medicine

question_text: A middle-aged man with hematemesis is rushed to the casualty. On examination, he is icteric, PR-122 /min and BP- 88/64 mmHg. The following finding is seen on his abdomen. Which of the following is false regarding his initial management?
options: pRBC is used to maintain Hb between 7-9g/dL
IV octreotide is used to acheive hemostasis
Upper GI endoscopy is only performed after 12 hours
explanation: The given clinical scenario along with the image showing caput-medusae is suggestive of acute esophageal variceal bleeding due to portal hypertension. Upper GI endoscopy is performed within 12 hours after fluid resuscitation in variceal bleeding. The management of esophageal variceal bleeding involves: Resuscitation with IV fluids, airway protection, and oxygen Blood transfusion to maintain Hb between 7-9g/dL Antibiotic prophylaxis with ceftriaxone before endoscopy An attempt at hemostasis with octreotide or terlipressin or vasopressin Upper GI endoscopy within 12 hours after fluid resuscitation to confirm the source of the bleed Endoscopic variceal ligation of sclerotherapy In case, of failure or rebleeding - TIPS Nonselective beta-blockers like propranolol and nadolol are used in the prophylaxis of variceal bleeding.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is false about the given image?
options: Esophageal balloon should be deflated for about 5 mins every 6 hours
Gastric balloon should be inflated first
Pressure in the oesophageal balloon should not exceed 60 mm Hg.
Endotracheal intubation prior to tube insertion reduces the risk of pulmonary aspiration
explanation: The given image shows Sengstaken-Blakemore tube. Pressure in the oesophageal balloon should not exceed 45 mm Hg. It is used for balloon tamponade in variceal hemorrhage when medical therapy fails or is not available. Initially, only the gastric balloon should be inflated, with 200– 250 mL of air, as this will usually control bleeding. The oesophageal balloon is used in continued bleeding, it should be deflated for about 5 minutes every 6 hours to avoid oesophageal mucosal damage. Endotracheal intubation prior to tube insertion reduces the risk of pulmonary aspiration.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A patient with hereditary hemochromatosis shows marked confusion and gross disorientation. He is drowsy but responds to pain and voice stimuli. What is the most likely grading of hepatic encephalopathy in this patient?
explanation: Gross disorientation with an intact response to pain and voice suggest grade 3 hepatic encephalopathy. Hepatic encephalopathy is the alteration of mental status and cognitive function occurring in liver failure. This occurs due to the failure of removal of gut-derived neurotoxins like ammonia by liver. These neurotoxins enter the brain leading to the development of symptoms.
subject: Medicine

question_text: What is the earliest symptom of hepatic encephalopathy?
explanation: The earliest symptom of hepatic encephalopathy is an alteration in sleep pattern. Other signs and symptoms of hepatic encephalopathy include: Asterixis also called the flapping tremor Mood changes and inappropriate behavior Disorientation and confusion
subject: Medicine

question_text: A cirrhotic patient was admitted following variceal bleeding. On the 3rd day of his hospital stay, he appears to be drowsy and confused. His wife reports that he had been awake throughout the previous night. On examination, flapping tremors were noticed. Which of the following is least likely to have precipitated his symptoms?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hepatic encephalopathy. Antibiotics are unlikely to precipitate hepatic encephalopathy. The common precipitating factors of hepatic encephalopathy are : Gastrointestinal bleeding Infections like SBP or UTIs Peritoneal tap Constipation Renal failure Hypovolemia Hypoxia Drugs - sedatives, antidepressants, diuretics Hypoglycemia Hypokalemia
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following antibiotics could be used in the treatment of patients with hepatic encephalopathy?
explanation: Rifaximin can be used in the treatment of hepatic encephalopathy. It lowers blood ammonia levels. Treatment of hepatic encephalopathy includes: Correction of precipitating factors Lactulose - decreased GI transit time due to cathartic actions leading to increased elimination of ammonia Rifaximin - lowers the blood ammonia levels L-ornithine L-aspartate - stimulate the urea cycle, with resulting loss of ammonia
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is not part of the diagnostic criteria of hepatorenal syndrome?
options: 50% increase in creatinine from baseline within 7 days
Rise in creatinine of 0.3 mg/dl in 48 hours
No recent use of nephrotoxic agent
explanation: The absence of shock is a part of the diagnostic criteria for hepatorenal syndrome. Hepatorenal syndrome is a progressive renal failure in patients with acute or chronic liver disease. The diagnostic criteria for hepatorenal syndrome include: Cirrhosis with ascites Diagnosis of acute kidney injury (AKI) Increase in serum creatinine of  0.3mg/dL in 48 hours, OR 50% increase in serum creatinine from baseline within 7 days Absence of shock No evidence of recent use of nephrotoxic agents Absence of intrinsic renal disease
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following clinical features is most likely to be seen in patients with hepatopulmonary syndrome?
explanation: Among the given options, platypnea is most likely to be seen in patients with hepatopulmonary syndrome. Hepatopulmonary syndrome is characterized by a triad of liver disease, hypoxemia, and intrapulmonary vascular dilatations. Most patients have dyspnea on exertion. The classic clinical manifestations are: Platypnea - Increase in dyspnea when the patient moves from supine to upright position Orthodeoxia - Decrease in arterial oxygen tension when the patient moves from supine to upright position The hypoxemia is due to a ventilation-perfusion mismatch which causes an increased alveolar-arterial (A-a) gradient. The most sensitive test for diagnosis is contrast bubble echocardiography. Liver transplantation is the definitive treatment of this condition following which the symptoms subside.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 52-year-old man presents with oliguria, abdominal distension, and pedal edema. His medical records show long-standing cirrhosis with multiple hospitalisations for ascites and hepatic encephalopathy. His lab reports are given below. What is the best treatment for his condition?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hepatorenal syndrome. The best treatment modality for it is liver transplantation. Hepatorenal syndrome is characterised by a rise in: AST ALT Total bilirubin Serum creatinine Blood urea nitrogen (BUN). Management of hepatorenal syndrome include: Norepinephrine Octreotide Terlipressin Midodrine Intravenous albumin Liver transplantation- definitive treatment
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following conditions is not a MELD exception?
explanation: Chronic Hepatitis B is not a MELD exception. MELD (Model for End-stage Liver Disease) score is used to prioritize patients awaiting liver transplantation. However, there are certain diseases that impair patient survival and are not accounted for in the MELD score. Patients with these diseases are given upgraded MELD points to accurately represent the mortality risk and these conditions are called MELD exceptions. The MELD exceptions include:- Portopulmonary hypertension Hepatocellular carcinoma Familial amyloid polyneuropathy Primary hyperoxaluria (necessitating liver-kidney transplantation) Cystic fibrosis with liver disease Highly selected cases of hilar cholangiocarcinoma. Hepatopulmonary syndrome Hepatic artery thrombosis 7–14 days post-liver transplantation.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which among the following is false?
options: Components of MELD (Model for end stage liver disease) scoring system are creatinine, bilirubin, International normalized ratio (INR), serum sodium (mEq/L).
Components of CTP(Child Turcotte Pugh) score are albumin, bilirubin, INR, ascites, encephalopathy
Components of CTP (Child Turcotte Pugh ) are creatinine, bilirubin, International normalized ratio (INR)
MELD score is used to assess and prioritize patients awaiting liver transplantation
explanation: The Child Turcotte Pugh (CTP) score does not include creatinine. The components of the CTP score are: Albumin Bilirubin International normalized ratio (INR) Ascites Encephalopathy The Model for End-stage liver disease (MELD 3.0) is used to prioritize patients awaiting liver transplantation and includes: Female sex Bilirubin Albumin Serum sodium (mEq/L) INR (International Normalized ratio) Creatinine
subject: Medicine

question_text:
What is the Child-Turcotte-Pugh class for the patient who has a serum bilirubin 2.5 mg/dl, serum albumin 3 g/dl, prothrombin time increased by 5 seconds (INR = 2), no encephalopathy, and mild ascites?
Class A
Class B
Class C
explanation: The given patient belongs to Child-Turcotte-Pugh class B. The score can be calculated as follows: Serum bilirubin-2.5mg/dl: 2 Serum albumin-3g/dl: 2 Prothrombin time-5 seconds or INR-2: 2 No encephalopathy: 1 Mild ascites: 2 Therefore, the Child-Turcotte-Pugh score is (2+2+2+1+2)= 9 which is included in Class B. Peptic Ulcer Disease and Related Disorders
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is an epithelial mucosal defense mechanism of the gastric mucosa?
explanation: Restitution is an epithelial mucosal defense mechanism. It is the process by which healthy surface epithelial cells from the adjoining areas migrate to restore a damaged region of the gastric mucosa. The gastric mucosa has well-established mucosal defense mechanisms against various assaults like HCl, pepsin, alcohol, etc. These include: Pre-epithelial defense: A layer of mucous over the surface epithelium. This is secreted by the surface epithelium and contains HCO3- which maintains neutral pH at the cell surface Epithelial defense: It is constituted by the surface epithelial cells and their intercellular tight junctions that perform the following functions Act as a physical barrier Restitution is the migration of healthy cells to damaged areas Rapid renewal of surface epithelial layer Generating factors that prevent cellular damage such as heat shock proteins Sub-epithelial defense: Rich microvascular bed of the gastric submucosa that provides HCO3- and washes away the toxic metabolites. Alkaline tide- It is caused by the release of HCO3- into the gastric capillaries by the parietal cells. This HCO3- helps in the quick neutralization of HCl.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 50-year-old woman complains about a burning pain in her chest. She reports using NSAIDs for her constant knee pain. This drug impairs her gastric mucosal defense mechanism primarily by:
explanation: The NSAIDs impair the mucosal defense mechanism primarily by inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis. NSAIDs also decrease nitric oxide synthesis and have an irritant effect on the gastric mucosa but inhibition of COX enzymes/ prostaglandin synthesis is the most prominent factor. Almost all the mucosal defense mechanisms are primarily mediated by prostaglandins synthesized by the gastric mucosal cells. Apart from the prostaglandins, the other factors that play a role in mucosal defense include: Nitric oxide (NO)- Causes vasodilation thereby increasing the mucosal blood flow. Several growth factors like EGF, TGF, FGF- Play a role in epithelial regeneration and restitution.
subject: Medicine

question_text: All of the following are true about the risk factors of NSAIDs associated peptic ulcer disease except:
options: H pylori infection increases the risk
Even low dose of a NSAID can cause ulcers
Concomitant use of glucocorticoids decreases the risk
explanation: Concomitant use of glucocorticoids with NSAIDs increases the risk of peptic ulcer disease. Other risks factors for NSAID-induced PUD include: H pylori infection Serious or multisystem disease Alcohol and smoking Concomitant use of the following drugs with NSAIDs increases the risk of PUD and its complications: Glucocorticoids Anticoagulants Clopidogre Multiple NSAIDs PUD may occur even with low doses of NSAIDs. No dose of NSAIDs is considered completely safe.
subject: Medicine

question_text: What pattern of gastritis is most common in patients with H.pylori-related duodenal ulcers?
explanation: Antral predominant gastritis is associated with duodenal ulcers. Antral predominant gastritis is associated with increased acid production by the parietal cells. This subjects the duodenum to increased acid exposure, leading to the formation of duodenal ulcers. H. pylori infection may result in the following patterns of gastritis: Non-atrophic pangastritis- mostly asymptomatic and sometimes associated with MALToma. Corpus predominant gastritis- affects the corpus and causes atrophy. This leads to the loss of acid-producing parietal cells that are primarily found in the corpus. Hence, it is associated with decreased acid production. This is also a predisposing factor for the development of gastric cancer. Antral predominant gastritis- spares the parietal cells. Hence, it is associated with increased acid production. Option A: Autoimmune gastritis is caused due to autoantibodies against the parietal cells. It is not associated with H. pylori. Option C: Granulomatous gastritis is characterized by the presence of granulomas It is associated with Crohn's disease and sarcoidosis.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A patient presents with frequent epigastric pain with burning sensation for the past 2 years. The pain usually occurs 2-3 hours after a meal and is relieved by taking food. He also says that he sometimes wakes up at night because of severe pain. The most probable cause for his symptoms is:
explanation: Epigastric pain with a burning sensation that usually occurs 2-3 hours after a meal and is relieved by taking food suggestive of duodenal ulcer. The following patterns of pain are usually seen in peptic ulcer disease: Duodenal Ulcer- Pain occurs 1.5 to 3 hours after a meal and is frequently relieved by antacids or food. Pain may awaken the patient from sleep. Gastric Ulcer- Pain/discomfort may be precipitated by food. Nausea and weight loss are common. Perforated ulcer- The bed of the ulcer tunnels through the entire thickness of the gastric wall and opens into the peritoneum. This presents with sudden onset severe abdominal pain and leads to peritonitis. Radiography shows gas under the diaphragm. Penetrating ulcer- It is a type of perforation where the ulcer tunnels into an adjacent organ like the pancreas/liver. In this case, the pain is no longer relieved by food or antacids and might radiate to the back. Many patients with peptic ulcers, especially elderly patients, may not have these symptoms and may directly present with a complication like bleeding or perforation.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is true about gastric ulcers?
explanation: Gastric ulcers are associated with low basal acid production and low stimulated acid production. Gastric acid secretion occurs in two patterns: Basal acid output- Occurs in a circadian pattern. It is mediated by ACh from the vagus and histamine. Stimulated acid production- Occurs in response to food. It is mediated by gastrin in addition to other factors. Gastric Ulcer Duodenal Ulcer Less common More common Occurs later in life, with a pe ak incidence in the 6th decad e Occurs earlier in life Basal and stimulated acid pr oduction is low/normal, exce pt in type 3 gastric ulcers Basal and nocturnal acid pro duction is increased Can representmalignancyand should be biopsied Rarely malignant Most common site:Antrum(di stal to acid-secreting mucosa) on the lesser curvature Most common site: 1st part o f the duodenum ( within 3cm s from the pylorus) Painafterfood intake Painbefore food intake, andr eliefontaking food
subject: Medicine

question_text: H pylori causes gastric mucosal injury due to the presence of:
explanation: H.pylori produces vacuolating exotoxin (Vac A) which causes gastric mucosal injury. Vac A inhibits CD4+ T-cells and disrupts the function of B cells, macrophages & mast cells. Cag A positive strains of H pylori cause an increased risk of gastric cancer.
subject: Medicine

question_text: You are a first-year resident. You are asked to prescribe an H.pylori eradication regimen to a patient with peptic ulcer disease. Which of the following drugs will you not include in it?
explanation: Erythromycin is not effective in H pylori eradication. Note: Vonoprazan, a potassium-competitive acid blocker, has been recently approved by the FDA for the treatment of peptic acid-related disorders.
subject: Medicine

question_text: In which of the following patients presenting with epigastric pain and discomfort is H.pylori eradication therapy not indicated:
options: 46-year-old man with a family history of gastric cancer in the father
40-year-old woman with rheumatoid arthritis on NSAIDs for 5 years
58-year-old man with 35-pack years history of smoking
36-year-old man with GERD on PPI's for 3 months
explanation: The need for H pylori eradication therapy in patients with GERD on long-term PPIs is not well established and is controversial. H pylori eradication therapy is offered to patients diagnosed with peptic ulcer disease (PUD) as it greatly decreases the recurrence of ulcers. In addition to this, it should also be offered to patients at increased risk of PUD and gastric cancer such as: Patients with long-term NSAIDs usage. Eg. Rheumatoid arthritis Patients taking gastric acid inhibitors for >1 year Patients with increased exposure to risk factors of gastric cancers. Eg. heavy smokers, exposure to dust, coa Patients with previous history/family history of gastric neoplasm
subject: Medicine

question_text: Eradication of H.pylori infection in patients with peptic ulcer disease is determined by?
explanation: Eradication of H. pylori infection can be determined by a urea breath test. A stool antigen test can also be employed.
subject: Medicine

question_text: H.pylori increases the risk of:
explanation: H.pylori increases the risk of gastric MALT lymphoma. H.pylori is protective against the following: GERD Barrett's esophagus Adenocarcinoma of esophagus Adenocarcinoma of the cardia of the stomach H. pylori are inversely related to gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and its sequelae, which include Barrett's esophagus and esophageal adenocarcinoma. H.pylori strains positive for Cag A may be particularly protective against the development of esophageal adenocarcinoma. Thus, colonization with H. pylori, particularly Cag A strains, may be protective against the more severe forms of GERD. Eradication of H. pylori is associated with mild worsening of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) in patients with corpus-dominant or pangastritis. It improves symptoms in those with antral-dominant gastritis.
subject: Medicine

question_text: The most common complication in patients with peptic ulcer disease is:
explanation: GI bleeding is the most common complication of peptic ulcer disease. Other complications: Perforation- second most common Gastrocolic fistulas Gastric outlet obstruction Rarely malignancy
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 47-year-old woman presented to the ER with an altered sensorium. Her husband reported that she has had abdominal pain, vomiting, and constipation for the past 4 days. She has been self-medicating for gastritis. Her lab investigations are as shown. Which of the following drugs is she most likely on that could have caused her symptoms?
explanation: The given clinical features indicating hypercalcemia and investigations showing renal insufficiency, metabolic alkalosis are suggestive of milk-alkali syndrome. Long-term use of calcium carbonate can lead to this condition. In susceptible individuals, there is a loss of negative feedback, leading to excess calcium absorption when there is excess intake. It results in the following triad of clinical features: Hypercalcemia Alkalosis- due to HCO3 reabsorption caused by PTH suppression, natriuresis, and water depletion Renal failure- due to damage to renal tubules It is reversible once ingestion of antacid is stopped. However, in severe cases, a chronic form called Burnett’s syndrome can develop. It is associated with irreversible renal damage.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A patient is admitted to the ICU after he suffered trauma to his head. This patient is prone to develop what type of gastric ulcers?
explanation: The gastric ulcers associated with head trauma are Cushing ulcers. Head trauma leads to vagal stimulation which in turn leads to increased gastric acid production. Option A: Curling ulcers are seen in severe burns. Option C: Stress ulcers are seen in conditions like shock, sepsis, etc. They are thought to be caused by local ischemia and splanchnic vasoconstriction. Option D: Refractory ulcers are those that do not heal even after adequate medical therapy.
subject: Medicine

question_text: You would diagnose a patient to have a refractory gastric ulcer if the ulcer fails to heal after:
explanation: A gastric ulcer is said to be refractory if it fails to heal after 12 weeks. A refractory duodenal ulcer is that which fails to heal after 8 weeks. Management of refractory PUD: Rule out other diseases or causes High dose PPI Surgery
subject: Medicine

question_text: A middle-aged woman presents with acidity, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and weight loss for the past few months. Her symptoms are not relieved by taking antacids. An endoscopic evaluation shows ulcers on the second part of the duodenum. Which of the following conditions should be suspected in this patient?
explanation: The given scenario of symptoms not improving with antacids, associated diarrhea, and the unusual location of ulcers are highly suggestive of Zollinger Ellison syndrome. Zollinger Ellison syndrome (ZES) is a peptic ulcer disease caused by unregulated gastrin release from a neuroendocrine tumor/gastrinoma. About 60% of the tumors are malignant, hence, it is important to identify ZES. The clinical presentation of ZES is very similar to that of peptic ulcer disease. The features which help in suspecting ZES include: Unusual locations- the second part of the duodenum and beyond Refractory to medical therapy Recurrence after acid-reducing surgery Presenting with complications like bleeding and perforation Not associated with H. pylori or NSAID ingestion Patients of ZES often have associated diarrhea and involvement of the esophagus (esophagitis, ulceration, or stricture).
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 35-year-old man presented with recurrent duodenal ulcers with poor response to medical therapy. He had a history of hyperparathyroidism and transsphenoidal prolactinoma resection. Which among the following is the next appropriate step?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Zollinger Ellison syndrome (ZES). The next appropriate step to evaluate the patients for ZES is by measuring the serum gastrin levels. History of hyperparathyroidism and transsphenoidal prolactinoma resection indicates MEN1 syndrome. ZES is commonly associated with MEN1. The normal gastrin levels are <150 pg/mL. An increase of >10 times the normal levels is highly suggestive of ZES. Secretin test is a gastrin provocative test. It is done when the gastrin levels and the acid secretory studies are inconclusive for ZES. It is the most sensitive and specific gastrin provocative test for the diagnosis of gastrinoma. Endoscopic ultrasound is done to localize the tumor. It is done after the diagnosis of ZES has been established.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following investigations employs somatostatin analogues to detect gastrinomas?
explanation: OctreoScan detects gastrinomas using their property of uptake of somatostatin analogues. OctreoScan detects endocrine tumors that express receptors for somatostatin in conditions such as Zollinger-Ellison syndrome (ZES) and multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) syndromes. Other modalities used for localizing the tumor in ZES include: Endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) PET/CT with Ga-DOTATATE is the investigation of choice when available. Note: PET/CT with Ga-DOTATATE is the gold-standard test for localizing tumors in pheochromocytoma.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following viruses cause infectious gastritis in immunocompromised patients?
explanation: Viruses that cause infectious gastritis in immunocompromised individuals include cytomegalovirus and Herpes simplex virus.
subject: Medicine

question_text: An anemic patient on evaluation showed macrocytes with hypersegmented neutrophils on peripheral smear. Serology revealed anti-parietal cell antibodies. Which of the following is most likely to be associated with her condition?
explanation: The given peripheral smear findings and serology are suggestive of pernicious anemia. It is usually seen in type A gastritis. Type A autoimmune gastritis is caused by circulating antibodies against the parietal cells. The destruction of parietal cells leads to the deficiency of intrinsic factor that is necessary for the absorption of vitamin B12. The resulting B12 deficiency causes pernicious anemia.
subject: Medicine

question_text:
An 84-year-old woman living in an assisted care facility is rushed to the hospital with an upper GI bleed. On arrival, she is febrile and the nurse notes a sudden spurt of blood from her nasogastric tube. The following investigations are done. Which of the following is responsible for this patient's condition?
H.pylori
explanation: The given clinical scenario along with her endoscopy findings are suggestive of phlegmonous gastritis. It is caused due to E.coli. Phlegmonous gastritis is a potentially life-threatening disorder characterized by marked and diffuse acute inflammatory infiltrates of the entire gastric wall accompanied by necrosis. It usually affects the immunocompromised and elderly individuals. Organisms associated with phlegmonous gastritis are: E.coli Streptococci Staphylococci Proteus Haemophilus species Other uncommon forms of gastritis are: Eosinophilic gastritis: Presents as intestinal obstruction Russel’s body gastritis: Pseudotumor on endoscopy Granulomatous gastritis is seen in Crohn’s disease Lymphocytic gastritis is seen in celiac disease Evaluation of Diarrhea
subject: Medicine

question_text: A patient presents with chronic diarrhea, bloating sensation, and weight loss. History is significant for stools that are bulky, pale, foul-smelling, and difficult to flush. Further testing reveals fecal fat excretion of 8.2g/day. Which of the following would be a differential diagnosis?
explanation: The above scenario is suggestive of steatorrhoea, which is seen in short bowel syndrome. Steatorrhoea is defined as excess fat in stools (>7g/day) due to poor absorption of lipids. question_text: A 22-year-old man presented with diarrhea and intolerance to dairy products. On investigation, he was found to have a lactase deficiency. Which of the following agents is least likely to cause symptoms of lactose intolerance?

Lactase is a brush border enzyme that hydrolyzes lactose into glucose and galactose. In lactase deficiency, patients have great variability in clinical symptoms, depending on both the severity of lactase deficiency and the amount of lactose ingested. The goal of treatment in patients with isolated lactase deficiency is achieving patient comfort through the elimination of dietary lactose. Foods that are high in lactose include milk (12 g/cup), ice cream (9 g/cup), and cottage cheese (8 g/cup). Aged cheese has lower lactose content. Most people can tolerate up to 12g of lactose a day without significant symptoms.

question_text: A 32-year-old woman presents with complaints of abdominal pain and recurrent diarrhea for several months. History reveals that she regularly goes on camping trips. Stool osmolality was 200 mOsm/kg H2O and the stool osmolar gap was 20 mOsm/kg H2O. What is the most likely diagnosis?

explanation: The given urinary crystal is the bipyramidal or envelope-shaped crystals of calcium oxalate dihydrate. Calcium oxalate stones are more commonly associated with Crohn's disease. In Crohn's disease (especially post small bowel resection), fatty acids are not absorbed because of ileal dysfunction. These fatty acids in the gut lumen bind to calcium. Because of this, the dietary oxalates which normally bind to the calcium are now left unbound. This leads to increased absorption of dietary oxalates leading to hyperoxaluria and oxalate stones. Note: Celiac disease is also associated with calcium oxalate stones.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Perianal examination of a patient revealed the following finding. Which condition is this associated with?
explanation: The above image shows a large hemorrhoidal perianal skin tag. These are found in patients with Crohn's disease, especially those with colon involvement.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 28-year-old man was brought to the casualty with a high fever and abdominal pain for the past 2 days. His history is significant for bloody diarrhea over the past few months. The abdominal radiograph of this patient is given below. Identify the condition.
explanation: The clinical scenario and radiograph are suggestive of toxic megacolon. It is seen in severe ulcerative colitis. Abdominal radiography in toxic megacolon shows transverse or right colonic dilation >6 cm and loss of haustrations. Toxic megacolon may present with fever, abdominal pain, and abdominal distension or features of sepsis.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A patient with inflammatory bowel disease presents with ocular pain, photophobia, and blurred vision. Which among the following is the most likely cause?
explanation: Uveitis is the most common cause of the given symptoms in a patient with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). Uveitis is an ophthalmic manifestation of IBD. It is associated with both ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease. It can develop during remission and is seen even after bowel resection. Prompt intervention with glucocorticoids is required to prevent scarring and visual impairment. The other common ophthalmic manifestations in IBD are conjunctivitis and episcleritis. Episcleritis, more common in Crohn's, is a benign disorder presenting with mild ocular burning.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 34-year-old man with Crohn’s disease presents with red tender swellings on the lower leg as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of erythema nodosum seen in inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). Erythema nodosum is a dermatologic manifestation of IBD. It is seen in both ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease. It manifests as tender erythematous nodules on the anterior surface of the lower legs, ankles, thighs, and arms. Option A: Pyoderma gangrenosum is a dermatological manifestation of IBD. It begins as pustular lesions which then ulcerate with necrotic foci and exudation. Option C: Sweet’s syndrome is acute febrile neutrophilic dermatosis, seen in ulcerative colitis. Option D: Ecthyma gangrenosum is a skin infection caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa, often seen in immunocompromised patients. It presents as pustules/vesicles which progress to necrotic ulcers.
subject: Medicine

question_text: What are the cardiopulmonary manifestations associated with inflammatory bowel disease?
explanation: The cardiopulmonary manifestations of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) are: Endocarditis Myocarditis Pleuropericarditis Interstitial lung disease Both ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease have an increased risk of venous and arterial thrombosis.
subject: Medicine

question_text:
A 36-year-old man presents with worsening fatigue, jaundice, and pruritis for the last 3 months. Past history revealed recurrent episodes of bloody diarrhea and weight loss over the
past year. Lab investigations show raised ALP, GGT, and bilirubin, and an MRCP is done as shown below. Which of the following is most likely to be associated with his current presentation?
explanation: The above clinical scenario along with MRCP showing multiple areas of intrahepatic narrowing with alternating areas of normal and dilated segments of bile ducts is suggestive of primary sclerosing cholangitis. PSC is more common in ulcerative colitis than in Crohn's disease. Additionally, recurrent episodes of bloody diarrhea with weight loss seen in this patient also point toward a possible diagnosis of ulcerative colitis. Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) is an extraintestinal manifestation of IBD characterized by intrahepatic and extrahepatic duct inflammation/fibrosis. Around 50-75% of patients with primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) have inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) whereas, only 5% of IBD cases develop PSC. Option A: Chronic pancreatitis is associated with a chain of lakes appearance- dilated main duct with clubbing and dilatation of the side branches. Patients can present with steatorrhoea i.e., the passage of offensive-smelling large stools due to fat malabsorption. The image below shows chain of lakes appearance on MRI: Option B: Celiac disease may be associated with primary biliary cholangitis (PBC), rather than primary sclerosing cholangitis.
subject: Medicine

question_text: After initiating treatment for patients with IBD, in which of the following extraintestinal manifestations would you expect to see an improvement?
explanation: Arthritis worsens with exacerbation of bowel disease and improves with the treatment of bowel symptoms or surgery. Ankylosing spondylitis, uveitis, and pyoderma gangrenosum do not correlate with disease activity in the bowel. They may occur during the remission of disease or even after surgery.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A patient is diagnosed with ulcerative colitis on endoscopy. He is hemodynamically stable but currently has 3-4 episodes of blood-tinged loose stools per day. Which of the following drug would you prefer for treating this patient?
explanation: The above scenario is suggestive of mild ulcerative colitis. The preferred drug for mild ulcerative colitis (UC) is 5-ASA agents (5-aminosalicylic acid). Given below is the Truelove and Witts severity index for ulcerative colitis. Note: Mirikizumab ( an IL-23 inhibitor) was recently FDA approved for the treatment of moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. It reduces stool frequency, rectal bleeding and bowel urgency.
