question_text: A 36-year-old man presented with complaints of 7-8 episodes of bloody diarrhea per day. He is pale and febrile. Heart rate is 110 bpm and ESR is 50mm. Colonoscopy revealed continuous mucosal involvement with ulcerations and mucosal hemorrhages. Which of the following drugs would you not prefer in the management of this patient?
explanation: The above scenario is suggestive of severe ulcerative colitis. Mesalamine (5-ASA) is ineffective in the management of severe ulcerative colitis (UC). It is used in the treatment of mild-moderate UC. Given below is the Truelove and Witts severity index for ulcerative colitis. Note: Mirikizumab ( an IL-23 inhibitor) was recently FDA approved for the treatment of moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. It reduces stool frequency, rectal bleeding and bowel urgency. Mild Moderate Severe Bowel movements < 4 per day 4 – 6 per day > 6 per day Blood in stool Small Moderate Severe Fever None < 37.5ºC > 37.5ºC Tachycardia None < 90 mean pulse >90 mean pulse Anemia Mild Hb > 75% of normal Hb Hb < 75% of normal Hb ESR < 30mm < 30mm > 30mm Endoscopic appear ance ErythemaDecreased vascul ar markingsFine granularit y Marked erythemaAbsent va scular markingsCoarse gra nularityContact bleedingNo ulcerations Spontaneous bleedingUlcer ations Treatment of Ulcerative Colit is Mild Moderate Severe Induction 5-AS A 5-ASA + Oral steroids IV steroids + IV anti TNF alp ha + IV cyclosporine Maintainance 5-AS A 5-ASA + Azathioprine/6- MP Oral cyclosporine or inflixim ab
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following drugs have no role in the management of patients with ulcerative colitis?
explanation: Metronidazole has no role in the management of ulcerative colitis. It is an antibiotic that is useful in active inflammatory, fistulous, and perianal Crohn's disease. Note: Mirikizumab ( an IL-23 inhibitor) was recently FDA approved for the treatment of moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. It reduces stool frequency, rectal bleeding and bowel urgency.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A patient with Crohn's disease is started on infliximab. Which of the following conditions is the patient is at increased risk of developing?
explanation: Patients with Crohn's disease on infliximab are at increased risk of non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) and hepatosplenic T-cell lymphoma (HS-TCL). Infliximab is the first biologic therapy approved for Crohn's disease. It is an IgG1 antibody against TNF-alpha. Drugs used in treatment of Crohn’s disease: Oral budesonide (mainly for mild to moderate) Oral prednisolone Methotrexate Anti TNF alpha Azathioprine 6-mercaptopurine Monoclonal antibodies Antibiotics Infliximab is also used in the treatment of moderate to severely active ulcerative colitis.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Ustekinumab is effective in all of the following conditions except:
explanation: Ustekinumab has no role in rheumatoid arthritis. It is effective against both Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis. It can also be used in the management of plaque psoriasis and psoriatic arthritis. It is an IgG1 monoclonal antibody that blocks the activity of IL-12 and IL-23. Biological therapy in inflammatory bowel disease: Anti-TNF therapies: Infliximab Adalimumab Certolizumab Anti-integrins: Natalizumab Ustekinumab Vedolizumab Note: Mirikizumab (an IL-23 inhibitor) was recently FDA approved for the treatment of moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. It reduces stool frequency, rectal bleeding and bowel urgency.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following drugs has no role after induction of remission has been achieved in a patient with IBD?
explanation: Glucocorticoids play no role in maintenance therapy in inflammatory bowel disease. They are used for induction in Crohn's disease and moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. Once clinical remission has been induced, they should be tapered gradually.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A patient with IBD was brought to the ER with acute epigastric pain radiating to the back. His lab investigations revealed elevated serum amylase and lipase. He gives a history of being started on a new drug for maintenance therapy of his IBD 2 weeks back. The causative drug is most likely to be:
explanation: The above scenario is suggestive of pancreatitis. Azathioprine causes pancreatitis in some patients within the first few weeks of therapy. It is completely reversible on discontinuing the drug. Azathioprine and 6-mercaptopurine (purine analogues) also have an increased risk of toxicity as some individuals may lack the enzyme necessary for their metabolism. This may lead to hepatitis, bone marrow suppression, etc. Hence, the patient should be monitored regularly with blood counts and liver function tests.
subject: Medicine

question_text: What is nutritional therapy in inflammatory bowel disease used for?
explanation: Nutritional therapy is used for inducing remission in Crohn's disease. Dietary antigens may stimulate an immune response. Hence, nutritional therapies like total parenteral nutrition, enteral nutrition (peptide-based preparations), etc. can be used to provide bowel rest in active Crohn's disease. These interventions cannot be used for maintaining remission. Ulcerative colitis does not respond to dietary intervention. Drugs used in treatment of Crohn’s disease: Oral budesonide (mainly for mild to moderate) Oral prednisolone Methotrexate Anti TNF alpha Azathioprine 6-mercaptopurine Monoclonal antibodies Antibiotics
subject: Medicine

question_text:
What is the treatment of choice in a patient with refractory ulcerative colitis?
Mucosal proctectomy with ileal pouch–anal anastomosis
explanation: The treatment of choice in refractory ulcerative colitis (UC) is mucosal proctectomy with ileal pouch–anal anastomosis (IPAA). As ulcerative colitis is a mucosal disease, the rectal mucosa is dissected and removed down to the dentate line of the anus. The ileum is made into a pouch that serves as neorectum. Malabsorption Syndromes
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is unlikely to be seen in patients with malabsorption syndrome?
explanation: Constipation is not a feature of malabsorption syndrome. Malabsorption syndrome refers to a spectrum of conditions of various etiologies that arises due to diminished absorption of one or more dietary nutrients. The general features of malabsorption syndrome are abdominal pain, diarrhea, steatorrhea, and weight loss. Anemia may be present when there is defective absorption of iron, folate, or vitamin B12. Hypocalcemia and tetany can be seen due to defective absorption of vitamin D.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following tests is useful for the assessment of intestinal mucosal function in a patient presenting with symptoms of malabsorption?
explanation: D-xylose test is useful for the assessment of intestinal mucosal function. D-xylose is a monosaccharide that is directly absorbed by the intestinal mucosa without undergoing enzymatic digestion. The test is performed by administering 25g of D-xylose orally followed by the collection of urine 5h later. The test is considered abnormal (positive) if urinary D-xylose is <4.5g. A positive D-xylose test indicates abnormal small intestinal mucosa.
subject: Medicine

question_text: The result of a D-xylose test showed urinary excretion of the monosaccharide at 3.6g after 5 hours. Which of the following can be a differential diagnosis?
explanation: A urinary D-xylose <4.5g after 5 hours of oral D-xylose (abnormal) can be seen in Crohn’s disease. D-xylose is a monosaccharide that is directly absorbed by the small intestinal mucosa without undergoing enzymatic digestion. An abnormal (positive) D-xylose test indicates abnormal small intestinal mucosal absorption. A positive D-xylose test is seen in: Celiac disease Whipple’s disease Tropical sprue Short bowel syndrome Crohn’s disease The test is of limited clinical value today and mostly has been replaced by small intestinal biopsy.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Patients with which of the following conditions are likely to suffer from malabsorption?
explanation: A small bowel diverticulum can result in malabsorption. A small bowel diverticulum is a blind pouch protruding from the small intestine that communicates with the lumen of the gut. It becomes a potential site for bacterial overgrowth which causes malabsorption. The growing gut bacteria depletes vitamin B12 and deconjugates bile acids leading to steatorrhea, diarrhea, and macrocytic anemia. Anterior colon resection, ulcerative colitis, and sigmoid volvulus affect the large intestine and therefore do not cause malabsorption.
subject: Medicine

question_text: What is the most common cause of short bowel syndrome in adults?
explanation: The most common cause of short bowel syndrome in adults is mesenteric vascular occlusion. Short bowel syndrome (SBS) is a malabsorption disorder caused by a lack of functional small intestine. In adults, the common causes are : Mesenteric vascular disease (e.g: mesenteric vascular occlusion.) Primary mucosal and submucosal disease (e.g: Crohn’s disease) Operations without any preexisting small-intestinal disease (e.g: after trauma) In children, necrotizing enterocolitis is the most common cause.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Patients with which of the following conditions are unlikely to have protein malabsorption?
explanation: Homocystinuria is not a protein malabsorption disorder. It is a disorder of methionine metabolism that leads to increased homocysteine levels. Proteins are broken down by pancreatic enzymes and are absorbed as amino acids and peptides. So, protein malabsorption usually occurs only in pancreatic insufficiency. Additionally, there are three rare genetic disorders that lead to protein malabsorption. They are: Enterokinase deficiency- Defective conversion of the proenzyme trypsinogen to trypsin. It is characterised by: Diarrhoea Growth retardation Hypoproteinemia Hartnup disease- Defective transport of tryptophan and other neutral amino acids. It is characterised by: Pellagra-like rash Neuropsychiatric symptoms Cystinuria- Defective transport of cystine and other dibasic amino acids. It is characterised by: Renal calculi Chronic pancreatitis
subject: Medicine

question_text: A Schilling test was performed on a patient with vitamin B12 deficiency and the results are given below. What is the inference?
explanation: The above findings on Schilling test show reduced absorption of vitamin B12 irrespective of all interventions. This is suggestive of an ileal disease.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A patient presented with chronic diarrhea and steatorrhea. D-xylose test was normal and the Schilling test was abnormal. A duodenal biopsy was normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The clinical scenario describes a case of malabsorption syndrome (chronic diarrhea and steatorrhea), a normal xylose test and normal duodenal biopsy with abnormal schilling test points towards pancreatic insufficiency. A normal xylose test and normal duodenal biopsy rules out small intestinal pathologies like celiac disease (option A) and intestinal lymphangiectasia (option C), presence of steatorrhea rules out ulcerative colitis (option B) as it affects the large bowel which is not the main site of absorption of fat. Ileal disease is also characterized by normal xylose test, normal duodenal biopsy and steatorrhea and abnormal schilling test but among the given options the most appropriate answer would be pancreatic insufficiency due to chronic pancreatitis. Pancreatic insufficiency is characterised by the deficiency of exocrine pancreatic enzymes that result in maldigestion and malabsorption. The features in favor of the diagnosis: Steatorrhea - a deficiency of pancreatic lipases can lead to undigested fat in stools. D-xylose test - d-xylose is a monosaccharide that is directly absorbed by the intestinal mucosa without undergoing any enzymatic action. Normal d-xylose test denotes intact mucosa. Schilling test - it is abnormal as pancreatic enzymes are required for the absorption of vitamin B12. Diagnosis of various malabsorption syndromes: Pathologies D xylose test Duodenal mucosal biopsy Schilling test Celiac disease Decreased Abnormal; Short or absen t villi; epithelial cell dama ge; crypts hypertrophy Normal Ileal disease Normal Normal Abnormal Chronic pancreatitis Normal Normal Abnormal; normal after p ancreatic enzymes substit ution Intestinal lymphangiectasi a Normal Abnormal; dilated lympha tics, clubbed villi Normal Bacterial overgrowth synd rome Normal or may be abn ormal Usually normal or can hav e diffuse non specific dam age to villi Usually abnormal; normal after antibiotics administ ration
subject: Medicine

question_text: An 11-year-old boy presented with steatorrhea and chronic diarrhea. An evaluation revealed delayed intellectual development and ataxia. Acanthocytes were seen on the peripheral blood smear. Ophthalmological examination showed the following. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The image showing retinitis pigmentosa and presence of acanthocytes along with the given clinical features is suggestive of abetalipoproteinemia. Abetalipoproteinemia is a rare genetic disorder in which there is defective chylomicron formation. Chylomicrons are required for the absorption and transport of fats and fat-soluble vitamins. It presents in early childhood with steatorrhoea and diarrhea, hypolipidemia, failure to thrive, ataxia, sensory and motor neuropathies.
subject: Medicine

question_text: The findings associated with abetalipoproteinemia are :
explanation: Figure A shows vacuoles (unabsorbed fat) in the cytoplasm of the enterocytes. Figure B shows acanthocytes. These findings are associated with abetalipoproteinemia. Figure C shows distended macrophages in the lamina propria and periodic acid–Schiff (PAS)-positive granules as seen in Whipple's disease. Acanthocytes are abnormal red blood cells with spiked cell membranes due to thorn-like projections. Causes of acanthocytes in peripheral smear are: Abetalipoproteinemia Renal disease Liver disease Hemolytic anemia
subject: Medicine

question_text: All are true about the types of celiac disease except :
options: Latent type is associated with HLA DQ 2,8
Atypical type has a negative serology
Silent type has a positive serology
Classic type presents with diarrhea and steatorrhea
explanation: Atypical celiac disease has a positive serology with atypical symptoms. Serology in celiac disease refers to either anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies (anti-tTG) or anti-endomysial antibodies. Note: Tropical sprue and celiac disease have similar clinical, endoscopic and histologic findings. A diagnosis of tropical sprue must be considered with a negative celiac serology. Type of celiac disease Serol ogy Features A Classic + Diarrhea, steatorrhea B Atypical + Iron deficiency anemia, osteo penia, ataxia, peripheral neur opathy, infertility C Silent + No features D Latent - HLA DQ 2,8
subject: Medicine

question_text: What is the most common extraintestinal manifestation of celiac disease?
explanation: The most common extraintestinal manifestation of celiac disease is dermatitis herpetiformis (DH). DH is characterized by intensely pruritic small papules and vesicles on the extensor surfaces of extremities, buttocks, and neck. It can be considered a celiac disease of the skin. Other extraintestinal manifestations of celiac disease are: Anemia Low bone density Ataxia Peripheral neuropathy Infertility Celiac disease is often associated with other conditions such as type 1 diabetes mellitus, autoimmune thyroid disease, IgA deficiency, bird fancier's lung, and Down syndrome. The image below shows dermatitis herpetiformis.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 15-year-old girl presented with fatigue, chronic diarrhoea, weight loss, bone pain, and abdominal distension. Investigations revealed iron deficiency anemia and osteoporosis. Which of the following is the single best test to be done for her evaluation?
explanation: The presence of fatigue, chronic diarrhea, weight loss and abdominal distention along with investigations showing features of malabsorption (iron deficiency) lead to the diagnosis of celiac disease or gluten sensitive enteropathy. The single best test for which is checking serum for the presence of IgA tissue transglutaminase (anti-TTG) antibodies (Option D). Celiac disease is a disorder characterized by an immunological response to gluten causing damage to the proximal intestinal mucosa (villous atrophy) and malabsorption of nutrients. Symptoms usually begin 6 to 24 months from the introduction of gluten into diet, although most patients go undiagnosed. The common manifestations are - irritability, abdominal distention, chronic diarrhea, weight loss or muscle wasting and extra-intestinally, the symptoms observed are aphthous ulcers, delayed puberty, iron deficiency anemia and short stature. Screening for celiac disease is by testing for tissue transglutaminase IgA, endomysial, and deamidated antigliadin antibodies. IgA levels in serum are measured to detect false-negative results because of IgA deficiency. Small intestinal biopsy shows characteristic villus blunting, crypt hyperplasia, and increased intraepithelial lymphocytes. The treatment involves the exclusion of gluten-containing food from diet. Long term complications observed are osteoporosis, anemia, infertility and malignancy (enteropathy related-T cell lymphoma is the most common association) The Marsh classification is used to categorize celiac disease into different types and to quantify severity of disease involvement.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A patient who presented with severe malabsorption is found to be positive for IgA tissue trans-glutaminase antibodies. What will be the next best step?
explanation: In this patient with positive serology, a biopsy should be done next, to confirm the diagnosis of celiac disease. Tissue transglutaminase Ab (tTG-IgA) is the best screening test. IgA endomysial antibodies (EMA) are most specific. But a small-intestinal biopsy is required to establish a diagnosis of celiac disease, before starting treatment.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 30-year-old man presented with chronic diarrhea, steatorrhea, and weight loss. IgA tissue trans-glutaminase antibodies were found to be positive. Duodenal biopsy revealed the following. Which of the following complications would you not expect in this patient?
explanation: The above scenario along with the presence of IgA tissue trans-glutaminase antibodies and biopsy showing villous atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, lamina propria infiltrates indicate a case of celiac disease. Pancreatic insufficiency is not a complication of celiac disease. The complications of celiac disease are: Intestinal lymphomas Intestinal ulcers- also known as ulcerative jejunoileitis Collagenous sprue- development of a subepithelial collagen layer
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 46-year-old lady with celiac disease is recommended a gluten-free diet. Which among the following can she consume?
explanation: Rice can be consumed on a gluten-free diet. The primary management of celiac disease is avoiding gluten in the diet. Diet avoided (gluten)“BRO W” Diet Allowed“So M RP” Barley Soya bean Rye Maize Oats Rice Wheat Potato
subject: Medicine

question_text: When will you diagnose a patient with refractory celiac disease?
options: No remission of disease despite gluten free diet
Development of a subepithelial collagen layer
explanation: Refractory celiac disease is diagnosed when there is no remission of disease despite a strict gluten-free diet for 6-12 months. Patients are symptomatic and have persistent small intestinal villous atrophy on biopsy. They respond well to steroids.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Match the following disorders with their respective sites of involvement:
explanation: The sites involved in the given malabsorption syndromes are as follows: Disorder Site of involvement Celiac disease Proximal small intestine Whipple's disea se Proximal > Distal small intes tine Tropical sprue Whole small intestine (panint estine)
subject: Medicine

question_text: All are true about Whipple's disease except :
options: Caused by gram positive organism Tropheryma whipplei
Culture of organism from biopsy specimen helps in early diagnosis
explanation: Tropheryma whipplei is difficult to culture from the biopsy specimen. Hence, it cannot be used for the early diagnosis of Whipple's disease. Whipple's disease is a chronic multisystem disorder caused by the gram-positive bacteria Tropheryma whipplei. It primarily causes malabsorption along with central nervous system & cardiac problems. It mostly affects men and presents with fever, diarrhea weight loss, and arthralgia. The diagnosis of Whipple's disease is made through a biopsy which shows the presence of PAS-positive macrophages in the small intestine and other organs with evidence of disease.
subject: Medicine

question_text: What is the most common CNS manifestation associated with Whipple’s disease?
explanation: The most common CNS manifestation associated with Whipple’s disease is progressive dementia. Other important CNS manifestations in Whipple's disease are: Personality and mood changes Progressive supranuclear ophthalmoplegia Focal neurologic presentations Oculomasticatory myorrhythmia - an unusual combination of rhythmic eye and jaw movements which is pathognomonic of Whipple's disease. Whipple's disease associated with CNS symptoms has a poor prognosis. Note: Opsoclonus myoclonus syndrome is a paraneoplastic syndrome associated with neuroblastoma.
subject: Medicine

question_text: What is the most common cardiovascular presentation seen in patients with Whipple's disease?
explanation: The most common cardiovascular presentation in Whipple's disease is culture-negative endocarditis. Other cardiovascular findings include: Congestive heart failure Pericarditis Myocarditis
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 38-year-old man presented with chronic diarrhea, weight loss, and joint pains. A duodenal biopsy was done. Which of the following drug is used in the maintenance phase of treatment of this condition?
explanation: The above image shows PAS-positive foamy macrophages present in the lamina propria. This along with the given features suggests Whipple's disease. Cotrimoxazole is used in the maintenance phase of the treatment of Whipple's disease. Treatment of Whipple's disease: Induction phase- ceftriaxone or meropenem or penicillin G + streptomycin - 2 weeks Maintenance phase- trimethoprim / sulfamethoxazole (TMP/SMX) for 1 year. It has high CNS penetration so it is used in maintenance to prevent relapse.
subject: Medicine

question_text:
A 42-year-old man presented with diarrhea, floating stools, and weight loss for 3 months. Celiac serology was negative. Biopsy of the small intestinal mucosa revealed villous atrophy
and crypt hyperplasia with normal mucosal thickness. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The history of malabsorptive symptoms, a negative celiac serology, and the biopsy findings are suggestive of tropical sprue. Improvement in symptoms after folic acid intake is a hallmark of tropical sprue. Tropical sprue is an acquired malabsorptive condition of probable infectious aetiology. It is seen in people from the tropics such as India, Southeast Asia and South America. Tropical sprue and celiac disease have similar clinical, endoscopic and histologic findings. However, a positive celiac serology (anti-tissue transglutaminase and anti-endomysial antibodies) can be used to rule out tropical sprue.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following would you prescribe for a patient with tropical sprue?
explanation: The treatment of tropical sprue is tetracycline + folic acid. Because of marked folate deficiency, folic acid is most often given together with broad spectrum antibiotics for up to 6 months.
subject: Medicine

question_text:
Which of the following drug is used for the management of a patient with small intestinal bacterial overgrowth?
Ciprofloxacin
explanation: Rifaximin is the preferred drug for the management of small intestinal bacterial overgrowth (SIBO). The antibiotics are given for around 3 weeks. The other drugs that can be used are : Tetracyclines Cephalosporins Metronidazole Amoxicillin-Clavulanic acid Rifaximin is the antibiotic used in hepatic encephalopathy to lower blood ammonia levels. Other Gastrointestinal Conditions
subject: Medicine

question_text: An upper GI endoscopy is performed in a patient with dyspeptic symptoms. It shows the presence of thickened gastric folds. Which of the following differential diagnoses would you not consider in this patient?
explanation: Pancreatic rests are not a differential diagnosis for hypertrophied gastric folds. These usually present as a single lump in the stomach and are formed by ectopic pancreatic tissue. Thickened gastric folds can represent a local malignant process, inflammatory process, or hormonal response. The differential diagnoses of large gastric folds include: Menetrier's disease Zollinger–Ellison syndrome - hypergastrinemia leads to parietal cell hyperplasia and prominent folds Malignancy- lymphoma, infiltrating gastric cancer Infections- histoplasmosis, tuberculosis.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which part of the stomach is usually spared in Menetrier's disease?
explanation: The antrum is usually spared in Menetrier's disease. Foveolar hyperplasia results in the development of large rugal folds in the body and fundus of the stomach, sparing the antrum. These hypertrophied rugal folds give a cobblestone or cerebriform appearance to the gastric mucosa. The image given below shows the endoscopic appearance of Menetrier's disease.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 46-year-old man presented with a history of diarrhea for 5 months, occasional abdominal pain, and weight loss. Upper GI endoscopy showed the following finding. Which of the following is least likely to occur in this patient?
explanation: The given case scenario and endoscopy image showing large, rugal gastric folds are suggestive of Menetrier's disease. Among the given options, hematemesis is least likely to occur in this patient. Large, gastric rugal folds in Menetrier's disease occur due to massive overgrowth of mucous cells (foveolar cells) lining the stomach. Patients usually present with epigastric pain, nausea, diarrhea, vomiting, anorexia, peripheral edema, and weight loss. Occult gastrointestinal bleeding may occur, but overt bleeding is unusual. If overt bleeding is seen, it is usually due to superficial mucosal erosions. They develop protein-losing gastropathy, leading to hypoproteinemia as a result of increased secretion of gastric mucus. There is also a decrease in the number of parietal cells which leads to decreased acid secretion (hypochlorhydria) in the stomach. They are at an increased risk of developing gastric carcinoma.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 6-year-old child with vomiting, abdominal pain, weight loss, and peripheral edema underwent an upper GI biopsy. Histology showed foveolar hyperplasia and glandular atrophy within the gastric mucosa. Which of the following is most commonly associated with this condition?
explanation: The given case scenario is suggestive of Menetrier's disease. In children, it occurs commonly due to the infection by cytomegalovirus. The histopathological features of Menetrier's disease include: Foveolar hyperplasia - hyperplasia of surface and glandular mucosa Reduction in oxyntic glands, parietal cells, and chief cells Dilated, tortuous gastric glands Elongation of pits of gastric glands Eosinophilic infiltration in lamina propria The image given below shows the histopathological appearance of Menetrier's disease.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Overexpression of which of the following causes Menetrier’s disease?
explanation: Overexpression of TGF- (transforming growth factor-alpha) causes Menetrier's disease. This overexpression results in overstimulation of the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) pathway and increased proliferation of mucous cells, resulting in mucous cell (foveolar) hyperplasia.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 24-year old woman underwent extensive workup for unexplained weight loss, vomiting, and diarrhea. She was suspected to have Menetrier's disease. Which of the following investigations will confirm the diagnosis?
explanation: Menetrier's disease is confirmed by endoscopic full-thickness biopsy. A full-thickness biopsy allows for the visualization of the cells on the surface as well as the pits of the gastric glands. The histopathological specimen shows the following features: Foveolar hyperplasia - hyperplasia of surface and glandular mucosa Reduction in oxyntic glands, parietal cells, and chief cells Dilated, tortuous gastric glands Elongation of pits of gastric glands Eosinophilic infiltration in lamina propria A punch biopsy can only sample the surface of the gastric gland and hence is not preferred. The image given below shows the histopathological appearance of Menetrier's disease.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A middle-aged man presented with a history of dyspepsia. He has been taking pantoprazole for the last few months, however, his symptoms persisted. Upper GI endoscopy was done, and a full-thickness gastric biopsy was taken. The histopathological appearance is shown below. What is the treatment of choice?
explanation: The given clinical scenario and the image showing foveolar hyperplasia are suggestive of Menetrier's disease. The treatment of choice is cetuximab. Increased epidermal growth factor receptor(EGFR) signaling has been implicated in the pathogenesis of Menetrier's disease. Cetuximab is an EGFR inhibitor, and blocks this signaling pathway and helps in the improvement of the symptoms. Therefore, it is the first line of treatment. Medical therapy with proton pump inhibitors (lansoprazole) and somatostatin analogues (octreotide) may also be tried to manage symptoms. If the patient continues to have protein loss despite medical therapy, then total gastrectomy is indicated. The image given below shows the histopathological appearance of Menetrier's disease.
subject: Medicine

question_text: What is the most common site for a MALToma?
explanation: The most common site for mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (MALT) lymphoma or MALToma is the stomach. MALToma is a type of extranodal marginal zone lymphoma that most commonly occurs in the stomach and to a lesser extent in the salivary glands, lungs, small intestine, etc. It occurs as a result of the malignant proliferation of B cells in the marginal zone of mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (MALT).
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is false about MALTomas?
options: History of chronic gastritis usually seen
explanation: MALToma arises from B lymphocytes present in the marginal zone of the lymphoid tissue. The majority of the cases of MALToma are associated with H. pylori induced chronic gastritis. This infection results in an increased proliferation of lymphocytes in the mucosa of the stomach causing MALToma. It is initially low grade and if the infection is not treated, it later progresses to high grade. The patients usually present with non-specific symptoms like epigastric pain and discomfort. It is usually diagnosed in patients around 60 years of age. It is also associated with autoimmune diseases like Sjogren's syndrome and Hashimoto's thyroiditis.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 62-year-old woman underwent an endoscopic biopsy of a gastric tumor. The biopsy shows dense lymphocytic infiltration with lymphoepithelial lesions in the gastric glands. Which of the following investigations will confirm your diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario and lymphoepithelial lesions seen in the gastric glands is suggestive of MALToma. The diagnosis is confirmed by immunophenotyping. Histopathological examination of a MALToma shows the presence of lymphoepithelial lesions. These are caused due to the invasion of gastric glands and crypts by the neoplastic lymphocytes. These lymphocytes are positive for CD19, CD20 and negative for CD5 and CD10. Biopsy or aspiration of the bone marrow is also done to see the bone marrow involvement. Radiological investigations like CT scans, MRIs, and PET scans are useful in identifying the extent of the tumor and infiltration of the tumor to the adjacent organs. Note: Cytogenetic testing will be helpful in identifying chromosomal abnormalities. The image given below shows the histopathological appearance of a MALToma. The below image shows a sample of a MALToma showing positive immunophenotyping for CD20.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Immunophenotyping from a gastric tumor in an elderly man showed the following findings. The tumor was found to be limited to the gastric mucosa. What is the treatment of choice?
explanation: The given case scenario is suggestive of a low-grade gastric MALToma. The treatment of choice for this condition is H. pylori eradication therapy which can be done with the OCM regimen (omeprazole, clarithromycin and metronidazole). Immunophenotyping in MALTomas shows positive staining for CD19 and CD20 which is suggestive of a B-cell neoplasm. Negative staining for CD5 and CD10 is seen, suggesting it arises from the marginal zone of lymphoid tissues. Chronic infection with H. pylori leads to the development of MALTomas. When these lesions are limited to the mucosa, treatment of the infection alone is sufficient to cause regression of the tumour. In high-grade tumors or the tumors which invade into the adjacent or distant organs, radiotherapy and chemotherapy are required to treat the tumor. Radiotherapy is usually three-dimensional conformal radiotherapy. The chemotherapeutic agents used in the treatment of MALToma are rituximab, cyclophosphamide, fludarabine, doxorubicin, vincristine, and prednisone. Radical gastrectomy has a limited role and is done when the disease is confined to the stomach.
subject: Medicine

question_text:
A 65-year-old smoker presents with postprandial abdominal pain and diarrhea for the past 1 year. On examination, she is malnourished, and a bruit is heard in the epigastrium. What is the most probable diagnosis?
Acute mesenteric ischemia
explanation: The given case scenario is suggestive of chronic mesenteric ischemia. Chronic mesenteric ischemia occurs due to atherosclerosis of the celiac or mesenteric arteries. It is common in older women, and they usually have a history of smoking, coronary artery disease, cerebrovascular disease, or peripheral artery disease. The important clinical features of chronic mesenteric ischemia are: Postprandial abdominal pain occurs as a result of a mismatch between the increased deman and decreased blood flow to the intestine. This is called intestinal angina Weight loss- patients avoid eating due to postprandial pain and this leads to significant weight loss Diarrhea- occurs as a result of decreased absorption Physical examination may reveal epigastric bruit in almost half of the patients. The gold standard investigation to diagnose the blockade is mesenteric angiography. Once the disease is confirmed, the patients have to be started with antiplatelets and mesenteric angioplasty and stenting should be performed. Option A: Acute mesenteric ischemia present with acute abdomen, bloody diarrhea and nausea. Angiography will show occlusion of superior mesenteric artery. Option C: Wilkie's syndrome occurs due to compression of the third portion of the duodenum by the superior mesenteric artery. It can present similarly, however is associated with vomiting and rapid weight loss. It usually occurs in young, asthenic women. Option D: Nutcracker syndrome occurs due to compression of the left renal vein, between the aorta and the superior mesenteric artery. It presents with varicoceles and hematuria. Large and medium vessel vasculitis

explanation: Takayasu disease is an example of large vessel vasculitis.

question_text: Biopsy performed on a patient with suspected vasculitis showed the presence of granulomas. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: Churg-Strauss syndrome is the most likely diagnosis as it is a granulomatous vasculitis. question_text: A 42-year-old man presented with complaints of fever, malaise, and weight loss. His lab investigations showed mild anemia, elevated ESR, and serology was positive for cANCA. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener’s granulomatosis) is the most likely diagnosis as it is associated with cANCA.

question_text: Which of the following is not true about giant cell arteritis?
options: May lead to ischemic optic neuropathy
explanation: Giant cell arteritis is common in older women (>50 years of age). Giant cell arteritis is an inflammatory vasculitis of the large vessels, commonly seen in females over 50 years of age. It usually involves the temporal artery. It is characterized by fever, anemia, and headache. Depending on the artery involved, the patient may have tenderness over the affected artery, scalp pain, tongue and jaw claudication. Untreated patients may develop ischemic optic neuropathy. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated ESR and normochromic normocytic anemia. It shows good response to glucocorticoid therapy.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 65-year-old woman came with complaints of headache for the past 1-month. She also reported aching of the jaw during her meals. Over the last week, she has experienced episodes of painless visual loss which lasted for around 10 minutes. Which of the following is the best investigation for the diagnosis of her condition?
explanation: The given clinical presentation of headache, jaw claudication, and painless visual loss is suggestive of giant cell arteritis. The best investigation for the diagnosis of giant cell arteritis is temporal artery biopsy. Histopathology shows panarteritis with the presence of mononuclear cells and giant cells. The biopsy may not be positive in all patients due to patchy histologic findings. Since involvement of the vessel may be segmental, positive yield is increased by obtaining a biopsy segment of 3–5 cm together with serial sectioning of biopsy specimens. Note : According to the 21st edition of Harrison's Medicine, as involvement of the vessel may be segmental, getting a biopsy segment of 3–5 cm together with serial sectioning of biopsy specimens would help to increase a positive yield. And Robbin's 10th edition mentions that an adequate biopsy requires at least a 1-cm segment.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 50-year-old woman presents to your OPD with complaints of pain and stiffness of the shoulders which is worse in the morning. She works as a bus conductor and tells you that she has difficulty raising her shoulders to ring the bell. On examination, there is diffuse tenderness over the shoulders. Which of the following vasculitis is closely associated with her presentation?
explanation: The given clinical presentation of painful, tender, and stiff shoulders with restricted movement points toward a diagnosis of polymyalgia rheumatica, which is closely associated with giant cell arteritis. Polymyalgia rheumatica is characterized by pain and stiffness (worst in the morning) in the muscles of the neck, shoulder, back, hips, and thigh. On examination, diffuse tenderness is present without localization to any specific structures. Pain restricts the active range of motion but passive range of motion and muscle strength are normal. ESR and CRP are typically elevated in polymyalgia rheumatica whereas creatine phosphokinase (CPK) lies within the normal range. It shows a good response to prednisone therapy.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 60-year-old woman presents with severe right-sided throbbing headache. She also gives history of pain and stiffness of the shoulders and hips. Her lab values show an ESR of 80 mm/hr. What is the next best step in her management?
explanation: The given clinical presentation of headache and symptoms suggestive of polymyalgia rheumatica with raised ESR points towards a diagnosis of giant cell arteritis (GCA), for which the next best step is initiation of steroids (prednisone). Although temporal artery biopsy is the diagnostic investigation for GCA, it should not delay the initiation of steroids as it helps in reducing symptoms and preventing visual loss. The biopsy findings usually remain positive for at least 1 month after initiation of steroids. Newer drugs used in the treatment of giant cell arteritis are tocilizumab (anti-IL-6 receptor) and abatacept (CTLA4-Ig).
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which is the most common artery involved in Takayasu arteritis?
explanation: The most common artery involved in Takayasu arteritis is the subclavian artery. Patients present with pain, claudication, and weakness of the affected limb. The arterial pulse in the affected limb may be weak or absent. The order of arteries affected in Takayasu arteritis is subclavian artery > common carotid artery > abdominal aorta > renal artery > aortic arch = vertebral > coeliac axis > iliac > pulmonary > coronary artery.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 27-year-old woman presents to the hospital with fever, malaise, and arthralgia for a duration of 1 month. She also complains of pain, numbness, and weakness in her right arm, which has been increasing over the past 1 week. Clinical examination reveals weak radial pulses, and her laboratory investigations show elevated ESR. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The above clinical features with a marked weakening of pulse in the upper extremities and laboratory findings of elevated ESR are suggestive of Takayasu arteritis. It is also known as pulseless disease. Takayasu arteritis is a systemic disease and may present with generalized and vascular symptoms. It commonly affects adolescents or young females. Generalized symptoms like fever, night sweats, weight loss, malaise, arthralgias, and anorexia may occur long before vascular symptoms. Vascular symptoms depend on the vessel involved: Arch of the aorta and its branches: Subclavian artery (most commonly affected) - It leads to weak pulses in the upper extremities. Hence, it is also known as pulseless disease. It may also lead to Raynaud’s phenomenon. Carotid arteries- It leads to weak pulses, blindness, and neurological deficits. Aortic arch- It may lead to congestive heart failure. Abdominal aorta, celiac axis, and superior mesenteric artery - leads to abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting Iliac vessels - leads to claudication of the legs Renal arteries - leads to systemic hypertension Pulmonary artery - leads to pulmonary hypertension Coronary arteries (least commonly affected) - lead to myocardial infarction Investigations: Laboratory tests reveal an elevated ESR level, anemia, and elevated immunoglobulin levels. Arteriography is done as a confirmatory test. Treatment includes glucocorticoid therapy, methotrexate, immunotherapy with anti-TNF agents, and surgery.
subject: Medicine

question_text: In a patient with suspected Behcet's disease which of the following tests can be used to confirm the diagnosis?
explanation: Pathergy test can be used for confirming Behcet's disease. It is a nonspecific inflammatory skin reaction to scratch or intradermal saline injection and is a specific manifestation. The diagnostic criteria in Behcet's syndrome are the presence of recurrent oral ulcerations plus two of the following findings: Recurrent genital ulcerations Ocular lesions Skin lesions Positive pathergy test Option A: Foshay test is used in cat-scratch disease. Option B: Tzanck test is used to diagnose herpes infection. Option D: The cardiolipin antibody test is used to detect antiphospholipid antibodies.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 35-year-old woman presented with recurrent oral and genital ulcerations. An inflammatory skin reaction was observed after intradermal administration of normal saline. Which of the following statements is incorrect about her condition?
options: Associated with painless scarring oral ulcers
explanation: Recurrent oral and genital ulcerations with a positive pathergy test are suggestive of Behcet's syndrome. It is associated with oral ulcers that are painful and heal without scarring. Behcet's syndrome usually affects young individuals and is associated with HLA-B51 and anti-Saccharomyces cerevisiae antibodies. The clinical features of Behcet's syndrome include: Oral ulcers - painful, non-scarring Genital ulcers - painful, scarring Ocular involvement - scarring and bilateral panuveitis Skin involvement - folliculitis, acne-like rashes, erythema nodosum, and pyoderma gangrenosum Arthritis and peripheral vein thrombosis
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is a medium vessel vasculitis?
explanation: Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is a medium vessel vasculitis.

question_text: A 47-year-old man presented to the hospital with the findings shown in the image below. He also complained of pain in the upper and lower limbs. On examination, his BP was 160/100 mmHg and his peripheral pulses were palpable. Serology was negative for ANCA. What is the most probable diagnosis?
explanation: The most probable diagnosis is polyarteritis nodosa. The image shows the gangrene of the fingers. The presence of myalgia, the involvement of cutaneous vessels (gangrene with palpable peripheral pulses), renal vessels causing hypertension and serology negative for ANCA make polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) the most probable diagnosis. Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is necrotizing arteritis of the medium-sized blood vessels. It can affect the skin, peripheral nerves, renal vessels, mesenteric vessels, heart, and brain. Lungs are usually spared in PAN. The disease initially starts with non-specific symptoms like fever, malaise, arthralgia, and myalgia. Later, depending on the artery involved, patients may develop the following symptoms: Skin findings - ulcers, digital gangrene, and livedo reticularis Renal arteries - hypertension and renal failure Mesenteric arteries - abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, bleeding, and a bowel perforation Other options: Takayasu arteritis- It is a large vessel vasculitis. Also known as pulseless disease as it may be associated with weak upper extremity pulses. Microscopic polyangiitis- It is a small vessel vasculitis. It is positive for p-ANCA. Presentation is similar to granulomatosis with polyangiitis but without upper airway involvement. Cryoglobulinemic vasculitis- It is frequently associated with hepatitis C. Circulating cryoglubulins and rheumatoid factor can be found in blood. Most common clinical manifestations are cutaneous vasculitis, peripheral neuropathy, glomerulonephritis and arthritis.
subject: Medicine

question_text: In a patient diagnosed with polyarteritis nodosa which of the following arteries are characteristically spared?
explanation: Pulmonary arteries are characteristically spared in polyarteritis nodosa (PAN). PAN mainly involves renal and visceral arteries. Histopathology of the involved arteries usually shows the following findings: Transmural necrotizing vasculitis of the arteries and adjacent veins. Venules are spared. Renal arteries - arteritis without glomerulonephritis Fibrinoid necrosis Absence of granuloma and eosinophilia
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is true about polyarteritis nodosa?
explanation: One-third of polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) cases are associated with Hepatitis B. Other options: Option A: Polyarteritis nodosa is a systemic vasculitis which is associated with necrotizing inflammation of small and medium-sized muscular arteries. Option B: Patients show hypergammaglobulinemia. Option C: PAN is rarely associated with ANCA positivity. There is no serological test for PAN. Most patients exhibit an elevated leukocyte count with a predominance of neutrophils. PAN is usually seen in young adults, characterized by rapidly accelerating hypertension, abdominal pain, bloody stools, myalgias, and peripheral neuropathy. Arterial inflammation is segmental, necrotizing, and transmural, leading to aneurysms and thrombosis. The involved vessels are typically found at arterial bifurcations, spreading to veins but sparing venules. The most commonly affected organs are the kidney, heart, liver, and gastrointestinal tract, in that order. Pulmonary arteries are not involved. Inadequate blood flow leads to ischemia, ulcers, infarcts, atrophy, or hemorrhage. Diagnosis relies on histopathological findings from organ biopsies or the demonstration of aneurysms in small to medium-sized arteries of the renal, hepatic, and visceral vasculature. Untreated PAN has an extremely poor prognosis, with a 5-year survival rate of only 10 to 20%. Common causes of death include gastrointestinal complications, such as bowel infarcts and perforation, as well as cardiovascular issues. Timely treatment is vital for improved outcomes. Combining prednisone and cyclophosphamide has shown significant benefits in survival rates. Glucocorticoids alone may be sufficient for milder cases. In PAN cases associated with hepatitis B or C, antiviral therapy is combined with glucocorticoids and plasma exchange. Managing hypertension effectively can help reduce vascular complications. Despite successful treatment, relapses occur in approximately 10-20% of patients. What is the most common cause of vasculitis in children in India?
Henoch-Schonlein purpura
explanation: The most common cause of vasculitis in children in India is Kawasaki disease. Kawasaki disease has a higher incidence in children in the Indian subcontinent. question_text: Which of the following findings would you not expect in a patient diagnosed with small-vessel vasculitis?
explanation: Ischemic optic neuropathy associated with giant cell arteritis (large vessel vasculitis) can present as visual loss. Small vessel vasculitis is the inflammation of arterioles, capillaries, or venules. It starts with nonspecific symptoms like fever, fatigue, and arthralgia. Since it mainly affects the small vessels and capillaries present in the lungs, kidney, and skin, the majority of the patients will have: Hemoptysis Glomerulonephritis (hematuria, proteinuria) Palpable purpura

question_text: Which of the following structures is most commonly involved in cutaneous small-vessel vasculitis?
explanation: The structure most commonly involved in cutaneous small-vessel vasculitis is postcapillary venules. Cutaneous small-vessel vasculitis is defined as vasculitis which is limited to the small vessels of the skin. There is no systemic vasculitis and glomerulonephritis. It most commonly affects postcapillary venules. It is characterized by the presence of leukocytoclasis (presence of neutrophil debris in and around the blood vessels).

question_text: Which is the most common form of vasculitis associated with connective tissue disorders?
explanation: The most common form of vasculitis associated with connective tissue disorders is small-vessel venulitis. Connective tissue disorders that can cause vasculitis are: Systemic lupus erythematosus Rheumatoid arthritis Relapsing polychondritis Sjögren's syndrome

question_text: A pathology resident is examining biopsy specimens of patients with clinical features of vasculitis. In which of the following conditions would he report granulomatous inflammation of the vessels?
explanation: Biopsy findings of giant cell arteritis, Churg-Strauss syndrome, and Takayasu arteritis show granulomatous inflammation of vessels as they are granulomatous vasculitis. question_text: A 45-year-old woman presents with pain over the forehead aggravated on bending and occasional hemoptysis. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated ESR and red cell casts in the urine. Her serology is positive for cANCA. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario with cANCA positivity is suggestive of granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's granulomatosis). It is characterized by the involvement of the upper respiratory tract (sinusitis), lower respiratory tract (occasional hemoptysis), and kidneys (red cell casts). It is a granulomatous, necrotizing vasculitis of the small vessels that mainly affects: Upper respiratory tract- presenting with sinusitis, otitis media, and nasal septal perforation. Lower respiratory tract- presenting with hemoptysis. Kidney (glomerulonephritis)- presenting with proteinuria, hematuria, and hypertension. Apart from these organs, the disease can also affect the eye and skin. Skin lesions present as palpable purpura or subcutaneous nodules. Laboratory investigations show anemia, leucocytosis, elevated ESR, and ANCA positivity. Options A and C: In Goodpasture's syndrome and microscopic polyangiitis, the symptoms of upper respiratory tract involvement are very rare. Option D: Henoch-Schonlein purpura is commonly seen in children. It presents with palpable purpura, joint pain, abdominal pain, and glomerulonephritis.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A patient who presented with skin rashes, otitis media and hematuria has been diagnosed with granulomatosis with polyangiitis. Which of the following drugs would you not use in the management of this patient?
explanation: Abatacept is a disease-modifying antirheumatic drug (DMARD) used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis. Important drugs used in the management of granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's granulomatosis) are: Cyclophosphamide Rituximab (anti CD20 antibody) Glucocorticoids Methotrexate
subject: Medicine

question_text: A middle-aged woman presents with hemoptysis, proteinuria, and the clinical presentation given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario showing saddle nose deformity along with hemoptysis, and proteinuria is suggestive of granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's granulomatosis). Involvement of upper respiratory tract in granulomatosis with polyangiitis manifests as: Paranasal sinusitis, serous otitis media Nasal ulcers, purulent or bloody nasal discharge Nasal perforation leading to the destruction of septum and saddle nose deformity Subglottic tracheal stenosis
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is not a feature associated with Wegener's granulomatosis?
explanation: Wegener's granulomatosis is associated with necrotizing vasculitis. Wegener's granulomatosis predominantly affects the small blood vessels of the upper respiratory tract, lungs, and kidneys. Lung involvement will show multiple, bilateral cavitating nodules and pulmonary infiltrates on chest X-ray. The radiograph below shows cavitating nodules in a patient with granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's granulomatosis). Renal involvement initially appears as focal or segmental glomerulonephritis on biopsy. If left untreated, it can lead to rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN). Patients with Wegener's granulomatosis have an increased incidence of venous thrombosis, like deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism. The diagnosis is confirmed by the presence of necrotizing granulomatous vasculitis on biopsy. This finding is commonly seen in the tissues obtained from lungs, skin, upper airways, and rarely kidneys.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 57-year-old man presented with complaints of fever, weight loss, and hemoptysis. His serology was positive for pANCA and biopsy showed small vessel vasculitis with neutrophil infiltration. Which of the following is a feature associated with his condition?
explanation: The given clinical presentation along with pANCA positivity and biopsy findings of leukocytoclastic (neutrophil infiltration) vasculitis point towards a diagnosis of microscopic polyangiitis. It is associated with fibrinoid necrosis. Microscopic polyangiitis, also known as hypersensitivity vasculitis, causes segmental fibrinoid necrosis of small arterioles and venules. It is associated with neutrophil infiltration, and hence also called leukocytoclastic vasculitis. Histopathology of the affected tissue will show necrotizing vasculitis of arterioles, venules, and capillaries without any granulomas. It is caused by ANCA (antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies) and is not mediated by the immune complex. It primarily affects the kidneys and lungs.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following features is not useful to distinguish between microscopic polyangiitis and granulomatosis with polyangiitis?
explanation: Both microscopic polyangiitis and granulomatosis with polyangiitis are associated with necrotizing vasculitis. Hence, this feature is not useful to distinguish between them.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A triad of skin lesions, asymmetric mononeuritis multiplex and eosinophilia is seen in which of the following conditions?
explanation: A triad of skin lesions, asymmetric mononeuritis multiplex, and eosinophilia is seen in Churg–Strauss syndrome (eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis). It is a necrotizing vasculitis of the small-to-medium-sized vessels and in order to be diagnosed with Churg-Strauss, a patient should have evidence of asthma, peripheral blood and tissue eosinophilia (>1000 cells/L), extravascular granuloma formation and clinical features consistent with vasculitis. Common presenting symptoms of this condition are lower respiratory tract symptoms such as severe attacks of asthma, upper respiratory tract symptoms such as allergic rhinitis, sinusitis, and nasal polyps, mono neuritis multiplex (a type of peripheral neuropathy affecting at least two nerves) which presents with a complaint of pain, numbness, or weakness in the affected areas and skin lesions like palpable purpura and subcutaneous nodules. Renal involvement is less common and less severe than other small vessel vasculitis. P-ANCA antibodies are present in Churg Strauss syndrome. Severe attacks of asthma Mononeuritis multiplex: a type of peripheral neuropathy affecting at least two nerves. Patients will complain of pain, numbness, or weakness in the affected areas. Skin lesions like palpable purpura and subcutaneous nodules. Glucocorticoids show effective responses in these patients. Other drugs that have been tried are mepolizumab and rituximab. For fulminant multisystem disease, daily cyclophosphamide with prednisolone followed by azathioprine or methotrexate is used. Option A: Cryoglobulinemic vasculitis presents with palpable purpura, arthralgia, neuropathy, and glomerulonephritis. It is most commonly associated with Hepatitis C. Option B: Polyarteritis nodosa can also present with mononeuritis multiplex and skin lesions, but they do not have eosinophilia, it has predominant neutrophilia. Option D: Giant cell arteritis manifests with the cardinal symptom of headache localized to the temporal region. Common symptoms include headache, polymyalgia rheumatica , jaw claudication, fever, and decrease in body weight. Laboratory results show increased ESR, CRP levels, normochromic or mildly hypochromic anemia.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 47-year-old housewife presented with recurrent attacks of asthma and pain and numbness along the distribution of the median and ulnar nerve. Her serology was positive for pANCA. Further evaluation is unlikely to reveal which of the following findings?
explanation: The given clinical scenario of asthma, mononeuritis multiplex, and pANCA positivity is suggestive of Churg-Strauss syndrome (eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis). It affects small to medium-sized arteries. Laboratory investigations will show peripheral blood eosinophilia. Some patients may be positive for pANCA (antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies). Histopathology will show the presence of necrotizing vasculitis, tissue eosinophilia, and extravascular granulomas. Histopathology of ANCA associated vasculitides can be remembered as: Microscopic polyangiitis: necrotizing vasculitis Wegener's granulomatosis: necrotizing vasculitis with granulomas Churg Strauss syndrome: necrotizing vasculitis with extravascular granulomas and eosinophilia
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 6-year-old boy presents to the ER with colicky abdominal pain. His mother tells you that he refuses to walk due to knee pain. On examination, palpable purpura is noted. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical presentation of palpable purpura, colicky abdominal pain, and arthritis, point towards a diagnosis of Henoch Schonlein purpura (HSP) also known as IgA vasculitis. It is a small vessel vasculitis that occurs due to IgA immune complex deposition within the wall of the blood vessels. It is commonly seen in children and is characterized by: Palpable purpura without thrombocytopenia and coagulopathy. Arthralgia- commonly affecting hip, knee, or ankle joints. Abdominal pain Glomerulonephritis: proteinuria, microscopic hematuria, RBC casts in urine. The skin biopsy will show small vessel vasculitis, with IgA and C3 deposition in the affected organs by immunofluorescence. Option B: Hemolytic uremic syndrome is characterized by a triad of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury. Option C: Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) is characterized by fever of at least 2 weeks duration associated with arthritis, evanescent erythematous rash, hepatosplenomegaly, generalized lymphadenopathy, and serositis. Option D: Patients with IgA nephropathy or Berger's disease present with gross hematuria, often associated with a preceding or ongoing viral infection of the upper respiratory tract (synpharyngitic presentation).
subject: Medicine

question_text:
Cryoglobulinemia is associated with .
Hepatitis C
explanation: Cryoglobulinemia is associated with hepatitis C infection. Following Hepatitis C infection, there is an aberrant immune response leading to an immune complex formation containing hepatitis C antigens, polyclonal IgG specific to Hepatitis C, and monoclonal IgM rheumatoid factor, which triggers an inflammatory cascade results in Cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. Cryoglobulins are the immunoglobulins that precipitate at temperatures less than 37°C, the presence of these cryoglobulins in serum leads to Cryoglobulinemia, which is characterized by cutaneous vasculitis, palpable purpura, arthritis, peripheral neuropathy, and glomerulonephritis. Important conditions associated with cryoglobulinemia are: Hepatitis C Multiple myeloma Connective tissue disorders Lymphoproliferative disorders Crystal Arthropathies
subject: Medicine

question_text: A patient receiving anti-tubercular therapy has been recently diagnosed with gout. Which of the following statements is incorrect about this condition?
options: Most commonly involves the first MTP joint
explanation: In gout, the crystals are negatively birefringent on polarized light microscopy of the joint aspirate. Gout is a metabolic disease that is characterized by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals in joints and connective tissue. It is more common in males. It usually presents as monoarthritis that may be acute and episodic or chronic. Acute gout presents with a joint that is red, hot, swollen, and extremely tender on examination. The metatarsophalangeal joint of the great toe is the most frequently involved joint. Synovial fluid analysis of joint aspirate is diagnostic and shows the following features: Increased leukocyte count with a neutrophilic predominance Negatively birefringent crystals on polarized light microscopy of the synovial fluid Antitubercular drugs like pyrazinamide and ethambutol cause hyperuricemia by inhibiting uric acid excretion in the kidney. Monosodium urate crystals as seen on polarized light microscopy:

question_text: An elderly man presented to the OPD with painful swelling of his left big toe. Synovial fluid examination showed negatively birefringent needle-shaped crystals. What are these crystals made of?
explanation: The given clinical presentation and polarised microscopy showing negatively birefringent needle-shaped crystals point towards a diagnosis of gout. In gout, the negatively birefringent needle-shaped crystals are due to the deposition of monosodium urate crystals. Monosodium urate crystals in gout: Option A: Calcium apatite crystals can accumulate in areas of tissue damage, hypercalcemia, or hyperparathyroid states. Option C: Calcium pyrophosphate crystals are positively birefringent rhomboid-shaped crystals that are seen in pseudogout. Calcium pyrophosphate crystals seen in pseudogout: Option D: Ammonium urate crystals can cause urinary bladder stones which are radiolucent but may develop a calcific coating making it visible on X-rays.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following synovial fluid crystals cannot be identified using polarized light microscopy?
explanation: Calcium apatite crystals cannot be identified using polarized light microscopy. Polarized light microscopy can identify crystals such as: Monosodium urate Calcium pyrophosphate Calcium oxalate
subject: Medicine

question_text: A patient has a history of multiple episodes of painful swelling of ankles and big toes which is relieved with NSAIDs. You would avoid all of the following drugs in her except:
explanation: The given scenario of multiple painful swelling of ankles and toes that responded to NSAIDs is suggestive of gout. High-dose salicylates (>3g/day) do not precipitate gout. Although high-dose salicylates inhibit both the secretion and reabsorption of urate, the inhibition of reabsorption is more than the inhibition of secretion, and therefore the net effect is uricosuric. On the other hand, low-dose salicylates (<2 to 3g/day) are associated with uric acid retention. They inhibit renal tubular secretion of uric acid resulting in hyperuricemia and may precipitate gout. Aspirin is not used to treat acute attacks of gout due to its uric acid retention property. However, low-dose aspirin used for cardiovascular prophylaxis need not be discontinued during the treatment of a gout flare.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A patient with chronic gout now presented to the emergency room after sustaining trauma to his left foot. Identify the abnormality in his X-ray given below.
explanation: The given X-ray of a patient with chronic gout shows Martel's sign. Martel's sign also known as the G sign, or rat-bite erosion, refers to the punched-out lytic lesion and overhanging margin of the new bone along the edge of erosion seen in chronic tophaceous gout. Option A: Podagra is the inflammation of the base of the great toe (metatarsophalangeal joint) during flares of gout. It is not a radiological sign. Option C: Chopart's fracture is a fracture between talonavicular and calcaneocuboid joints. Option D: March fracture is fracture neck of 2nd or 3rd metatarsal. X-ray showing Martel's sign:

question_text: A 52-year-old man presented to the OPD with complaints of severe joint pain in his big toe with history of multiple similar episodes in the past. An ultrasound of the first metatarsophalangeal joint was performed. What is the characteristic finding depicted in the image given below?
explanation: The characteristic finding depicted in the given ultrasound image of a patient with chronic gout is the double contour sign. Double contour sign is characterized by an echogenic line on the outer surface of the joint cartilage, due to the deposition of monosodium urate crystals on the surface of articular cartilage. It is seen in chronic gout. Option A: Double wall sign also known as Rigler's sign is an abdominal radiograph finding seen in pneumoperitoneum. Here both the inner and outer walls of the bowel are visible. Option B: Double density sign on chest X-ray PA view is seen due to left atrial enlargement. Here, the right border of the left atrium becomes laterally displaced and convex producing this appearance. Option D: Double barrel sign is a USG finding seen in common bile duct (CBD) obstruction causing dilatation of CBD and its lumen size becomes comparable to portal vein giving the appearance of a double-barrel.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A middle-aged man presented to the ER with severe pain and swelling as shown in the image below. He told that he had consumed 2 bottles of beer a few hours before. Which of the following drugs is not used in the management of this patient?
explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of an acute attack of gout. Allopurinol is used in the management of chronic gout. Urate-lowering drugs such as allopurinol, probenecid, and lesinurad are not initiated during acute attacks. The treatment options for an acute attack of gout include: NSAIDs: Indomethacin, naproxen, ibuprofen, and diclofenac are highly effective Colchicine: It acts by inhibiting neutrophil migration and reduces inflammation. It is used orally and is most effective if given early in an attack. Glucocorticoids: Systemic glucocorticoids may be used in polyarticular involvement. If the disease is limited to one joint, intraarticular triamcinolone may be given.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following drugs is the best agent for the long-term treatment of chronic gout in a 50-year-old patient?
explanation: Allopurinol is the best agent for the long-term treatment of chronic or recurrent gout. Hypouricemic drugs that can be used for definitive treatment of chronic gout include: Xanthine oxidase inhibitors- allopurinol, febuxostat Uricosuric agents- probenecid, lesinurad Recombinant uricases- rasburicase and pegloticase
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 58-year-old man with history of gout is now diagnosed with hypertension. Which of the following is the drug of choice for this patient?
explanation: Losartan is the drug of choice for the management of hypertension in a patient with gout because of its uricosuric action. Thiazides (hydrochlorothiazide, metolazone) and loop diuretics (furosemide) cause reduced excretion of uric acid from the renal tubules and result in hyperuricemia. Therefore they are not preferred for management of hypertension in patients with gout.
subject: Medicine

question_text:
Which joint is most commonly affected in calcium pyrophosphate disease?
Wrist
explanation: The knee joint is most commonly affected in calcium pyrophosphate (CPPD) disease or pseudogout. Other sites include the wrist, shoulder, ankle, elbow, and hands. Acute CPPD arthropathy is commonly seen in the elderly and may be associated with conditions such as primary hyperparathyroidism, hypothyroidism, and hemochromatosis. ray of the affected joint may reveal chondrocalcinosis, which represents calcium deposition in articular cartilage. Polarised light microscopy of the joint aspirate demonstrates positively birefringent rhomboid crystals, as shown below: Sjogren's Syndrome and Scleroderma

question_text: What is the most common cause of secondary Sjogren's syndrome?
explanation: The most common cause of secondary Sjögren’s syndrome is rheumatoid arthritis. Sjögren's syndrome is a chronic autoimmune disorder that affects the lacrimal and salivary glands. It also affects other organ systems, such as lungs, kidneys, and nervous system. It is seen in association with: Rheumatoid arthritis Systemic lupus erythematosus Scleroderma Mixed connective tissue disease Primary biliary cirrhosis Vasculitis Chronic active hepatitis C
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which is the most common extraglandular manifestation seen in patients diagnosed with Sjogren's syndrome?
explanation: The most common extraglandular manifestation seen in patients with Sjögren’s syndrome is arthritis or arthralgia. The extraglandular manifestations in Sjögren’s syndrome are: Arthralgia or arthritis - most common manifestation. It is usually non-erosive and leads t Jaccoud's arthropathy. Jaccoud's arthropathy is a deforming non-erosive arthropathy characterized by the ulnar deviation of the second to 5th fingers with metacarpophalangeal joint subluxation. Raynaud's phenomenon Interstitial lung disease - most common type is non-specific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP) Renal tubular acidosis - Type 1 (distal) RTA Primary biliary cirrhosis Lymphoma - MALToma The give X-ray shows Jaccoud's arthropathy: The given image shows a patient with Jaccoud's arthropathy of the hands:

question_text: A middle-aged woman presented with complaints of persistent dry eyes and dry mouth since past few months. On examination, dry mucous membranes, bilateral parotid region swelling, and conjunctivitis were noted. This condition is associated with which of the following?
explanation: Dry eyes and dry mouth along with parotid swelling and conjunctivitis are suggestive of Sjögren’s syndrome. It is associated with HLA-DR3 allele. HLA allele Disease HLA DR2, HL A-DR3 SLE HLA-DR3 Sjogren's syndrome HLA-DR4 Rheumatoid arthritis HLA allele Disease HLA allele Disease HLA-B27 Seronegative arthritis

question_text:
A software engineer presented with complaints of dryness and itching of eyes on staring at his laptop screen. On examination, parotid swelling was noted and the test shown below was
positive. The serology of this patient is likely to be positive for which of the following antibodies?
explanation: The given scenario of dry eyes, parotid swelling, and a positive Schirmer test is suggestive of Sjögren's syndrome. It is associated with anti-Ro/SS-A and anti-La/SS-B autoantibodies. The presence of anti-Ro/SS-A and anti-La/SS-B indicate extra glandular involvement and poor prognosis. Note: Anti-Ro and anti-La in SLE indicate a good prognosis, due to decreased risk of nephritis and vasculitis.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 55-year-old woman presents with dry mouth, and difficulty swallowing solid food. Physical examination finds enlargement of her parotid glands along with marked dryness of her buccal mucosa. Laboratory examination finds the presence of both SS-A and SS-B antibodies. Which of the following statements is not true about this condition?
options: About 75% of patients have rheumatoid factor
Patients are at high risk for development of B-cell lymphomas
Lacrimal gland is a major target for this disease
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Sjogren's syndrome. In this condition, glomerular lesions are extremely rare. Defects of tubular function, including renal tubular acidosis, uricosuria, and phosphaturia, are often seen and are associated histologically with tubulointerstitial nephritis. Lacrimal and salivary glands are the major targets of this disease, while the respiratory and gastrointestinal tracts and the vagina may also be involved. The characteristic decrease in tears and saliva (sicca syndrome) is the result of lymphocytic infiltration and fibrosis of the lacrimal and salivary glands. The infiltrate contains predominantly activated CD4+ helper T cells and some B cells, including plasma cells. Antibodies detected are: Rheumatoid factor - seen in 75% of patients, whether or not coexisting rheumatoid arthritis is present Anti-nuclear antibodies (ANAs) SS-A (Ro) - associated with early disease onset, longer disease duration, and extra-glandular manifestations, such as cutaneous vasculitis and nephritis SS-B (La) These patients are at high risk for the development of B-cell lymphomas. About 60% of patients have another accompanying autoimmune disorder, such as rheumatoid arthritis, and these patients also have the symptoms and signs of that disorder. Biopsy of the lip (to examine minor salivary glands) is essential for the diagnosis of Sjögren's syndrome. The image shows an enlargement of the salivary gland with intense lymphocytic and plasma cell infiltration with ductal epithelial hyperplasia in the salivary gland. Note: Mikulicz syndrome is characterized by lacrimal and salivary gland enlargement from any cause, including sarcoidosis, lymphomas, and other tumors.
subject: Medicine

question_text:
A 35-year-old woman presented with complaints of thickening of her skin and the finding shown below. On workup, ANA was positive and immunofluorescence showed nucleolar pattern. What is the most common extracutaneous manifestation associated with her
condition?
explanation: The given image is suggestive of microstomia. The findings of skin thickening, microstomia, positive ANA, and immunofluorescence showing nucleolar pattern point towards a diagnosis of systemic sclerosis. The most common extracutaneous manifestation of systemic sclerosis (scleroderma) is Raynaud's phenomenon. Raynaud's phenomenon is characterized by episodes of reversible vasoconstriction in the fingers and toes on exposure to cold. Rarely, it affects the lips, tip of the nose, and earlobes. These episodes classically occur in the following sequence: Affected part turning pale due to vasoconstriction. Blue due to ischemia, often associated with numbness or pain. As blood flow returns, the area turns red with a burning sensation.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 14-year-old girl has the pallor of extremities followed by pain and cyanosis on exposure to cold. Which of the following diseases is she likely to develop in the later stages of life?
explanation: The above clinical scenario suggests that the patient has Raynaud phenomenon, which is associated with the risk of developing scleroderma in later stages of life. Raynaud phenomenon is manifested as episodic vasoconstriction of the arteries and arterioles of the extremities, causing pallor of extremities followed by pain and cyanosis. It is seen in virtually all patients with systemic sclerosis or scleroderma and precedes other symptoms in 70% of cases. The image shows features of Raynaud's phenomenon. Systemic sclerosis is characterized by progressive fibrosis involving the skin, gastrointestinal tract, and other tissues. Fibrosis may be the result of the activation of fibroblasts by cytokines produced by T cells. Focal, and sometimes diffuse, subcutaneous calcifications may develop, especially in patients with CREST syndrome. The most ominous manifestation is malignant hypertension.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following statements is false about Raynaud’s phenomenon?
options: Secondary Raynaud’s is associated with more severe symptoms
Secondary Raynaud’s develops predominantly after the age of 30 years
Primary Raynaud's is usually ANA negative
Primary Raynaud’s is associated with digital tissue necrosis and ulcers
explanation: Primary Raynaud's phenomenon is not associated with tissue necrosis and ulcers.
