question_text: Which of the following is false regarding lung cancer?
options: It is the most common cancer in Indian men
Tobacco smoking is the most common cause
Adenocarcinoma is the most common histologic type
It is the most common cause of cancer death
explanation: The most common cancer seen in Indian men is lip and oral cavity cancer, not lung cancer. Most common cancer: In men globally- Lung cancer In Indian men- Lip and oral cavity cancer In women globally- Breast cancer In Indian women- Breast cancer Tobacco smoking is a primary cause of the development of lung cancer. It increases 10 fold greater risk of developing lung cancer compared to those who have never smoked. It is the most common cause of cancer death.
subject: Medicine

question_text: What is the most common type of lung cancer in light smokers?
explanation: The most common lung cancer in light smokers (<10 pack-year history) is adenocarcinoma. WHO classification of lung carcinomas: The WHO classification system divides epithelial lung cancers into four major cell types: Small-cell lung cancer (SCLC) Non-small-cell lung carcinomas (NSCLCs) Adenocarcinoma Squamous cell carcinoma Large-cell carcinoma Adenocarcinoma is most commonly seen in: Lifetime non-smokers Light smokers (<10 pack-years history) Women Younger adults (<60 years) In smokers, the most common types are small-cell carcinoma and squamous cell carcinomas.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 60-year-old man with a 35 pack-year history of smoking presented for a routine check-up. His brother was diagnosed with lung cancer at a similar age. Which of the following would be preferred to screen him for lung cancer?
explanation: Low-dose CT/ thin-slice spiral chest CT would be preferred to screen him for lung cancer. He belongs to the high-risk population to develop lung cancer. The high-risk population is individuals whose age is 60 years and who have a smoking history of 10 pack-years. Low dose CT scans are shown to detect more lung nodules and cancers than the standard CXR in selected high-risk populations. Also, up to 85% of cancers thus detected are classified as stage I. Early staged cancers are considered potentially curable with surgical resection. Here, the aim is to reduce medical radiation exposure as much as possible, low dose CT is effective in screening for lung cancer, and is thus preferred.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is false about hypertrophic osteoarthropathy?
options: Platelets have a role in the development of HOA
HOA is commonly associated with lung malignancies
Skin changes are more common in secondary HOA
explanation: Skin changes are more common in primary HOA, not secondary HOA. Hypertrophic osteoarthropathy is a condition characterized by the clubbing of the digits. In advanced stages, it is characterized by the periosteal new bone formation and synovial effusion. The exact mechanism of its development is unclear. However, platelets are said to have a role in the development of HOA via platelet-derived growth factor. question_text: A middle-aged non-smoker presented with a dry persistent cough and hemoptysis. A CT scan showed a mass in the periphery of his right lung. A biopsy was taken, cells showed an acinar pattern with mucin formation. The cells were positive for thyroid transcription factor 1 and napsin A. What other feature is most likely to be seen in this patient?
explanation: The given clinical scenario along with the biopsy findings is suggestive of lung adenocarcinoma. It is most commonly associated with hypertrophic osteoarthropathy. Adenocarcinomas are mainly seen in the periphery of the lung. They grow in various patterns like acinar, lepidic, papillary, micropapillary, and solid with mucin formation. Cells are positive for markers like thyroid transcription factor 1 and napsin A. Option C: Hypercalcemia due to ectopic production of PTH-related peptide is seen in squamous cell carcinoma. Options B and D: However, SIADH, Cushing’s syndrome, Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome are associated with small-cell lung carcinoma.

question_text: A female patient comes with complaints of unintentional weight loss and right shoulder pain for the past 6 months. She reports that the pain radiates to her arm and is not relieved by NSAIDs. Chest X-ray is given below. Which nerve roots are likely to be compressed?
explanation: The given clinical scenario along with the X-ray findings is suggestive of Pancoast syndrome / superior sulcus tumor. This affects the C8, T1, and T2 nerve roots. It presents with pain that radiates to the ulnar distribution of the arm, often with the destruction of the 1st and 2nd ribs. Patients with the central or endobronchial growth of the primary tumor may present with a cough, hemoptysis, wheeze, stridor, dyspnea, or post-obstructive pneumonitis. Regional spread can cause Tracheal obstruction Esophageal compression with dysphagia Recurrent laryngeal paralysis with hoarseness Phrenic nerve palsy with the elevation of the hemidiaphragm and dyspnea Sympathetic nerve paralysis with Horner’s syndrome (enophthalmos, ptosis, miosis, and anhydrosis)

question_text: What is the treatment of choice in patients with adenocarcinoma of the lung with EGFR mutation?
explanation: Adenocarcinomas with EGFR mutation are exquisitely sensitive to tyrosine kinase inhibitors of the EGFR signal pathway such as gefitinib and erlotinib. Option A: Bevacizumab is a monoclonal antibody against VEGF. Option B: Paclitaxel- a taxane, is a plant alkaloid and chemotherapeutic agent. Option C: Imatinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor effective in the treatment of CML and GIST.

question_text: A 55-year-old man presents with persistent cough and hemoptysis. The intern notices that he has moon-like facies and purple striae on his abdomen. On evaluation, a chest X-ray revealed a mass in his right lung. Which of the following type of lung carcinoma could be the cause of this patient's features?
explanation: In the given clinical scenario the patient has features of Cushing's syndrome, secondary to small-cell lung cancer. This occurs due to ectopic ACTH production. It can also seen in pulmonary carcinoids. Most effective management is treating underlying SCLC or carcinoid.
subject: Medicine

question_text:
An elderly man was rushed to the ED with confusion and multiple episodes of vomiting. His wife reported that he had increased frequency of urination and constipation for the past 3
days. He is a known case of lung cancer. ECG showed a shortened QT interval. What could be the primary cause of his symptoms?
options: Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion
Ectopic secretion of PTH related peptide
explanation: The primary cause of his symptoms is ectopic secretion of PTH related peptide. Lung cancers are associated with several paraneoplastic syndromes. Squamous cell lung cancer is associated with hypercalcemia due to ectopic PTH related peptide. Hypercalcemia may present as vomiting, abdominal pain, constipation, increased frequency of urination, kidney stones, bone pain and shortened QT interval.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 62-year-old woman presents with vomiting, diarrhea, and decreased urine output since morning. On the previous day, she received chemotherapy for her stage 4 lung cancer. On examination, she is drowsy, HR-110/min and RR-30/min. All of the following biochemical findings can be seen in this patient except:
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of tumor lysis syndrome (TLS). It is associated with hypocalcemia, not hypercalcemia. TLS is caused by the destruction of a large number of rapidly proliferating neoplastic cells. It is usually seen within 1-5 days of receiving chemotherapy. It has also been observed with the administration of glucocorticoids, letrozole, tamoxifen, rituximab and gemtuzumab. Rarely, spontaneous necrosis of malignancies causes TLS. Clinical features: Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, lethargy Pruritus, renal colicky pain, oliguria Muscle cramps, carpopedal spasm, tetany Biochemical findings: Hyperuricemia Hyperkalemia Hypocalcemia Hyperphosphatemia Due to these biochemical changes, there is an increased risk of arrhythmias, acidosis, and acute kidney injury.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is not used in the management of patients with tumor lysis syndrome?
explanation: Sodium bicarbonate is not recommended in the treatment of tumor lysis syndrome (TLS). Urinary alkalinization by sodium bicarbonate decreases the solubility of xanthine, hypoxanthine, and calcium phosphate. This potentially increases the risk of intratubular crystallization. Management of TLS includes: Aggressive hydration Allopurino Rasburicase - recombinant urate oxidase Febuxostat - non-purine selective xanthine oxidase inhibitor
subject: Medicine

question_text:
Which of the following patients with non-small lung carcinoma is a suitable candidate to undergo a potentially curative surgical resection:
60-year-old smoker with a tumor within 2cm of carina
options: 55-year-old non-smoker with tumor involving the main pulmonary artery
57-year old light smoker with ipsilateral mediastinal node metastases
explanation: Patients with ipsilateral mediastinal node metastases are suitable candidates for curative resection. In patients with NSCLC, the following are contraindications to potentially curative resection: Extra-thoracic metastases Vocal cord involvement Superior vena cava syndrome Involvement of the main pulmonary artery Cardiac tamponade Phrenic nerve paralysis Malignant pleural effusion Tumor within 2 cm of the carina Metastasis to the contralateral lung Metastases to supraclavicular lymph nodes Contralateral mediastinal node metastases Sleep apnea

question_text: Sleep apnea is defined as a temporary pause in breathing during sleep lasting at least :
explanation: Sleep apnea is defined as a temporary pause in breathing during sleep lasting at least 10 seconds. Sleep apneas can be further divided into: Obstructive apneas - Sleep apnea with persistent respiratory effort. Central apneas - Sleep apnea with an absence of respiratory effort. The gold standard for the diagnosis of obstructive sleep apnea/hypopnea syndrome (OSAHS) is an overnight polysomnogram (PSG).
subject: Medicine

question_text: A patient is referred to the sleep clinic for polysomnography. Which of the following is not a component of it?
explanation: Arterial blood gases are not part of polysomnography. However, they are usually measured to rule out alveolar hypoventilation secondary to lung disease or chest wall abnormalities. An overnight polysomnogram is a multi-parametric test and is the gold standard for the diagnosis of obstructive sleep apnea. It includes: EEG Eye movements (EOG) Muscle activity or skeletal muscle activation (EMG) ECG Respiratory airflow and respiratory effort indicators Peripheral pulse oximetry Sleep latency Sleep efficiency Arousal index Other sleep disorders diagnosed by polysomnography: Narcolepsy Idiopathic hypersomnia Periodic limb movement disorder REM behavior disorder Parasomnias
subject: Medicine

question_text: A middle-aged obese patient presented with complaints of daytime tiredness and decreased exercise tolerance. Echocardiology revealed reduced ejection fraction. The sleep study showed periods of apnea without respiratory efforts. Which of the following is not true regarding his condition?
options: Transient cessation of neural drive to all respiratory muscles
Is due to decreased sensitivity to pCO2
Can be induced by CPAP at high pressure
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of central sleep apnea (CSA), and it is caused by increased sensitivity to pCO2. Thus changes in pCO2 levels during sleep lead to an unstable breathing pattern that manifests as hyperventilation alternating with apnea. Crescendo-decrescendo breathing pattern known as Cheyne-Stokes respiration is seen. Risk factors for CSA: Heart failure Opioid medications Hypoxia (e.g., breathing at high altitude) Continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) at high pressures seems to induce central apnea; this condition is referred to as complex sleep apnea.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following drugs is not a risk factor for the development of central sleep apnea?
explanation: Strychnine is not a risk factor as it does not cause respiratory depression. It is a CNS stimulant. Only drugs that cause respiratory centre depression are risk factors for the development of central sleep apnea. Option A: Opioids depress the respiratory centre in a dose-dependent manner. Option C: Barbiturates cause respiratory depression in high doses. Option D: Gelsemium is an ergot-type alkaloid and is a CNS depressant. Often used in homoeopathy, in large doses, paralysis and death from respiratory failure can occur. The pink shaded area shows an apneic period without any respiratory efforts.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A patient comes to the sleep clinic and the following pattern is seen on polysomnography. What type of breathing pattern is it?
explanation: The breathing pattern shown in the image is suggestive of Cheyne-Stokes respiration. It is characterized by progressively deeper and sometimes faster breathing, followed by a gradual decrease that results in a temporary stop in breathing called apnea. It is caused by an increased sensitivity of the respiratory center to arterial PCO2. There is an apneic phase, during which arterial PO2 falls and arterial PCO2 rises. These changes in the arterial blood gas content stimulate the respiratory center, resulting in hyperventilation and hypocapnia, followed by recurrence of apnea. It is present in 40% of patients with advanced HF and usually is associated with low cardiac output.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 40-year-old man presents with daytime sleepiness and impaired concentration and memory. On examination, his BMI is 41 kg/m2, blood pressure is 160/100 mm of Hg. His awake arterial blood gas analysis is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The most probable diagnosis of this patient is obesity hypoventilation syndrome. Obesity hypoventilation syndrome (OHS) or Pickwickian syndrome is defined as the presence of awake alveolar hypoventilation in an obese individual which cannot be attributed to other conditions associated with alveolar hypoventilation. Patients with OHS are obese and give a history of daytime hypersomnolence, loud snoring, choking during sleep, fatigue, impaired concentration, and memory. On examination usually, there is a small oropharynx and a thick neck. OHS may be associated with the following findings: Elevated serum bicarbonate (>27 mE˜/L) Hypercapnia (PaCO2 >45 mmHg) Hypoxemia (PaO2 <70 mmHg) Polycythemia Options A and D: In obstructive sleep apnea and central sleep apnea, the awake ABG values are usually normal. Option B: There are no ABG changes in narcolepsy.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 55-year-old man is brought to the OPD by his wife for gasping episodes during sleep and excessive daytime sleepiness. She reported that he even dozed off while driving yesterday and nearly caused an accident. He is being treated for hypertension, gastro-oesophageal reflux, and type 2 diabetes. What else would be the ideal therapy for his symptoms?
options: Implantable neuro-stimulation of the hypoglossal nerve
explanation: The given clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of obstructive sleep apnea/hypopnea syndrome (OSAHS). The ideal therapy is continuous positive airway pressure therapy (CPAP). Option A: Supplemental oxygenation can improve oxygen saturation but there is little evidence that it improves OSAHS symptoms. Option B: Uvulopalatopharyngoplasty is the most common surgery done in OSAHS but it is reserved for patients who cannot tolerate CPAP. Option D: Unilateral neuro-stimulation of the hypoglossal nerve through a surgically implanted device is a recently tested therapy for OSAHS. It can be used as an alternative in selected patients who cannot tolerate CPAP.
subject: Medicine

question_text:
Which of the following is not a component of Syndrome Z?
Obstructive sleep apnea
explanation: Syndrome Z is defined as a combination of obstructive sleep apnea syndrome with metabolic syndrome. LDL more than 100 mg/dL is not a criterion for the diagnosis of metabolic syndrome. Metabolic syndrome is diagnosed based on The NCEP: ATP III Criteria. Three or more of the following must be present : Central obesity: waist circumference >102 cm (M), >88 cm (F) Hypertriglyceridemia: triglyceride level 150 mg/dL or specific medication Low HDL cholesterol: <40 mg/dL and <50 mg/dL for men and women, respectively, or specific medication Hypertension: blood pressure 130 mmHg systolic or 85 mmHg diastolic or specific medication Fasting plasma glucose level 100 mg/dL or specific medication or previously diagnosed type 2 iabetes Urine Analysis

question_text: Urine sample of a patient has been collected for analysis. How soon should it be analyzed?
explanation: Urine samples should be analyzed within 2-4 hours after collection to avoid cell lysis and precipitation of solutes. If urine analysis is not possible in the given time, then the sample can be stored at 4-8 oC for a maximum of 12 hours. Urine samples can be collected using the following techniques: Midstream sample during spontaneous voiding Fresh specimen from an indwelling catheter Suprapubic needle aspiration of the bladder, especially in infants

question_text: All of the following determine the color of urine except:
explanation: The solubility of solutes is not a determining factor of the color of urine. Determinants of the color of urine are: Chemical content Concentration H (Normal pH is 4.5-8) The normal color of urine is pale straw due to the presence of urochrome.

question_text: Which of the following drugs can cause green-colored urine in a patient?
explanation: Green urine can be caused by triamterene, a potassium-sparing diuretic.

question_text: What value of urine specific gravity is called isosthenuria?
explanation: Isosthenuria is defined as a urine specific gravity of 1.010, which is similar to that of plasma. The normal specific gravity of urine is around 1.020 to 1.030. Specific gravity and osmolality are measures of the concentration or relative density of urine. Specific gravity: The weight of a solution relative to that of equal amounts of water. It is measured by refractometry or using reagent strips. Osmolality: The gold standard for relative density. It is defined as the number of osmoles of solute per kilogram of solvent. It is measured directly with an osmometer. Isosthenuria means that the kidney is neither concentrating nor diluting the urine. This is seen in chronic renal failure (CRF) and acute tubular necrosis (ATN). Abnormality Causes Isosthenuria CRF, ATN Abnormality Causes Hyposthenuria (low specific g ravity) Diabetes insipidus Hypersthenuria (high specific gravity) SIADH, Severe dehydrati on

question_text: A patient is being evaluated for the following appearance of his urine. A urine dipstick test is performed and the result is negative. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given image shows reddish discoloration of the urine sample. A negative urine dipstick indicates absence of RBCs and is suggestive of porphyria. A urine dipstick test is the first step to be done in a patient with high coloured urine to help identify true hematuria. A positive dipstick test identifies heme that is present in red blood cells, haemoglobin or myoglobin. A negative dipstick test implies that the reddish discolouration is due to pigments from certain food items (beetroot), drugs or porphyrias.

question_text: Which of the following patients are considered to have significant hematuria based on their urine analysis findings?
explanation: Hematuria is defined as the presence of 2-5 RBCs / high-powered field (HPF). It is considered significant or persistent in the presence of one of the following: RBCs > 3 / HPF on 3 or more occasions RBCs > 100 / HPF on 1 occasion Gross hematuria

explanation: Acanthocytes are a subtype of dysmorphic red blood cells with protruding blebs that are seen in glomerular disease. question_text: An 18-year-old boy presents to the clinic with a history of malaise. He was diagnosed with mild sensorineural hearing loss nearly 10 years ago. He also has a history of recurrent hematuria. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: This clinical scenario is suggestive of Alport syndrome. The clinical features include: Recurrent hematuria and nephritic syndrome Sensorineural hearing loss Anterior lenticonus Other causes of recurrent hematuria include: Alport syndrome IgA nephropathy Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) Papillary necrosis Renal cell carcinoma

question_text: Which of the following is true about proteinuria?
options: Proteinuria is always due to glomerular pathology
Albuminuria upto 150 mg/day is considered normal
Proteins are reabsorbed in the DCT
explanation: Nephrotic-range or heavy proteinuria refers to excretion of > 3.5 g/day or > 1000 mg/m2/day in children. Normally, the following mechanisms prevent proteinuria: The glomerular basement membrane acts as a barrier to prevent the loss of negatively charged and large proteins. Reabsorption of small proteins in the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT). The various types of proteinuria are: Glomerular - increased filtration of proteins due to disruption of basement membrane Tubular - damage to tubules prevents protein reabsorption in the PCT Overflow - excess production of low molecular weight proteins such as light chains Postrenal - infections or stones can lead to secretion of IgA and IgG by the urinary tract Type of Proteinuria Total proteinuria (mg/day) Albuminuria(mg/d ay) Normal-range <150MainlyTamm-Horsfallpr otein (•0-•5 mg/day) < 30 Moderately increased 150-500 30-300 Severely increased > 500 > 300 Orthostatic proteinuria 150-500 —

question_text: All of the following findings in a patient are suggestive of non-glomerular proteinuria except:
explanation: Non-glomerular proteinuria is characterized by the presence of N-acetyl glucosaminidase (NAG). This form of proteinuria occurs as a result of tubular injury. N-acetyl glucosaminidase (NAG) is a lysosomal enzyme present in the proximal tubular cells and is released into the urine following any injury to the tubules. ˜ow-molecular-weight proteins such as 2-microglobulin are normally reabsorbed in the PCT. When there is tubular injury, the proportion of these proteins in urine increases. This lowers the albumin: 2-microglobulin ratio in urine. question_text: A patient presents with recurrent kidney stones. The microscopic examination of urine is shown below. What is the type of stone seen in this patient?
explanation: The image shows a hexagonal crystal, suggesting cystine stones. These stones are a recurrent feature in patients with cystinuria. Crystals in urine are usually associated with kidney stones. Crystals form in the urine depends upon a variety of factors including: The degree of concentration of constituent molecules The urine pH The presence of inhibitors of crystallization Calcium oxalate and uric acid crystals can sometimes be found in normal urine that has been left to stand, due to crystal formation ex vivo.

question_text: Which of the following is incorrect about casts in urine?
options: Width of cast depends on the size of tubule in which it is formed
Casts in urine are specific to kidneys
Site of formation is proximal convoluted tubule
Casts are made up of uromodulin
explanation: The sites of formation of casts are the collecting ducts and DCTs (distal convoluted tubules). Casts are cylindrical structures formed by the aggregation of Tamm-Horsfall mucoprotein or uromodulin. This protein is secreted in the thick ascending loop of Henle. They assume the shape and size of the lumen in which they are formed. Several factors favour cast formation, such as urine stasis, low pH and high concentration. Casts are the only elements in urine sediments that are specifically of renal origin.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A patient with cryptococcal meningitis was started on amphotericin B. Two days later, he is found to have decreased urine output. Urinalysis reveals granular casts. What could be the possible diagnosis?
explanation: Muddy-brown granular casts are seen in acute tubular necrosis, a type of intrinsic renal failure. ATN can occur secondary to nephrotoxicity or hypovolemia.
subject: Medicine

question_text:
Which of the following casts are associated with a poor prognosis?
Epithelial casts
explanation: Broad casts are associated with a poor prognosis. They refer to wider waxy casts that are seen in advanced chronic kidney disease. It implies dilation of the tubules. Chronic Kidney Disease

question_text: Which of the following is not a risk factor for chronic kidney disease?
options: Large for gestational age at birth
explanation: Small for gestational age (SGA) at birth is a risk factor for chronic kidney disease (CKD), not LGA. Important risk factors for CKD or chronic renal failure are: SGA Childhood obesity Hypertension Diabetes mellitus Autoimmune disease Family history of kidney disease Previous episode of acute kidney injury Structural abnormalities of the urinary tract Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease

question_text: What is the most common cause of chronic kidney disease?
explanation: Diabetic nephropathy is the most common cause of chronic kidney disease (CKD). The leading causes of CKD in decreasing order of frequency are as follows: Diabetic nephropathy Glomerulonephritis Hypertension-associated CKD ADPKD (Adult or autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease)

question_text: Patients with which of the following conditions are unlikely to develop chronic renal failure?
explanation: Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) is least likely to cause chronic renal failure. It is a rapidly progressive condition and a cause of acute renal failure.

question_text: Which of the following parameters are used in the staging of chronic kidney disease?
explanation: Stages of chronic kidney disease (CKD) are stratified by estimated GFR (eGFR) and degree of albuminuria in order to predict the risk of progression of CKD. Serum creatinine is not directly used in the staging of chronic kidney disease. question_text: In patients with chronic kidney disease, at which stage do the complications of kidney failure start appearing?
explanation: The features of kidney failure become prominent as the GFR progressively declines to stages 3 and 4. The following complications occur as a result of loss of kidney function: Volume overload Hyperkalemia Metabolic acidosis Hyperphosphatemia Mineral and bone disorders Hypertension Anemia Dyslipidemia

question_text: A 66-year-old woman is being evaluated for new-onset uremic encephalopathy. What is her GFR likely to be?
explanation: Clinical features of uremia start to appear in patients with GFR < 15 mL/min/1.73 m2 or end-stage renal disease (ESRD). By this stage, renal clearance is severely impaired and the accumulation of uremic toxins leads to several complications including: Uremic encephalopathy Pruritus Malnutrition Anorexia, nausea, fatigue Platelet dysfunction Sexual dysfunction Pericarditis, pleuritis Peripheral neuropathy Stag e GFR(ml/ min/ 1.73 m2) Description 1 90 Normal or increased GFR wit h other evidence of Kidney D amage 2 60-89 A slight decrease in GFR, wit h other evidence of kidney da mage 3A 45-59 Moderate decrease in GFR wi th or without other evidence of Kidney Damage 3B 30-44 4 15-29 Severe decrease in GFR, with or without other evidence of kidney damage 5 <15 End-stage renal disease

question_text: Which of the following is incorrect about uremic syndrome?
options: It occurs due to accumulation of toxins
There is loss of kidney function and hormone regulation
Can be eliminated by removing urea through intensive dialysis
explanation: Uremic syndrome cannot be eliminated by removing urea alone. It is a complex condition occurring due to the accumulation of multiple toxins. The pathophysiology of uremic syndrome involves the following: Accumulation of toxins (uremia) - urea, creatinine, other products of protein metabolism like urates, hippurates, polyamines, indoles. Loss of kidney function leading to fluid and electrolyte imbalance and hormone dysregulation. Progressive systemic inflammation with vascular and nutritional impairment. Clinical features secondary to loss of kidney function tend to develop in parallel with declining GFR. However the features of uremia and, hence, uremic syndrome, usually occur only in stage 5 or ESRD.

question_text: A middle-aged woman with chronic kidney disease presents to the OPD with exercise intolerance, fatigue, and shortness of breath. On examination, she is found to have severe pallor. Which of the following is least likely to be a cause for these findings?
explanation: Sickle cell anemia is not a feature of chronic kidney disease (CKD). Common causes of anemia in CKD include: Erythropoietin deficiency Diminished red blood cell surviva Bleeding diathesis Iron deficiency Vitamin B12 and folate deficiency Hyperparathyroidism (due to bone marrow fibrosis) Hemoglobinopathy

question_text: Which of the following is not seen in patients with chronic renal failure?
explanation: Hyperthyroidism is not a feature of chronic renal failure. Option A: Peripheral neuropathy can occur secondary to uremia. Options C and D: In chronic renal failure, calcitriol (vitamin D3) production is decreased, leading to metabolic bone disease, which in turn leads to low serum calcium levels, secondary hyperparathyroidism, and osteomalacia.

question_text: What is the most common neurological disorder seen in patients with CKD?
explanation: The most common neurological disorder seen in patients with CKD is peripheral neuropathy. The various neuromuscular manifestations of CKD include: Memory and concentration impairment Dialysis dementia - due to aluminum intoxication Restless leg syndrome Peripheral neuropathy Hiccups Cramps Uremic encephalopathy Confusion and lethargy Tremors Myoclonus Asterixis Seizures Coma

question_text: A 27-year-old woman goes to her family doctor as she is unable to fall asleep at night. She complains of tingling and crawling sensations over her legs at night. She also feels a strong urge to move her legs, which relieves the symptoms for a while. Which of the following is incorrect about this condition?
options: Most common cause is chronic kidney disease
Most common movement disorder in pregnancy
explanation: This clinical scenario is suggestive of restless legs syndrome (RLS) or Willis-Ekbom disease. Chronic kidney disease (CKD) is not the most common cause of this condition. RLS is a neurological sleep disorder that can be primary or secondary. The primary form is more common. It shows autosomal dominant inheritance in most cases, but can be idiopathic. Secondary RLS is associated with the following: Iron deficiency Pregnancy - most common movement disorder Peripheral neuropathy Diabetes mellitus CKD Parkinson's disease Multiple sclerosis It is characterized by an uncontrollable, restless urge to move the legs. It tends to worsen during periods of inactivity and at evening or night. It is accompanied by crawling, tingling or burning sensations. These symptoms show partial or complete improvement with movement. This cycle may continue for a while and result in insomnia. Primary RLS is managed by improving sleep hygiene and dopamine agonists (pramipexole or ropinirole) if symptoms persist. Iron supplements can also be given. In secondary RLS, the underlying cause must be treated.
subject: Medicine

question_text: What is the most likely cause of convulsions in a patient with CKD?
explanation: The most likely cause of convulsions in a patient with CKD is water intoxication. Volume overload in these patients as well as damage to the blood-brain barrier by uremic toxins causes cerebral edema and seizures.
subject: Medicine

question_text: What is most common cause of mortality in patients with chronic kidney disease?
explanation: Cardiovascular disease is the leading cause of morbidity and mortality in patients at every stage of CKD.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following would be elevated in patients with chronic kidney disease?
explanation: Chronic kidney disease (CKD) is associated with elevated levels of fibrinogen. CKD is a pro-inflammatory state characterized by altered levels of acute-phase reactants (APR) Elevated levels of positive APR like CRP and fibrinogen (associated with high ESR). Reduced levels of negative APR like albumin and fetuin.
subject: Medicine

question_text: What is the predominant electrolyte abnormality seen in patients with advanced CKD?
explanation: High anion gap metabolic acidosis is the predominant electrolyte abnormality in a patient with advanced CKD. In advanced CKD, impaired renal functioning causes decreased urinary excretion of acids. These retained organic acids result in a high anion gap. In early CKD, potassium retention is associated with bicarbonate loss. This gives rise to hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis with a normal anion gap in early CKD. The following electrolyte abnormalities are seen in CKD: Hyperkalemia Hypocalcemia Hyperphosphatemia Hyperuricemia Hypermagnesemia Hypokalemia is uncommon in CKD and usually reflects markedly reduced dietary potassium intake, especially in association with excessive diuretic therapy or concurrent GI losses.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which among the following is the most life-threatening manifestation of CKD?
explanation: Of the given options, hyperkalemia is the most life-threatening complication of chronic kidney disease (CKD) as it can result in cardiac arrhythmias and sudden death. CKD is staged based on declining glomerular filtration rate (GFR) and albuminuria. The various clinical manifestations occur due to loss of kidney function and accumulation of various uremic toxins (urea, creatinine, and other products of protein metabolism). Complications of declining kidney function include: Volume overload Hyperkalemia Metabolic acidosis Hyperphosphatemia Mineral and bone disorders Hypertension Anemia Dyslipidemia
subject: Medicine

question_text: Patients with CKD have increased levels of all of the following except:
explanation: Serum estrogen levels are low in CKD patients. This leads to menstrual abnormalities and infertility. Option A: Plasma levels of insulin are elevated in CKD patients due to impaired clearance by the affected kidneys. Hence, insulin dose must be reduced in these patients. Option B: Elevated parathyroid hormone levels in CKD are secondary to derangements in the homeostasis of calcium, phosphate, and vitamin D. Option D: FGF-23 (fibroblast growth factor) is part of a family of phosphatonins that promotes renal phosphate excretion. The levels of this hormone increase early in the course of CKD.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A patient presents to the emergency with chest pain that is radiating to his shoulder, shortness of breath, and diaphoresis. He is a known case of chronic kidney disease. Which of the following investigations is best for diagnosis?
options: Troponin levels on admission and 1 hour later
Troponin and CK-MB levels at admission
explanation: This clinical scenario is suggestive of acute myocardial infarction (MI) in a patient with chronic kidney disease (CKD). A serial rise in cardiac troponin levels over 3-6 hours following presentation is needed to make a diagnosis. An interval of 1-hour is not considered sufficient. Minor chronic elevations in serum troponins are commonly observed in patients with CKD even in the absence of cardiovascular disease. Hence, a single elevated troponin value in such patients cannot be used to diagnose MI. CK-MB is far less sensitive and specific than troponins. Hence, it is not preferred.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is the most sensitive test to detect early diabetic nephropathy in a patient?
explanation: Microalbuminuria is the most sensitive and earliest finding of diabetic nephropathy. It refers to urine albumin of 30–300 mg/24-hour urine. It is seen in the stage of incipient diabetic kidney disease. However, microalbuminuria is a very variable finding and is not required to diagnose nephropathy. Non-albuminuric diabetic nephropathy may occur in some patients and regression of albuminuria may be seen in type 1 diabetics. Diabetic nephropathy can be diagnosed if the following are satisfied: Reduced GFR (< 60 mL/min/1.73 m2) with or without persistent albuminuria (> 30 mg/day or urine PCR > 30 mg/g) Long duration of diabetes or established diabetic retinopathy Other etiologies are ruled out
subject: Medicine

question_text: A patient with chronic kidney disease is found to have normal-sized kidneys on ultrasonography. Which of the following diagnoses is least likely?
explanation: Hypertensive nephropathy is unlikely in this patient as it usually presents with shrunken kidneys. Longstanding CKD due to most causes results in bilaterally small kidneys. Causes of CKD with normal size kidneys are: Diabetic nephropathy (kidney size may be increased at the onset) Amyloidosis HIV nephropathy
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 65-year-old hypertensive patient has recently been diagnosed with stage 3 chronic kidney disease. According to the ESC 2018 guidelines, what target blood pressure would you choose for this patient?
explanation: According to the ESC 2018 guidelines, the target blood pressure in hypertensive patients with CKD is < 140/ 80 mm Hg regardless of age.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 50-year-old man who has been on dialysis for 2 years presents with bone pain and bowing of legs. Further evaluation reveals hyperparathyroidism and hyperphosphatemia. What is the initial treatment of choice in this patient?
explanation: This clinical scenario is suggestive of secondary hyperparathyroidism (HPT) and hyperphosphatemia in a patient with CKD. Sevelamer is the best initial treatment for this patient. It is a phosphate binder that reduces the absorption of phosphate from the gastrointestinal tract. Other phosphate binders that can be used include: Calcium containing Calcium acetate Calcium carbonate Non-calcium containing Sevelamer Lanthanum Calcitriol and cinacalcet are used to decrease PTH levels in secondary hyperparathyroidism. However, they also cause increased serum phosphate levels. Hence, they should not be given as initial treatment in patients with hyperphosphatemia. Bisphosphonates like pamidronate are used in the treatment of primary hyperparathyroidism.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is the most appropriate definitive treatment for anemia in patients with chronic kidney disease?
explanation: Anemia in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) is primarily due to decreased erythropoietin production. Hence, human recombinant erythropoietin (EPO) such as darbepoetin is the most appropriate treatment and is considered the mainstay. However, an optimal response to treatment with EPO occurs only when iron stores are adequate. Hence, iron supplements (oral or IV) must be given first to ensure the effectiveness of EPO therapy. Other treatment options for anemia in CKD are: Vitamin B12 and folate supplementation Blood transfusion - in severe anemia and failure to EPO therapy
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following should not be used in a patient with CKD?
explanation: Diclofenac should not be used in a patient with CKD as it is nephrotoxic. Renal blood flow is regulated by prostaglandin E2. Aspirin, diclofenac and other NSAIDs inhibit cyclooxygenase. This decreases prostaglandin E2 concentration, thereby causing a reduction in blood flow and GFR. Nephrotoxic drugs include the following: NSAIDs Antifungals (amphotericin B) Antibiotics Aminoglycosides Vancomycin Cephalosporins Sulfonamides Streptomycin Antivirals Acyclovir Foscarnet Chemotherapy drugs Methotrexate Platins Immunosuppressants (cyclosporine)
subject: Medicine

question_text:
A 50-year-old man with type 2 diabetes has developed stage 4 CKD secondary to diabetic nephropathy. He currently takes insulin for his diabetes. What changes need to be made to his regimen?
No adjustment required
explanation: In CKD patients with diabetes, the dose of insulin must be reduced. In CKD patients, the plasma levels of insulin are elevated due to diminished renal degradation of insulin by the impaired kidney. This impaired renal clearance of insulin can lead to hypoglycemia. Hence, the dose of insulin must be reduced to prevent this. Acute Kidney Injury

question_text: Which of the following criteria is diagnostic of acute kidney injury in a patient?
options: Rise in creatinine 1.5 times the baseline value within 7 days
Rise in creatinine  0.3mg/dl from baseline within 7 days
Rise in creatinine  0.5 mg/dl from baseline within 48 hours
explanation: A rise in creatinine 1.5 times the baseline value within 7 days is diagnostic of acute kidney injury (AKI). AKI is an abrupt decrease in kidney function within hours to days. According to the KDIGO definition, it is defined as any of the following: Increase in serum creatinine by 0.3 mg/dL within 48 hours OR Increase in serum creatinine to 1.5 times the baseline within 7 days OR Urine volume <0.5 mL/kg/h for 6 hours.

question_text: Patients with urine output below what level are said to have anuria?
explanation: Anuria is defined as urine output less than 100 mL/day. Oliguria is defined as urine output less than 400 mL/day. Acute kidney injury (AKI) can have varied clinical features depending on the etiology. The history and physical examination in AKI aims mainly at: Finding the etiology Identifying the occurrence of any complications The following clinical features may be seen: Oliguria or anuria Gross hematuria Renal colic pain (in renal stones) Loss of skin turgor, dry mouth, hypotension, tachycardia (in hypovolemia) Prostatomegaly and/or a pelvic mass (in post-renal obstruction) Dysuria, fever with chills and rigors, increased frequency of micturition, renal angle tenderness (in pyelonephritis) Edema, hypertension (volume overload) Encephalopathy, seizures, platelet dysfunction (uremia)
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following causes prerenal AKI?
explanation: NSAIDs, Rhabdomyolysis and ACE inhibitors cause prerenal acute kidney injury (AKI). The use of NSAIDs causes reduced production of vasodilatory prostaglandins. This leads to decreased renal perfusion and glomerular capillary pressure. NSAIDs can also lead to acute interstitial nephritis, a cause of renal AKI. However, this is relatively uncommon. ACE inhibitors cause inhibition of efferent arteriole vasoconstriction, leading to reduced renal perfusion. Rhabdomyolysis causes AKI by both prerenal mechanisms (due to volume sequestration) and ATN (due to precipitation of myoglobin in the renal tubules). Nephrotoxins like myeloma light chains, snake venom, myoglobin (due to rhabdomyolysis) cause acute tubular necrosis (ATN). This leads to renal or intrinsic AKI.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 48-year-old woman presented with severe abdominal pain, vomiting, and dark-coloured urine for the past 3 days. She has been on a combination painkiller for rheumatoid arthritis for 10 years. On examination, severe pallor was noted and BP was 180/120 mmHg. CT abdomen is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
explanation: This clinical scenario and CT scan showing papillary calcifications are highly suggestive of chronic kidney disease caused by analgesic nephropathy. This condition is more common in females secondary to excessive prolonged use of a combination of analgesics. The mechanism of injury is medullary hypoxia leading to papillary necrosis and finally causes chronic tubulointerstitial nephritis. Patients can remain asymptomatic for a long time. Sloughing or obstruction of papillae can cause abdominal pain and hematuria. It increases the risk of urothelial malignancies. The following CT findings can be seen: Papillary calcifications Small kidneys Irregular contour Note: NSAID-induced nephropathy causes acute interstitial nephritis. It is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction. The features include non-oliguric AKI, fractional excretion of sodium (FeNa) < 1, and hyperkalemia. It is seen within a few days of use and is reversible. explanation: The given clinical scenario is highly suggestive of prerenal AKI based on the following: Urine osmolality >500 mOsm/kg Urinary sodium < 20 meq/ BUN: Creatinine ratio of 20:1 Differences between prerenal, and renal AKI: Indices Prerenal Renal Spot urine sodium (mEq/L) <20 >40 Fractional excretion of sodiu m (FENa) <1% >2% Fractional excretion of urea ( FEUrea) <35% >35% Urine osmolality (mOsm/kg) >500 <350 BUN to serum creatinine rati o >20:1 <10:1 Urine creatinine/plasma creat inine >40:1 <20:1 Urinary sediment Nil or hyaline casts only Renal tubular epithelial casts, muddy brown granular casts

question_text: A 35-year-old man was admitted following a crush injury to his left leg. Two days later, his urine/plasma creatinine levels are < 20. What is the likely cause?
explanation: This clinical scenario and urine/ plasma creatinine ratio of <20 is suggestive of renal AKI due to rhabdomyolysis-induced acute tubular necrosis. Rhabdomyolysis is a serious complication of crush injuries. It leads to muscle breakdown, releasing a high amount of myoglobin in the blood. Myoglobinuria can lead to acute kidney injury by the following mechanisms: Direct toxic effect of myoglobin and heme on the PCT Tubular obstruction by precipitation of pigmented casts Renal vasoconstriction can cause FeNa < 1 (unlike other renal causes of AKI) Indices Prerenal Renal Spot urine sodium (mEq/L) <20 >40 Fractional excretion of sodiu m (FENa) <1% >2% Fractional excretion of urea ( FEUrea) <35% >35% Urine osmolality (mOsm/kg) >500 <350 BUN to serum creatinine rati o >20:1 <10:1 Urine creatinine/plasma creat inine >40:1 <20:1 Urinary sediment Nil or hyaline casts only Renal tubular epithelial casts, muddy brown granular casts
