question_text: Which of the following is unlikely in patients with atheroembolic kidney disease?
explanation: Atheroembolic kidney disease is associated with decreased complement levels. Atheroembolic kidney disease is more frequent in males with a history of diabetes, hypertension, and ischemic heart disease. Most clinical atheroembolic events follow angiographic procedures, often of the coronary vessels. It is associated with aortic aneurysms and renal artery stenosis. Systemic embolic manifestations such as fever, abdominal pain, and weight loss are also present, although cutaneous manifestations are more common like livedo reticularis and localized toe gangrene. The lab findings include: Rising serum creatinine Transient eosinophilia Elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate Hypocomplementemia Definitive diagnosis depends on kidney biopsy which demonstrates microvessel occlusion with cholesterol crystals that leave a cleft in the vessel as shown below.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 50-year-old patient is being evaluated for uncontrolled hypertension despite being on 3 antihypertensive drugs. He has a history of myocardial infarction which was managed with percutaneous intervention last month. On examination, an abdominal bruit is noted. Lab values indicate elevated serum urea and creatinine. Which of the following investigations is the gold standard test to diagnose this condition?
explanation: This clinical scenario is suggestive of renal artery stenosis. Renal intra-arterial angiography is the gold standard for diagnosis.In a patient with hypertension and increased creatinine, an ultrasound of the abdomen must be performed first to visualize the renal size and morphology to look for a unilateral shrunken kidney and thereby renal artery stenosis. Option A: MR angiography is less preferred as gadolinium contrast can lead to nephrogenic fibrosis, particularly in patients with reduced kidney function. Option C: CT scan with image reconstruction provides an excellent image but also carries a risk of contrast nephropathy. Option D: Renal arterial doppler ultrasound measures renal artery velocities and can predict hemodynamically important lesions. However, it is not the gold standard test. Duplex ultrasonography is used as a screening investigation.
subject: Medicine

question_text:
Which of the following drugs must be avoided in patients with bilateral renal artery stenosis?
ACE inhibitors
explanation: ACE inhibitors must be avoided in patients with bilateral renal artery stenosis (RAS). In renal artery stenosis, blood flow to the kidney is reduced, thereby reducing blood flow to the afferent arterioles. Hence, constriction of efferent arterioles is needed to maintain hydrostatic pressure within the glomerulus in order to maintain GFR. ACEIs and ARBs inhibit efferent renal arteriolar vasoconstriction. In bilateral RAS, this causes a decline in the GFR within a few days of starting the drug. Note: Bilateral renal artery stenosis has been classically considered as an absolute contraindication to the use of ACE inhibitors. However, new studies show that they may be used in some cases with careful monitoring. Diagnosis of cardiovascular disorders
subject: Medicine

question_text: 'a' wave in JVP corresponds to?
explanation: The "a" wave in jugular venous pressure (JVP) is a positive wave, which corresponds to right atrial contraction. The waveforms seen in a normal JVP are: a wave corresponds to atrial contraction and occurs just after the P wave (on ECG) and just before the first heart sound. c wave represents the bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during ventricular systole. x descent corresponds to the atrial relaxation during atrial diastole. v wave represents atrial filling during ventricular systole and peaks at the second heart sound. y descent represents passive emptying of the right atrium into the right ventricle after tricuspid valve opening.
subject: Medicine

question_text: The c wave seen in a normal JVP waveform represents?
options: Bulging of tricuspid valve into the right atrium
Venous filling of the right atrium
Emptying of the right atrium into the right ventricle
explanation: The c-wave in a JVP waveform represents the bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during ventricular systole. JVP measured in the internal jugular vein is a reflection of the right atrial pressure. The waveforms seen in a normal JVP are: a wave corresponds to atrial contraction and occurs just after the P wave (on ECG) and just before the first heart sound. c wave represents the bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during ventricular systole. x descent corresponds to the atrial relaxation during atrial diastole. v wave represents atrial filling during ventricular systole and peaks at the second heart sound. y descent represents passive emptying of the right atrium into the right ventricle after tricuspid valve opening.
subject: Medicine

question_text: The following abnormality on a JVP waveform can be seen in which of the given conditions?
explanation: The given waveform shows a cannon ‘a’ wave seen in ventricular tachycardia. It occurs since atria contract against a closed tricuspid valve in ventricular tachycardia. JVP measured in the internal jugular vein is a reflection of the right atrial pressure. Note: Giant/prominent a-waves occur during every beat while cannon a-waves result from arrhythmias, therefore, are usually intermittent. The ECG is helpful to look for rhythm disturbances that are associated with cannon a-waves whereas echocardiography can be used to assess structural defects (of right atrium) that are associated with giant a-waves.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 37-year-old male patient comes to the clinic with complaints of weakness, restlessness, and chest pain. On examination, his blood pressure is found to be 90/60 mmHg, his heart sounds are muffled, and his neck veins are distended. What is the typical JVP finding in this patient?
explanation: Hypotension, soft or absent heart sounds, and jugular venous distention (Beck’s triad) are the three principal features of cardiac tamponade. The typical JVP finding here is absent y-descent. JVP shows a prominent x (early systolic) descent and an absent y (early diastolic) descent because of the ventricle's limited or absent early diastolic filling. JVP is almost always elevated in cardiac tamponade and may be associated with venous distention in the forehead and scalp. There may be reductions in the amplitude of the QRS complexes, and electrical alternans of the P, QRS, or T waves in cardiac tamponade. Note: Alternation of QRS complexes, usually in a 2:1 ratio, on ECG is called electrical alternans. It is caused by the movement of the heart in the pericardial space. Electrical alternans is also seen in patients with myocardial ischemia, acute pulmonary embolism, and tachyarrhythmias.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Deep y descent in JVP is seen in all except:
explanation: The y-descent in jugular venous pulse (JVP) corresponds to the fall in right atrial pressure after the tricuspid valve opening in the early diastolic phase of the right ventricle. Y-descent is attenuated or absent in cardiac tamponade because of resistance to ventricular filling in the early diastole. Other options: Options B and C: Restrictive cardiomyopathy and constrictive pericarditis can have deep y descent due to rapid filling of the right ventricle during early diastole. Option D: In patients with tricuspid regurgitation, increased blood flow to the right atria through the incompetent tricuspid valve during ventricular systole results in a prominent v wave. When the tricuspid valve opens during ventricular diastole, this increased blood in the right atria enters rapidly into the right ventricle during early diastole resulting in deep y-descent.
subject: Medicine

question_text: The following four patients were examined on a tilt table for postural hypotension. The blood pressures before and immediately after performing head-up tilt are given below. Choose the correct option regarding the patients who suffer from orthostatic hypotension.
explanation: Orthostatic hypotension is defined as a reduction in systolic blood pressure of at least 20 mmHg or diastolic blood pressure of at least 10 mmHg within 3 min of standing or head-up tilt on a tilt table. On standing, blood is displaced to the lower extremities, causing a drop in the venous return to the heart. This drop leads to a decrease in cardiac output and stimulation of compensatory mechanisms which trigger a reflex increase in sympathetic (vasoconstrictor) outflow. Orthostatic hypotension is a manifestation of sympathetic (autonomic) failure. Symptoms include light-headedness, dizziness, and presyncope (near-faintness) in response to sudden postural change.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Pulsus paradoxus is seen in all of the following except:
explanation: Pulsus bisferiens is seen in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, not pulsus paradoxus. Pulsus paradoxus refers to the fall in systolic pressure by > 10 mmHg with inspiration. It is an exaggeration of the normal response. It is seen in the following conditions: Cardiac tamponade Massive pulmonary embolism Hemorrhagic shock Obstructive lung disease Tension pneumothorax
subject: Medicine

question_text: Pulsus bisferiens is seen in all of the following conditions except:
explanation: Pulsus alternans (characterized by alternating strong and weak beats) is seen in left ventricular dysfunction. Pulsus bisferiens is a bifid pulse with two systolic peaks. It is seen in the following conditions: Advanced aortic regurgitation (AR) Aortic stenosis (AS) with AR Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
subject: Medicine

question_text: Water hammer pulse is seen in which of the following conditions?
explanation: Water hammer pulse, also known as Corrigan’s pulse, is characterized by a sharp rise and a rapid fall-off and is seen in aortic regurgitation (AR) due to the fact that arterial pressure falls rapidly in late systole and early diastole. In AR, the pulse pressure is widened due to systolic hypertension and decreased diastolic pressure. The diastolic pressure is measured at Korotkoff phase IV. In certain patients with AR or a combination of aortic stenosis (AS) and AR, the carotid arterial pulse may exhibit a bisferiens pattern, characterized by two systolic waves separated by a trough. The apical impulse is heaving and displaced inferiorly. A diastolic thrill may be palpable along the left sternal border. A2 is usually absent in AR. An early diastolic murmur can be auscultated in chronic AR. It is best heard in the third intercostal space along the left sternal edge. Severe AS (Option A) would show pulsus parvus et tardus, characterized by the carotid pulse rising slowly to a delayed peak. Chronic mitral regurgitation (Option D) shows a sharp, low volume upstroke due to reduced cardiac output and acute mitral regurgitation demonstrates narrow pulse pressure.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A loud S1 is associated with?
explanation: Rheumatic mitral stenosis is associated with loud S1. The greater the distance the valve travels to close, the louder is the sound. Increased left atrial pressures in rheumatic mitral stenosis force the mobile portion of the mitral valve leaflets far apart such that they are forced closed from a relatively far distance, resulting in a loud S1. In calcific mitral stenosis, leaflet mobility is poor, and they are not separated by a large distance, resulting in a soft S1. Loud S1 is heard in the following: Short PR intervals Early stages of mitral stenosis as long as the valves are pliable Atrial myxoma High output states Tachycardia Soft S1 is heard in the following: Mitral regurgitation Aortic regurgitation Long PR intervals Calcified Mitral stenosis Left ventricular contractile dysfunction Beta-receptor blockers ericardial effusion, obesity, COPD- due to decreased conduction through the chest wall
subject: Medicine

question_text: A hypertensive patient presented with chest pain and was found to have dilated cardiomyopathy on an echocardiogram. On auscultation, a reversed splitting of second heart sound was heard. Which of the following could most likely be responsible for the same?
explanation: Reversed (or paradoxical) splitting refers to the situation when P2 is heard before A2. This is seen in the following: LBBB HOCM Right ventricular pacing Severe AS Acute myocardial ischemia
subject: Medicine

question_text: Disappearance of loud S1 in mitral stenosis occurs in all except:
explanation: Loud S1 is heard in mild mitral stenosis (MS). The intensity of S1 depends on the distance over which the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve moves, leaflet mobility, LV contractility, and PR interval. It is independent of the severity of MS. Loud S1 is seen in early rheumatic MS, short PR interval, and hyperdynamic circulatory states. S1 becomes soft in case of calcified leaflets, long PR interval, associated aortic regurgitation and LV dysfunction.
subject: Medicine

question_text: While examining a patient, you hear a widely split S2 on auscultation. Which of the following is not a possible diagnosis?
explanation: A wide split of S2 is not seen in the left bundle branch block (LBBB), however paradoxical splitting is seen. S2 is normally heard as A2-P2. This split is exaggerated in conditions that cause early aortic valve closure or delayed pulmonary valve closure. Option A: In atrial septal defect (ASD), left ventricle (LV) ejection time decreases due to the shunting of the blood from the left atrium (LA) to the right atrium leading to early aortic valve closure. Option B: In mitral regurgitation (MR), due to the regurgitation of blood from the LV to the LA, the LV ejection time decreases leading to early aortic valve closure. Option C: In pulmonary stenosis (PS), the delayed closure of pulmonary valves leads to the splitting of S2. Wide splitting of S2 is also heard in RBBB and LV pacing.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following conditions is associated with a fixed wide splitting of S2?
explanation: Fixed wide splitting of S2 is seen in atrial septal defect (ASD). The ASD creates a left to right shunt that increases the blood flow to the right side of the heart. This causes the pulmonary valve to close later than the aortic valve independent of inspiration/expiration.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following statements is true?
options: S3 and S4 are high pitched systolic sounds
S4 is heard during the ventricular-filling phase
S3 occurs due to rapid filling of the ventricles during atrial systole
explanation: S4 is heard during the ventricular-filling phase. S3 and S4 are diastolic sounds that are low pitched, and best heard with the bell of the stethoscope at the cardiac apex in the left lateral decubitus position. The presence of an S3 and S4 heart sound is called a summation gallop and sounds like a galloping horse. S3 - Ventricular gallop S4 - Atrial gallop Occurs during early ventricul ar diastole Occurs near the end of ventri cular diastole During the first rapid ventric ular filling During active ventricular filli ng (filling by atrial contra ction) Due to a sudden rush of bloo d entering a volume-depleted ventricle (normal ventricular compliance) Due tovibration of the ventric ular wall during atrial contra ction because of increased sti ffness of ventricular walls (de creased ventricular complian ce) Itcan be physiologicalin child ren and young adults. Always pathological In older patients, it indicates systolic heart failure Indicates diastolic heart failu re
subject: Medicine

question_text: An ECG of a patient who underwent pulmonary artery catheterization showed a right bundle branch block. On auscultation, a widely split S1 was observed. Which of the following is true regarding this auscultatory finding?
options: The split remains constant with inspiration and expiration
The change in split depends on the degree of bundle branch block
explanation: In a patient with a right bundle branch block (RBBB), there's a widely split S1 which increases with inspiration. S1 is normally heard as a single sound. Any delay in the closure of the tricuspid valve or early closure of the mitral valve produces a split in S1. During inspiration, venous return to the right atrium increases. Therefore, the atria take a longer time to empty into the ventricles delaying the closure of the tricuspid valve. This increases the split in S1 during inspiration. In a patient with an RBBB, the tricuspid valve closure is further delayed leading to a wide split in S1.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 23-year-old woman presents with a history of occasional palpitations. She has no history of chest pain or dyspnea. On examination, blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg, the pulse is 82/min and regular. Joint hypermobility and thoracolumbar scoliosis are present. Gorlin's sign is positive. On auscultation, a click is heard after S1, followed by a late systolic murmur. What is the probable diagnosis?
explanation: The probable diagnosis of the above scenario is Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS). EDS is a group of clinically and genetically heterogeneous connective tissue disorders. Typical presenting features include joint hypermobility, skin hyperextensibility, and tissue fragility. EDS type 6 is also characterized by scoliosis. Gorlin’s sign refers to the ability of patients of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome to touch the tip of the nose with the tip of their tongue. Mitral valve prolapse (MVP) is a frequent finding in patients with EDS. An early systolic click which may be followed by a late systolic murmur is the auscultatory finding heard in MVP.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is not a diastolic sound?
explanation: The ejection click is a systolic sound. Ejection clicks are high-pitched sounds that occur at the moment of the maximal opening of the aortic or pulmonary valves. They are heard just after the first heart sound. Ejection clicks occur in: Non-calcific aortic or pulmonary stenosis Aortic or pulmonary root dilatation Congenital bicuspid aortic or pulmonary valves Nonejection clicks, which occur after the onset of the carotid upstroke, are related to the mitral valve prolapse.
subject: Medicine

question_text: On auscultation of a patient, you hear a murmur between S1 and S2. Which of the following conditions is not likely to be associated with this finding?
explanation: A murmur occurring between S1 and S2 is a systolic murmur. Pulmonary regurgitation produces a diastolic murmur. The causes of systolic murmurs are as follows: Mid-systolic- aortic stenosis, pulmonic stenosis, ASD, HOCM. Holosystolic/pansystolic- mitral regurgitation, tricuspid regurgitation, VSD. Late systolic- mitral valve prolapse. The causes of diastolic murmurs are as follows: Early diastolic- aortic regurgitation, pulmonic regurgitation. Mid/late diastolic- mitral stenosis, tricuspid stenosis, Austin-Flint. The causes of continuous murmurs are as follows: atent ductus arteriosus (machinery or Gibson's murmur). Venous hum AV fistula Ruptured sinus of Valsalva aneurysm
subject: Medicine

question_text: While examining a patient, you hear a mid-diastolic murmur with presystolic accentuation on auscultation of the precordium. Which of the following condition is associated with this finding?
explanation: A mid-diastolic murmur with presystolic accentuation and an opening snap is typically seen in mitral stenosis. The presystolic accentuation is due to the atrial contraction forcing blood through the stenosed mitral valve. The presystolic accentuation disappears in atrial fibrillation. Option A: Mitral regurgitation presents with a holosystolic murmur, best heard at the apex with radiation to the left axilla. Option B: Mitral valve prolapse presents with an early systolic click followed by a late systolic murmur is heard. Option C: Aortic stenosis presents with a harsh crescendo-decrescendo ejection systolic murmur heard best at the right upper sternal border, with radiation of the murmur to the carotid arteries.
subject: Medicine

question_text: You are a part of a health camp conducting check-ups for cardiovascular ailments. On auscultation of a patient's precordial area, you hear a systolic murmur. On asking the patient to perform the following maneuver, the intensity of the murmur increased. Which of the following conditions is associated with this finding?
explanation: The above image shows the Valsalva maneuver. The murmur of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) increases in intensity while performing the Valsalva maneuver. The murmurs produced by TR (tricuspid regurgitation), AS (aortic stenosis), and MR (mitral regurgitation) decrease in intensity while performing the Valsalva maneuver. Note: Valsalva maneuver decreases the intensity of all murmurs except MVP (mitral valve prolapse) and HCM.
subject: Medicine

question_text: While auscultating a patient's precordium, a murmur was heard that decreased in intensity on performing the following sustained maneuver. Which of the given condition is associated with this finding?
explanation: The above image shows a sustained handgrip maneuver. The murmur of aortic stenosis decreases in intensity during sustained handgrip. Maneuvers like sustained handgrip, simultaneous inflation of blood pressure cuffs above the systolic in both upper limbs, and infusion of vasopressors increase the systemic vascular resistance (afterload). Since increasing afterload will prevent blood from flowing in a normal forward path, it will increase any murmurs that are due to backward flowing blood and decresase the ones due to forward blood flow. Murmurs that increase in intensity on sustained handgrip: Mitral regurgitation Ventricular septal defect Aortic regurgitation Murmurs that decrease in intensity on sustained handgrip: Aortic stenosis Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following murmur increases on standing?
explanation: The murmur of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HOCM) increases with standing, as there is a reduction in preload. In conditions of reduced preload, there is lesser end diastolic volume in the left ventricle, leading to a narrower outflow tract, and a louder murmur is heard. The murmur heard in HOCM is a mid-systolic murmur, which is loudest along the left sternal border. It increases in conditions of decreased preload and afterload (standing, valsalva, vagal maneuvers) or conditions of increased contractility (inotropic stimulation) and decreases when preload and afterload are increased (squatting, vasopressors). Most murmurs decrease in intensity with reduced preload and afterload except HOCM and mitral valve prolapse (MVP).
subject: Medicine

question_text: A child was being evaluated for an underlying cardiac defect. On auscultation, a murmur was heard which began in systole, enveloped the second heart sound, and continued through some portion of the diastole. Which of the following condition is not associated with this finding?
options: Ventricular septal defect with aortic regurgitation
explanation: The murmur described above is a continuous murmur. A continuous murmur is produced when there is a pressure gradient between the cardiac chambers or the blood vessels throughout the systole and diastole. Continous murmurs are characterised by the flow of blood in the same direction and through the same channel during systole and diastole. These murmurs begin in systole, envelope the second heart sound (S2), and continue through some portion of diastole. Conditions producing a continuous murmur: atent ductus arteriosus Venous hum AV fistula Ruptured sinus of Valsalva aneurysm Ventricular septal defect with aortic regurgitation does not produce a continuous murmur. It produces a systolic-diastolic murmur as the blood flows through different channels during systole and diastole. These murmurs do not envelope S2.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is true about Gallavardin effect?
options: It is associated with a diastolic murmur
It is seen in aortic stenosis
It refers to the radiation of murmur to the carotids
The transmission makes the murmur low pitched
explanation: The Gallavardin effect refers to the phenomenon of the transmission of the mid-systolic murmur of aortic stenosis to the apex where it becomes higher pitched.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A patient presents with easy fatiguability and shortness of breath on moderate physical activity. On auscultation, a holosystolic murmur is heard over the lower left sternal border and radiating to the epigastrium. Which of the following condition is most likely to be associated with this finding?
explanation: A holosystolic murmur that is best heard over the lower left sternal border and radiating to the epigastrium most likely arises from tricuspid regurgitation.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is true about Still’s murmur?
options: It is heard in mitral regurgitation
It is best heard in left lateral decubitus position
explanation: Still’s murmur refers to the benign grade 2 mid-systolic murmur heard at mid or lower left sternal border in normal children and adolescents. Louder in hyperdynamic states(fever, anxiety). The anatomic basis for the murmur has not been definitively determined. It is best heard in a supine position.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Graham Steell murmur is heard in?
explanation: Graham Steell murmur is the early to mid-diastolic murmur heard in pulmonary regurgitation. It is best heard in 2nd left intercostal space and radiates along left sternal border. It can increase with inspiration.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Carey Coombs murmur is heard in?
explanation: Carey Coombs murmur is heard in mitral valvulitis. It is a mid-diastolic murmur heard during an episode of acute rheumatic fever causing mitral valvulitis. It is produced due to the flow of blood through an edematous mitral valve and dissipates with the resolution of the acute attack.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Austin-Flint murmur is associated with which of the following conditions?
explanation: Austin-Flint murmur is a low-pitched mid to late diastolic murmur of chronic severe AR. It results from the turbulence at the mitral inflow area from the mixture of regurgitant and forward blood flow. It is best heard at the apex. Austin-Flint murmur is often confused with the murmur of mitral stenosis. This can be differentiated based on the following: Features Chronic AR MS Opening snap Absent Present Effect of vasodilator administ ration Murmur becomes shorter an d softer.Mechanism- Fall in t he diastolic pressure gradient between the aorta and left ve ntricle. Murmur remains constant or increases in intensity.Mecha nism- Reflex increase in cardi ac output and mitral valve flo w.
subject: Medicine

question_text:
A 60-year-old man presented with an episode of acute onset dizziness and loss of consciousness which lasted for a few seconds followed by a regain of full consciousness. There were no similar episodes in the past. Which of the following is a true statement regarding this scenario?
ECG to rule out atrial fibrillation
options: If ECG is normal, CT scan should be done
Vestibular neuritis is a possible condition that can cause these symptoms
explanation: The clinical scenario of transient loss of consciousness in this patient is suggestive of syncope. Hence, an ECG must be done to rule out cardiac causes for syncope like - arrhythmias (atrial fibrillation, sinus node dysfunction, supra ventricular tachycardias) or a structural cardiac abnormality. A CT would only be required if a seizure or transient ischemic attack (TIA) is suspected. However, in this case - the episode only lasted for a few seconds, the patient has no history of similar episodes in the past and there are no lasting neurological deficits after the episode. Therefore, option B is incorrect. Syncope is a transient loss of consciousness caused by global cerebral hypoperfusion. It can be due to multiple causes, but is broadly divided into - neurally mediated syncope, orthostatic hypotension and cardiac syncope. The initial workup for a case of syncope includes: Detailed history of the episode and past history of similar episodes hysical examination mainly to check BP in standing and supine positions to rule out orthostatic hypotension. A resting ECG to look for cardiac arrhythmia Option B: If the ECG is normal, no further tests are needed. If the ECG is suggestive of cardiac arrhythmia, then further tests including continuous ECG monitoring and electrophysiological studies may be done. Option C: Tilt-table testing is done in patients with recurrent syncopal attacks who are suspected to have vasovagal syncope. Psychiatric evaluation is done in patients with recurrent unexplained syncopal attacks. Option D: Vestibular neuritis is associated with vertigo, where the patients typically complain of dizziness and a sense of spinning of the head. ECG Basics
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which electrophysiological activity is responsible for the T wave in ECG?
explanation: The T wave in ECG is due to ventricular repolarisation.
subject: Medicine

question_text: The PR intervals obtained from the ECG recording of 4 patients are given below. Which of the following patients has a normal PR interval?
explanation: The normal duration of the PR interval is 0.12-0.2 seconds (3 to 5 small boxes). PR interval is said to be prolonged if it is > 0.2 seconds and short if it is < 0.12 seconds. It is measured from the beginning of the P wave to the beginning of the QRS complex. It represents the time from the start of atrial depolarization to the start of ventricular depolarization.
subject: Medicine

question_text: What is the normal QRS interval?
explanation: The normal duration of the QRS interval is normally 0.1-0.11 seconds (less than 3 small boxes). QRS interval represents the duration of ventricular depolarization. When the QRS complex is > 0.11 seconds, it is called a wide QRS complex. It can occur in: Bundle branch blocks (RBBB or LBBB) Depolarizations originating in the ventricles Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome Hyperkalaemia
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which lead does the given ECG tracing represent in a normal ECG?
explanation: As all the waves (P, QRS, T) are negative in the given ECG, it should be lead aVR. All the depolarisations waves (P, QRS, T) move away from lead aVR in the normal sinus. Depolarisation wave moving towards the positive pole of the lead (or active electrode) produces a positive deflection in the ECG and depolarization moving away from the positive pole of the lead produces a negative deflection in the ECG. The lead aVR provides information from the right upper side of the heart. The given image shows a normal 12 lead ECG:
subject: Medicine

question_text: In a normal ECG obtained from a patient, a biphasic P wave may be seen in which of the following lead(s)?
explanation: In a normal ECG, a biphasic P wave is seen in lead V1 only. Lead V1 is a chest lead. So, it records potentials in the horizontal plane. The P wave in lead V1 consists of: Positive component reflecting right atrial depolarization (due to anteriorly oriented vector) Negative component reflecting left atrial depolarization (due to posteriorly oriented vector)
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following leads would show maximum R wave with the cardiac axis as +‹0°?
explanation: With the cardiac axis at +‹0°, lead aVF would show the maximum R wave. The cardiac axis represents the mean QRS axis (direction of mean depolarization vector). The normal adult QRS axis is directed downward and to the left, which is between -30° and +100°. The position of lead aVF is at +‹0°. If the cardiac axis is also at +‹0°, it would be in the same direction as lead aVF and hence aVF would show maximum R wave amplitude. If the mean axis is: More negative than –30°: left axis deviation More positive than +‹0 to +100°: right axis deviation Lies between -‹0 to +1˜0°: extreme axis deviation
subject: Medicine

question_text: Pseudo P pulmonale is seen in which electrolyte abnormality?
explanation: Pseudo P pulmonale refers to tall peaked P waves seen in hypokalemia. P-pulmonale refers to P waves taller than >2.5mm in an ECG lead. Hypocalcemia (Option C) prolongs the QT interval. Hypercalcemia (Option D) shortens the QT interval.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following ECG findings are seen in a patient with hypokalemia?
options: Prolonged PR interval with ST elevation
Decreased PR interval with ST depression
Decreased QT interval with tall T waves
Prolonged QT interval with flat T waves
explanation: Prolonged QT interval with flat T waves is seen in hypokalemia. Hypokalemia prolongs ventricular repolarization. The ECG changes seen are as follows: Flattening of T wave ST-segment depression Prolongation of QT interval The appearance of U wave
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 45-year-old male patient with a long-standing history of rheumatic heart disease comes to the clinic with complaints of dyspnea. Interpret the ECG finding.
explanation: The P waves in the given ECG are broad and notched. This is the P mitrale pattern which is seen in left atrial enlargement. This patient has likely developed mitral stenosis (heard as a mid-diastolic murmur) secondary to his rheumatic heart disease. Mitral valve stenosis and atrial inflammation in rheumatic carditis lead to left atrial dilation. The features of P mitrale are: lead II: broad (>2.5mm) notched P waves Lead V1: Biphasic wave with a prominent negative terminal component (representing delayed depolarization of the LA) P pulmonale is seen in right atrial enlargement. Option A: The rabbit ear pattern is seen in the right bundle branch block. The ECG of RBBB below shows the rSR' pattern of the QRS complex (rabbit ear) in leads V1-V2 and slurred S wave in lead V6. Option D: Sawtooth pattern in ECG is seen in atrial flutter (shown below).
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 67-year-old man with a history of COPD presented with worsening dyspnea for 2 weeks. On examination, pedal edema was present. An ECG was done and lead II showed the following pattern. Which of the following is responsible for this ECG finding?
explanation: In the given ECG, a peaked P wave can be seen. This is called P pulmonale and it is seen in cases of right atrial enlargement. The patient is showing features of heart failure possibly as a consequence of dysfunction caused by the overload. Signs of heart failure in this patient: Bilateral pitting edema in lower extremities (systemic congestion) Worsening dyspnea due to increased PCWP causing pulmonary hypertension and pulmonary edema (pulmonary congestion) The features of P pulmonale include: The amplitude of the P wave is >2.5mm on Lead II Prominent positive wave in the biphasic P wave of lead V1
subject: Medicine

question_text: What is the likely diagnosis of this patient based on the given ECG?
explanation: The given ECG shows deep S-waves in V6 and large R-waves in V1. This is suggestive of right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH). Diagnostic criteria for RVH: Dominant R wave in V1 (R/S ratio > 1). Dominant S wave in V5 or V6 (R/S ratio < 1). Right ventricular strain pattern - ST depression/T wave inversion in the right precordial (V1-4) and inferior leads (II, III, aVF) Right axis deviation of +110° or more. For left ventricular hypertrophy, Sokolow Lyon criteria are commonly used. It is based on the presence of tall left precordial R waves and deep right precordial S waves (S wave in V1 + [R wave in V5 or V6] >35 mm).
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 45-year-old man comes to the emergency room with complaints of sudden onset chest pain that radiates to the left arm and jaw. He is profusely sweating. An ECG was taken immediately. Interpret his ECG.
explanation: The patient has a myocardial infarction (MI) with ECG changes of a left bundle-branch block (LBBB), which can be identified by the following classical features: Wide QRS complex- QRS 120 ms Predominantly negative (QS) complexes in lead V1 and entirely positive (R) complexes in lead V6. M pattern seen in left chest leads (V5, V6) MI can have the following ECG changes: ST-segment elevation- zone of injury T wave depression Deep Q waves- late sign to develop New left bundle branch block (LBBB) The ECG findings below are characteristic of LBBB: Mnemonic WILLIAM (W pattern in V1-V2; L-LBBB; M pattern in V3-V6) The ECG findings below are characteristic of RBBB: Mnemonic MARROW (M pattern in V1-V2; R-RBBB; W pattern in V3-V6)
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 50-year-old patient comes to the emergency room with a history of severe retrosternal pain radiating to the jaw. The patient initially felt some uneasiness while eating lunch after which he experienced pain. His ECG is as shown. Interpret his ECG.
explanation: The given ECG shows ST-segment elevation in the anterior chest leads suggestive of myocardial infarction. Features of MI on ECG: ST-segment elevation: Zone of injury T wave inversions Deep Q waves: late sign to develop New left bundle branch block (LBBB) Option A: Atrial flutter shows a sawtooth wave pattern. Option B: WPW syndrome shows delta waves. Option D: Ventricular tachycardia has wide QRS complex and increased heart rate.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 72-year-old man comes to the emergency room complaining his heart is pounding and that he is going to die. The emergency physician orders an ECG. What is the diagnosis?
explanation: The given ECG shows ST elevation in leads V1-V4 which is suggestive of acute anteroseptal myocardial infarction (MI). ST depression in the leads III and aVF signifies an old inferior wall infarction.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 52-year-old diabetic man presents with retrosternal chest pain and profuse sweating and lightheadedness. Based on the ECG findings, what is the diagnosis?
explanation: The ECG shows ST elevations in leads I, aVL, and V1-V6. This is suggestive of extensive anterior wall MI.
subject: Medicine

question_text: What is the diagnosis based on the given ECG?
explanation: The ECG is suggestive of lateral wall MI and possible posterior wall MI. ST-elevation is present in the high lateral leads (I and aVL) and in V5 and V6. Reciprocal ST depression is seen in the inferior leads (III and aVF) with associated ST depression in V1, V2, and V3 (which could represent posterior wall MI). This pattern is consistent with an acute infarction localized to the superior portion of the lateral wall of the left ventricle (high lateral STEMI).
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 60-year-old patient presents with chest pain on the left side radiating to the arm and jaw on the same side. Cardiac troponins are found to be raised. What is the diagnosis based on this ECG?
explanation: The given ECG is of posterior wall MI. The ECG findings in posterior wall MI include, Reciprocal ST depressions in leads V1 to V3. Posterior wall ischemia is indirectly recognized in this way Tall and broad R waves (>30ms) in V2 and V3 Dominant R waves (R/S ratio > 1) in V2 Upright terminal portions of the T waves in V2 and V3
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following ECG findings are unlikely to be present in a patient with hyperkalemia?
explanation: Prolonged QT interval is not a feature of hyperkalemia, it is a feature of hypokalemia.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A patient was brought to the ER with complaints of multiple episodes of vomiting, increased frequency of urination, and constipation for the past 5 days. He also complained of lethargy and muscle pain. He is a known case of SCC of the lung. What is likely to be seen in the ECG of this patient?
explanation: The above scenario is suggestive of hypercalcemia due to ectopic production of PTH-related peptides. It is mostly associated with squamous-cell lung cancer (SCC). ECG is likely to show a decreased QT interval. Hypocalcemia shows increased QT interval.
subject: Medicine

question_text: ECG of a patient revealed a QT interval of 0.55s. Which of the following will not be a differential diagnosis?
explanation: QT interval of 0.55s suggests QT prolongation. It is not seen in digitalis toxicity. Rather, a QT shortening with characteristic “scooping” of the ST–T-wave complex, called a digitalis effect, is seen. The ECG changes seen in digitalis toxicity are as follows: Prolonged PR interval ST-segment depression Short QT interval QT interval represents the time taken for the ventricles to depolarize and repolarize. It is prolonged in the following: Hypocalcemia Hypokalemia Congenital long QT syndromes such as Romano-Ward syndrome Hypothermia Drugs: Class IA and Class III antiarrhythmics Intracranial bleeds: particularly SAH
subject: Medicine

question_text: Osborn waves in ECG are seen in:
explanation: Osborn waves are seen in hypothermia. Osborn waves can also be seen in severe hypothyroidism (Option A), but even in those cases, hypothermia is the reason for the appearance of Osborn waves. Therefore, hypothermia is the better answer here. It consists of an abrupt ascent right at the J point (the junctional point between the QRS complex and the ST segment) and then an equally sudden plunge back to the baseline. It is also called the J wave. This is because systemic hypothermia prolongs repolarisation. Osborn wave can also be seen in: Hypercalcemia Brain injury Subarachnoid hemorrhage Vasospastic angina Cardiopulmonary arrest from oversedation Idiopathic ventricular fibrillation
subject: Medicine

question_text:
In a patient with a left-sided massive pneumothorax, all of the following ECG changes are seen except:
Reduced R wave amplitude
explanation: Right axis deviation is seen in left-sided pneumothorax. The ECG changes seen in left-sided pneumothorax are as follows: Reduced R wave amplitude Inversion of T wave in precordial leads Amplitude changes in QRS complex Right axis deviation Supraventricular Arrhythmias
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 52-year-old man has come to the emergency complaining of a burning type of chest pain. Comment on his ECG recording shown below.
explanation: The above ECG strip shows normal sinus rhythm. The features in this ECG that suggest this diagnosis are as follows: The QRS complexes are narrow (<120 ms or 3 small squares) which implies that the impulse is supraventricular and is conducted via the normal conduction pathway. Each QRS complex is preceded by a P wave. This means that all the atrial depolarizations that arise in the sinus node are conducted to the ventricles. The PR interval is constant for all the impulses and is normal (<200 ms) in duration. The RR interval is constant which implies a regular rhythm.
subject: Medicine

question_text: All of the following are supraventricular tachycardias except:
explanation: Premature ventricular beats are a type of ventricular tachycardias, not supraventricular tachycardias. Tachycardia is defined as a heart rate of >100 beats/min. It can be classified based on the site of origin of the cardiac impulse as follows: Supraventricular tachycardias (SVTs) originate above the ventricles, that is, in the sinoatria node, atria, or the atrioventricular node. Supraventricular tachycardias include: Tachycardias originating from the atrium: Sinus tachycardia- from the SA node Focal atrial tachycardia Multifocal atrial tachycardia Atrial flutter Atrial fibrillation Tachycardias originating from the AV node: Junctional tachycardia- automaticity within AV Node AV nodal reentry tachycardia (AVNRT) Tachycardia associated with accessory atrioventricular pathways: atrioventricular reentry tachycardia (AVRT) Ventricular tachycardias originate from the ectopic foci or the reentry pathways in the ventricles. Ventricular tachycardias include: Premature ventricular beats Ventricular tachycardia (VT) Monomorphic VT- Very rapid monomorphic VT is also known as ventricular flutter Polymorphic VT- associated with Torsades de pointes Ventricular fibrillation
subject: Medicine

question_text: ECG of a patient who presented with palpitations to the ER is shown below. Which of the following is a likely diagnosis?
explanation: The above ECG shows increased heart rate with wide QRS complexes (> 0.12s). This is suggestive of ventricular tachycardia (VT). Types of ventricular tachycardia based on QRS morphology: Monomorphic- a stable QRS morphology from beat to beat Polymorphic- changing or multiform QRS variance from beat to beat. Torsades de pointes is an example of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia. Bidirectional- has a beat-to-beat alternation in the QRS frontal plane axis. It is associated with digitalis toxicity or catecholaminergic polymorphic VT. The most common cause of VT is ischemic heart disease. Ventricular tachyarrhythmias occur due to impulses that originate within the ventricles. These impulses are conducted through the normal ventricular myocardial cells instead of the fast conducting Purkinje system. Hence, they present with wide QRS complexes ( >0.12 sec) on the ECG. Supraventricular tachyarrhythmias occur due to impulses originating above the ventricles. These impulses reach the ventricles through the proper fast conduction pathway resulting in a narrow QRS complex. SVTs are associated with wide QRS in few exceptional conditions like: Conduction block in the left or right bundle branch Activation of ventricles from an accessory pathway- antidromic AVRT The given ECG shows wide stable QRS complexes in monomorphic ventricular tachycardia:

question_text: Which is the most common supraventricular tachyarrhythmia?
explanation: The most common supraventricular arrhythmia is sinus tachycardia. It can either be physiological or pathological. Physiological sinus tachycardia is seen in exercise, fever, anemia, hyperthyroidism, etc. Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardias are those supraventricular tachycardias that occur with sudden onset and termination, they are non-sustained arrhythmias (lasts < 30 seconds). They include AVNRT, AVRT, and atrial tachycardias. The most common sustained (lasts > 30 seconds) arrhythmia is atrial fibrillation. Junctional tachycardia originates from ectopic foci in the AV node. It is an uncommon tachycardia.

question_text: A 65-year-old hypertensive patient presents with chest pain and dyspnea following an alcohol binge. His ECG is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The ECG shows narrow QRS complexes with irregular RR intervals and no distinct P waves. This is suggestive of atrial fibrillation. Atrial fibrillation (AF) is a supraventricular tachycardia caused by ectopic foci or small reentry circuits within the atria. It has an atrial rate of 400-600/min and a ventricular rate of 100-160/min. Risk factors for developing AF include: Age- usually above 60 years of age Underlying heart disease Hypertension Diabetes mellitus Obesity Sleep apnea Post-cardiac surgery Inflammatory pericarditis Acute precipitating factors for AF include: Hyperthyroidism Acute alcohol intoxication Acute illness like myocardial infarction and pulmonary embolism

question_text: A 60-year-old man who is on treatment for chronic AF presents with nausea, dizziness, and anorexia. He has a regular heart rate of 50/min. The most likely cause is:
explanation: A patient of atrial fibrillation usually has an irregular heart rate of >100/ min but this patient presents with a regular slow heart rate. The most likely cause of slow regular heart rate in chronic AF is digitalis toxicity. Symptoms such as nausea, anorexia are also suggestive of digitalis toxicity. Digitalis lowers the AV nodal conduction by stimulating the vagal nerve endings leading to increased vagal tone. Hence digitalis toxicity can cause AV nodal block. This leads to a junctional escape rhythm taking over the ventricles causing slow and regular heart rate. Digitalis toxicity can also lead to a variety of arrhythmias as it increases the intracellular calcium levels increasing the risk of tachyarrhythmias.

question_text: A 50-year-old man was brought to the emergency in an unconscious state. He had a fever for the past two days and is a known case of severe COPD. His ECG is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

This leads to supraventricular tachycardia with p waves and QRS complexes of different morphologies. It is usually encountered in patients with chronic pulmonary disease and acute illness. Therapy for MAT is directed at treating the underlying disease and correcting any metabolic abnormalities. Calcium-channel blockers and radiofrequency ablation of the AV node are the other treatment modalities. question_text: A 32-year-old man is brought to the casualty after he developed sudden onset dyspnea, chest pain, and palpitations at a party. His blood pressure is 100/62 mmHg. His ECG is shown below. What is the drug of choice to treat his condition?
explanation: The ECG is suggestive of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT) as it shows: Narrow QRS complexes No visible p waves Pseudo R' waves in V1 lead Adenosine is the preferred drug in stable paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). Treatment of PSVT: In hemodynamically unstable patients, QRS-synchronous DC cardioversion should be done. In hemodynamically stable patients, Mechanical measures: These maneuvers result in an acute increase in the vagal tone which decreases AV conduction and terminates the arrhythmia. They include the following: Valsalva maneuver Lowering the head between the knees Coughing Splashing cold water on the face Breath-holding Carotid sinus massage Pharmacologic therapy: Adenosine- it is the first-line agent. It blocks conduction across the AV node and terminates the SVT. It is given as a 6-18 mg bolus Calcium channel blockers- verapamil and diltiazem Beta-blockers- esmolol, propranolol, and metoprolo IV Procainamide- it is administered if the tachycardia is being mediated through an accessory pathway. question_text: The ECG of a patient who presented to the ER is as given below. The patient was already given a carotid massage and IV Adenosine but the BP is currently 60/30 mm Hg. What is the next best step of management?
explanation: The given ECG showing narrow QRS complex (<0.12 s) tachycardia with absent P wave is suggestive of paroxysmal ventricular tachycardia (PSVT). The next best step in the management of a patient with unstable vitals (systolic blood pressure < 90 mm Hg) is synchronized cardioversion. Synchronized cardioversion is the treatment of choice in unstable PSVT patients, in which shocks are delivered with the defibrillator/monitor in synchronized mode with an initial energy level of 100J. Synchronization times the delivery so that it is given at the peak of the QRS complex. If the shock occurs in the ST segment or the T wave (unsynchronized), it can precipitate a more serious arrhythmia such as ventricular fibrillation. question_text: A patient came with sudden onset palpitations. ECG showed a narrow complex, regular tachycardia without P waves, and a rate of 160 BPM. His blood pressure is 96/68 mmHg. What is the next step in management?

Carotid sinus massage can be considered in the absence of carotid bruits and no history of stroke. If vagal maneuvers fail or cannot be performed, intravenous adenosine can be used. Non-DHP calcium channel blockers and beta blockers are second-line pharmacological agents in the management of PSVT. They can cause hypotension before and after terminating the arrhythmia. If the patient is hemodynamically unstable (systolic blood pressure <90 mmHg or mean arterial pressure <65 mm Hg), immediate QRS-synchronous direct current cardioversion is necessary. question_text: Which of the following is false about accessory pathways?
options: Bundle of Kent has antegrade conduction
explanation: Retrograde conduction via accessory pathways does not cause preexcitation. Accessory pathways (APs) are abnormal conduction pathways connecting the atrium and ventricle. They can conduct impulses in the following ways: Antegrade conduction: Occurs from the atria to the ventricle The impulses from atria reach the ventricles faster via the accessory pathway as compared to the normal AV nodal pathway as they bypass the AV nodal delay. This leads to an earlier excitation of the ventricles known as the preexcitation of the ventricles and thus a wide QRS complex. Examples- WPW syndrome and antidromic AVRT Retrograde conduction: Occurs from the ventricle to the atria. The impulses reach the ventricles via the normal AV nodal pathway but re-enter the atria through the accessory pathway. Ventricular depolarization is normal, there is no preexcitation and thus a narrow QRS complex. It causes supraventricular tachycardia as the impulses re-enter the atria via the accessory pathway. Examples- concealed accessory pathways (can cause SVTs) and orthodromic AVRT.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is the most common reentrant tachycardia caused by an accessory pathway?
explanation: The most common reentrant tachycardia caused by an accessory pathway is orthodromic AV reentry. Accessory pathways (APs) are abnormal conduction pathways connecting the atrium and ventricle. They can conduct impulses in the following ways: Antegrade conduction: Occurs from the atria to the ventricle The impulses from atria reach the ventricles faster via the accessory pathway as compared to the normal AV nodal pathway as they bypass the AV nodal delay. This leads to an earlier excitation of the ventricles known as the preexcitation of the ventricles and thus a wide QRS complex. Examples- WPW syndrome and antidromic AVRT Retrograde conduction: Occurs from the ventricle to the atria. The impulses reach the ventricles via the normal AV nodal pathway but re-enter the atria through the accessory pathway. Ventricular depolarization is normal, there is no preexcitation and thus a narrow QRS complex. It causes supraventricular tachycardia as the impulses re-enter the atria via the accessory pathway. Examples- concealed accessory pathways (can cause SVTs) and orthodromic AVRT. AV nodal reentry tachycardia (AVNRT) is not caused by an accessory pathway. It involves tissues with different conduction speeds within the AV node or just adjacent to the AV node, known as the fast pathway and the slow pathway. This is known as dual AV nodal physiology.

question_text: A patient's ECG shows a short PR interval and delta wave. Additional findings include atrial fibrillation and rapid ventricular rate. He is hemodynamically stable. All of the following drugs can be used in the management except:

Rate-slowing drugs such as non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (eg, verapamil, diltiazem), beta-blockers, and digoxin are contraindicated in these patients. They increase the refractoriness of the AV node with minimal or no effect on the accessory pathway. This can lead to faster ventricular rates, increasing the risk of ventricular fibrillation. question_text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the clinic with complaints of recurrent palpitation and lightheadedness. An ECG was taken and is as shown below. What is the best step in management?
explanation: The ECG shows the presence of delta waves (preexcitation wave), wide QRS, and short PR interval which are classically seen in Wolff Parkinson White (WPW) syndrome. In this patient, catheter ablation is the best for long-term management. Patients with preexcitation who have symptoms of arrhythmia are at risk for developing AF and sudden death if they have an accessory pathway that allows rapid antegrade conduction (preexcitation & tachyarrhythmias are features of WPW syndrome due to the abnormal accessory pathway). Complications of catheter ablation are rare but include AV block, cardiac tamponade, thromboembolic events, and hematoma at the access site.

question_text:
Which of the following is true regarding sick sinus syndrome?
Most patients are symptomatic in the early stages
options: Frequently seen in patients with atrial fibrillation
explanation: Sick sinus syndrome is frequently seen in patients with concomitant atrial fibrillation. Sick sinus syndrome (or sinus node dysfunction) is a group of abnormal heart rhythms. It is a disorder of the sinoatrial node caused by impaired pacemaker function and impulse transmission. This leads to a combination of abnormal rhythms, including atrial bradyarrhythmias, atrial tachyarrhythmias, and sometimes a pattern of alternating bradycardia and tachycardia, known as tachy-brady syndrome. These irregular rhythms can cause symptoms such as palpitations, decreased tissue perfusion, subsequent fatigue, lightheadedness, pre-syncope, and syncope. The management of sick sinus syndrome includes identifying and correcting reversible factors, as an initial step. Some examples of reversible causes of Sinus Node Dysfunction include, Hypothyroidism Sleep apnea Anti-hypertensive medications eg. Beta-blockers Anti-arrhythmic medications eg. Amiodarone, Procainamide Ambulatory ECG monitoring is required to diagnose as the symptoms are nonspecific. Treatment involves permanent pacing. Other options: Option A: The course of sinus node dysfunction is usually a slow progression over decades. In the early stages, most patients are asymptomatic. Option B: It occurs most commonly in elderly patients due to the gradual loss of SA node function. Option D: Beta-blockers are contraindicated in this condition. question_text: A hypertensive patient was brought to the emergency due to complaints of palpitations and breathing difficulty. Comment on his ECG.
explanation: The above ECG shows a pattern of premature ventricular contractions, one premature beat after one normal beat. This is seen in ventricular bigeminy. Premature ventricular contractions/beats (PVC) are single ventricular beats that occur earlier than the next normal supraventricular beat. They originate from abnormal foci in the ventricular tissue: Unifocal PVCs arise from a single focus and hence have the same QRS morphology Multifocal PVCs arise from multiple foci and therefore have different QRS morphologie They are not preceded by a P wave as they do not originate in the atria. They show wide QRS complexes (>0.12 ms) on the ECG because they are conducted via normal myocardial tissue instead of the Purkinje system. Ventricular bigeminy refers to a pair of normal and premature ventricular contractions, whereas ventricular trigeminy refers to a premature beat that occurs after two normal beats. Quadrigeminy is when a premature beat follows three normal beats. Few other terms associated with premature ventricular contractions: Two successive PVCs are known as a couplet Three successive PVCs are known as a triplet. The given ECG shows ventricular bigeminy with premature beats circled in red and normal ventricular contractions circled in green.

question_text: Identify the marked ECG feature in a patient diagnosed with ventricular tachycardia.
explanation: The ECG feature of ventricular tachycardia seen in the given image is a fusion beat. It occurs when a sinus and ventricular beat coincide to produce a hybrid complex. Ventricular tachycardia (VT) is defined as  3 consecutive premature ventricular contractions at a rate of >100/min. It is characterized by: Wide QRS complex AV dissociation- Atrial activity independent of ventricular activity, seen on the ECG as every p wave not followed by QRS complex Fusion beats- occur when a sinus and ventricular beat coincide to produce a hybrid complex Capture beats occur when the SA node transiently ‘captures’ the ventricles, that is, ventricles are depolarized by the impulses from the SA node producing a QRS complex of normal duration. The given ECG shows a fusion beat (red arrow), and a capture beat (green arrow) can also be seen: The given image shows capture beats in VT: Option C: Polymorphic QRS, that is, continuously changing QRS morphology is seen in polymorphic ventricular tachycardia. Option D: Triphasic QRS (eg. RSR pattern on V1) is seen in supraventricular tachycardias with the wide QRS complex.

question_text: A 50-year-old man is brought to the emergency following an episode of syncope during his morning walk. His blood pressure is 80/60 mm Hg. He has a history of myocardial infarction 5 yrs back. His present ECG is given below. Which is the most appropriate treatment for the patient?
explanation: The clinical scenario describes a man with history of coronary artery disease developing syncope. The ECG shows wide QRS complex (> 0.12 s) tachycardia with a single QRS morphology suggestive of monomorphic ventricular tachycardia (VT). The most appropriate treatment of VT in a hemodynamically unstable (systolic blood pressure < 90 mm Hg) patient is DC cardioversion. VT can be casued by structural heart disease, scar-related reentry, cardiomyopathies, or abnormalities in the conduction pathways. VT is said to be sustained if it lasts for at least 30 seconds or requires intervention for termination. Rapid VT can lead to hypotension and syncope, especially in patients with ventricular dysfunction. Patients with normal cardiac function may tolerate sustained VT, presenting with palpitations. Monomorphic VT associated with structural heart disease can progress to ventricular fibrillation (VF) and sudden cardiac arrest. QRS synchronous electrical cardioversion is performed for unstable patients. Intravenous amiodarone is the preferred drug for stable VT associated with heart disease. After restoring sinus rhythm, further evaluation is necessary to determine the underlying heart disease. Treatment options include antiarrhythmic medications, catheter ablation, or implantable cardioverter-defibrillators (ICDs) for recurrent or high-risk VT. ICDs are commonly used for secondary prevention of sudden death in patients with sustained VT and structural heart disease.
subject: Medicine

question_text: All of the following are effective in the management of patients with ventricular tachycardia except:
explanation: Carotid sinus massage will be effective only in supraventricular tachycardias but not in ventricular tachycardias. This is because it acts by increasing the AV node block which does not play any role in the pathogenesis of ventricular tachycardia. Hence, AV node blocking maneuvers (carotid sinus massage, valsalva) and drugs (adenosine) are not used in the management of VT.

question_text: Accelerated idioventricular rhythm is the most common arrhythmia associated with:
explanation: Accelerated idioventricular rhythm is the most common arrhythmia associated with myocardial reperfusion, most commonly in the first 2 days after presentation. Idioventricular rhythm is defined as  3 consecutive premature ventricular contractions with a heart rate of <50 bpm. If the heart rate is 60-100 bpm, it is known as accelerated idioventricular rhythm, and if it is more than 100 bpm it is known as ventricular tachycardia. It may be the result of an abnormal focus in the ventricle that generates an impulse faster than the sinus node and therefore assumes control. Other causes of AIVR include: Buerger disease Congenital heart disease Dilated cardiomyopathy Myocarditi Drugs: Digoxin toxicity, cocaine toxicity, and various anesthesia agent Electrolyte abnormality Postresuscitation Episodes of AIVR have not been found to affect prognosis in acute MI and usually do not require intervention. If AIVR is accompanied by hemodynamic compromise, treatment with atropine or atrial pacing will often suppress the rhythm.

question_text: Automatic implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (AICD) implantation is done for all of the following conditions except:
options: Acute coronary syndrome with low ejection fraction
explanation: An automated implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (AICD) is a device placed in the chest or abdomen to detect arrhythmias and perform cardioversion, defibrillation, and pace the heart. It is contraindicated in patients experiencing tachyarrhythmias with reversible or transient causes such as acute MI. It is used in: Brugada syndrome- refers to a sodium channelopathy with a high risk of arrhythmias that can lead to sudden cardiac death. Ventricular fibrillation and ventricular tachycardia. Cardiac resynchronization therapy for prevention of sudden cardiac death in heart failure. High-risk situations of sudden cardiac death in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

question_text: Sudden cardiac death is defined as unexpected nontraumatic death in stable patients within:
explanation: Sudden cardiac death is defined as unexpected non-traumatic death in clinically well or stable patients who die within 1 hour after onset of symptoms. The causative rhythm in most cases is ventricular fibrillation, which is usually preceded by ventricular tachycardia except in the setting of acute ischemia or infarction.

question_text: A patient who is a known case of Crohn's disease was brought to the emergency. He complained of sudden onset cold sweats and palpitations. Which among the following is the likely cause of his ECG finding shown in the given image?
explanation: The given ECG finding shows torsades de pointes, which can occur due to hypomagnesemia (Crohn's disease causes chronic diarrhea which can cause excess GI loss of magnesium). Torsades de pointes means twisting of points, it implies twisting of the QRS complexes around the isoelectric line of the ECG. It is a form of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia that is seen in patients with a prolonged QT interval. A prolonged QT interval usually results from prolonged ventricular repolarization (lengthening of T wave). A premature ventricular contraction falling in the elongated T wave can initiate torsades de pointes. The features of torsades de pointes are: Polymorphic QRS complexes that change in amplitude Cycle length giving an appearance of oscillations around the baseline QT prolongation

question_text: The ECG of a pregnant lady having pre-eclampsia is shown below. Her vitals are stable. What is the best step in the management of the condition?
explanation: The given ECG showing a wide QRS complex tachycardia with waxing and waning QRS amplitude points to the diagnosis of torsades des pointes. As the patient is hemodynamically stable, intravenous MgSO4 is the treatment of choice. Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia (VT) has a continually changing QRS morphology. Polymorphic VT that occurs in individuals with congenital or acquired prolongation of QT interval is referred to as torsades des pointes. Patients present with near-syncope, syncope, or cardiac arrest. IV MgSO4 is highly effective for both treatment and the prevention of recurrence of long QT-related ventricular ectopic beats that trigger torsades des pointes. If magnesium alone is ineffective, isoproterenol infusion or pacing, to a rate of 100-120 depolarization/minute usually suppresses VT recurrences. If the patient is hemodynamically unstable, then immediate defibrillation should be done. question_text: Identify the false statement about the bundle of Kent.

It is slower than AV nodal pathway
explanation: The bundle of Kent is the accessory pathway of conduction between the atria and ventricle in Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome. It conducts impulses faster than the AV nodal pathway and avoids AV nodal delay, leading to shortened PR interval. question_text: Which of the following is seen in patients with Brugada syndrome?
options: ST segment elevation in 1, V5, AvL
ST segment elevation in II , III AvF
explanation: The major feature of Brugada syndrome is transient or concealed ST-segment elevation in V1 to V3. Brugada syndrome is a rare syndrome characterized by ST-segment elevation and negative T waves in more than 1 anterior precordial leads ( V1- V3 ). It is associated with mutations involving cardiac sodium channels. The patients have episodes of polymorphic VT which may lead to syncope or cardiac arrest. It shows an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern and affects males more than females. The episodes of VT may occur either in sleep or maybe provoked by febrile illness or sodium channel-blocking drugs (Class I antiarrhythmics) like ajmaline, flecainide, and procainamide. The episodes of VT can be suppressed using quinidine or catheter ablation. ICD can be used in individuals who have been resuscitated from cardiac arrest.

question_text: Romano-Ward syndrome is:
options: Congenital short PR associated with deafne
Congenital long QT associated with cataract
explanation: Romano-Ward syndrome is a congenital long QT syndrome without deafness. Romano-Ward syndrome is associated with specific genetic mutations affecting membrane potassium and sodium channels. The inheritance pattern may be autosomal recessive or autosomal dominant. explanation: The given ECG shows a constant PR interval in each successive cycle followed by a dropped QRS (P wave fails to produce a QRS complex). This pattern is suggestive of Mobitz type II block. Hypokalemia
explanation: The symptoms of weakness, paresthesia, and dyspnea along with the given ECG showing depression of the ST segment, a decrease in the amplitude of the T wave (flattening or inversion), and an increase in the amplitude of U waves (at the end of the T wave) are characteristic of hypokalemia. In the given ECG, leads V1-V6 exhibit T wave inversion. U waves are well appreciated in leads V2-V5. Hypokalemia leads to dynamic ECG changes. The image given shows the sequence of changes observed: Hypokalemia is defined as plasma K+ concentration of <3.5meq/L. It can also cause premature atrial and ventricular beats, sinus bradycardia, paroxysmal atrial or junctional tachycardia, atrioventricular block, and ventricular tachycardia or fibrillation. Other options: Option B: Hyperkalemia causes tall peaked T waves with a shortened QT interval. There is a progressive lengthening of the PR interval and QRS duration with an increase in potassium levels, eventually leading to the disappearance of the P wave; and widening of the QRS complex to a sine wave pattern. Option C: Hypocalcemia causes prolongation of the QT interval. There is a lengthening of the ST segment, while the T wave (which correlates with the time for repolarization) remains unaltered. Option D: Hypercalcemia causes shortening of the QT interval and a decrease in the ST segment duration. Valvular Heart Diseases

question_text: What is the most common cause of valvular heart disease in developing countries?
explanation: The most common cause of valvular heart disease in developing countries is rheumatic fever. This is mainly due to the repeated infections with rheumatogenic streptococci and inadequate coverage of antibiotics. It mainly affects the mitral valve. In developed countries, degenerative or inflammatory processes are the most common cause of valvular heart diseases.

question_text: What is the normal range for the mitral valve area in an adult?
explanation: The size of the mitral orifice in a normal adult is 4-6 sq cm. Depending on the area of mitral valve opening (MVA), mitral stenosis can be classified as: Progressive MS - MVA > 1.5 sq cm Severe MS - MVA  1.5 sq cm Very severe MS -  1 sq cm

question_text: A 45-year-old woman is diagnosed with mitral stenosis. Which of the following features is least likely to be seen in this patient?
explanation: Left ventricular hypertrophy is not seen in mitral stenosis. On the contrary, right ventricle hypertrophy is seen. Mechanism of mitral stenosis (MS): In a normal mitral valve, there is no obstruction to the flow of blood from the left atrium(LA) to the left ventricle. Therefore a small LA pressure is sufficient to empty the blood into the ventricle. When the MVA is <~2 sq cm, blood flows from the left atrium to the left ventricle, propelled by a mildly elevated atrial pressure. Hence, patients are usually asymptomatic and may develop dyspnea only when the heart rate increases, as seen in exertion, excitement, fever, etc. All these conditions: Increase the rate of blood flow across the mitral orifice, resulting in further elevation of the LA pressure Decrease the diastolic filling time, resulting in a reduction in cardiac output The image below explains the mechanism of mitral stenosis.

question_text: A 48-year-old female patient was admitted to the hospital in view of severe dyspnea. History revealed that the dyspnea was exertional initially and later worsened to breathlessness during normal daily activities. She died on the 3rd day following admission. explanation: The given image is of mitral stenosis showing fish mouth or buttonhole appearance.
