question_text: A 62-year-old woman presents with breathlessness for 5 months. She is unable to carry out her daily activities and has difficulty sleeping. On examination, she has a parasternal heave. On auscultation, opening snap (OS) is heard followed by a low pitched rumbling diastolic murmur. Which of the following findings is suggestive of increased severity of the given condition?
explanation: The above clinical scenario is suggestive of mitral stenosis. The more severe the thickening, the earlier the opening snap occurs in diastole. Hence, the decreased interval between A2 and opening snap (OS) indicates increased severity of the stenosis. The auscultatory findings which are suggestive of increased severity of murmur are: Decreased interval between A2 and OS Increased duration of the diastolic murmur Loud S1 is seen in the initial stages of MS when the mitral leaflets are flexible. When there is further thickening and calcification of the leaflets, they become immobile, and the amplitude of S1 decreases. Increased severity of the stenosis increases the left atrial pressure. This increase in left atrial pressure can increase pulmonary artery pressure which leads to loud P2 on auscultation.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following cardiac chambers is enlarged in mitral stenosis on chest X-ray initially?
explanation: Left atrium (LA) is the first cardiac chamber to get enlarged in mitral stenosis (MS). It is due to the pressure overload of LA. It can be appreciated on the lateral and left anterior oblique views. Other radiographic changes seen in MS are straightening of the upper left border of the cardiac silhouette, posterior displacement of the esophagus by an enlarged LA, and Kerley B lines due to distention of interlobular septae and lymphatics with edema. Severe MS causing pulmonary hypertension leads to enlargement of the pulmonary artery, right ventricle, and right atrium. Left ventricle remains unaffected in isolated MS.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A patient with mitral stenosis presented with worsening dyspnea and fatigue which are now present at rest. He also complained of a feeling of heavy pounding in the chest with recurrent chest pain. You decided to evaluate the patient using echocardiography. When would you advise the patient to undergo a valvotomy?
options: In all patients who are symptomatic
explanation: Mitral valvotomy is indicated in symptomatic (NYHA Functional Class II-IV) patients with mitral stenosis (MS) with orifice < 1.5 cm2 in normal-sized adults or <1 cm2/m2 body surface area. Treatment of mitral stenosis: Administration of warfarin in patients with MS who develop atrial fibrillation. Surgical treatment includes: Mitral valvotomy: It is done in symptomatic patients whose mitral orifice is less than 1.5 cm2. This can be either percutaneous mitral valvotomy or open surgical valvotomy. Mitral valve replacement: This is done in patients whose mitral valve is severely distorted.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 26-year-old woman undergoing evaluation for panic disorder was referred to the physician for complaints of palpitations and breathlessness. Detailed history revealed the presence of chest pain, which was substernal and not related to exercise. On auscultation, mid-systolic clicks were audible. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The above clinical scenario is suggestive of mitral valve prolapse. It is caused due to the myxomatous degeneration of the mitral valve. It may be associated with Marfan's syndrome, osteogenesis imperfecta, and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome. It is more common in females of the age group of 15- 30 years. Most patients are usually asymptomatic. However, some patients may present with symptoms such as palpitations, syncope due to arrhythmias (premature ventricular contractions, ventricular tachycardia, and atrial fibrillation), non-specific chest pain, and dyspnea Auscultation reveals mid-systolic clicks. If there is associated mitral regurgitation, a systolic murmur might also be heard. The duration of the murmur of MVP decreases on squatting and increases on standing. Whereas the duration of the murmur of MR increases on squatting and decreases on standing.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Carvallo’s sign is associated with the murmur of which valvulopathy?
explanation: Carvallo’s sign refers to the increase in the intensity of systolic murmur of tricuspid regurgitation with inspiration. During inspiration, the venous return to the heart increases due to the negative intrathoracic pressure. This increases the leak from the right ventricle to the right atrium making the murmur louder. In general, the right-sided heart murmurs increase in intensity with inspiration and decrease in intensity with expiration, while the opposite is true for left-sided heart murmurs. Pulmonic ejection sound is the only right-sided acoustic event that decreases in intensity with inspiration.
subject: Medicine

question_text: The severity of mitral regurgitation can be assessed by:
explanation: The severity of mitral regurgitation (MR) can be assessed by the wide splitting of the S2. Due to severe regurgitation of blood, the pressure in the left ventricle falls rapidly, leading to the early closure of the aortic valve. Clinical findings that indicate the severity of MR is: Reduced cardiac output Palpable systolic thrill Palpable S3 Wide splitting of S2 N te: The intensity of murmur does not always correlate with the severity of the murmur. Intensity may be diminished in severe MR caused by LV dysfunction, acute MI and periprosthetic valve regugitation.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 65-year-old male patient presented with chest pain, exertional dyspnea and syncope. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The most likely diagnosis is aortic stenosis. Aortic stenosis is the narrowing of the aortic valve. It may be caused due to the calcification of the normal aortic valve, calcification of congenital bicuspid valve, and rheumatic heart disease. Three cardinal clinical features of aortic stenosis are: Exertional dyspnea - this occurs due to the left ventricular (LV) diastolic dysfunction. Raised end-diastolic LV volume and reduced LV compliance lead to increased LV pressure, leading t elevation of pulmonary capillary wedge pressure. Angina pectoris - it occurs due to the combination of the increased O2 needs of hypertrophied myocardium and reduction of O2 delivery. Syncope - it occurs due to the combination of decreased cardiac output and systemic arterial dilation which lead to a reduction of cerebral perfusion.
subject: Medicine

question_text: On auscultation of a patient, a murmur was heard which is depicted by the following phonocardiogram. Which of the given conditions is most likely to produce this murmur?
explanation: The phonocardiogram given above is of an ejection systolic murmur, which is seen in aortic stenosis. It is also heard in pulmonary stenosis. They are differentiated based on the difference in symptoms, site of murmur, etc. Clinical findings in aortic stenosis: Pulse - slow rising and late peaking pulse which is known as pulsus parvus et tardus. A carotid thrill may also be palpated over these arteries. Apical impulse - A double apical impulse may be recognized, and in the later stages, it may be displaced laterally. Auscultation findings in aortic stenosis: Early systolic ejection sound - heard in early stages, disappears when the valve becomes calcified and rigid Paradoxical splitting of S2 - With worsening of stenosis, delayed closure of the aortic valve ccurs. This leads to narrowing of S2 sound, and in severe cases, leads to paradoxical splitting of S2. S4 and S3 - heard in severe cases Ejection systolic murmur - starts after S1, increases in intensity to reach the peak, and ends before A2. It radiates to the neck and base of the heart. It is augmented by squatting and reduced by the strain of the Valsalva maneuver. The image below shows phonocardiograms of normal and abnormal heart sounds.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A patient presented with breathlessness on exertion and chest pain. Auscultation revealed an ejection systolic murmur heard best at the base of the heart. Echocardiography showed reduced left ventricular ejection fraction and left ventricular hypertrophy. Which of the following features does not signify a severe form of this disease?
explanation: The above features point to a diagnosis of aortic stenosis. Wide splitting of S2 is not a feature of severe aortic stenosis. On the contrary, there might be single S2 or paradoxical splitting of S2. Features of severe aortic stenosis are: Pulsus parvus et tardus Palpable carotid thrill Louder and late peaking of systolic murmur Single S2 or paradoxical splitting of S2 Presence of S3 and S4 heart sounds Signs of right and left ventricular failure Left ventricular hypertrophy

question_text: Which of the following conditions is not associated with aortic regurgitation?
explanation: Acute myocardial infarction is not associated with aortic regurgitation. Aortic regurgitation is the backflow of the blood from the aorta to the left ventricle. It may be caused either due to the defect in the valve or defect in the aortic root (dilation of the aortic annulus). Conditions that affect valves are: Congenital Endocarditis Rheumatic fever Myxomatous (prolapse) Traumatic Syphilis Ankylosing spondylitis Conditions that affect aortic root are: Aortic dissection Cystic medial degeneration Marfan syndrome Bicuspid aortic valve Hypertension

question_text: A 55-year-old male patient presents to the hospital with palpitations. On examination, a diastolic murmur is heard in the left third intercostal space and pistol shot sound is heard over the femoral arteries. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The presence of a diastolic murmur along with the pistol shot sound over the femoral is most likely to be due to aortic regurgitation. The image below explains the mechanism of aortic regurgitation.

question_text: A 58-year-old man presented with exertional dyspnea and angina. On examination, the pulse was characterized by abrupt distention and quick collapse. Auscultation revealed an early diastolic murmur. Which of the following is a feature of this murmur with respect to the likely diagnosis in this case?
options: Severity correlates with intensity of murmur
explanation: The given clinical features are suggestive of aortic regurgitation. An early diastolic murmur is a high-pitched decrescendo diastolic murmur. Auscultatory findings in AR are: Soft S1 - due to the early closure of the mitral valve Diminished or absent A2 S3 - due to increased left ventricular (LV) end-diastolic volume. The presence of S3 may be a sign f impaired LV function. Austin Flint murmur - a low-pitched, mid to late diastolic murmur. It is caused due to the large volume of regurgitant blood, hitting the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve or LV wall.

question_text: Which of the following is the criteria for severe aortic regurgitation, in transthoracic doppler echocardiography?
explanation: Regurgitant volume >60mL/ beat is the criteria for severe aortic regurgitation, in transthoracic doppler echocardiography (TTE). Doppler echocardiography can be used to assess the severity of aortic regurgitation. According to this, AR is considered to be severe when: Central jet width is more than 65% of left ventricular outflow tract Vena contracta width >6mm Regurgitant fraction >50% Regurgitant volume >60mL/beat Effective regurgitant orifice >0.3cm2

question_text: What is the treatment of choice in symptomatic acute severe aortic regurgitation?
explanation: The treatment of choice in symptomatic acute severe AR is aortic valve replacement (AVR). Treatment of aortic regurgitation: In non-severe AR, periodic monitoring can be done. The symptoms of dyspnea and decreased cardiac output can be managed by diuretics and vasodilators. In severe AR, surgery (AVR) is indicated in the following conditions: The patient is symptomatic. The patient is asymptomatic, but the LV ejection fraction is less than 50% or LV end-diastolic diameter is more than 65mm. The patient is asymptomatic and undergoing other cardiac surgeries.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A patient has enlarged neck veins, hepatomegaly and a holosystolic murmur along the lower left sternal margin. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The most likely diagnosis in the above clinical scenario is tricuspid regurgitation. Clinical features of tricuspid regurgitation are: Distended neck veins with prominent c-v waves Hepatomegaly with systolic pulsations Positive hepatojugular reflex - the distension of the jugular vein when firm pressure is applied ver the liver Blowing holosystolic murmur along the lower left sternal margin

question_text: On auscultation of a patient, a murmur was heard which is depicted by the following phonocardiogram. Which of the given conditions is most likely to produce this murmur?
explanation: The given phonocardiogram is of a pansystolic/holosystolic murmur. It is heard in mitral regurgitation (MR), tricuspid regurgitation (TR), and ventricular septal defect (VSD).

question_text: A patient has a right upper limb BP of 180/95 mm Hg and a left upper limb BP of 130/90 mm Hg. He also has an early diastolic murmur in right 2nd intercostal space. Which of the following is least likely to be associated with these findings?
explanation: A significant difference in blood pressure measured between two arms (>10 mm Hg) may be seen in Takayasu arteritis (subclavian artery disease), supravalvular aortic stenosis, aortic coarctation, and aortic dissection (all four options). An early diastolic murmur in the right second intercostal space (aortic area) is suggestive of aortic regurgitation. Supravalvular aortic stenosis (Option A), which involves the part of the aorta distal to the aortic valve, is unlikely to cause aortic regurgitation and hence the best answer. Carcinoid of heart
explanation: Barlow’s syndrome refers to mitral valve prolapse. Mitral valve prolapse syndrome is also called as systolic click-murmur syndrome, Barlow’s syndrome or floppy valve syndrome. question_text: In patients with infective endocarditis, the vegetations are most commonly present on:
explanation: The mitral valve is the most common valve affected in infective endocarditis. Infective endocarditis is the infection of the endocardial layer of the heart. It may involve the endocardial layer over the heart valves, mural endocardium, or septum. However, it can also affect intracardiac devices. Note: Infection of the arteriovenous shunts and the arterio-arterial shunt is called infective endarteritis and not infective endocarditis.

question_text: Which of the following is not a cardiac manifestation of infective endocarditis?
explanation: Roth's spots are not the cardiac manifestation of infective endocarditis (IE). They are the immunological phenomenon seen in patients with infective endocarditis. Symptoms of infective endocarditis can be broadly divided into cardiac and non-cardiac manifestations. Non-cardiac manifestations of infective endocarditis are further divided into immunologic and vascular phenomena. Cardiac manifestations of IE: Presence of new regurgitant murmurs Congestive heart failure due to valve dysfunction Perivalvular abscesses and intracardiac fistulae- caused due to the extension of infection beyond the valves and into the adjacent myocardial tissue Conduction system defects- due to the damage of the interventricular septum by the abscess. Embolization of coronary arteries Non-cardiac manifestations of IE: Immunological phenomena (mnemonic ROGeR): Osler's nodes- small, tender, red papules that are present on the distal finger and toe pads. Roth's spots- white-centered retinal hemorrhages Immune-complex mediated glomerulonephritis Positivity for rheumatoid factor Vascular phenomena: Janeway lesions- these are faint, red, macular, painless lesions, commonly present on the thenar and hypothenar eminences. question_text: Which of the following is not included in the minor criteria of modified Duke criteria for clinical diagnosis of infective endocarditis?
options: Positive blood culture but not meeting the major criterion
Positive echocardiogram not meeting major criteria

question_text: According to the modified Duke criteria, a single positive blood culture is included in the major criteria for which organism?
explanation: According to modified Duke criteria for the diagnosis of infective endocarditis, single positive blood culture for Coxiella burnetii or phase I IgG antibody titre > 1:800 is included in the major criteria.

question_text: A known IV drug abuser is referred to medicine OPD from the de-addiction wing due to prolonged fever and new-onset seizures. His fever has been present for 2 weeks and did not come down with antibiotics. An early diastolic murmur is heard on auscultation. Multiple painless skin lesions are present on the hands. What are these lesions?
explanation: The above scenario is suggestive of infective endocarditis. The skin lesions shown in the image are Janeway lesions. They are non-tender, erythematous, or hemorrhagic macular or nodular lesions, which are present on the palms or soles. Another skin finding that can be found in patients with infective endocarditis is Osler's nodes. In contrast to Janeway lesions, these are small, tender, red papules which are present on the distal finger and toe pads.

question_text: Which of the following is true about the vegetations seen in infective endocarditis?
options: Present mainly along the lines of closure
Present on both side of valve leaflets
explanation: Vegetations of infective endocarditis can extend onto chordae and are: Large and irregular Mainly present on valve cusps Prone to embolization

question_text: You are asked to collect blood samples for culture from a patient suspected to have infective endocarditis by a typical pathogen. Choose the correct statement for the same.
options: 3 separate culture sets - two aerobic and one anaerobic
3 separate culture sets - two anaerobic and one aerobic
2 separate culture sets - one aerobic and one anaerobic
explanation: Option D. According to the Modified Duke 2023 Criteria for infective endocarditis, when a typical organism is suspected, two separate culture sets are required, one aerobic and one anaerobic. If an atypical organism is suspected, three or more separate culture sets are used. According to the new Duke’s criteria, there is no specific timing to draw blood for blood culture.

question_text: A patient develops prosthetic valve endocarditis 2 years after valve replacement surgery. Which of the following organism is the most likely cause?
explanation: Patient developing endocarditis 2 years after prosthetic valve surgery suggests late-onset endocarditis. In such cases, the most common causative organism is streptococci.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 38-year-old patient presented with malaise, fatigue, and rigors for 1 week. Multiple puncture sites were present on the forearm along with sclerosed veins. His temperature on admission was 38.5 °C. Examination revealed a pan-systolic murmur which was loudest at the left sternal edge. Three sets of blood cultures were taken. Which organism is most likely to be found in his blood cultures?
explanation: The above clinical scenario is suggestive of infective endocarditis. Staphylococcus aureus is most likely to be positive in cultures as it is the most common cause of infective endocarditis in IV drug abusers. Endocarditis in injection drug users is mostly right-sided and involves the tricuspid valve.
subject: Medicine

question_text: What is the most common cause of culture-negative infective endocarditis?
explanation: The most common cause of culture-negative infective endocarditis is the prior use of antibiotics. Some proportion of patients with endocarditis have negative blood cultures. The important causes are: Prior antibiotic use (most common cause) IE due to fastidious organisms or unusual pathogens or fungi such as: Streptococci (Granulicatella and Abiotrophia species) HACEK organisms Coxiella burnetii Bartonella species Brucella Tropheryma whipplei
subject: Medicine

question_text:
An 80-year-old woman with a history of moderate aortic stenosis presented with fatigue, weight loss, and night sweats for 2 weeks. Blood tests showed the following.
Echocardiography revealed an intracardiac mass on the mitral valve. Blood cultures showed growth of Streptococcus gallolyticus. What additional investigation should be performed?
explanation: The given clinical features and laboratory investigations are suggestive of infective endocarditis caused due to Streptococcus gallolyticus. In this condition, a colonoscopy should be performed. Streptococcus gallolyticus originates from the gastrointestinal tract and is associated with polyps and colon cancer. Hence, the presence of this organism in the vegetation of infective endocarditis should warrant a gastrointestinal investigation.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Transesophageal echocardiography is preferred over transthoracic echocardiography as initial investigation in all of the following patients, except:
options: Patient with suspected prosthetic valve endocarditis
Patient with suspected IE presenting with fever
Patient with suspected IE with a new onset regurgitant murmur
Patient with suspected IE who has previous history of IE
explanation: For a patient with low suspicion of IE, transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) will be done as an initial investigation. Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) is preferred as the initial investigation in all high-risk patients and/or in patients where a high clinical suspicion of infective endocarditis (IE) exists. TEE is also preferred over TTE for evaluating: Vegetations < 2mm in diameter Prosthetic valve endocarditis (PVE) Detection of myocardial abscess Detection of valve perforation Detection of intracardiac fistulae Detection of vegetations in a patient with a cardiovascular implantable electronic device (CIED)
subject: Medicine

question_text: Patients with which of the following conditions have the lowest risk of developing infective endocarditis?
explanation: Atrial septal defect (ASD) is associated with a very low incidence of IE. In ASD, the velocity of the shunt blood is low due to the decreased pressure gradient between the two atria. This low velocity of the blood does not usually damage the lining endocardium. Unrepaired VSD is the most frequent congenital heart disease lesion associated with IE, followed by ventricular outflow tract obstructive lesions, such as with tetralogy of Fallot. question_text: A 50-year-old woman underwent mitral valve replacement for severe MR, 5 years ago. She is now posted for an elective colonoscopy, for evaluation of altered bowel habits. What is the recommendation regarding antibiotic prophylaxis for this patient?
options: Amoxicillin, 2g orally, taken 30 to 60 minutes before the procedure
Clindamycin 600mg orally, taken 30 minutes before the procedure
Ampicillin, 2g IM or IV 60 minutes before the procedure
explanation: Antibiotic prophylaxis is not required in patients undergoing genitourinary or gastrointestinal procedures even if they have a high-risk cardiac lesion for developing infecting endocarditis (e.g., prosthetic valve). Antibiotic prophylaxis is recommended for patients who are undergoing dental procedures, invasive respiratory tract procedures, and procedures on the infected skin.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Antibiotic prophylaxis is recommended for each of the following patients undergoing dental procedures, except:
options: A patient with palliative shunt for cyanotic CHD
A patient with previous CABG surgery
Patient with valvulopathy post cardiac transplantation
A patient with prosthetic heart valve
explanation: Routine antibiotic prophylaxis for infective endocarditis is not recommended for patients with previous coronary artery bypass graft surgery. They do not have a long-term risk of infection. High-risk cardiac lesions, for which endocarditis prophylaxis is advised before dental procedures are: Prosthetic heart valves Prior endocarditis Unrepaired cyanotic congenital heart disease, including palliative shunts or conduits Completely repaired congenital heart defects during the 6 months after repair Incompletely repaired congenital heart disease with residual defects adjacent to prosthetic material Valvulopathy developing after cardiac transplantation Antibiotic prophylaxis is not routinely recommended for patients with acquired valvular heart diseases. Standard regimen: Amoxicillin 2g per orally is given 1-hour prior to surgery. In patients with penicillin allergy, clarithromycin, and azithromycin 500mg per orally can be given.
subject: Medicine

question_text: The blood culture of a patient with suspected infective endocarditis is positive for gram-positive cocci in chains. What is the treatment of choice?
explanation: The treatment for infective endocarditis with streptococci consists of penicillin with gentamicin for 2 weeks. Penicillin G (2-3mU IV Q4h) or Ceftriaxone (2g single dose daily) can be given as a monotherapy for 4 weeks. question_text: A 43-year-old patient presented with spikes of fever and difficulty in breathing. Transesophageal echo revealed vegetations in the heart. The culture was positive for Burkholderia cepacia. Which of the following is the first line of management?
explanation: The first-line agents used in the management of Burkholderia cepacia complex (BCC) infections are trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (cotrimoxazole), meropenem, minocycline, and ceftazidime (3rd generation cephalosporin). Other options: Option A: Burkholderia species are intrinsically resistant to aminoglycosides and polymyxins. Option C: Tigecycline is less effective in the case of Burkholderia infections. Option D: Carbapenems and 3rd generation cephalosporins have the same mechanism of action and compete for the same binding site. Hence, it is not a rational drug combination. BCC is a group of bacteria known for causing severe respiratory distress and septicemia, particularly in patients with cystic fibrosis (CF). BCC organisms are also found in ICU patients and individuals with chronic granulomatous disease, leading to lung disease. BCC colonization in CF patients prior to lung transplantation increases the risk of death during the early transplant period.
subject: Medicine

question_text: What is the causative organism of acute rheumatic fever?
explanation: Acute rheumatic fever is caused due to infection with group A streptococcus (GAS), which is Streptococcus pyogenes. It usually follows a streptococcal sore throat or scarlet fever. Other groups of streptococci do not cause acute rheumatic fever. The pathogenesis of the development of ARF is based on the concept of molecular mimicry. The antibodies which are produced against M protein and N-acetyl glucosamine of group A streptococci, bind to and damage the human endothelial cells. It mainly affects children between 5-14 years of age. Patients have various rheumatologic, cardiac, and neurological manifestations. Modified Jone's criteria is used for the diagnosis of acute rheumatic fever. The main aim of treatment of rheumatic fever is to relieve symptoms, prevent inflammation and prevent further infections by group A streptoccus by the use of penicillins.
subject: Medicine

question_text: What is the most common clinical feature seen in patients with acute rheumatic fever?
explanation: The most common clinical feature of acute rheumatic fever is carditis followed by polyarthritis.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is a feature of Sydenham’s chorea?
options: Affects mainly the head and upper limbs
Occurs within 3 weeks of streptococcal infection
Only restricted to one half of the body
explanation: Choreiform movements in Sydenham’s chorea is mainly seen in the head & upper limbs. Sydenham chorea is characterized by the presence of involuntary, purposeless, jerky movements of the hands, arms, shoulders, feet, legs, face, and trunk. The movements may be generalized or restricted to one side of the body. It follows a long latent period (more than 6 months) and therefore can occur alone without any other clinical manifestations.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is a feature of subcutaneous nodules palpated in a patient with acute rheumatic fever?
explanation: Subcutaneous nodules are commonly present in hands, feet, elbows, and occiput. They are firm, painless, and freely movable subcutaneous nodules, present over the bony prominences of hands, feet, elbow, and occiput. They are a delayed manifestation of rheumatic fever and are usually associated with carditis.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is a minor criterion according to modified Jones criteria for diagnosis of rheumatic fever in low risk population?
explanation: ESR 60 mm and polyarthralgia are a part of minor criteria for the low-risk population among the given options. The major and minor criteria for arthritis differ in low risk and medium to high-risk populations. For low-risk populations, polyarthritis is a major criterion and polyarthralgia is a minor criterion. In the medium to high-risk populations, polyarthritis, polyarthralgia, monoarthritis are major criteria and monoarthralgia is a minor criterion.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which among the following is not a feature of joint pain seen in patients with rheumatic fever?
explanation: In rheumatic fever, joint pain is usually asymmetric. Characteristic features of arthritis of acute rheumatic fever are: Migratory- the pain moves from one joint to another over a period of hours Involvement of large joints – most commonly knees, ankle, hips & elbows Asymmetric Highly responsive to salicylates
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 30-year-old patient presented to the clinic with skin lesions as shown in the image. On examination, body temperature is 38.5 °C, ESR and ASLO titers are elevated. What is true about the skin finding?
options: Generally occurs in patients with carditis
explanation: The above clinical features are suggestive of rheumatic fever and the skin finding shown in the image is erythema marginatum. It generally occurs in patients with carditis. Erythema marginatum is a pink, non-pruritic rash that generally occurs on the upper part of the arms or trunk but not on the face. It extends from the centre with an irregular serpiginous border. As the size of the rash increases, the center of the rash returns to normal, while the borders remain pink. Hence it is named erythema marginatum. The rash may also become more prominent after a hot shower.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Evidence of preceding streptococcal infection is not essential for making a diagnosis of acute rheumatic fever in patients presenting with:
explanation: Evidence of preceding streptococcal infection for making diagnosis of acute rheumatic fever (ARF) is not required in the presence of chorea. Chorea is frequently a late finding of ARF. When chorea appears, major findings, minor findings and findings of preceding streptococcal infection would have been disappeared.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A patient diagnosed with acute rheumatic fever develops a new-onset murmur. His echocardiography is likely to reveal:
explanation: Characteristic initial valvular manifestation in acute rheumatic fever (ARF) is mitral regurgitation. Damage of the valves leads to mitral regurgitation in the early stages. With repeated episodes of rheumatic fever, there is thickening, calcification, and stenosis of the affected valve. Mitral regurgitation is the most common cardiac lesion in ARF, while mitral stenosis is the most common lesion in rheumatic heart disease. Other cardiac manifestations of acute rheumatic fever include myocardial inflammation that can also affect electrical conduction pathways, leading to P-R interval prolongation (first-degree atrioventricular block or rarely higher-level block) and softening of the first heart sound.
subject: Medicine

question_text: The prevalence of rheumatic valvular heart disease peaks between:
explanation: The prevalence of rheumatic valvular heart disease peaks between 25-40 years. Acute rheumatic fever is mainly a disease of children and is common between 5–14 years of age and rare in a person aged more 30 years. In contrast to this, rheumatic valvular heart disease is common between 25-40 years.
subject: Medicine

question_text: The drug used for refractory intractable rheumatic chorea is:
explanation: The drug used for refractory intractable rheumatic chorea is sodium valproate. Sydenham's chorea is characterized by involuntary, purposeless, jerky movements which mainly affect the head and upper limbs. In the tongue, it is visible as the characteristic darting movements. Medications used to treat Sydenham chorea are: Mild cases: managed by providing a calm environment Severe cases: dopamine antagonists like haloperidol, pimozide, or antiepileptic medications like sodium valproate (preferred due to no extrapyramidal side effects) and carbamazepine Since Sydenham chorea is thought to be an immune-mediated disorder, steroids are effective in the treatment of severe or refractory cases.
subject: Medicine

question_text:
A 12-year-old boy is admitted with fever and polyarthritis. His ESR on admission is 80mm/hr. There is no evidence of carditis. A diagnosis of acute rheumatic fever is made and treatment is initiated. How long will you put the patient on secondary prophylaxis?
Till 21 years of age
explanation: This patient has a rheumatic fever without carditis. He should be given prophylaxis till 21 years of age as the duration of secondary prophylaxis is 5 years or until 21 years of age (whichever is longer). Secondary prophylaxis is given for patients with acute rheumatic fever (ARF). These patients are at a higher risk of developing a further episode of ARF after a group A streptococcal infection. Hence they should receive long-term penicillin prophylaxis to prevent recurrent infections. The antibiotics that can be given for secondary prophylaxis are: Benzathine penicillin G (1.2 million units) given every 4 weeks (Best antibiotic) Oral penicillin V (250 mg) given twice daily (less effective than benzathine penicillin G) Erythromycin (250 mg) twice daily (For patients allergic to penicillin) Hypertensive Vascular Disease
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is false with respect to lifestyle modifications for managing essential hypertension as recommended by AHA 2019 guidelines?
explanation: Low potassium increases blood pressure and hence is not recommended in the dietary modifications. On the contrary, potassium supplementation lowers the BP significantly in hypertensives. It is given preferably by dietary modifications unless contraindicated.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 57-year-old male patient presented to the clinic for a routine clinical check-up. On examination, his BP was found to be 136/88 mmHg. During his subsequent visits, the systolic blood pressure recorded was found to be within the range of 130-138 mmHg and diastolic blood pressure was within the range of 86-88mmHg. According to the European guidelines for hypertension 2018, his blood pressure would be classified as
explanation: According to European guidelines for hypertension 2018, systolic blood pressure between 130-139 mmHg and diastolic blood pressure between 85-89 mmHg is classified as high normal.
subject: Medicine

question_text: An 80-year-old male patient complains of headache and dizziness. His ambulatory BP was recorded to be in the range of 144-152/80-86 mmHg. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: SBP 140 mm Hg and DBP <90 mmHg is called isolated systolic hypertension. White-coat hypertension is characterized by: The office blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg on 3 separate office visits 2 blood pressure measurements taken outside the office are <140/90 mm Hg, frequently using home blood pressure monitoring; and There is no evidence of hypertensive target organ damage.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is the gold standard investigation to measure vessel wall stiffness in patients suspected to have hypertension mediated end-organ damage (HMOD)?
explanation: Carotid-femoral pulse wave velocity (PWV) is the gold standard for measuring large artery stiffness due to hypertension. Long-standing hypertension can lead to structural and functional changes in arteries and target organs like the heart, brain, arteries, and kidneys. This is called hypertension mediated organ damage (HMOD). question_text: A 60-year-old male patient has grade 2 hypertension. He is also a known case of type 2 diabetes for 9 years. What is the desired goal for blood pressure range in this patient?
explanation: In a patient (18-65 years) with hypertension and coexisting diabetes, the desired goal for systolic blood pressure is between 120-130 mmHg and diastolic blood pressure is between 70-79 mmHg. In patients above 65 years of age, the desired goal of systolic blood pressure is between 130-139 while the desired diastolic range remains the same. This goal is in accordance with the European Society of Cardiology guidelines (2018).
subject: Medicine

question_text: While treating a 45 year old hypertensive patient with underlying coronary artery disease, what target blood pressure should you titrate for, as per the ESC 2018 guidelines?
explanation: The target systolic blood pressure for hypertensive patients in the age group 18-65 years with coronary artery disease is between 120-130 mmHg.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 58-year-old male patient has been diagnosed with hypertension. On examination, there is no existing cardiovascular disease, no hypertension mediated organ damage (HMOD) and the renal function is normal. He should be immediately started with pharmacological management if his blood pressure is more than .
explanation: In this patient with no markers of cardiovascular disease, no hypertension-mediated end-organ damage (HMOD), and normal renal function, immediate pharmacological treatment is recommended when the blood pressure (BP) is 140/90 mmHg according to the AHA and ESH on the management of hypertension. Guidelines for Hypertension Management: Adults 18–79 y with SBP 140 mm Hg or DBP 90 mm Hg Adults 80 y with SBP 160 mm Hg but 140 mm Hg can be considered. In frail patients, individualize treatment. In patients with CVD, especially CAD, SBP 130 mm Hg, or DBP 80 mm Hg. Treatment BP targets: Adults 18–79 y, primary SBP/DBP goal <140/90 mm Hg; if treatment well tolerated target SBP/DBP <130/80 mm Hg but not SBP <120 mm Hg or DBP <70 mm Hg. For adults with isolated systolic hypertension, target SBP lowering, albeit cautiously. question_text: A 72-year-old man who is a known hypertensive for 12 years comes for a regular health check-up. On examination, his blood pressure is 172/100 mmHg. His serum creatinine is 1.5mg/dL, urinary albumin to creatinine ratio (UACR) is 40mg/g, and GFR is 49mL/min. What is the preferred antihypertensive treatment in this scenario?
explanation: In the given clinical scenario, the patient is hypertensive along with chronic kidney disease. The preferred initial antihypertensive treatment is captopril with amlodipine. The preferred treatment in hypertensive patients with chronic kidney disease is a combination of angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACEi) or angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs) with calcium channel blockers (CCBs) or diuretics (ACEi/ARBs + CCBs/diuretics).
subject: Medicine

question_text: A hypertensive patient is on metoprolol. If verapamil is added, there is a risk of:
explanation: Metoprolol, when added with verapamil, leads to bradycardia with AV block. Verapamil and  blockers have additive effect on inhibiting SA node and AV conduction, and the combination should be avoided to prevent severe bradycardia and conduction block. These agents can also have additive effect on decreasing left ventricular function which could seriously impair cardiac output in a patient with heart failure.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A hypertensive patient underwent coronary angiography after he presented with chest pain. His angiographic image is as below. What is the preferred drug for the management of hypertension in this patient?
explanation: The above coronary angiogram shows partial occlusion of the left circumflex coronary artery. Beta-blockers like atenolol in combination with ACE inhibitors or ARBs or calcium channe blockers or diuretics are preferred for the management of hypertension in patients with coronary artery disease. Other indications for beta-blockers are: Congestive heart failure due to systolic dysfunction Post myocardial infarction Sinus tachycardia Ventricular arrhythmias The image below shows partial occlusion of left circumflex coronary artery.

question_text: A 30-year-old man presents with sudden onset of a headache, palpitation, and profuse sweating. He had several such episodes in the past. During these episodes, his BP is found to be high. A 24-hour urinary metanephrine is elevated. What is the most likely etiology?
explanation: The most likely etiology is pheochromocytoma. Patients commonly present with a classical triad of palpitation, headache and profuse sweating. The presence of this triad in association with hypertension and elevated 24-hour urinary metanephrine makes pheochromocytoma a likely diagnosis.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 35-year-old female patient has hypokalemia, hypertension and metabolic alkalosis. What is the most likely etiology?
explanation: Hypertension with hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis is seen in Liddle's syndrome. Liddle's syndrome (pseudo aldosteronism) is an autosomal dominant condition that is caused due to the increased activation of ENaC channels. This causes increased reabsorption of Na+ exchanged for K+ causing hypokalemia. Increased Na absorption leads to hypertension, and there is also a loss of H+ ion with K+, leading to metabolic alkalosis. It is associated with low renin and low aldosterone levels.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following statements are true with respect to hypertensive emergency as per ESC 2018 guidelines?
explanation: Hypertensive emergencies are situations in which grade 3 hypertension (BP>180/110 mmHg) is associated with acute hypertension-mediated organ damage (HMOD). Treatment of hypertensive emergency depends on the type of end-organ damage present (as shown in the table below). It is treated with rapidly acting intravenous antihypertensive agents. In hypertensive encephalopathy, the initial goal of therapy is to immediately reduce mean arterial blood (MAP) pressure by no more than 25%. Rapid reduction of blood pressure may lead to reduced cerebral blood flow and result in cerebral infarction. The table below shows the treatment of various hypertensive emergencies with intravenous drug therapy.

question_text: Which of the following patients would you diagnose as having hypertensive urgency?
explanation: Patient 3 suffers from hypertensive urgency as BP > 180/110 mmHg and end-organ damage is not seen. Target organ damage is absent in hypertensive urgency but is present in a hypertensive emergency. Severe hypertension (grade 3) is generally defined as blood pressure 180/110 mmHg. Hypertensive emergency, hypertensive urgency, and malignant hypertension are all forms of severe hypertension. Option A: Patient 1 suffers from hypertension. Since BP <180/110 mmHg it is not a hypertensive crisis (urgency or emergency). Option B: Patient 2 has a BP > 180/110 mmHg along with symptoms of hypertensive encephalopathy. This is an example of a hypertensive emergency as there is severe hypertension with signs or symptoms of hypertensive-mediated organ damage (HMOD). Option D: Patient 4 has a BP > 180/110 mm Hg along with papilledema. This is a case of severe hypertension associated with fundoscopic changes (flame hemorrhages, papilloedema) which is suggestive of malignant hypertension. Microangiopathy, DIC, and encephalopathy may also be present. Fibrinoid necrosis of arterioles and small arteries is seen. The prognosis is very poor if untreated. Posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome (PRES) or acute hypertensive encephalopathy is a rare complication in patients with an acute rise in blood pressure. Due to the acute rise, there is increased cerebral perfusion and edema of the brain. Clinically it is recognized by alteration in mental status, nausea, headache, visual disturbance, seizure, or development of focal neurological deficits.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 55-year-old female patient who is a known case of hypertension, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia presents to the emergency department with a severe headache and vomiting. The patient is agitated and her blood pressure is 220/120 mmHg. Ophthalmoscopy reveals the presence of papilledema. Which of the following antihypertensive is least useful in the management of this patient?
explanation: The above scenario points towards the diagnosis of malignant hypertension. The drug which is east useful in the management is furosemide(diuretic). Volume depletion is common in patients with malignant hypertension, and the administration of a diuretic together with a hypertensive agent can lead to an extreme drop in blood pressure. Diuretics are generally not recommended for the rapid reduction of blood pressure in patients with hypertensive crises. They are used only in conditions of volume overload such as acute pulmonary edema.
subject: Medicine

question_text:
Which of the following is the most important risk factor for the development of hypertension?
High salt intake
explanation: The most important risk factor for the development of hypertension is obesity. Hypertension is defined as repeated office systolic blood pressure of  140 mm Hg and/or diastolic blood pressure of  90 mm Hg. Primary/essential hypertension is the leading cause of hypertension in adults. It is caused due to the interaction of genetic factors with various other factors such as diet, sedentary lifestyle, etc. In some people, hypertension may result from renal, endocrine, or adrenal disorders (secondary hypertension). Risk factors of hypertension can be divided into modifiable and non-modifiable: Non-modifiable risk factors are: Age- risk increases with age Sex- in young and middle-aged adults, the risk is higher in males Genetic factors- mutation in the genes which encode the components of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system, atrial natriuretic peptide, and alpha adducin Ethnicity Modifiable risk factors are: Obesity (most important) High alcohol intake High salt intake Sedentary lifestyle Stress Dyslipidemia Diet low in potassium and calcium Ischemic Heart Disease - Presentation and Diagnosis
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following arteries is most commonly involved in patients with coronary artery disease?
explanation: The left anterior descending (anterior interventricular) coronary artery is most commonly involved in coronary artery disease (CAD) or coronary heart disease or ischemic heart disease. The regions affected are the anterior wall of the left ventricle near the apex and the anterior portion of the ventricular septum. CAD is caused by plaque buildup in the walls of the coronary arteries that narrow over time and can partially or totally block the blood flow causing myocardial ischemia and subsequently infarction. The image below shows coronary circulation.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which area of the myocardium is most vulnerable to damage in patients with ischemic heart disease?
explanation: Subendocardium is the region of the myocardium most vulnerable to ischemic damage. The myocardium is perfused from the epicardium to the endocardium. This results in the subendocardium being the least perfused region making it most vulnerable to ischemic damage. A narrow zone of the myocardium immediately beneath the endocardium is spared from necrosis because it can be oxygenated by diffusion from the ventricle.
subject: Medicine

question_text:
A patient presented to the emergency with symptoms of unstable angina. ECG done in pain-free interval showed biphasic T waves in precordial leads without ST changes. Cardiac
troponins were normal. Coronary angiography revealed stenosis of the proximal left anterior descending artery. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The above scenario is suggestive of Wellens syndrome. It is alternatively known as anterior, descending, T-wave syndrome. The ECG pattern of Wellens syndrome is relatively common in patients who exhibit symptoms consistent with unstable angina. ECG in the pain-free interval is characterized by deeply inverted or biphasic T waves in precordial leads and with minimal or no ST elevations. Cardiac enzymes are normal or mildly elevated. These patients are at high risk for impending large anterior wall acute myocardial infarction. The ECG below shows biphasic T waves in leads V2 and V3 and inverted T waves in leads V4 and V5 in Wellens syndrome. Option A: Broken heart syndrome is another name for Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. Option C: Barlow syndrome is associated with mitral valve prolapse. Option D: Brugada syndrome is a genetic cardiac rhythm disorder.
subject: Medicine

question_text: In a patient with suspected stable angina, which of the following findings are likely to be present?
options: CK-MB is elevated ; Troponin T is norma
Troponin I is elevated ; Myoglobin is norma
Myoglobin is elevated ; CK-MB is norma
Troponin I is normal ; CK-MB is norma
explanation: The levels of cardiac markers remain unchanged in stable and unstable angina as there is no necrosis of cardiac myocytes. The clinical presentations of ischemic heart disease can be broadly classified into: Chronic coronary syndrome (CCS) - this includes Stable angina - this is an episodic angina that occurs with predictable severity, frequency, and threshold of precipitation by stressors, and is relieved by rest and nitrates Acute coronary syndrome (ACS) - this includes Unstable angina - this is diagnosed in patients with symptoms suggestive of an ACS with no elevation of biomarkers Myocardial infarction - it is the necrosis and death of a portion of the myocardium due to prolonged ischemia. The cardiac biomarkers are elevated in this condition

question_text: While evaluating a patient with chest pain in the emergency, you ask him to localize the sensation. He places a hand over the sternum with a clenched fist. What is this sign called?
explanation: When a patient with angina is asked to localize the sensation, he or she typically places a hand over the sternum, sometimes with a clenched fist, to indicate a squeezing, central, substernal discomfort. This is called Levine’s sign. Option A: Mayne's sign- Drop of at least 15 mmHg in the diastolic blood pressure on raising the arm. It occurs in patients with aortic regurgitation (not reliable). Option C: Frank’s sign- Diagonal crease in the ear lobe indicative of cardiovascular diseases and/or diabetes. Option D: Friedreich's sign- Exaggerated drop in JVP seen in constrictive pericarditis.

question_text: A 60-year-old woman presents with chest discomfort, associated with a squeezing sensation in the substernal area. She added that it was precipitated by physical activity and relieved on taking rest. Which of the following is a feature of this condition?
explanation: The above scenario is suggestive of stable angina in which the pain is usually crescendo-decrescendo in nature.
