It is an autoimmune disorder triggered by infections like: Campylobacter jejuni Cytomegalovirus (CMV) Epstein Barr virus Mycoplasma Varicella zoster virus Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), dengue, or influenza It manifests as a rapidly evolving areflexic motor paralysis, with or without sensory disturbance. The usual pattern is ascending paralysis. Proximal and distal muscles are equally involved. The lower cranial nerves are frequently affected, causing bulbar weakness.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following sensory deficits is severely affected in a patient with Guillain-Barre syndrome?
explanation: Loss of proprioception is severe in Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS). GBS affects the large sensory fibers, leading to attenuation or loss of deep tendon reflexes and loss of proprioception. Cutaneous sensory deficits (e.g., loss of pain and temperature sensation) are usually relatively mild.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A patient presents with complaints of lower extremity weakness. He initially noticed difficulty climbing the stairs and now he is unable to stand. He gives a history of bloody diarrhea a few weeks ago. Which of the following parameters are expected to be elevated in the CSF of this patient?
explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS). Protein levels are elevated (100-1000mg/dl) in the CSF of a patient with this condition. The CSF cell counts are usually normal. Albuminocytologic dissociation, which is an elevation in CSF protein without an elevation in white blood cells, is characteristic in GBS. Causes of albuminocytologic dissociation are: Guillain-Barre Syndrome Spinal cord tumours
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following conditions does not present with autonomic dysfunction?
explanation: Subclavian steal syndrome does not present with autonomic dysfunction. Option A: Polyneuropathy is seen in sporadic and familial amyloidosis. In some cases, autonomic insufficiency presents before distal painful polyneuropathy accompanied by sensory loss Option B: Guillain-Barré syndrome is associated with autonomic instability. This can present with BP fluctuations, arrhythmias, and GI disturbances. Option C: Botulinum toxin binds presynaptically to cholinergic nerve terminals. After uptake into the cytoplasm, it blocks ACh release. Thus, patients with botulism present with motor paralysis and autonomic disturbances.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 23-year-old patient presents with rapidly progressing symmetric ascending paralysis since 2 days. Nerve conduction studies are consistent with demyelination. He is found to have an elevated protein level in his CSF. Which of the following autonomic disturbance is likely to be seen in this patient?
explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of Guillian-Barre syndrome (GBS). Postural hypotension is a common autonomic disturbance seen in this condition. Autonomic involvement is common and may occur even in patients whose GBS is otherwise mild. The usual autonomic manifestations are: Loss of vasomotor control with wide fluctuation in blood pressure, postural hypotension Cardiac dysrhythmias
subject: Medicine

question_text: The triad of Miller-Fisher syndrome includes all of the following, except:
explanation: Weakness is not seen in the triad of Miller-Fisher syndrome (MFS). Miller Fisher syndrome is a variant of Guillain-Barré syndrome(GBS). Like Guillain-Barré syndrome, symptoms may be preceded by a viral illness. It classically presents as a triad of: Ataxia Areflexia Ophthalmoplegia The condition is usually not associated with weakness, and even if present, is very mild. It is strongly associated with antibodies to the ganglioside GQ1b. The prognosis in Miller Fisher syndrome is usually good with recovery beginning within 2 to 4 weeks of the symptom onset, and completing by 6 months. Some individuals are left with residual deficits. Relapses are rare. Treatment for Miller Fisher syndrome is identical to treatment for Guillain-Barré syndrome: intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIg) or plasmapheresis and supportive care.
subject: Medicine

question_text:
A patient presented to the ER with tingling, numbness, and weakness in all four limbs. She says that the weakness started in the lower limbs and progressed to the upper limbs within a day. History is significant for a recent COVID-19 infection and surgery for cervical spondylosis and disc herniation 3 years ago. CT brain was normal and an MRI of the lumbar spine showed foraminal narrowing at L2-L3. CSF analysis showed increased protein levels.
Which of the following is recommended for the initial therapy of this patient?
explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of Guillain-Barre syndrome(GBS) probably as a result of COVID-19. IV Immunoglobulin is the recommended initial therapy for patients with GBS. High-dose intravenous immune globulin (IVIg) and plasmapheresis are both equally effective in GBS and can be used as the initial therapy. However, IVIg is often the initial therapy chosen because of its ease of administration and good safety record. It is administered as five daily infusions for a total dose of 2 g/kg body weight. Glucocorticoids have not been found to be effective in GBS.
subject: Medicine

question_text: In a patient with Guillain-Barre syndrome, chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy is suspected when
options: GBS deteriorates >5 weeks after onset or relapses at least three times
GBS deteriorates >5 weeks after onset or relapses at least two times
GBS deteriorates >9 weeks after onset or relapses at least three times
GBS deteriorates >8 weeks after onset or relapses at least two times
explanation: Chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (CIDP) should be suspected when GBS deteriorates >9 weeks after onset or relapses at least three times. Onset is usually gradual over a few months or longer, but in a few cases, the initial attack is indistinguishable from that of GBS. CIDP is distinguished from GBS by its chronic course. In other respects, this neuropathy shares many features with the common demyelinating form of GBS, including elevated CSF protein levels and the electrodiagnostic studies findings of acquired demyelination.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following conditions are not associated with chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy?
explanation: Hepatitis A infection is not associated with CIDP. Diseases associated with CIDP are: Hepatitis B Hepatitis C Lymphoma HIV Diabetic mellitus Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) Pregnancy Paraneoplastic syndrome Inflammatory bowel disease Amyloidosis
subject: Medicine

question_text: All are true about chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy, except:
options: Relapse at least 3 times in a patient with Guillain-Barré syndrome
Small nerve fibers are affected more than large fibers
explanation: Large nerve fibers are affected more than small fibers in CIDP. Difference between CIDP and Guillain-barré syndrome(GBS): GBS CIDP Duration <4 we eks >8 weeks Motor symptoms Affect ed Affected Sensory symptoms Mild More significantLargefiber > small fiber Autonomic nervous syst em Affect ed Rare Antecedent event Prese nt Rare GBS CIDP Deep tendon reflex Absen t Absent Steroid No ro le 2nd line of treatment
subject: Medicine

question_text: A patient with chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy is undergoing nerve conduction study. Which of the following findings is least likely to be seen in this patient?
explanation: In CIDP, the amplitude is normal since the axons are intact. Nerve conduction study (NCS) in axonal injury and demyelinating diseases: Axonal injury Demyelination Amplitude Decreased Normal Distal latency Normal Prolonged Conduction veloci ty Normal Slow Conduction block Absent Present Temporal dispersi on Absent Present H wave Normal or abs ent Prolonged or abse nt F wave Normal or abs ent Prolonged or abse nt
subject: Medicine

question_text: In which of the following situations is nerve biopsy not indicated in patients with chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy?
options: When other causes of polyneuropathy cannot be ruled out
When there is no clinical or electrophysiological evidence of nerve functionality
explanation: Nerve biopsy should not be done if there is no clinical or electrophysiological evidence of nerve functionality of that nerve in CIDP patients. This is because completely degenerated nerves usually convey limited information. In CIDP, nerve biopsy is indicated when: Diagnosis is not clear Other causes of polyneuropathy cannot be ruled out Electromyography (EMG) shows axonal involvement
subject: Medicine

question_text: All of the following can be used for the treatment of a patient with chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy, except:
explanation: NSAIDs are not used in the treatment of CIDP. The treatment of chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (CIDP) includes high-dose IV immunoglobulin, plasmapheresis, and glucocorticoids. Initial therapy is usually with IV immunoglobulin. If all the first-line agents fail, immunosuppressants are attempted either alone or as an adjunctive treatment.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 63-year-old man presented with complaints of fatiguability and chronic back pain. On evaluation, he was found to have anemia and hypercalcemia. The X-ray of his skull is given below. Which of the following statements is true with regard to neuropathy seen in this condition?
options: Polyneuropathy is seen in 50% of patients presenting with osteoporotic bone lesions
Polyneuropathy is seen in 5% of patients presenting with osteosclerotic features
explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of multiple myeloma and the pattern of polyneuropathy seen in this condition is sensorimotor type. Multiple myeloma-associated polyneuropathies occur in ~5% of patients with the commonly encountered type of multiple myeloma. Myeloma with osteosclerotic features, although representing only 3% of all myelomas, is associated with polyneuropathy in one-half of cases. Polyneuropathy generally does not reverse even with successful suppression of the myeloma.
subject: Medicine

question_text:
What is the most common pattern of peripheral neuropathy in patients with polyarteritis nodosa?
Pure motor neuropathy
explanation: Most common pattern of peripheral neuropathy in polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is mononeuritis multiplex (multifocal motor-sensory neuropathy). It is asymmetric, due to ischemic lesions of nerve trunks and roots. Some cases present as a distal, symmetric sensorimotor polyneuropathy. Small- to medium-sized arteries of the vasa nervorum, particularly the epineural vessels, are affected in PAN, resulting in a widespread ischemic neuropathy. Combination therapy with glucocorticoids and rituximab is increasingly recommended as the standard initial treatment, particularly for ANCA-associated vasculitis. Diseases of the Spinal Cord
subject: Medicine

question_text: A patient has sensory loss just below the circumferential level of the umbilicus. This corresponds to a lesion at which spinal cord segment?
explanation: The sensory loss just below the circumferential level of the umbilicus corresponds to the lesion at the T10 spinal cord segment. It indicates the involvement of the cord adjacent to T7-T8 vertebral bodies. The spinal cord has 31 segments, but they do not always correspond to the same vertebral body. The first seven pairs of cervical spinal nerves exit above the same-numbered vertebral bodies. All the subsequent nerves exit below the same-numbered vertebral bodies. This is because of the presence of eight cervical spinal cord segments but only seven cervical vertebrae. The lower spinal nerves take an increasingly downward course to exit via intervertebral foramina.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A patient presents with quadriplegia and difficulty in breathing. This presentation can be seen in spinal cord lesions at what level?
explanation: Quadriplegia and weakness of the diaphragm (manifesting as difficulty in breathing) are associated with spinal cord lesion at the level of C1-C4 spinal segments. Diaphragm is supplied by the phrenic nerve arising from C3 - C5. The uppermost level of weakness and reflex loss with lesions: At C5-C6 : Bicep At C7: Finger, wrist extensors, and tricep At C8 : Finger and wrist flexion Note: Horner’s syndrome (characterized by miosis, ptosis, and facial hypohidrosis) may accompany a cervical cord lesion at any level.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Beevor’s sign is noted in a patient who has spinal cord injury. At what level is the injury likely to be?
explanation: The Beevor’s sign localizes the spinal cord injury at T10-T12. Beevor’s sign is the abnormal upward movement of the umbilicus on abdominal wall contraction in the supine position. This is because a lesion in the T10-T12 level of the spinal cord paralyzes the lower abdominal muscles but the upper abdominal muscles are normally resulting in the upward movement of the umbilicus.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A patient has a spinal cord lesion at the level of L2 – L4 spinal nerve roots. All of the following may be seen in this patient, except:
options: Paralysis of hip flexion and adduction
explanation: Lesions at L2 – L4 spinal nerve roots do not cause paralysis of the knee flexors. The paralysis of the flexion at the knee occurs due to the lesion at L5 – S1.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following features would you expect to see in a patient with conus medullaris syndrome?
explanation: The clinical features of the conus medullaris syndrome include: Bilateral saddle anesthesia Bladder and bowel dysfunction Impotence Absence of bulbocavernosus (S2-S4) and anal reflexes (S4-S5) The conus medullaris is the tapered caudal termination of the spinal cord, comprising all the sacral and single coccygeal segments. Damage at this level of the cord, often occurs due to injuries to the lumbar vertebra, result in conus medullaris syndrome. Muscle strength is largely preserved in this condition.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following conditions will you suspect in a patient who has bladder dysfunction early in the progression of the disease?
explanation: Early loss of bladder control is a feature of the conus medullaris syndrome. It is characterized by urinary retention and atonic anal sphincter, which cause overflow urinary incontinence and fecal incontinence, respectively. Option A: In the cauda equina syndrome, there is relative sparing of bladder control. Options C and D: Bladder dysfunction is uncommon in Guillian–Barre syndrome and ALS.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A patient with a history of a backache for 10 days, has now presented with sudden onset difficulty in micturition and defaecation. There was no history of a cough or fever previously. What is the diagnosis?
explanation: This is a case of cauda equina syndrome (CES). CES signifies an injury of multiple lumbosacral nerve roots within the spinal canal distal to the termination of the spinal cord at L1-L2. It is commonly due to a ruptured lumbosacral intervertebral disk, lumbosacral spine fracture, hematoma within the spinal canal, compressive tumor, or other mass lesions. Low back pain, weakness, and areflexia in the legs, saddle anesthesia, or loss of bladder function may occur. Treatment options include surgical decompression, sometimes urgently in an attempt to restore or preserve motor or sphincter function, or radiotherapy for metastatic tumors.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following features will help you differentiate conus medullaris syndrome from cauda equina syndrome?
explanation: Symmetric weakness of lower limbs helps in a diagnosis of conus medullaris syndrome. There is an asymmetric motor loss in cauda equina syndrome. Mass lesions in the lower spinal canal often produce a mixed clinical picture with elements of both cauda equina and conus medullaris syndromes.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which is the characteristic pattern seen in Brown-Sequard syndrome?
options: Contralateral loss of joint sense and position
Ipsilateral loss of complete sensory function
explanation: The Brown–Sequard syndrome presents with contralateral loss of pain sensation. Lateral hemisection of the spinal cord produces the Brown–Séquard syndrome (also known as the hemicord syndrome). Knife or bullet injuries and demyelination are the most common causes of this condition. Clinical features include: Ipsilateral weakness (corticospinal tract involvement) Ipsilateral loss of joint position and vibratory sense (posterior column involvement) Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sense (spinothalamic tract involvement) one or two levels below the lesion Ipsilateral segmental signs like radicular pain, muscle atrophy, or loss of a deep tendon reflex
subject: Medicine

question_text: A patient is diagnosed with Brown–Sequard syndrome with a lesion on the right side. Which of the following sensations on the right side will be affected?
explanation: Proprioception is the type of sensation lost on the same side (ipsilateral) in Brown–Sequard syndrome. This is due to a lesion of the posterior column. The sensations of crude touch, pain and temperature are lost on the opposite side, due to the lesions of anterior column or spinothalamic tract.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A patient was brought to the casualty after he was hit by a plastic pipe on the back by a bully. On examination, the patient was found to have marked upper extremity weakness compared to the lower extremities. He also had a loss of pain and temperature sensations over the shoulders, lower neck, and upper trunk. Other sensations were intact in this region. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of cape distribution of sensory deficit is seen in central cord syndrome. This condition affects the cervical cord producing arm weakness > leg weakness. A dissociated sensory loss i.e. loss of pain and temperature with preservation of light touch, joint position, and vibration sensations is seen over the shoulders, lower neck, and upper trunk (cape distribution). It results from selective damage to the gray matter nerve cells and the decussating spinothalamic tracts surrounding the central canal. These decussating fibers carry crude touch, pain, and temperature sensations. Spinal trauma, syringomyelia, and intrinsic cord tumors are the main causes. Option A: In Brown–Sequard Syndrome, ipsilateral weakness and loss of joint position and vibratory sense, with contralateral loss of pain and temperature sense, one or two levels below the lesion is seen. Option C: Anterior spinal artery syndrome is caused due to an ASA infarct. It typically presents as loss of motor function and pain/temperature sensation, with relative sparing of proprioception and vibratory sense below the level of the lesion. Option D: In foramen magnum syndrome, compressive lesions near the foramen magnum may produce weakness of the ipsilateral shoulder and arm followed by weakness of the ipsilateral leg, then the contralateral leg, and finally the contralateral arm. This is referred to as 'around the clock' pattern.
subject: Medicine

question_text: The MRI spine of a patient is shown below. What is the characteristic deficit seen in this condition?
options: Around the clock pattern of weakne
explanation: The MRI shows a syrinx located at C6–C7 in the cervical spine which is suggestive of syringomyelia. Suspended distribution of sensory deficit is a feature of this condition. Syringomyelia is a developmental cavity of the cervical cord that may enlarge and produce progressive myelopathy or may remain asymptomatic. It presents as a central cord syndrome with unilateral sensory loss in the hands initially. There is a loss of pain and temperature sensation with the sparing of touch and vibration. The sensory deficit has a distribution that is 'suspended' over the nape of the neck, shoulders, and upper arms (cape distribution) or in the hands. Areflexic weakness is seen in the upper limbs. Extension of the syrinx into the grey matter of the cord causes muscle wasting in the lower neck, shoulders, arms, and hands with asymmetric or absent reflexes in the arms. Extension of the syrinx into the medulla (syringobulbia) causes palatal or vocal cord paralysis, dysarthria, horizontal or vertical nystagmus, episodic dizziness or vertigo, and tongue weakness with atrophy.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A patient presents with quadriparesis. He says that it started in his left arm, then progressed to the left leg, and then later to the right leg and arm. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of an 'around-the-clock' pattern of weakness, which is seen in foramen magnum syndrome. Around the clock pattern of weakness is described as a sequential weakness of the ipsilateral shoulder and arm followed by weakness of the ipsilateral leg, then the contralateral leg, and finally the contralateral arm. The weakness may begin in any of the limbs. The lesions in the foramen magnum area interrupt decussating pyramidal tract fibers destined for the legs, resulting in weakness of the legs. There is typically suboccipital pain spreading to the neck and shoulders in foramen magnum syndrome.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Anterior spinal artery thrombosis is characterized by all of the following, except:
options: Loss of power in the lower limb
explanation: Anterior spinal artery thrombosis does not lead to loss of vibration sense. Vibration sense is carried by the posterior column. Anterior spinal artery syndrome or anterior cord syndrome is the result of occlusion or diminished flow in the anterior spinal artery. There is bilateral tissue destruction at several contiguous levels that spares the posterior columns. All spinal cord functions (motor, sensory, and autonomic) are lost below the level of the lesion, except vibration and position sensation.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A patient with neurofibromatosis 1 is found to have multiple tumors above the level of the lumbar spine. Which of the following is an early feature of dysautonomia in this patient?
explanation: The early feature of dysautonomia that can occur in this patient is spastic bladder. Dysautonomia due to brain and spinal cord disease above the level of the lumbar spine result first in increased urinary frequency and small bladder volume. Eventually, incontinence occurs. These features are suggestive of an upper motor neuron lesion, i.e., spastic bladder. On the other hand, dysautonomia due to peripheral nervous system (PNS) disease of autonomic nerve fibers results in large bladder volumes, increased urinary frequency, and overflow incontinence. These are features suggestive of a lower motor neuron lesion, i.e., flaccid bladder. Postvoidal residual volume helps to distinguish between upper and lower motor neuron bladder dysfunction in the early stages of dysautonomia.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following autonomic disorders do not involve the spinal cord?
explanation: Syringobulbia is a condition that affects the brainstem, not the spinal cord. It is a neurological disorder characterized by a fluid-filled cavity (syrinx) which affects the brainstem (medulla). The following autonomic disorders are associated with spinal cord involvement: Syringomyelia Multiple sclerosis and neuromyelitis optica Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) Traumatic quadriplegia Subacute combined degeneration Tetanu Stiff-person syndrome Spinal cord tumor
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following features would you not expect to see in a patient with an extramedullary tumor in the spinal cord?
explanation: Sacral sparing is not a feature of extramedullary tumors, it is seen in intramedullary tumors. Differences between extramedullary and intramedullary syndromes are: Extramedullary tumors lie outside the cord and compress the spinal cord or its vascular supply. Intramedullary tumors arise within the substance of the cord. The spinothalamic tract has a laminated configuration with the sacral fibers outermost, and hence, there is an early sacral sensory loss in extramedullary tumors. Extramedullary Intramedullary Radicular pain Poorly localized burning pain Early sacral sensory loss Sacral sparing Incontinence due to the supe rficial location of the corresp onding sensory and motor fib ers in the spinothalamic and corticospinal tracts Corticospinal tract signs appe ar later
subject: Medicine

question_text:
Which of the following is not a cause of subacute combined degeneration?
Pernicious anemia
explanation: Subacute combined degeneration (SACD) is due to the deficiency of vitamin B12. Pernicious anemia, partial gastrectomy, and Diphyllobothrium latum infestation can lead to this condition. High consumption of refined rice leads to thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency. The most severely affected regions in SACD are the posterior columns at the cervical and upper thoracic levels. Clinical features include: Signs of both peripheral nerve and spinal cord involvement Paresthesias in the hands or feet > Weakness and unsteadiness of gait Loss of vibration or joint position sense in the leg Mental slowing, depression, confusion, delusions, and hallucination SACD is treated by a replacement regimen of intramuscular daily injections of 1000 g of vitamin B12 for the first week, followed by weekly 1000 g injections for 1 month, and monthly injections thereafter. Myasthenia gravis and Other Neuromuscular Junction Disorders
subject: Medicine

question_text: Myasthenia gravis is associated with which of the following?
options: Decreased acetylcholine release at the nerve endings
Increased acetylcholine release at the nerve endings
Increased synaptic transmission at the myoneural junction
Decreased synaptic transmission at the myoneural junction
explanation: Myasthenia gravis is associated with a decrease in synaptic transmission at the myoneural junction. Myasthenia gravis is a neuromuscular disorder that is characterized by weakness and fatigability of skeletal muscles. It is due to autoantibody-mediated destruction of the acetylcholine receptors (AChRs) at the neuromuscular junction. This consequentially leads to a decreased transmission at the neuromuscular (myoneural) junction.
subject: Medicine

question_text: In myasthenia gravis, the anti-AChR antibodies reduce the number of available AChRs at the neuromuscular junction by all of the following mechanisms except:
options: Damage to the postsynaptic muscle membrane
Damage to muscle-specific receptor tyrosine kinase
Blockade of the active site of the AChR
explanation: In myasthenia gravis, damage to muscle-specific receptor tyrosine kinase is not a mechanism by which anti-AChR antibodies reduce the number of available AChRs at the neuromuscular junction. The anti-AChR antibodies reduce the number of available AChRs at the neuromuscular junction using three distinct mechanisms: Accelerated turnover of AChRs Damage to the postsynaptic muscle membrane mediated by antibodies and complement Blockade of the active site of the AChR Patients whose sera test negative for both AChR and MuSK antibodies possess antibodies specific to another protein at the neuromuscular junction called low-density lipoprotein receptor-related protein 4 (LRP4). LRP4 plays a functional role in the clustering of AChRs. Anti-MuSK antibodies are directed against muscle-specific receptor tyrosine kinase (MuSK), a protein involved in AChR clustering at the neuromuscular junction.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following statements about myasthenia gravis is false?
options: Weakness and fatigability of muscles is present
Lids and extraocular muscles are involved
explanation: Remissions may occur spontaneously but are usually not complete or permanent. The cardinal clinical features of myasthenia gravis include: Women are affected by myasthenia gravis more frequently than men, in a ratio of ~3:2. Weakness and fatigability of muscles - Weakness may increase upon repeated use or later in the day. It may improve with rest or sleep. Diplopia and ptosis - They are common initial clinical complaints. The cranial muscles, particularly the eyelids and the extraocular muscles, are typically involved early in the course of myasthenia gravis. Limb weakness - It is often proximal and may be asymmetric. Deep tendon reflexes - They are preserved despite muscle weakness.
subject: Medicine

question_text:
A school teacher presents to the OPD with excessive fatigability and double vision. She says that her symptoms are aggravated towards the end of the day. Her colleagues told her that, lately, she has developed a nasal twang in her voice. Which of the following statements is true
regarding this condition?
options: Thymoma is present in more than 75% of the patients with this condition
In most of the cases the thymus is hypoplastic
Myoid cells in thymus serve as the source of autoantigens
Thymus is abnormal in 20% of patients with AChR antibody–positive status
explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of myasthenia gravis (MG). Myoid cells in the thymus serve as the source of autoantigens in this condition. The muscle-like cells within the thymus called myoid cells, express AChRs on their surface. These cells are known to serve as a source of autoantigen and trigger autoimmune reactions within the thymus gland. This stimulates the production of autoantibodies, thus causing myasthenia gravis. The thymus is abnormal in ~75% of patients with AChR antibody-positive MG. In these cases, the thymus is hyperplastic. 10% of the patients show symptoms of thymoma.
subject: Medicine

question_text:
A 55-year old woman presented with shortness of breath, cough with expectoration and fever for ten days. Chest x-ray revealed mediastinal widening. CECT chest showed a
well-circumscribed heterogeneous solid enhancing mass lesion. FNAC showed features in favor of thymoma. Which of the following is not associated with this condition?
explanation: Thymoma is associated with hypogammaglobulinemia, not hypergammaglobulinemia. Thymoma with hypogammaglobulinemia is also called Good’s syndrome. The following conditions are associated with thymomas: Myasthenia gravis (30%) Pure red cell aplasia (5-8%) Hypogammaglobulinemia (~5%) Polymyositis SLE Thyroiditis Sjogren's syndrome Ulcerative colitis Addison's disease Pernicious anemia Scleroderma Panhypopituitarism Aplastic anemia Limbic encephalitis
subject: Medicine

question_text: What is not a feature of myasthenia gravis among the following?
explanation: Absent deep tendon reflex is not a feature of myasthenia gravis (MG). MG usually occurs in young females. Patients usually present with weakness and fatiguability of the muscles, which worsens on repeated use or late in the day and improves on rest. The cranial muscles, particularly the eyelids and extraocular muscles are involved early in the course of MG. Diplopia and ptosis are common initial complaints. When MG becomes generalized, the proximal muscles of the limbs are affected first. Despite the muscle weakness, the deep tendon reflexes remain normal. Snarling expression on smiling (facial weakness), nasal timbre of speech (weakness of palate and tongue), and difficulty swallowing may be seen. Bulbar weakness and respiratory depression are seen more frequently in MuSK antibody–positive MG. MG is an autoimmune disorder most commonly caused by antibodies against the acetylcholine receptor (AChR). These antibodies cause damage to the postsynaptic muscle membrane and increased endocytosis of the AChR. This autoimmune response against the AChR seems to be mediated by the thymus. The myoid (muscle-like) cells present in the thymus express AChRs on their surface and are postulated to provide the autoantigen which triggers this autoimmune reaction. Thymic hyperplasia is seen in 65% of the patients, and thymomas are seen in 10% of the patients. The tests which are used to confirm the diagnosis of MG include: Anti-AChR antibody immunoassay: 85% of myasthenic patients have detectable anti-AChR antibodies, but only 50% of patients with weakness limited to ocular muscles. The presence of anti-AChR antibodies is highly suggestive of MG, but a negative test does not exclude the disease. Antibodies to MuSK and LRP4 are found in some patients Recurrent nerve stimulation test: MG shows a decremental response > 10%, while Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS) shows an incremental response Block and jitter response on single-fiber electromyography Positive edrophonium test: improvement of ptosis on the administration of anticholinesterase such as edrophonium Positive ice-pack test: improvement of ptosis on the application of ice-pack on the affected eye The first line of medical management in MG is anticholinesterase drugs. Pyridostigmine 30–60 mg three to four times daily is the most commonly used drug. Patients are evaluated for associated thymic abnormalities using a CT chest. Thymectomy is considered in patients with thymoma and in generalized MG patients with anti-AChR antibodies. Immunotherapy therapy can be initiated in patients with poor control on pyridostigmine after thymectomy. Glucocorticoids, cyclosporine, or tacrolimus are generally effective within 1-3 months. Azathioprine and mycophenolate mofetil may take several months to show beneficial effects and are used for the long-term management of MG. Rituximab has shown effectiveness in patients with MuSK antibodies. Intravenous eculizumab, which binds to terminal complement component 5, is also effective. Myasthenic crisis is the life-threatening exacerbation of MG leading to respiratory failure. Treatment for myasthenic crisis should take place in intensive care units. It is important to rule out excessive anticholinesterase medication as a cause of deterioration by temporarily discontinuing these drugs. Plasmapheresis and intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIg) are beneficial in hastening recovery.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 45-year-old patient comes with complaints of progressive weakness as the day progresses. He is found to have antibodies against nicotinic acetylcholine receptors. Which is the most common ocular finding in this disease?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of myasthenia gravis and ptosis is the most common ocular feature of the disease. Myasthenia gravis (MG) is an autoimmune disorder of the neuromuscular junction most commonly caused by anti-acetylcholine receptor antibodies. The disorder is characterized by weakness and fatigability of skeletal muscles where the weakness increases during repeated use and may improve following rest. Ptosis and diplopia are common initial complaints due to early involvement of the lids and extraocular muscles (EOMs). Of them, Ptosis is a more common manifestation than diplopia. Ptosis in myasthenia gravis is insidious, bilateral, and frequently asymmetrical. Investigations of myasthenia gravis include: Ice pack test -This tests for a transient improvement of the ptotic eyelid on placing an ice pack for 2 minutes, as the cold inhibits the breakdown of acetylcholine by acetylcholinesterase. Tensilon (Edrophonium) test - This tests for a transient improvement in the weakness on administration of a short-acting anticholinesterase such as edrophonium. Antibody testing - for Acetylcholine receptor (AChR) antibodies, MuSK protein antibodies helps support a diagnosis of myasthenia gravis.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following features would you not expect to see in patients with ocular myasthenia?
options: Ptosis may switch from one eye to the other over time
Manually raising the more ptotic lid causes increased ptosis on the opposite side
Extraocular muscle involvement produces binocular diplopia
Pupils are affected in 50% of the cases
explanation: The pupils are always spared in myasthenia gravis (MG), differentiating it from other disorders marked by similar ocular symptoms (e.g. botulism) If weakness remains restricted to the extraocular muscles for 3 years, it is likely that it will not become generalized. These patients are said to have ocular MG. Ptosis and/or diplopia are the initial symptoms of MG in up to 85% of patients. The ptosis may increase with sustained upward gaze or by holding up the opposite eyelid with the examiner's finger (curtain sign). Cogan lid twitch is characteristic of MG. It refers to a brief overshoot twitch of the lid when the patient is made to gaze upwards after a period of downgaze. RNS studies (repetitive nerve stimulation) and anti-AChR antibodies are often negative. Single-fiber EMG (SFEMG) testing may be required for confirming the diagnosis in seronegative patients.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following conditions is not associated with congenital myasthenic syndrome?
explanation: Dysferlin deficiency is not associated with congenital myasthenic syndrome (CMS). CMS is an uncommon cause of neuromuscular junction failure in newborns. In CMS, the immune system is unaffected. The common syndromes associated with CMS are as follows: Slow-channel congenital myasthenic syndrome (SCCMS) Fast-channel congenital myasthenic syndrome (FCCMS) Primary acetylcholine receptor deficiency Endplate acetylcholinesterase deficiency
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 65-year-old man who is a laborer presents with progressive weakness of the legs. He says that the weakness is more in the morning and as the day progresses, it improves for a while usually. He is a known smoker. Examination reveals diminished deep tendon reflexes in the lower limbs. Which of the following statements is true regarding this condition?
options: Paraneoplastic syndrome seen in lung adenocarcinoma
Incremental response on repetitive nerve stimulation
explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS). Incremental response to repetitive nerve stimulation is a feature of this condition. LEMS is a neuromuscular junction disorder associated with the reduced acetylcholine (Ach) release from the presynaptic nerve terminals, despite normal ACh vesicle numbers. Antibodies directed against the P/Q voltage-gated calcium channel (VGCC) interfere with the normal calcium flux required for the release of acetylcholine. Approximately 50% of LEMS cases are associated with malignancy, mainly small cell lung cancer (SCLC). Most patients with LEMS present with symptoms as slowly progressive proximal muscle weakness. In LEMS, the weakness improves for a while after exertion. Diminished or absent deep tendon reflexes help differentiate between LEMS and myasthenia gravis. An increase in the compound muscle action potential (CAMP) amplitude >100% after exercise or with high-frequency repetitive nerve stimulation (RNS) is considered to be of diagnostic significance.
subject: Medicine

question_text: For diagnosing patients with suspected myasthenia gravis, which of the following tests has the highest sensitivity?
explanation: Single-fiber electromyography has the highest sensitivity for the diagnosis of myasthenia gravis. The tests used in the diagnosis of myasthenia gravis are: Testing for autoantibodies against the acetylcholine receptor (AChR-Ab) should be performed on all patients (most specific). If the AChR-Abs test negative, an assay for antibodies against muscle-specific receptor tyrosine kinase (MuSK) should be performed. Single-fiber electromyography (SFEMG) simultaneously records action potentials of two muscle fibers innervated by the same motor axon. The variability in time of the second action potential relative to the first is called "jitter" and this is increased in myasthenia gravis. Repetitive nerve stimulation (RNS) is considered abnormal if there is a decremental response of >10%. The edrophonium ("Tensilon") test should be used for diagnosis only in those patients with obvious ptosis or ophthalmoparesis and is not confirmatory. This test is not used routinely. Electrophysiological (RNS/SFEMG) tests are used to diagnose patients affected with seronegative myasthenia gravis.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is the first line drug of choice in a patient with myasthenia gravis?
explanation: Pyridostigmine is the first-line drug of choice in the treatment of symptomatic myasthenia gravis. Treatment for myasthenia gravis involves: Symptomatic treatment: Anticholinesterase agents – Pyridostigmine is the initial therapy of choice. Chronic immunomodulating therapy: Glucocorticoids (prednisone) and immunosuppressive drugs (azathioprine, mycophenolate mofetil, cyclosporine) implemented in patients significantly symptomatic on pyridostigmine. Rapid immunomodulating treatment: IVIG and therapeutic plasma exchange—Used to tide over severe illness (myasthenic crisis) and as 'bridge' therapy before surgery, or starting chronic mmunomodulating treatment. Surgical approach: Thymectomy
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following statements is true regarding thymectomy in patients with generalized myasthenia gravis?
options: Indicated in most AChR-Ab positive patients with generalized myasthenia gravis
Indicated exclusively in patients with thymomatous myasthenia gravis
explanation: Thymectomy is indicated in most AChR-Ab positive patients with generalized myasthenia gravis Thymectomy is recommended for all patients aged <60 years with non-thymomatous, acetylcholine receptor (AChR) antibody-associated generalized myasthenia gravis. Significant improvement in symptoms is expected within one year after thymectomy. It is indicated in all patients with thymoma if resection is feasible, regardless of the subtype of myasthenia gravis.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A female patient with myasthenia gravis was admitted with complaints of sore throat, fever, cough, and weakness. She had a history of repeated hospital admissions due to exacerbation of myasthenia gravis. During some of the episodes, she even required intubation. Blood culture on admission revealed MRSA infection. Which of the following drugs can be safely administered to this patient for treating the infection?
explanation: Daptomycin can be safely administered to treat the patient's MRSA infection. This is because it is not known to unmask or worsen the symptoms of myasthenia gravis. Drugs that may unmask or worsen myasthenia gravis include: Anesthetic agents: Neuromuscular-blocking agents Antibiotics: Aminoglycosides (eg., gentamicin, neomycin, tobramycin) Clindamycin Fluoroquinolones (eg., ciprofloxacin, levofloxacin, norfloxacin) Ketolides (eg., telithromycin) Vancomycin Cardiovascular drugs: Beta-blockers (eg., atenolol, labetalol, metoprolol, propranolol) Procainamide Quinidine Other drugs: Botulinum toxin Chloroquine Hydroxychloroquine Magnesium Penicillamine Quinine
subject: Medicine

question_text: Patients with myasthenia gravis are resistant to anesthesia with which of the following drugs?
explanation: Patients with myasthenia gravis are resistant to neuromuscular blockade with depolarizing NMBAs (e.g., succinylcholine), possibly because they have a decreased number of acetylcholine receptors. Local anesthetics and inhalation anesthetics are usually well-tolerated in myasthenia gravis with occasional exacerbations.
subject: Medicine

question_text:
All of the following are the drugs that are used for the treatment of patients with myasthenia gravis. Which of the following does not alter the disease process?
Pyridostigmine
explanation: Pyridostigmine is an anticholinesterase agent that does not alter the disease process of myasthenia gravis. Anticholinesterase agents improve muscle contractions by allowing released acetylcholine to accumulate and act on the receptors over a large area and also have the additional direct depolarizing effect on the motor endplate. They do not alter the disease process but provide symptomatic relief. The underlying disease process continues and ultimately it may not be possible to restore muscle strength with anticholinesterase agents alone. It is due to the reduction of the receptors by the antibodies. Drugs like prednisone, mycophenolate mofetil, and azathioprine are immunosuppressive agents that reduce the antibody titers and can modify the disease process. Multiple Sclerosis & Other Demyelinating Disorders
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following statements is false regarding demyelinating disorders?
options: Multiple sclerosis is the most common type
It is caused by biochemical abnormality of myelin
explanation: Demyelinating disorders do not include biochemical abnormalities of myelin. Disorders occuring due to biochemical abnormalities of myelin are called dysmyelinating disorders. Multiple sclerosis is the most common immune-mediated, inflammatory demyelinating disorder. It commonly presents in adulthood.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following statements is true regarding multiple sclerosis?
options: It is an acute inflammatory condition of neurons
It is an autoimmune disease affecting the central nervous system
It may also involve the peripheral nervous system
The condition is always benign and resolves spontaneously
explanation: Multiple sclerosis is an autoimmune disease of the central nervous system. It is characterized by chronic inflammation, demyelination, gliosis (scarring), and neuronal loss. The peripheral nervous system is spared in MS. The course of the disease may be relapsing-remitting or progressive. The clinical course of manifestation can be variable ranging from a benign condition to a rapidly evolving and incapacitating disease.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A patient with weakness of the limbs and reduced vision, after evaluation, was diagnosed to be a case of multiple sclerosis. Which of the following is not a risk factor for the development of this condition?
explanation: HLA-DRB1 is a risk factor for the development of multiple sclerosis, not HLA-B27. Risk factors supporting the course of development of multiple sclerosis include: Cigarette smoking Vitamin D deficiency Family history, HLA-DRB1 Exposure to Epstein-Barr virus (Human Herpesvirus 4) after early childhood
subject: Medicine

question_text: The slowing of conduction in multiple sclerosis is due to which of the following?
explanation: In multiple sclerosis, the slowing of conduction is due to the loss of the myelin sheath. Under normal circumstances, nerve conduction in myelinated axons occurs in a saltatory manner i.e from one node of Ranvier to another. But, when demyelination sets in, the nerve impulse are unable to travel as fast due to not being saltatory. This produces either a conduction block or delay. Lesions due to multiple sclerosis begin with perivenular cuffing by inflammatory mononuclear cells. Myelin-specific autoantibodies cause degeneration of myelin sheaths. As lesions evolve, prominent astrocytic proliferation (gliosis) is observed. Demyelination is the hallmark in the pathology of multiple sclerosis. But, it is not solely a disease affecting the myelin sheath. Partial or total axonal destruction (neuronal loss) can also occur.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Autoantibodies in multiple sclerosis are directed against which of the following?
options: Both Myelin basic protein & Myelin oligodendrocyte glycoprotein
explanation: The autoantibodies in multiple sclerosis are directed against both myelin basic protein (MBP) and myelin oligodendrocyte glycoprotein (MOG).
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following processes lead to the formation of shadow plaques in patients with multiple sclerosis?
options: Demyelination of axons in the central nervous system
Demyelination of axons in the peripheral nervous system
Remyelination of axons in the central nervous system
Remyelination of axons in the peripheral nervous system
explanation: Remyelination of axons in the central nervous system leads to the formation of shadow plaques. Shadow plaques develop due to the partial remyelination of the naked axons by surviving oligodendrocytes or those that differentiate from precursor cells.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 40-year-old woman with a history of multiple sclerosis comes to the hospital. She describes an electric shock–like sensation radiating down the back into the legs. What is the name of this sign?
explanation: An electric shock-like sensation radiating down the back into the legs is called Lhermitte's sign. It is associated with multiple sclerosis. It is induced typically by flexion or other movements of the neck. Lhermitte’s sign can also occur simultaneously with other disorders of the cervical spinal cord like cervical spondylosis. Option A: Uhthoff ’s phenomenon refers to the unilateral visual blurring that may occur during a hot shower or with physical exercise. It is an exacerbation of the symptoms of multiple sclerosis due to heat. Option C: Stransky's sign is a clinical sign in which vigorous abduction followed by the sudden release of the little toe causes an extensor plantar reflex. It is seen in pyramidal tract lesions. Option D: Cornell's sign is a clinical sign in which scratching along the inner side of the extensor hallucis longus tendon elicits an extensor plantar reflex. It is seen in pyramidal tract lesions.
subject: Medicine

question_text: An MRI image of a patient with multiple sclerosis is shown below. What is this sign called?
explanation: The MRI image shows Dawson's fingers. Dawson's fingers are demyelinating plaques through the corpus callosum, arranged at right angles along medullary veins (callososeptal location). They are a characteristic feature of multiple sclerosis and presents as T2 hyperintensities. MRI is the imaging of choice in a patient with multiple sclerosis due to its high sensitivity. Option A: Black hole lesions are multiple sclerosis plaques indicative of the chronic stage when they display T1 hypointense signals. They signify axonal destruction and irreversible damage. Option B: The molar tooth sign refers to the appearance of the midbrain in an axial section in which the elongated superior cerebellar peduncles gives the midbrain the appearance of a molar or wisdom tooth. It is seen in Joubert syndrome. Option C: Tram-track sign in the brain refers to the parallel calcification of the cortex in patients with Sturge-Weber syndrome.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A woman presents with recurrent episodes of blurry vision, tingling and numbness in the legs, and falls. She says that during hot weather, she finds it difficult to walk and often falls. Recently she had flu, due to which the symptoms aggravated. MRI brain was done which showed Dawson's fingers. What is the criteria used for the clinical diagnosis of her condition?
explanation: The given scenario and the MRI finding of Dawson's fingers are suggestive of multiple sclerosis. Revised McDonald’s criteria is used in the diagnosis of multiple sclerosis. It takes into consideration the clinical attacks and objective lesions. In addition, it also involves the assessment of the lesions based on MRI and other imaging techniques. The Kurtzke expanded disability status scale (EDSS) and functional status (FS) score are widely used measures of neurologic impairment, which are performed following the confirmed diagnosis of multiple sclerosis.
subject: Medicine

question_text: In patients with multiple sclerosis, which of the following is used to determine neurological impairment?
explanation: The Expanded disability status scale (EDSS) gives a measure of neurological impairment in multiple sclerosis. EDSS scores <3.5: The patient walks normally, shows no disability EDSS scores >5.5: Progressive disease, gait impairment, and occupational disability EDSS scores =10.0: Death due to multiple sclerosis
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 45-year-old woman with multiple sclerosis presents with an exacerbation of her symptoms. Which of the following drugs should be prescribed to her for initial management?
explanation: Glucocorticoids are used in the clinical management of either first attacks or acute exacerbations. Intravenous methylprednisolone administration at a dose of 500–1000 mg/day for 3-5 days, followed by a course of oral prednisolone beginning at a dose of 60–80 mg/day and gradually tapered over 2 weeks is given. These medications reduce the severity and shorten the duration of attacks. Disease-modifying therapies for relapsing forms of multiple sclerosis are: IFN--1a IFN--1b Glatiramer acetate Natalizumab Fingolimod Dimethyl fumarate Teriflunomide Mitoxantrone Alemtuzumab
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following patients have Marburg’s variant of multiple sclerosis?
options: A patient with chronic form of multiple sclerosis with no remissions
A patient with acute form of multiple sclerosis with remissions
A patient with acute form of multiple sclerosis with no remissions
A patient with chronic form of multiple sclerosis with remissions
explanation: Marburg’s variant is an acute form of multiple sclerosis, typically with no remissions. It is a fulminant demyelinating process that in some cases progresses, leading to death within 1–2 years. Marburg’s variant does not seem to be associated with infection or vaccination. Clinical management by high-dose glucocorticoids, plasma exchange, and cyclophosphamide have been tried, with uncertain benefit.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A patient has recurrent optic neuritis of both eyes with extensive transverse myelitis. Visual acuity in the right eye is 6/60 and visual acuity in the left eye 6/18. The patient showed a partial response to steroids. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of neuromyelitis optica, which is also known as Devic's disease. It is an aggressive inflammatory demyelinating disorder characterized by recurrent attacks of optic neuritis and myelitis. Attacks of Optic neuritis can be bilateral or unilateral and myelitis can be severe and involve three or more contiguous vertebral segments. Core clinical characteristics are: Optic neuritis Acute myelitis Area postrema syndrome: episodes of otherwise unexplained hiccups or nausea or vomiting Acute brainstem syndrome Symptomatic narcolepsy or acute diencephalic clinical syndrome with NMOSD*-typica diencephalic MRI lesions Symptomatic cerebral syndrome with NMOSD*-typical brain lesions Option A: Acute Disseminated Encephalomyelitis (ADEM) is a demyelinating condition most frequently associated with an antecedent infection Option C: Riddoch syndrome is the ability to consciously perceive the stimulus in a blind field. It is seen when there is a lesion in the occipital lobe. Option D: Acute fulminant multiple sclerosis is an acute episode of multiple sclerosis, known as Marburg’s variant *NMOSD stands for neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following drugs will you prescribe for a patient with an acute attack of neuromyelitis optica?
explanation: Acute attacks of neuromyelitis optica are managed by high-dose glucocorticoids or plasma exchange. Drugs used for prophylaxis against relapses include: Mycophenolate mofeti Rituximab Glucocorticoids + azathioprine
subject: Medicine

question_text: A child presents to the casualty with high-grade fever and altered sensorium. He is suspected to have acute disseminated encephalomyelitis. This condition is associated with which of the following?
explanation: Acute disseminated encephalomyelitis (ADEM) is associated with measles infection, measles vaccination, rubella infection, and rubella vaccination. ADEM is a demyelinating disease of the central nervous system that typically presents as a monophasic disorder associated with multifocal neurological symptoms and encephalopathy. It may be : Post-infectious (95%) - associated infections are with varicella, measles, rubella, mumps, influenza, EBV, HHV-6, HIV, other viruses, and Mycoplasma pneumoniae. Post-vaccination (5%) - presently it is most often associated with measles (most common), mumps, and rubella vaccination.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding acute disseminated encephalomyelitis?
options: Cerebellar involvement is seen in post-varicella ADEM
Autoantibodies to myelin basic protein can be found
Initial treatment is with high-dose glucocorticoids.
explanation: Seizures are common in ADEM. ADEM results from a cross-reactive immune response to the infectious agent (most commonly measles virus) or vaccine which then triggers an inflammatory demyelinating response. Autoantibodies to MBP and to other myelin antigens have been detected in the CSF of some patients with ADEM. In ADEM due to chickenpox, cerebellar involvement is often conspicuous. Initial treatment is with high-dose glucocorticoids.
subject: Medicine

question_text:
Tigroid white matter on MR imaging is seen in which of the following conditions?
Pantothenate kinase deficiency
explanation: Tigroid white matter on MR imaging is seen in Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease. It is a rare, X-linked recessive disorder characterized by central nervous system dysmyelination. The proteolipid protein gene (PLP1) is affected, leading to the failure of axon myelination by oligodendrocytes in the central nervous system. Clinical Features: Nystagmus Developmental delay Psychomotor delay Seizure Stridor Feeding difficulties Ataxia Hypotonia progressing to spasticity. The degree of dysmyelination is correlated with the severity of the clinical manifestations. Genetic analysis can confirm the diagnosis. MRI shows a lack of myelination and MR spectroscopy reveals aberrant N-acetyl aspartate (NAA) and choline concentrations that reflect axonal and myelination abnormalities. Unlike other demyelinating leukodystrophies such as metachromatic leukodystrophy and adrenoleukodystrophy, where myelin is formed but subsequently destroyed, PMD shows a failure of myelin formation. Headache Disorders

question_text: What is the most common type of headache?
explanation: The most common type of headache is tension-type headache (TTH). The pain of TTH can generally be managed with simple analgesics such as acetaminophen, aspirin, or NSAIDs. For chronic TTH, amitriptyline is the only proven treatment. Causes of primary headache, in decreasing order: Tension-type headache Migraine Idiopathic stabbing Exertional Cluster Causes of secondary headache, in decreasing order: Systemic infection Head injury Vascular disorders Subarachnoid hemorrhage Brain tumor

question_text: What is the most common cause of secondary headache?
explanation: The most common cause of secondary headache is a systemic infection. Causes of primary headache, in decreasing order: Tension-type headache Migraine Idiopathic stabbing Exertional Cluster Causes of secondary headache, in decreasing order: Systemic infection Head injury Vascular disorders Subarachnoid hemorrhage Brain tumor

question_text: Which of the following case scenarios do not depict tension-type headache?
options: A 34-year-old woman presenting with a chronic headache for >15 days per month
A 41-year-old man presenting with a bilateral headache lasting for 4-6 hours
A 38-year-old man presenting with a tight band-like discomfort around the head
A 34-year-old woman presenting with a pulsatile headache associated with nausea
explanation: A pulsatile headache associated with nausea is not a feature of tension-type headache (TTH). Tension-type headache is a chronic head-pain syndrome characterized by bilateral, tight, band-like discomfort. The pain typically builds slowly, fluctuates in severity, and may persist more or less continuously for many days. The headache may be episodic or chronic (present >15 days per month). explanation: A bilateral, non-pulsatile headache of tightening quality without any nausea or photophobia suggests a diagnosis of tension-type headache (TTH). question_text: A 41-year-old man has a 4-year history of severe left-sided excruciating episodic headaches. Most episodes are accompanied by ipsilateral lacrimation, conjunctival injection, and rhinorrhea. There are no cutaneous triggers. It does not respond to indomethacin and attacks get triggered by alcohol. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: This patient's clinical features are suggestive of cluster headache. Patients with cluster headaches are more often smokers with a higher than average alcohol consumption. Cluster headache causes severe, unilateral periorbital pain with autonomic features, such as unilateral lacrimation, nasal congestion, and conjunctival injection. Occasionally features of Horner's syndrome may be seen. The pain, though severe, is characteristically brief (30–90 minutes). There are 1-8 attacks/day lasting for 15min-3 hours.

question_text: A man presents with complaints of a recurrent left-sided stabbing headache. He has been experiencing this every day, along with a runny nose during the episodes, for the last week. These episodes last for about an hour. Examination shows the following. Which of the following is not used for the prophylaxis of this condition?
explanation: Repetitive brief, unilateral, stabbing headaches associated with lacrimation and rhinorrhea suggest a diagnosis of cluster headaches. Indomethacin is not used for the prophylaxis of these headaches. The drug of choice used in the prophylaxis of cluster headaches is verapamil. Steroids and lithium can also be used.
subject: Medicine

question_text: What is the most common positive visual aura seen by patients during an attack of migraine?
explanation: The most common positive visual aura seen in attacks of migraine is a zig-zag line in front of the eyes. The most common negative visual aura is scotoma. The classic migraine is associated with an aura. The aura can be: Visual (most common): Zigzag lines Tunnel vision Scotoma Transient visual loss Sensory: Tingling sensation of hands, which spreads proximally
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 26-year old woman presents with a unilateral throbbing headache associated with nausea and vomiting. She has had similar episodes in the past where the headache usually lasts for 1-2 days. Bright light increases her discomfort and she prefers sitting in a dark room. Which of the following is associated with this condition?
explanation: Multiple unilateral throbbing headache associated with nausea, vomiting and photophobia suggests a diagnosis of migraine. Calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) is a vasoactive neuropeptide associated with this condition. It is present at vascular terminations of the trigeminal nerve and within the trigeminal nucleus. CGRP antagonists approved for migraine prevention are: Erenumab Fremanezumab Galcanezumab Eptinezumab Note: The FDA has recently approved Atogepant, a calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) receptor antagonist for the preventive treatment of episodic migraine in adults. The recommended dosage is 10 mg, 30 mg, or 60 mg orally once daily. In severe renal impairment or end-stage renal disease it is 10 mg once daily.

question_text: In patients with familial hemiplegic migraine, which of the following is least likely to be defective?
explanation: Familial hemiplegic migraine (FHM) is due to defective voltage-gated calcium channel gene, sodium-potassium ATPase gene, and voltage-gated sodium channel. The voltage-gated chloride channel is not defective in this condition. question_text:
A 23-year-old woman experiences severe throbbing headaches on the right side of her forehead. Soon after the headache begins, she becomes very nauseous and occasionally gets
dizzy. She has also vomited multiple times during these episodes and is subsequently diagnosed with severe migraine. Which among the following is the most efficacious triptan used to treat this condition?
explanation: The most efficacious triptans for moderate to severe acute migraines are rizatriptan and eletriptan. Oral dosage forms of triptans are the most convenient to use. Still, they may not be practical in patients experiencing migraine-associated nausea and vomiting, for whom injectable and nasal spray formulations are helpful. Standard treatment comprises a 6-mg subcutaneous dose of sumatriptan. All triptans have similar pharmacologic properties but vary slightly in terms of clinical efficacy. Rizatriptan and eletriptan are the most efficacious of the triptans currently available.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A young woman has been suffering from 1-2 episodes of migraine every week. These episodes are affecting her quality of life. All of the following drugs can be used in the prophylaxis of migraine in this patient except
explanation: Sumatriptan is used in the treatment of an acute attack of migraine not in prophylaxis. It can be given by oral, subcutaneous, intravenous or intranasal routes. Drugs used in the prophylaxis of migraine: Beta-blockers- propranolol Calcium channel blocker- flunarizine (verapamil, nimodipine has no role) Antidepressants- amitriptyline, venlafaxine (SSRIs like fluoxetine are not used) Anticonvulsants- valproate, topiramate 5-HT2 antagonist- pizotifen CGRP antagonists - erenumab, framanezumab, galcanezumab, eptinezumab Other modalities of preventative treatment: Greater occipital nerve block Onabotulinum toxin A Supraorbital transcutaneous stimulation

question_text: Sumatriptan can be given in which of the following patients diagnosed with migraine?
options: A 42-year-old woman who had taken ergot alkaloids in the past one week
A 34-year-old woman presenting with a positive urine pregnancy test
A 48-year-old man with a history of cerebrovascular disease
A 51-year-old man with a history of coronary artery disease
explanation: Taking ergot alkaloids in the past one week is not a contraindication for sumatriptan. However, they shouldn't be given together as doing so could result in excessive blood vessel narrowing. Ergots constrict arteries and triptans narrow normal heart arteries by up to 20%. For this reason, ergots should not be taken with triptans on the same day. Sumatriptan is a 5HT1B/1D receptor agonist used in an acute migraine attack. It is contraindicated in the following conditions: Cerebrovascular disease Coronary artery disease Option B- Sumatriptan is the safest triptan in pregnancy, but its use is recommended only if the benefits outweigh the risks, and if all first line options do not provide relief.
subject: Medicine

question_text: What is the use of MIDAS questionnaire?
options: To help decide treatment of migraine
explanation: The Migraine Disability Assessment Score (MIDAS) questionnaire was put together to help measure the impact of migraine on patients' lives.

question_text: Which of the following is used in the preventive treatment of a patient with chronic migraine?
explanation: Onabotulinum toxin A is used in the preventive treatment of patients with chronic migraine. Sumatriptan, ergotamine, and metoclopramide are used in the treatment of an acute attack of migraine. question_text: Which of the following is not a trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia?
explanation: Nummular headache is not a trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia. It is characterized by small circumscribed areas of continuous pain on the head. Trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia is characterized by pain along the distribution of trigeminal nerve (unilateral) and cranial autonomic symptoms. This is due to increased parasympathetic flow and decreased sympathetic flow.
subject: Medicine

question_text: All are true about patients with trigeminal autonomic cephalgia except:
options: Cluster headache is more common in males
SUNCT has highest attack frequency rate
Cutaneous trigger is seen in cluster headache
explanation: The cutaneous trigger is not seen in cluster headache. It is seen in short-lasting unilateral neuralgiform headache with conjunctival injection and tearing (SUNCT).

question_text: A patient was prescribed indomethacin for his complaint of headache and he felt relief after taking the drug. Which of the following could be a likely diagnosis?
explanation: Paroxysmal hemicrania could be the likely diagnosis since it responds to indomethacin. It is characterized by frequent unilateral, severe, short-lasting, and frequent episodes of headache. They have marked autonomic features ipsilateral to the pain. Indomethacin (25–75 mg t.i.d) can completely suppress attacks of paroxysmal hemicrania. It is also effective in: Hemicrania continuum Primary sexual / exercise headache Tension-type headache

question_text: A 40-year-old male is diagnosed to have SUNCT. It can be distinguished from trigeminal neuralgia by the presence of all except:
explanation: Short attacks of stabbing pain are common to both SUNCT and trigeminal neuralgia. SUNCT has autonomic symptoms such as lacrimation, nasal congestion, conjunctival injection, and salivation. Trigeminal neuralgia does not have autonomic symptoms.
subject: Medicine

question_text: All are true about patients with trigeminal neuralgia except:
options: Pain along V2 and V3 division of trigeminal nerve
No objective signs of sensory loss
explanation: Trigeminal neuralgia is associated with superficial pain and not deep-seated pain. It is more common (~ 60% of cases) in females (Option A) over 50 years and is characterized by unilateral lancinating facial pain. This most commonly involves the second and/or third divisions (Option B) of the trigeminal nerve territory. Bilateral or early-onset pain is associated with multiple sclerosis. Unilateral trigeminal nerve compression can be due to the superior cerebellar artery. Pain is repetitive, severe, and brief and can be triggered by touch, cold, wind, or eating. Physical signs are usually absent, although the spasms may make the patient wince and sit silently (tic douloureux). No signs of sensory loss are present (Option D) The drug of choice is carbamazepine. Note: It is important to note that trigeminal neuralgia and trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia (TAC) are different entities. TAC is a group of primary headaches that include - cluster headaches, paroxysmal hemicrania, short-lasting unilateral neuralgiform headache attacks with conjunctival injection and tearing (SUNCT)/short-lasting unilateral neuralgiform headache attacks with cranial autonomic symptoms (SUNA), and hemicrania continua.
subject: Medicine

question_text:
A 42-year-old man presented with an extremely painful headache that came on suddenly without warning. It reached maximum intensity within 1 minute and lasted for 5 minutes. Which of the following would you not include as a differential?
Subdural hemorrhage
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a thunderclap headache. Subdural hemorrhage will not produce this type of headache. Causes of thunderclap headache: Subarachnoid hemorrhage Acute hydrocephalus Pituitary apoplexy Cerebral venous thrombosis Hypertensive crisis Movement Disorders

question_text: Which of the following diseases primarily involves the marked structure?
explanation: The structure marked in this transverse section of the brain at the level of superior colliculus is substantia nigra. Degeneration of substantia nigra is seen in Parkinson's disease, also known as paralysis agitans. Substantia nigra is pigmented due to the presence of neuromelanin granules, which help in the synthesis of dopamine. In Parkinson's disease, there is an absence/reduced pigmentation of the substantia nigra. Bradykinesia, rigidity, and resting tremor are classic features of Parkinson's disease. Because of motor disability, it is also referred to as paralysis agitans. Other options: Option B: Depression is often a comorbid finding with Parkinson's disease, but is not due to damage to the substantia nigra. Option C: Alzheimer’s disease is the most common cause of dementia. It is due to atrophy of the entorhinal cortex, located in the medial temporal lobe. Option D: Huntington’s chorea is an autosomal dominant disorder of movement and cognition primarily involving the striatum (caudate nucleus and putamen).
subject: Medicine

question_text: What is the most common gene mutation seen in patients with familial Parkinson's disease?
explanation: The most common form of monogenic familial PD is PARK8, caused by mutations in the leucine-rich repeat kinase-2 (LRRK2) gene. Familial forms of parkinsonism (designated PARK1 through PARK13) have been associated with causative mutations in a number of nuclear genes. A few of these are: The LRRK2 gene mutation causes autosomal dominant PD (PARK8). In this condition, Middle to late-onset PD is seen, which resembles typical PD and is responsive to levodopa. Mutations in alpha-synuclein (PARK 1 and PARK4) cause rare forms of familial PD and constitute the major component of Lewy bodies in sporadic PD. Parkin-associated PD (PARK 2) & PINK1-associated PD (PARK6) are autosomal recessive seen in young-onset PD. Mutation in the glucocerebrosidase gene (GBA) gene of Gauchers represents the most important risk factor for the development of Parkinson's disease. Patients with PD who are GBA mutation carriers have a younger age at onset.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following features would you not expect to see in patients with Parkinson’s disease?
explanation: Exaggerated deep tendon reflexes are not a feature of Parkinson's disease. Cardinal motor features in PD include: Resting tremors Bradykinesia Rigidity Gait disturbance / postural instability Mnemonic: TRAP - Tremors + Rigidity + Akinesia + Postural instability Other motor features include: Micrographia Masked facies (hypomimia) Reduced eye blinking Soft voice (hypophonia) Dysphagia Non-motor features are: Anosmia Sensory disturbance (pain) Mood Disorders (depression) Sleep disturbances (rapid eye movement behavior disorder) Autonomic: GI disturbances Genitourinary disturbances Sexual dysfunction Orthostatic hypotension Cognitive impairment Parkinson’s disease(PD) is the second most common neurodegenerative disorder after Alzheimer's disease. UK Brain Bank criteria is used for the diagnosis of PD.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 66-year-old man presents with complaints of resting tremor in his right hand, which improves with movement. He also says that he has difficulty initiating movements and his wife says his movements have been slow. On examination, rigidity is observed to passive arm movement and shuffling gait with a stooped posture is noticed. Which of the following statements is false regarding the pathology of this condition?
options: Substantia nigra pars reticulata is unaffected by the disease process
Decreased striatal dopamine is seen in this condition
Degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta
Lewy bodies which containing degenerated tau protein are seen
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Parkinson's disease and Lewy bodies seen in Parkinson's disease do not contain tau protein. They contain the protein -synuclein. Pathologic hallmarks of Parkinson's disease include: Degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta (SNc) Reduced striatal dopamine Intracytoplasmic proteinaceous inclusions called Lewy bodies, which contain the protein -synuclein
subject: Medicine

question_text: A patient with Parkinson's disease says that he cannot even hold a coffee mug properly due to tremors. What is the frequency of the tremors likely to be?
explanation: The frequency of resting tremors in Parkinson’s disease is 4–6 Hz. More than 70 percent of patients with Parkinson's disease have tremors as the presenting feature. The classic parkinsonian tremor begins as a low-frequency, pill-rolling motion of the fingers, progressing to forearm pronation/supination and elbow flexion/extension. Other features of the tremors are: Typically asymmetric Occurs at rest Becomes less prominent with voluntary movement Frequency of various types of tremors: Physiological tremor (12 Hz ) > Essential tremor (8–10 Hz) > Resting tremor in PD (4–6 Hz ).
subject: Medicine

question_text: What is the most common psychiatric disturbance seen in patients with Parkinson's disease?
explanation: The most common psychiatric disturbance seen in Parkinson's disease is depression. The non-motor symptoms seen in Parkinson's disease include: Cognitive dysfunction and subcortical dementia Psychosis and hallucinations - Visual hallucinations are the most common psychotic symptom Mood disorders: Depression - most common psychiatric disturbance Anxiety - second most common psychiatric disturbance Abulia/apathy Sleep disorders - insomnia, daytime sleepiness with sleep attacks, restless leg syndrome Autonomic dysfunction

question_text: Which of the following is not an example of secondary parkinsonism?
explanation: Corticobasal syndrome is not an example of secondary parkinsonism. It s a type of Parkinson's plus syndrome. question_text: What is the most common cause of secondary parkinsonism?
explanation: Dopamine-blocking agents such as neuroleptics are the most common cause of secondary parkinsonism. question_text: A patient presented to the OPD with a shuffling gait, slowed movements and speech, and cogwheeling. He was started on a new drug recently. Which of the following drugs cannot cause this condition?
explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of secondary parkinsonism. Bezatropine, also known as benztropine, is used in the treatment of parkinsonism. It does not cause secondary parkinsonism. Benztropine is a centrally acting anticholinergic. It has been used for controlling tremors in drug-induced Parkinson's. Side effects include urinary dysfunction, glaucoma, and cognitive impairment. Drugs causing secondary parkinsonism: Neuroleptics (typical antipsychotics) Metoclopramide, chlorpromazine Dopamine depleting agents (reserpine, tetrabenazine) Calcium channel blocker: Flunnarizine, Cinnarizine Lithium carbonate, amiodarone, -Methyldopa

question_text: Which of the following is a peripheral decarboxylase inhibitor?
explanation: Benserazide is a peripheral decarboxylase inhibitor. Options B & D: Benztropine and trihexyphenidyl are centrally acting anticholinergic agents. Option C: Tetrabenazine is a dopamine depleting agent. It causes drug-induced Parkinsonism.

question_text: A 75-year-old patient presents with an inability to move and speak. He has been experiencing increasing stiffness and slowness from the past 1 hour. He has an 8-year history of Parkinson's disease and takes his levodopa-carbidopa every day. The last dose was 4 hours back. What drug should be prescribed for this patient?
explanation: The clinical features of the patient are suggestive of a severe 'off' episode. The rescue agent for the treatment of severe 'off' episodes is apomorphine. Levodopa-induced motor complications consist of fluctuations in motor response ('on' episodes when the drug is working and 'off' episodes when parkinsonian features return) and involuntary movements are known as dyskinesias which typically complicate 'on' periods. Apomorphine is a non-ergot dopamine agonist. It has efficacy comparable to levodopa, but it must be administered parenterally (intravenous or subcutaneous) and has a very short half-life and duration of activity (45 min).
