question_text: Patients with which of the following do not need to be evaluated for iron deficiency?
options: Unusual craving to eat clay and paper
Insomnia due to a compulsive urge to keep moving the legs
Incidental finding of esophageal webs on upper GI endoscopy
Tingling and numbness of lower extremities
explanation: Tingling and numbness of the lower extremities are suggestive of peripheral neuropathy. It is a feature of vitamin B12 deficiency, not iron deficiency. Iron-deficiency anemia is associated with the following findings: Smooth tongue - due to loss of papillae Cheilosis - fissuring at corners of mouth Brittle nails Koilonychia - spooning of nails Pica - craving for non-edible foods like ice chips, hair, paper, clay Plummer–Vinson syndrome - dysphagia due to the formation of esophageal webs Restless legs syndrome - compulsive urge to keep moving the legs which results in insomnia
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following PBF findings is least likely to be seen in patients with iron deficiency anemia?
explanation: Image 4 shows dense RBCs with loss of central pallor or spherocytes. They are seen in autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA) and hereditary spherocytosis, not iron deficiency anemia. The peripheral blood smear in iron deficiency anemia shows: Microcytic hypochromic cells Target cells Pencil-shaped or cigar-shaped cells Poikilocytosis- variations in the shape of RBCs Anisocytosis- variations in the size of RBCs.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 28-year-old woman is brought to the ER after she faints at home. Her husband says that she is very body-conscious and does intermittent fasting. She has been on a vegan diet for the past 2 months. Lab values are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: This clinical scenario is suggestive of iron deficiency anemia due to the following findings: Low MCV (N: 87-96 fL) Low MCH (N: 27-33 pg) Elevated RDW High TIBC Option A: Anemia of chronic disease is associated with low TIBC. Options B and D: Anemia due to B12 and folate deficiency presents with a high MCV (macrocytosis).
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 62-year-old woman is found to have a Hb of 7.2 g/dl and high ferritin levels. She has been undergoing chemotherapy for breast cancer since last year. Which of the following is responsible for this presentation?
explanation: This clinical scenario is suggestive of anemia of chronic disease. The chief mediator of this condition is hepcidin. Anemia of chronic disease is associated with chronic inflammatory states such as inflammatory bowel disease, rheumatoid arthritis, chronic infections, and malignancies. Hepcidin is a positive acute-phase reactant (ARP) that increases in chronic inflammatory states. It binds with ferroportin which results in both reduced iron intake in the gut and reduced iron transfer from macrophages to erythroid progenitor cells in the bone marrow. Hence, hepcidin is a negative regulator of iron balance.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Normocytic normochromic anemia is seen in patients with which of the following?
explanation: Normocytic normochromic anemia is seen in chronic kidney disease (CKD). It is also seen in the following conditions: RBC membrane disorders - hereditary spherocytosis, elliptocytosis RBC enzyme disorders - G6PD deficiency, Pyruvate kinase deficiency Parvovirus B19 infection Anemia of chronic disease - can also present as microcytic anemia
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 38-year-old woman presented to the OPD with progressive tiredness over the last 2 months. She also reported having heavy menstrual bleeding during her previous 2 cycles. She is a known case of rheumatoid arthritis. Lab investigations are given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: This clinical scenario is suggestive of anemia of chronic disease due to the following findings: Low MCV (N: 87-96 fl) Low TIBC (N: 300-360g/dL) Elevated ferritin level (N: 50-200 g/L) Normal transferrin saturation (N: 25-50%)
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 60-year-old man with stage 4 chronic kidney disease on hemodialysis is found to have a hemoglobin of 6.3 mg/dl. Which of the following will be additionally seen in this patient?
explanation: Anemia of CKD is a form of hypoproliferative anemia presenting with decreased reticulocytes. It mainly occurs due to a failure of erythropoietin production by the diseased kidney and a reduction in the survival of RBCs. Also, patients with CKD maintained on chronic hemodialysis may develop iron deficiency from blood loss through the dialysis procedure. The following features are seen: Normocytic and normochromic RBCs Decreased reticulocytes Serum iron, transferrin saturation, TIBC are usually normal or low Decreased serum ferritin The degree of anemia usually correlates with the severity of the renal failure. Note: Anaemia in CKD is not the same as anaemia of chronic disease.
subject: Medicine

question_text: What is the predominant inheritance pattern of sideroblastic anemia?
explanation: Inherited forms of sideroblastic anemia are usually X-linked. Rarely, autosomal recessive forms may also occur. linked sideroblastic anemia results from the deficient activity of the erythroid form of ALA-synthase (ALA-synthase 2) and is associated with ineffective erythropoiesis
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following would not be seen in patients with sideroblastic anemia?
explanation: High serum iron levels are seen in patients with sideroblastic anemia. Sideroblastic anemia presents with the following features: Serum iron level - high/norma Transferrin saturation - high Serum ferritin levels - high TIBC - low/norma Peripheral smear - dimorphic population (both microcytes and macrocytes). Bone marrow study - marked erythroid hyperplasia. The iron profile of sideroblastic anemia is opposite to that of iron deficiency anemia.
subject: Medicine

question_text: The bone marrow biopsy sample of a patient with chronic anemia is stained with Prussian blue, as shown below. The stained deposits are present in which of the following?
explanation: The given image shows ringed sideroblasts, which are erythroid precursors in the marrow. In these cells, iron deposits in the mitochondria form a ring around the nucleus and are stained by Prussian blue. The mature red blood cell counterparts of ringed sideroblasts in the circulation are called siderocytes. These cells have iron-containing basophilic granules called Pappenheimer bodies, as shown below. Ringed sideroblasts and Pappenheimer bodies are pathognomonic of sideroblastic anemia.
subject: Medicine

question_text:
Which of the following drugs is known to cause sideroblastic anemia?
Cyclophosphamide
explanation: Chloramphenicol is known to cause sideroblastic anemia. The agents known to cause sideroblastic anemia are: Isoniazid Chloramphenico Linezolid Excessive alcoho Macrocytic Anemia
subject: Medicine

question_text: The peripheral blood smear of a patient is given below. All of the following can cause this except:
explanation: The given image shows hypersegmented neutrophils (> 5 nuclear lobes), which are seen in megaloblastic anemia. Chronic alcoholism causes non-megaloblastic macrocytic anemia. Megaloblastic anemia is a form of macrocytic anemia with impaired nucleic acid metabolism and defective erythropoiesis. The causes include vitamin B12 deficiency, folate deficiency, and orotic aciduria. Nuclear maturation lags behind cytoplasmic maturation giving the appearance of hypersegmented neutrophils. Peripheral smear findings include: Oval macrocytes Anisocytosis Hypersegmented neutrophils Other features of ineffective erythropoiesis seen in megaloblastic anemias include: Howell-Jolly bodies are nuclear remnants in red cells. They are usually single, round, dark purple-red in color and peripheral in location, as shown below. Basophilic stippling refers to blue granules of various sizes dispersed throughout the cytoplasm of the red cell. They represent ribosomal precipitates. Cabot rings are red cell inclusions appearing as fine, purple filamentous loops or figure-of-eight forms, as shown below. They are presumed to be remnants of mitotic spindles.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Patients with which of the following conditions are unlikely to develop cobalamin deficiency?
explanation: Ancylostoma duodenale (hookworm) infection does not affect the absorption of cobalamin or vitamin B12. Small amounts of blood loss during the attachment of hookworms to the intestinal mucosa can cause iron-deficiency anemia. Vitamin B12-intrinsic factor (IF) complex is absorbed in the ileum. Tropical sprue, Diphyllobothrium latum (fish tapeworm) infection and Crohn's disease affect the ileum leading to defective absorption of vitamin B12.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following would not be seen in a patient with cyanocobalamin deficiency?
explanation: Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia is seen in cyanocobalamin or vitamin B12 deficiency, not conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Vitamin B12 deficiency causes megaloblastic anemia due to ineffective erythropoiesis. This leads to the formation of nucleated RBCs in the marrow, which undergo early lysis. This leads to increased unconjugated bilirubin in the plasma. The clinical features of cyanocobalamin and folate deficiency include: System Clinical features Oral GlossitisAngular cheilosis Gastrointestinal AnorexiaWeight lossDiarrhea Constipation Skin Hyperpigmentation(reversibl e) Hematological ThrombocytopeniaLeucopeni aIneffective erythropoiesis an d unconjugatedjaundice Cardiovascular Atherosclerosis leading to PV D, CAD (due to elevated hom ocysteine) Neurological (only B12) Peripheral neuropathySubac ute combined degeneration ( degeneration of the posterior and pyramidal tracts of the s pinal cord) Pregnancy (only folate) Recurrent fetal lossNeural tu be defects Others Mildfeverin severe casesPsyc hiatric disturbances
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 56-year-old male patient is being evaluated for peripheral neuropathy and excessive tiredness. He has uncontrolled diabetes and consumes alcohol nearly every day. Lab investigations reveal the following findings. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: This clinical scenario is suggestive of folate deficiency. It is associated with the following clinical and laboratory findings: Raised MCV (normal: 80-100 fL) - macrocytosis Normal MCHC (normal: 33-36 g/dl) Increased MCH (mean corpuscular hemoglobin) Elevated RDW (red cell distribution width) Decreased reticulocyte count - due to destruction of abnormal erythroid precursors Elevated homocysteine Normal MMA (methyl malonic acid) In vitamin B12 deficiency, elevated homocysteine and elevated MMA levels are seen. Peripheral neuropathy is a feature of B12 deficiency, not folate deficiency. In this patient, it may be due to diabetic neuropathy.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following drugs is not associated with megaloblastic anemia?
explanation: Temafloxacin is not associated with megaloblastic anemia. Megaloblastic anemia is associated with the following drugs: Anticonvulsant drugs - phenytoin, primidone, barbiturates Sulfasalazine Nitrofurantoin Tetracycline Folate antagonists - trimethoprim, methotrexate, pyrimethamine, pentamidine, cotrimoxazole Temafloxacin is a fluoroquinolone with severe adverse effects like hemolytic anemia and allergic reactions. It was withdrawn from the market and is no longer used.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 45-year-old woman is rushed to the ER following a seizure. She is a known case of epilepsy but is non-compliant with her medications. Her lab values are given below. All of the following drugs can cause this presentation except:
explanation: This patient likely has folate deficiency secondary to the use of an anti-folate anti-convulsant drug. Lamotrigine has no effect on folate metabolism and does not cause its deficiency. The following anticonvulsants have anti-folate properties: Phenytoin Barbiturates (amobarbital) Primidone Folate deficiency causes megaloblastic macrocytic anemia which results in the following findings in RBCs: Anemia (low Hb = 10g/dl) Macrocytic (high MCV = 110 fl) Hyperchromic (high MCH = 40 pg)
subject: Medicine

question_text:
A dose of oral 58-Co-labeled cobalamin was administered to a 65-year-old woman. The
24-hour urinary excretion of radiolabeled cobalamin was found to be < 10%. The test was repeated after a 5-day course of antibiotics and showed urinary excretion > 10%. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: This clinical scenario refers to Schilling's test done for the determination of the cause of B12 deficiency. Improvement of urinary B12 excretion > 10% after antibiotic administration is suggestive of small intestinal bacterial overgrowth (SIBO).
subject: Medicine

question_text: A child diagnosed with megaloblastic anemia failed to respond to treatment with vitamin C, vitamin B12, and folic acid. He was started on uridine monophosphate which improved his symptoms. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: Megaloblastic anemia that is responsive to treatment with uridine is suggestive of orotic aciduria. Orotic aciduria is a rare inborn error of metabolism in children. It occurs due to a defect in the pyrimidine synthesis pathway causing a failure of conversion of orotic acid to uridine. It manifests in early childhood with anemia and failure to thrive.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 28-year-old woman presents with fatigue and a red, painful tongue. On examination, there is reduced vibration sense and proprioception in the feet. She is under treatment for Hashimoto's thyroiditis. Peripheral smear reveals macrocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils. Which of the following is unlikely to be seen in this patient?
explanation: This clinical scenario in a patient with a history of autoimmune thyroiditis is suspicious for pernicious anemia. It is an autoimmune cause of B12 deficiency. Antibodies against gastrin are not seen in these patients. The following autoantibodies are seen: Type I or blocking antibodies - prevent the combination of IF and cobalamin Type II or binding antibodies - prevent attachment of IF to the ileal mucosa Anti-parietal cell antibodies - target the gastric proton pump located in these cells This leads to the deficiency of the intrinsic factor of Castle (IF) and hydrochloric acid produced by the parietal cells. The resulting atrophic gastritis causes high gastrin and low pepsinogen levels. Lack of IF further causes vitamin B12 deficiency and megaloblastic anemia.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A pathologist receives a gastric biopsy sample of a patient with pernicious anemia. Which of the following findings is he unlikely to find?
explanation: Gastric biopsy in pernicious anemia shows loss of glandular elements, not hypertrophy. This is an autoimmune condition that occurs in genetically susceptible individuals. One of the common triggers of the disease process is Helicobacter pylori infection. Gastric biopsy findings in pernicious anemia include the following: Atrophy of all layers of the body and fundus Loss of glandular elements Absence of parietal and chief cells and replacement by mucus cells Mixed inflammatory cell infiltrate (excess of CD4 cells against gastric H+/K+-ATPase) Intestinal metaplasia Antral mucosa is usually well preserved.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Patients with pernicious anemia are at a higher risk of which of the following?
explanation: Patients with pernicious anemia have an increased risk of intestinal-type of gastric adenocarcinoma and gastric carcinoid tumors. These patients must undergo regular endoscopic screening for these conditions. The presumed mechanism is prolonged achlorhydria due to parietal cell loss. This leads to hypergastrinemia and cellular hyperplasia.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is the most common cause of folate deficiency?
explanation: Reduced nutritional intake is the most common cause of folate deficiency.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Dietary folates are absorbed from which of the following sites?
explanation: Dietary folates are absorbed from the duodenum and jejunum in the form of monoglutamates. Vitamin B12 absorption takes place in the terminal ileum.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 49-year-old woman is brought with increased forgetfulness and clumsiness for the past 1 month. Since the death of her husband 3 months ago, she has been tired and eating poorly. She began taking over-the-counter iron and folic acid tablets 2 months ago. Examination reveals positive Romberg's sign with eyes closed and loss of vibration in lower extremities. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: This clinical scenario is suggestive of dorsal column involvement of the spinal cord due to underlying vitamin B12 deficiency. Vitamin B12 deficiency causes subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord (SACD). It affects the following structures: Dorsal column - sensory loss, paresthesias, incontinence, sensory ataxia (positive Romberg sign with eyes closed) Lateral column - spasticity and paraplegias in later stages Folate deficiency is typically not associated with neurological manifestations. In patients with combined deficiency of B12 and folate, B12 deficiency must always be corrected first. This is because the administration of folate supplements may improve hematologic abnormalities but worsens neurological manifestations. Treatment of cobalamin deficiency is as follows: Replenishment of body stores: Six 1000-g IM injections of hydroxocobalamin given at 3- to 7-day intervals. Maintenance therapy: 1000 g hydroxocobalamin IM once every 3 months Treatment of folate deficiency is as follows: 5–15 mg oral folic acid daily for a minimum of 4 months. Option C: Thiamine deficiency causes Wernicke's syndrome with ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, and nystagmus. As this is due to cerebellar damage, Romberg's sign would be positive even with eyes open. Option D: Pyridoxine deficiency causes pellagra like syndrome with features of dermatitis, diarrhea, dementia.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 19-year-old girl with a seizure disorder is started on phenytoin therapy. Which of the following must be supplemented in this patient?
explanation: Usage of phenytoin leads to folate deficiency and megaloblastic anemia. Hence, folic acid must be supplemented.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 23-year-old woman comes to you for pre-conceptional counseling. Her previous pregnancy resulted in fetal death due to a neural tube defect. What dose of folic acid would you recommend?
options: 4-5 mg pre-conceptionally and in first trimester
explanation: The recommended prophylactic dose of folic acid in women who have had a previous fetus with a neural tube defect is 4-5 mg daily, pre-conceptionally, and during the first trimester of pregnancy. Following the first trimester, these patients are then switched to 400 g of folic acid for the remainder of the pregnancy. This high dose of folic acid (4-5 mg) should be initiated at least one to three months before pregnancy and should be continued for 12 weeks after pregnancy. The patient can be prescribed 1 mg tablet of folic acid and advised to take them 4- 5 times a day or they can be recommended 5mg tablets/capsules once daily. Prophylactic folic acid with 400 g daily, pre-conceptionally, and throughout pregnancy is indicated in all pregnant women to prevent megaloblastic anemia and reduce the incidence of neural tube defects.
subject: Medicine

question_text:
Which of the following would not be seen in a patient with Imerslund-Grasbeck syndrome?
Congenital cobalamin malabsorption
explanation: Imerslund-Grasbeck syndrome (IGS) is an autosomal recessive disorder. IGS occurs due to mutations in either the cubulin (CUBN) or amnionless (AMN) genes. They form the cubam receptor responsible for the absorption of the Cbl-IF complex. Hence, this condition leads to congenital cobalamin malabsorption. It is the most common cause of megaloblastic anemia due to B12 deficiency in infancy in Western countries. Affected children present with lethargy, failure to thrive, and neurological symptoms like hypotonia, developmental delay, and movement disorders. Non-specific proteinuria with normal renal function is seen in 90% of patients. Hemolytic Anemia

explanation: In intravascular hemolysis, there is elevated MCV, LDH, and urinary urobilinogen, with low haptoglobin. question_text: Which of the following is not due to an extracorpuscular defect in RBCs?
explanation: Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) is a hemolytic anemia due to an intracorpuscular defect. It is caused due to an acquired somatic mutation leading to deficiency of membrane protective factors CD59 and CD55. This makes the RBC extremely sensitive to complement activation and causes intravascular hemolysis. The other conditions occur due to extracorpuscular defects. Option A: In autoimmune hemolytic anemia, RBCs are coated with autoantibodies. This triggers phagocytosis in the reticuloendothelial system leading to extravascular hemolysis. Option C: Familial hemolytic uremic syndrome (atypical HUS) is an inherited abnormality with excessive complement activation leading to episodic and excessive production of membrane attack complex destroying normal RBCs. Option D: Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia is non-immune hemolysis resulting from intravascular red blood cell fragmentation due to abnormalities in the microvasculature.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is true about paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria?
explanation: Deficiency of CD55 and CD59 is seen in paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH). It is due to an acquired mutation in the X-linked phosphatidylinositol class A PIG-A gene (Option A) causing a deficiency of GPI anchor proteins. GPI is a glycolipid that anchors membrane protective factors such as CD59 and CD55 to the membrane. The deficiency of CD55 and CD59 makes the RBC sensitive to complement-mediated intravascular hemolysis(Option B). The anemia is usually normo-macrocytic (Option D). Hemolysis tends to occur at night due to a slight decrease in blood pH during sleep, which triggers complement activity (nocturnal hemoglobinuria). PNH is characterized by hemolytic anemia, pancytopenia, and venous thrombosis. PNH is diagnosed using flow cytometry. The drugs of choice for treatment are Eculizumab or Ravulizumab which work against complement C5. Supportive management of PNH includes folic acid and iron supplementation. Bone marrow transplantation is another option for the treatment of this condition.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A patient with hemolytic anemia develops features of pancytopenia and venous thrombosis. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) is a type of hemolytic anemia associated with pancytopenia and venous thrombosis. In PNH, there is complement-mediated intravascular hemolysis. Bone marrow dysfunction also occurs, resulting in pancytopenia. Transformation to aplastic anemia or acute myeloid leukemia (AML) may rarely occur. PNH is also associated with venous thrombosis (cerebral, renal, hepatic). This is the most common cause of death in PNH. Option A: Shwachman-Diamond syndrome is inherited aplastic anemia with neutropenia with pancreatic insufficiency and malabsorption. Options B and C: Pyruvate kinase and G6PD deficiency are inherited RBC enzyme disorders causing extravascular hemolytic anemias. They do not affect other cell lines and are not associated with venous thrombosis.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 31-year-old woman presents with a fever and cough. She also reports excessive tiredness and occasional dark-colored urine for the past 6 months. Chest X-ray reveals lower lobe pneumonia. Labs reveal the following. What is the investigation of choice for this condition?
explanation: This clinical scenario is suggestive of intravascular hemolysis due to paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH). The gold standard for diagnosis is flow cytometry. Flow cytometry is performed with fluorescently labeled monoclonal antibodies that bind to GPI-anchored proteins (CD59, CD55). Most tests also use FLuorescent AERolysin (FLAER), a reagent that directly binds the GPI anchor. Absence of CD59 and CD55 are diagnostic of PNH. Other investigations in PNH include: Ham test (acidified serum lysis) - lysis of RBCs in a mildly acidic pH due to complement fixation. Bone marrow biopsy: Hypercellularity with erythroid hyperplasia is seen in classical presentations. Patients who develop pancytopenia will have hypocellular bone marrow. Imaging - to evaluate venous thrombosis. Option B and D: Eosin-5-maleimide-binding and acidified glycerol lysis tests are done in hereditary spherocytosis.
subject: Medicine

question_text:
A 46-year-old woman presents with abdominal pain and yellowish discoloration of her skin. She gives a history of dark-colored urine which is more pronounced in the early mornings. Imaging reveals hepatic venous thrombosis. Flow cytometry reveals the absence of
GPI-anchored proteins. What is the drug of choice?
explanation: This clinical scenario is suggestive of paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH). C5 complement inhibitors like eculizumab and ravalizumab are the drugs of choice in PNH. Management of PNH involves the following: C5 complement inhibitors prevent the formation of membrane attack complex and complement-mediated lysis. Bone marrow transplant is useful for patients with severe pancytopenia Supportive measures: Transfusion of filtered RBCs Folic acid, and iron supplementation Anticoagulants in case of venous thrombosis
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 10-year-old boy is brought for evaluation of fatigue. On examination, he is jaundiced and mild splenomegaly is noted. He was adopted and his family history is unknown. Periphera smear findings are shown below. What is the most specific investigation for this condition?
explanation: The peripheral smear shows hyperchromic RBCs with loss of central pallor or spherocytes. These findings are suggestive of hereditary spherocytosis. The eosin-5-maleimide test is the most specific investigation for this condition. It is a flow cytometric test based on the interaction between the dye eosin-5-maleimide and band 3 protein. Other investigations that can be performed in this condition are: Acidified glycerol lysis test: Spherocytes from patients with hereditary spherocytosis lyse more quickly than normal red blood cells when incubated in a phosphate buffered hypotonic solution with added glycerol. It has greater sensitivity and specificity than the osmotic fragility test. Osmotic fragility test: Detects hemolysis by measuring the fraction of total hemoglobin released from red cells when suspended in progressively more dilute salt concentrations. Note: NESTROFT (Naked eye single tube red-cell osmotic fragility test) is a highly sensitive test used as a screening test for thalassemia.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is true regarding the treatment of hereditary spherocytosis?
options: Cholecystectomy is only indicated for patients with clinical cholelithiasis at the time of splenectomy
Cholecystectomy cannot be performed via laparoscopic route for patients with HS and pigment gall stones
Splenectomy is indicated in patients with mild and asymptomatic disease only after puberty
Lifelong penicillin prophylaxis after splenectomy is mandatory for all adult patients
explanation: Cholecystectomy at the time of splenectomy is indicated in patients with hereditary spherocytosis (HS) only if they have symptomatic cholelithiasis at the time of surgery. It is usually carried out via a laparoscopic approach. Penicillin prophylaxis after splenectomy is controversial. Routine penicillin prophylaxis is not mandatory for adults. It is recommended up to age of five and for at least one year following splenectomy. Guidelines for the timing of splenectomy in HS: Mild cases - avoid splenectomy. Moderate cases - delay until puberty Severe cases - at 4–6 years of age
subject: Medicine

question_text: The peripheral smear of a patient is given below. What is the most common mutation associated with the hereditary form of this condition?
explanation: The given peripheral smear shows oval, elongated, rod, or cigar-shaped RBCs suggestive of elliptocytosis. The hereditary form is most commonly associated with the spectrin genes. The following proteins are implicated in hereditary elliptocytosis (HE): -Spectrin (SPTA1 gene) - 65% -Spectrin (SPTB gene) - 30% Band 4.1 The treatment of choice is splenectomy, preferably after 5 years of age.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A young couple comes to you for genetic counseling. The husband is a known case of G6PD deficiency and is concerned about passing it on to his future children. What is the chance that his children will inherit the disease?
options: Only male children will be affected
explanation: G6PD deficiency is an X-linked recessive disorder. Male children of an affected man are not affected as they receive only the paternal Y chromosome. However, the mutation can be passed on to female children, who are typically carriers of the disease. G6PD deficiency is the most common enzymatic disorder of RBCs. G6PD enzyme is involved in the generation of NADPH and protects RBCs from oxidative injury. Hence, patients with G6PD deficiency have episodes of acute hemolysis in the setting of oxidant injury from medications, acute infections, and certain foods (fava beans/broad beans).
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 35-year-old male with chronic bacterial prostatitis was treated with cotrimoxazole. Within a few days, he developed malaise, jaundice, abdominal pain, and dark urine. The blood picture is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical features are suggestive of an acute hemolytic reaction following the administration of cotrimoxazole. This is suggestive of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency. In G6PD deficiency uncontrolled oxidative stress causes hemoglobin to denature and form Heinz bodies. Removal of Heinz bodies by macrophages in the spleen results in the formation of characteristic bite cells or degmacytes or blister cells (as shown in the image). A hemolytic attack starts with abrupt onset of malaise, weakness, and abdominal or lumbar pain. After an interval of several hours to 2–3 days, the patient develops jaundice and often dark urine, due to hemoglobinuria. Drugs that carry the risk of clinical hemolysis in persons with G6PD deficiency: Note: Cotrimoxazole contains sulfamethoxazole. question_text: The peripheral smear of a patient is given below. It is characteristic of which of the following conditions?
explanation: The above peripheral smear shows basophilic stippling. It is characteristic of 5' nucleotidase deficiency. Pyrimidine 5'-nucleotidase (P5'N-1) deficiency is the third most common enzyme abnormality causing hereditary hemolytic anemia. It is an autosomal recessive trait. The hallmark of this enzyme deficiency is the presence of pronounced basophilic stippling and accumulation of pyrimidine nucleotides (RNA remnants) within erythrocytes. Cabot rings may also be seen. They are thin, threadlike, red to violet rings or figure-of-8 shaped inclusions in red blood cells. They are remnants of the mitotic spindle and are seen in conditions causing dyserythropoiesis. Basophilic stippling is also seen in the following conditions: Lead toxicity Sideroblastic anemia Severe thalassemia Conditions with impaired cell division
subject: Medicine

question_text: A patient with SLE is found to have warm autoimmune hemolytic anemia. Name the antibody and the site of hemolysis in this condition?
explanation: The antibody involved in warm autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA) is IgG, which causes extravascular hemolysis. IgG is called a warm antibody, as it binds to target proteins at 37 oC. On the other hand, cold antibodies or IgM are reactive at 4 to 30oC. In AIHA, autoantibodies against RBC antigens are produced which coat the RBC membrane. The Fc portion of the antibody is recognized by the Fc receptor on macrophages causing phagocytosis. RBC destruction takes place in extravascular sites where macrophages are abundant.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Patients with which of the following are least likely to develop autoimmune hemolytic anemia?
explanation: Autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA) is commonly associated with CLL (chronic lymphocytic leukemia). It is not a typical feature of CML (chronic myeloid leukemia). AIHA can develop secondary to several autoimmune and infectious causes, as well as drugs. question_text: Which of the following are associated with a positive Coombs test?
explanation: Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) and hereditary spherocytosis are not Coomb's positive conditions. The following are Coombs-positive hemolytic anemias: Autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA) Warm AIHA Cold agglutinin disease Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria (PCH) Drug-induced hemolytic anemia In PCH, the direct Coomb's test will be positive for complement only. This condition is characterized by the presence of the Donath-Landsteiner antibody. It is a unique antibody with anti-P specificity at 4°C. Hence, it binds to the RBC at 4°C. However, it causes complement-mediated lysis at 37°C. Interpretation of direct Coomb's test results: Condition Agglutination wit h anti- IgG anti- C3 Warm AIHA + + Drug-induced + + PCH - + Cold agglutinin disease (IgM) - + PNH - -

question_text: A 20-year-old woman presented with fatigue and intermittent dark-colored urine. Further evaluation revealed positive Donath Landsteiner antibodies. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: Donath Landsteiner antibody is specific for paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria (PCH). PCH is a rare form of autoimmune hemolytic anemia. The mechanism of this antibody includes: Binding to RBCs at 4°C Complement-mediated lysis at 37°C This condition presents with intravascular hemolysis and hemoglobinuria. Blood transfusion is required in severe anemia. It is a self-limiting condition. question_text: Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia is seen in all of the following except:
explanation: Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA) is not seen in prosthetic heart valves. It is associated with macroangiopathic hemolytic anemia. MAHA refers to cell fragmentation that occurs in microcirculation. Microvascular lesions lead to luminal narrowing due to the deposition of fibrin and platelets. These produce shear stress that mechanically injures passing red cells. Hence, it is a type of non-immune hemolysis (Coombs-negative). On peripheral blood smear, schistocytes are seen. Common causes of MAHA include: Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura Hemolytic uremic syndrome Disseminated intravascular coagulation Vasculitis Malignant hypertension APLA syndrome Drug-induced hemolysis Eclampsia
subject: Medicine

question_text: In patients with atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome, which of the following mutations is associated with the best prognosis?
explanation: The best prognosis in atypical HUS is seen in membrane cofactor protein (MCP) gene mutation. Familial HUS or atypical HUS (aHUS) is the only inherited cause of extracorpuscular hemolytic anemia. It can occur due to mutations in any one of several genes encoding complement regulatory proteins. Mutations in the following genes are seen: Membrane cofactor protein - best prognosis Complement factor B - worst prognosis Complement factor H - most common Complement factor I - least common In these patients, infection or other triggers cause complement activation through the alternative pathway. This causes hemolysis and damage to endothelial cells in the kidney. It is usually self-limited. The standard treatment is plasma exchange. Eculizumab has recently been shown to be beneficial in atypical HUS.
subject: Medicine

question_text: You have decided to prescribe an oral iron chelator for a 10-year-old girl with thalassemia. Which of the following will you not prefer?
explanation: Deferoxamine has poor oral bioavailability and is administered parenterally (SC/IV). Oral formulations of both deferiprone and deferasirox are available. The adverse effects of iron chelators include: Deferiprone - neutropenia, and agranulocytosis. Deferasirox - transaminitis and mild, asymptomatic rise in serum creatinine Deferoxamine - occasional cataracts, deafness, and local skin reactions, but is usually well-tolerated
subject: Medicine

options: Naked eye single tube red-cell osmotic fragility test
explanation: Naked eye single tube red-cell osmotic fragility test (NESTROFT) is the most sensitive test to detect thalassemia in the population. Hence, it is an effective screening test. The principle is based on the decreased osmotic fragility of red cells in thalassemia. It is performed as follows: Mix EDTA blood and 0.36% buffered saline solution. question_text: During a master health check-up, a 25-year-old woman was found to have the following lab values. Which of the following will help in establishing a diagnosis in this patient?
explanation: This clinical scenario is consistent with -thalassemia minor. The diagnosis can be established by hemoglobin electrophoresis. This condition presents with the following features: Microcytes (N: 80-96 fL) Hypochromic (N: 27-33 pg) Mild anemia Target cells Normal iron profile Hemoglobin electrophoresis findings are as follows: 4% of HbA2 5% of HbF

question_text: Which of the following clinical manifestations is not associated with sickle cell trait?
explanation: Acute pain crisis is not associated with sickle cell trait. Acute pain crisis is classicaly seen in sickle cell disease. Manifestations of sickle cell trait include: Often asymptomatic. Hyposthenuria Painless hematuria - due to papillary necrosis Recurrent UTIs Risk of renal medullary carcinoma - rare Increased risk of CKD Sloughing of papillae with urethral obstruction is very rare Anemia and painful crises are rare.
subject: Medicine

question_text:
Patients with sickle cell anemia most commonly present with which of the following?
Acute pain crisis
explanation: Acute pain crisis is the most common clinical presentation of sickle cell anemia. These are intermittent episodes of vaso-occlusion in connective and musculoskeletal structures. This results in ischemia resulting in acute pain and tenderness, fever, tachycardia, and anxiety. The management includes vigorous hydration, evaluation for underlying causes, and aggressive analgesia. Other manifestations of sickle cell anemia include: Hand-foot syndrome - painful infarcts of the digits and dactylitis Priapism - infarction of the penile venous outflow tracts Chronic lower leg ulcers - ischemia and superinfection in the distal circulation Splenic sequestration crisis - life-threatening complication due to acute venous obstruction that requires emergency transfusion and/or splenectomy Aplastic crisis - commonly secondary to parvovirus B19 infection Acute chest syndrome - sickling within the lung, producing pain and temporary pulmonary dysfunction. Treatment may include lifelong transfusion support, using partial exchange transfusion Stroke - common in children Myeloproliferative Disorders and Aplastic Anemia
subject: Medicine

question_text: According to WHO 2022 classification, which of the following is not a chronic myeloproliferative neoplasm?
explanation: Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) is a lymphoid neoplasm. It is not a myeloproliferative neoplasm. Myeloproliferative neoplasms (MPN) are a group of disorders that cause an increased number of red blood cells, white blood cells, or platelets. According to 5th edition WHO classification (2022), myeloproliferative neoplasms consist of the following: Chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) Polycythemia vera (PV) Primary myelofibrosis (PMF) Essential thrombocythemia Juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia (JMML) Chronic neutrophilic leukemia (CNL) Chronic eosinophilic leukemia Myeloproliferative neoplasm, not otherwise specified
subject: Medicine

question_text: What is the most common myeloproliferative neoplasm?
explanation: The most common myeloproliferative neoplasm is polycythemia vera. It is a hematopoietic stem cell disorder that is characterized by uncontrolled proliferation of the red blood cells in the body. It is also frequently associated with an increase in white blood cells and platelets.
subject: Medicine

question_text: During a routine health checkup, the following lab reports were obtained for a young male patient. What will be your next step in the evaluation?
explanation: This patient has increased Hb and normal WBCs and platelets. The next step is to measure RBC mass to evaluate for polycythemia. A person has to be evaluated for polycythemia if there is: Increased hemoglobin: >16.5 g/dL in men or >16.0 g/dL in women, (or) Increased hematocrit: >49 percent in men or >48 percent in women This condition is due to either a true increase in the number of RBCs (absolute polycythemia) or an apparent increase due to a decrease in the plasma volume (relative polycythemia). Both of these conditions can be differentiated by measuring RBC mass (amount of total blood volume that is occupied by RBCs). In patients with absolute polycythemia, erythropoietin (EPO) levels must be measured. Primary polycythemia - low or normal EPO levels Secondary polycythemia - elevated EPO levels
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 45-year-old man is found to have a hemoglobin level of 18 g/dl, a hematocrit of 54%, and an elevated erythropoietin level. Which of the following is the least likely diagnosis?
explanation: Polycythemia vera is associated with low or normal erythropoietin (EPO) levels. Polycythemia refers to an increase in the number of red blood cells (RBC) in the body. It is classified as: Autonomous production of erythropoietin occurs in renal cell carcinoma (RCC), hepatocellular carcinoma, cerebellar hemangioblastoma. Relative (spurious) polycythemia refers to an apparent increase in RBC or hemoglobin count due to a decrease in the plasma volume. It is commonly seen in dehydration. question_text: What is the most common cytogenetic abnormality in patients with polycythemia vera?
explanation: The most common cytogenetic abnormality in polycythemia vera is the JAK2 mutation. JAK2 mutations can be found in the following neoplasms: Polycythemia vera Essential thrombocythemia Primary myelofibrosis

question_text: Which of the following statements about polycythemia vera is true?
options: Risk of thrombosis strongly correlates with the degree of thrombocytosis
Generalized pruritus is a consequence of mast cell activation by JAK 2 mutation
It is protective against H.pylori infection
Acute myeloid leukemia is the most common cause of mortality
explanation: Generalized pruritus seen in polycythemia vera (PV) is a consequence of the activation of mast cells by JAK 2 mutation. Other options: Option A: The risk of thrombosis strongly correlates with erythrocytosis, not the degree of thrombocytosis. Option C: In polycythemia vera, there is an increased risk of H.pylori infection. Option D: Thrombosis is the major cause of mortality in polycythemia vera. The incidence of acute leukemia in patients not exposed to chemotherapy or radiation therapy is low. PV is a clonal hematopoietic stem cell disorder in which red cells, granulocytes & platelets accumulate in the absence of a physiological stimulus. The most common mutation seen in PV is he JAK2 mutation. Clinical features of polycythemia vera are: Thrombosis is the most common manifestation and is the major cause of mortality. Uncontrolled erythrocytosis causes increased viscosity of the blood causing thrombosis of the vessels. Patients may present with stroke, transient ischemic attacks, myocardial infarction, and Budd-Chiari syndrome. Aquagenic pruritis is generalized itching following a warm bath or a shower due to increased mast cells and histamine. Erythromelalgia is erythema and pain in the fingers, hands, and feet due to increased platele stickiness. Splenomegaly due to increased destruction of RBCs in the spleen Gout is due to the excessive proliferation of the marrow cells leading to elevated uric acid levels.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following would not be seen in patients with polycythemia vera?
explanation: Low WBC count is not a feature of polycythemia vera. It is associated with an elevated WBC count. Common laboratory findings of polycythemia vera are: Elevated hemoglobin concentration, hematocrit levels, and RBC coun Elevated WBCs and platelet counts Low to normal erythropoietin levels Elevated serum lactate dehydrogenase
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 40-year-old man presents with a 1-month history of severe itching every time he takes a hot shower. He also reports a burning sensation in his fingers and frequent headaches. His hemoglobin is 18 g/dL and his EPO levels are low. Which of the following can provide symptomatic relief in this patient?
explanation: This clinical scenario is suggestive of polycythemia vera. In these patients, ruxolitinib, a Janus-kinase inhibitor is used to provide symptomatic relief. The treatment of polycythemia vera is as follows: Therapeutic phlebotomy - definitive treatmen Anticoagulants - in patients with thrombosis Symptomatic relief: Ruxolitinib Hydroxyurea Interferon-alpha PUVA therapy
subject: Medicine

question_text: You are a first-year medicine resident. While examining a patient, you note that his spleen is enlarged 8.5 cm below his costal margin. You would include all of the following in your differential diagnosis except:
explanation: Enlargement of the spleen > 8 cm below the costal margin or weight > 1000 g is called massive splenomegaly. It is not a feature of essential thrombocythemia (ET), as it causes only mild splenomegaly. The causes of massive splenomegaly include: Chronic myeloid leukemia Primary myelofibrosis Polycythemia vera Chronic lymphocytic leukemia Lymphoma Hairy cell leukemia Gaucher's disease Sarcoidosis Autoimmune hemolytic anemia ET is a neoplasm in which the body produces too many platelets, resulting in a platelet count > 4.5 lakhs/L. It occurs due to the mutations in the JAK2, CALR, or MPL genes. The majority of the patients are asymptomatic and are diagnosed incidentally. Some patients may present with thrombotic events or rarely, hemorrhages. The following findings are seen: Peripheral smear - abnormally large platelets Bone marrow biopsy - increased number of megakaryocytes, with hyperlobulated nuclei
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 24-year-old woman, who was diagnosed with essential thrombocythemia, is being planned for cytoreductive therapy. What first-line drug should she be started on?
explanation: The first-line drug for cytoreductive therapy in patients with essential thrombocythemia is hydroxyurea. Treatment of essential thrombocythemia is as follows: No symptoms or risk of thrombosis: Observation alone Low dose aspirin may be considered High risk of thrombosis (cardiovascular risk factors, prior history of thrombosis) Low dose aspirin Cytoreduction with hydroxyurea, busulfan, or interferon-alpha
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 60-year-old man was referred with severe anemia and hepatosplenomegaly. Peripheral smear showed teardrop cells, nucleated RBCs, and giant abnormal platelets. Bone marrow aspirate could not be obtained despite multiple attempts, hence a bone marrow biopsy was done. The findings are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The image shows the deposition of numerous collagen fibers in the bone marrow, which indicates marrow fibrosis. These clinical findings and history of a dry tap on bone marrow aspiration are diagnostic of primary myelofibrosis. In this condition, the neoplastic proliferation of hematopoietic stem cells results in increased and abnormal proliferation of the megakaryocytes. These megakaryocytes release excessive amounts of platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF) and TGF-. Increased growth factors lead to the deposition of collagen in the bone marrow which eventually leads to fibrosis. The clinical features include: Early phase: Thrombocytosis (large, abnormal platelets) and leukocytosis Hypercellularity of bone marrow Late phase: Pancytopenia Hypocellularity and fibrosis of bone marrow (dry tap) Teardrop-shaped RBCs and leukoerythroblastosis (premature release of nucleated erythroid and early granulocytes into blood) Hepatosplenomegaly - due to extramedullary hematopoiesis.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Bone marrow aspirate of a patient with pancytopenia revealed a hypercellular marrow. Which of the following conditions is unlikely?
explanation: Fanconi anemia results in pancytopenia with hypocellular bone marrow. Hence, it is not likely in this patient. Causes of pancytopenia with hypocellular bone marrow include: Inherited aplastic anemia Fanconi anemia Dyskeratosis congenita Shwachman-Diamond syndrome Acquired aplastic anemia Causes of pancytopenia with hypercellular bone marrow include: Primary bone marrow disorders Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) Myelodysplastic syndrome Myelofibrosis Systemic diseases Megaloblastic anemia Alcoholism Sarcoidosis Tuberculosis Brucellosis
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 20-year-old male patient with the following exam findings is found to have pancytopenia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The most likely diagnosis is dyskeratosis congenita. This condition is characterized by pancytopenia along with the clinical triad of: Reticular skin pigmentation Nail dystrophy Oral leukoplakia Option A: Fanconi anemia is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by pancytopenia, congenital anomalies, and an increased risk of malignancies. Option B: Shwachman-Diamond syndrome presents with bone marrow failure and exocrine pancreatic insufficiency. Option C: Diamond-Blackfan syndrome presents with low RBC counts due to congenital erythroid aplasia. Note: Fanconi anemia is different from Fanconi syndrome. Fanconi syndrome is a disorder of renal tubular function (type 2 RTA) that results in increased excretion of glucose, amino acids, bicarbonates, and phosphates.
subject: Medicine

question_text: All of the following can cause acquired aplastic anemia except:
explanation: Herpes simplex infection is not a cause of acquired aplastic anemia. Secondary causes of acquired aplastic anemia include: Radiation Toxins - Benzene Drugs Chemotherapy drugs (including cyclophosphamide) Sulfonamides Chloramphenicol Infections: 1-2 months after an attack of seronegative viral hepatitis HIV, EBV, CMV Parvovirus B19 Eosinophilic fasciitis Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria Graft vs host disease
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 25-year-old lady is being evaluated for recurrent epistaxis. On examination, the spleen is not palpable. Investigations reveal Hb of 6 g/dL, platelet count of 18,000/L, and WBC count of 3000/L. The results of a bone marrow biopsy are given below. What is the best method of management in this patient?
explanation: The clinical and laboratory findings, as well as bone marrow hypocellularity are diagnostic of aplastic anemia. In this young patient, the best method of management is hematopoietic stem cell transplantation. Aplastic anemia presents with pancytopenia and resulting bleeding manifestations, anemia, and frequent infections. Bone marrow biopsy reveals hypocellularity with fatty infiltration of the bone marrow. The management is as follows: Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation - best method of management in young patients Antithymocyte globulin with cyclosporine - elderly patients and patients without HLA-matched donors Eltrombopag - a thrombopoietin analog used as add-on therapy
subject: Medicine

question_text: What is the most common cytogenetic abnormality seen in patients with myelodysplastic neoplasm?
explanation: The most common cytogenetic abnormality seen in myelodysplastic neoplasm is the 5q deletion. Myelodysplastic syndromes/neoplasm (MDS) are a group of disorders in which abnormal stem cells produce increased numbers of immature blood cells. These immature cells are defective and die prematurely resulting in lower numbers of mature blood cells. It is characterized by pancytopenia and a high risk of acute myeloid leukemia (AML). The cytogenetic abnormalities identified in this condition include: 5q deletion 3q deletion 7q deletion Monosomy 7 Monosomy 5 5th edition WHO Classification of MDS (2022): MDS with defining genetic abnormalities: MDS with a low blast and isolated 5q deletion (MDS-5q): <5% blasts in the bone marrow or <2% blasts in the peripheral blood. MDS with a low blast and SF3B1 mutation (MDS-SF3B1): Detection of 15% ring sideroblasts may substitute for SF3B1 mutation. MDS with biallelic TP53 inactivation (MDS-biTP53): <20% blasts in the bone marrow or peripheral blood. MDS, morphologically defined: MDS with low blasts: <5% blasts in the bone marrow or <2% blasts in the peripheral blood. MDS-hypoplastic: 25% bone marrow cellularity MDS with increased blasts (IB): MDS-IB1: 5–9% of blasts in bone marrow or 2–4% in peripheral blood MDS-IB2:10-19% of blasts in bone marrow or 5-19% in peripheral blood or Auer rods MDS-fibrosis: 5-19% of blasts in bone marrow or 2–19% in peripheral blood Childhood myelodysplastic neoplasm: Childhood MDS with low blasts:<5% blasts in the bone marrow or <2% blasts in the peripheral blood Childhood MDS with increased blasts: 5-19% blasts in the bone marrow or 2-19% blasts in the peripheral blood.
subject: Medicine

question_text:
A patient with myelodysplastic syndrome was found to have 5q deletion. What is the drug of choice for this patient?
Cyclosporine
explanation: Lenalidomide is the drug of choice in patients with myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) associated with 5q deletion. It is a thalidomide derivative with the following benefits in these patients: Patients achieve transfusion independence Normal or near-normal hemoglobin levels Normalization of cytogenetics Adverse effects include: Myelosuppression (worsening thrombocytopenia and neutropenia, necessitating blood coun monitoring) Deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism However, hematopoietic stem cell transplant remains the definitive treatment. Platelet Disorders
subject: Medicine

question_text: What is the lifespan of a platelet?
explanation: The average lifespan of platelets in circulation is 7–10 days. Thrombopoietin (TPO) is the regulator of platelet production. A reduction in platelet and megakaryocyte mass increases the level of TPO, which then stimulates platelet production. The shelf life of donor platelets is 5 days. It is stored on a special agitator at 20-24 °C. The half-life of transfused platelets is 3-5 days.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following would you not expect to see in patients with a platelet disorder?
explanation: Hemarthrosis is highly suggestive of a coagulation disorder, not a platelet disorder. Bleeding diathesis can occur due to: Platelet disorders - mucocutaneous bleeding like petechiae, purpura, ecchymoses, epistaxis, menorrhagia, gastrointestinal (GI) bleeds Coagulation disorders - hemarthrosis, muscle hematomas, and bleeding into soft tissues Disorders of the vessel wall (Henoch-Schönlein purpura, scurvy) - purpura and ecchymosis
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is a disorder of platelet adhesion?
explanation: Bernard Soulier syndrome is a disorder of platelet adhesion. It occurs due to an inherited defect in the GPIb-IX complex.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Patients with which of the following conditions would have a low platelet count?
explanation: Thrombocytopenia is a feature of Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome. It is an X-linked recessive condition caused by mutations in the WASP gene. It affects T-cells and platelets and presents with the following features: Eczema Thrombocytopenia - along with decreased platelet size, impaired platelet aggregation response Immunodeficiency - low IgM, high IgE, defective regulatory T cells causing recurrent bacterial infections. Option A: Platelet storage pool disorder is a disorder of defective platelet granule formation. Option C: Henoch-Schonlein purpura is a type of small vessel vasculitis in children and young adults. Option D: Hemophilia is a coagulation disorder, hence the platelet count is not affected.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Immune-mediated destruction of platelets is seen in patients with which of the following conditions?
explanation: Immune-mediated destruction of platelets is seen in drug-induced thrombocytopenia. Common drugs that cause this are quinidine, heparin, sulfa compounds. Drug-dependent antibody binding can only be demonstrated in the presence of the drug in the laboratory assays. The thrombocytopenia normally occurs within 21 days of initial exposure and usually gets resolved after 7-10 days once the drug is stopped. Immune-mediated destruction of platelets is seen in: Drug-induced thrombocytopenia Infection-induced thrombocytopenia Idiopathic/ immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) Option A: Bernard-Soulier syndrome is a disorder of platelet adhesion. There are no autoantibodies against platelets. Option B: Hermansky-Pudlak syndrome is an inherited disorder with defective granule formation in platelets. It affects platelet activation and aggregation. Option C: Thrombotic microangiopathies like thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) and hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) lead to thrombocytopenia due to increased platelet consumption.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A young man comes to you with complaints of bleeding gums and the following skin rash. He reports that he had diarrhea last week after eating at a roadside eatery. History is significant for deep vein thrombosis 6 months ago that was treated with heparin. His CBC report revealed a platelet count of 15,000/µL, normal RBC and WBC count. His peripheral smear was normal. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario and image showing petechiae are suggestive of immune thrombocytopenic purpura. Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) is an acquired disorder with autoantibodies against platelet membrane glycoproteins IIb-IIIa or Ib-IX. It can either be primary (idiopathic) or secondary to autoimmune conditions like SLE or infections like HIV and hepatitis C. It presents with features of mucocutaneous bleeding. CBC shows isolated thrombocytopenia and peripheral smear does not reveal any hemolysis. Options A and B: HUS and TTP are microangiopathies. They are associated with hemolysis and schistocytes on peripheral smear. Option D: Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia typically presents within 5-10 days of treatment. Hence, it is not the likely diagnosis in this patient. Acute ITP Chronic ITP Common in children Common in adults (females > males) Associated with an anteceden t viral infection Not associated with antecede nt infection Spontaneous remission in 80 % cases Spontaneous remission is not usually seen
subject: Medicine

question_text: Two weeks after an upper respiratory tract infection, a 5-year-old presents with ecchymosis and petechiae all over the body. Abdominal examination revealed no hepatosplenomegaly. The platelet count is 15,000/µL and the coagulation profile is normal. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?
options: Bone marrow biopsy shows increased megakaryocytes
Bleeding into the joints is a common manifestation
The condition resolves spontaneously in 80% patients
explanation: This scenario is suggestive of acute immune thrombocytopenic purpura. Bleeding into the joints is seen in coagulation disorders and is not a manifestation of this condition. Immune thrombocytopenic purpura or idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) is an acquired disorder in which there is an immune-mediated destruction of platelets. It can be acute or chronic. Acute ITP is common in children and is usually preceded by viral infection. It presents with mucocutaneous bleeding (epistaxis, petechiae, ecchymosis). Hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, fever and jaundice are absent. The following laboratory features are seen: Thrombocytopenia (commonly <20,000 / L) Bleeding time - prolonged PT/aPTT/INR - normal Bone marrow - normal/increased megakaryocytes Peripheral smear - normal This condition resolves spontaneously in 80% of the cases. Treatment is as follows: Platelet count < 30,000 with risk factors for bleeding (antiplatelet drugs/anticoagulants or concomitant bleeding disorders): Oral glucocorticoids or IVIG Severe bleeding symptoms: IV methylprednisolone ± IVIG Life-threatening bleeding (like intracranial hemorrhage): platelet transfusion + IV methylprednisolone + IVIG
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 50-year-old woman comes to the ER after developing a spontaneous nosebleed. Over the past 1 week, she has noticed blood on her toothbrush while brushing her teeth. She was diagnosed with hepatitis C three months ago. Investigations reveal a platelet count of 32,000/ µL and a bleeding time of 9 minutes . Which of the following is false regarding the treatment of this patient?
options: She requires regular platelet transfusions until platelet count is normalized
Prednisone or anti-D immunoglobulins can be used as the first-line treatment
Splenectomy may be done if she relapses after medical management
Romiplostim and eltrombopag can be used if there is no response to splenectomy
explanation: This clinical scenario in an adult patient is suggestive of chronic ITP (idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura). She does not require platelet transfusion. It is recommended only for patients with severe bleeding manifestations (intracranial/ gastrointestinal) or platelet count < 5000 L. Chronic ITP can either be primary (idiopathic) or secondary to autoimmune conditions like SLE or infections like HIV and hepatitis C. Depending on the clinical features, the management is as follows: Clinical features Management 1. Relapse after first-line therap y Splenectomy 4. Unresponsive to all other the rapy or relapse after splenect omy Thrombopoietin receptor ago nists -romiplostim(subcutane ous),eltrombopag(oral)

question_text: Which of the following is the best treatment for the relapse of immune thrombocytopenic purpura?
explanation: Splenectomy is the treatment of choice in a case of immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) relapse after first line therapy with glucocorticoids. The relapse usually occurs once they are tapered. Vaccination against encapsulated organisms (pneumococcus, meningococcus, H. influenzae) is advised before splenectomy is performed. It is important to note that in some patients ITP resolves by itself, and observation along with intermittent IV immunoglobulins and anti - Rh(D) administration or administration of a thrombopoietin receptor agonist (eltrombopag, romiplostim) can be a viable option before splenectomy is considered. The treatment of ITP is as follows: ITP is an acquired disorder characterized by the immune-mediated destruction of platelets and possibly inhibition of platelet release from the megakaryocyte. Secondary causes of ITP include systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), HIV-AIDS, and Hepatitis C. ITP usually presents with mucocutaneous bleeding, very low platelet count, and normal peripheral blood cells. Patients typically exhibit ecchymoses and petechiae or they may incidentally discover thrombocytopenia during a routine complete blood count. Rarely, life-threatening bleeding may occur. The presence of wet purpura (blood blisters in the mouth) and retinal hemorrhages can serve as warning signs of potentially life-threatening bleeding. Clinical features Management 1. Minor bleeding manifestatio ns (and/or)Platelet count > 5 000/ L Prednisone(OR)Anti-D immu noglobulin therapy- effective only in Rh-positive patients ( OR)Intravenous immunoglob ulin (IVIG) 2. Severe ITP (any of the followi ng):Significant GI / intracrani al bleedingPlatelet count < 5 000/LSigns of impending bl eeding (retinal or large oral mucosal bleeds) Platelet transfusion (AND)Hi gh-dose glucocorticoids (AN D)IVIG / Anti-D immunoglob ulins + Rituximab 3. Relapse after first-line therap y Splenectomy 4. Unresponsive to all other the rapy or relapse after splenect omy Thrombopoietin receptor ago nists -romiplostim(subcutane ous),eltrombopag(oral)

question_text: It is your first day as an intern in the medicine ward. The senior resident tells you to check the platelet count of a patient who is being monitored for thrombocytopenia. He was started on a new medication the previous night. What drug was most likely prescribed?
explanation: Abciximab can cause a drop in platelet count within 24 hours of initial exposure. Hence, these patients must be monitored for thrombocytopenia. This is due to naturally-occurring antibodies that cross-react with the drug bound to the platelets. Thrombocytopenia due to other drugs typically occurs several days after exposure (average 21 days) and resolves in 7-10 days after drug withdrawal. Drug-induced thrombocytopenia can occur due to the following mechanisms: Bone marrow suppression - chemotherapeutic drugs Drug dependent antibodies that react with platelet surface antigens - quinine and sulfonamides Naturally occurring antibodies that cross-react with drugs bound to the platelets - platelet Gp IIb/IIIa inhibitors Some of the drugs that cause thrombocytopenia are: Antibiotics - ampicillin, cephalosporins, piperacillin, vancomycine Analgesics - ibuprofen, acetaminophen Anti-epileptics - phenytoin, carbamazepine Heparin Amiodarone
subject: Medicine

question_text: Patients with all of the following usually present with bleeding except:
explanation: Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) is not associated with bleeding. On the contrary, it is associated with an increased risk of thrombosis. This condition occurs due to the production of antibodies against the heparin-PF4 complex (platelet factor 4, a platelet-specific protein). These antibodies can activate platelets and result in thrombosis. It is seen 5-14 days after exposure to heparin. These antibodies can be detected using ELISA or serotonin release assay. This condition is managed by discontinuing heparin and using alternative anticoagulants.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following cannot be used in the treatment of patients with heparin-induced thrombocytopenia?
explanation: Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) such as enoxaparin cannot be used in the treatment of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT). This is because HIT antibodies (against anti-PF4-heparin complex) may cross-react with LMWH. HIT can occur following exposure to unfractionated heparin and less commonly with LMWH. The treatment of HIT is as follows: Discontinue heparin Anticoagulation with non-heparin anticoagulants even in the absence of thrombosis, since there is a high risk of thrombosis. Direct thrombin inhibitors: Argatroban, lepirudin, bivalirudin Danaparoid (heparinoid)
subject: Medicine

question_text: The CBC of a 33-year-old woman revealed a low platelet count. However, further evaluation revealed this to be an in vitro sampling error. Which of the following is the likely cause of this finding?
explanation: This scenario is suggestive of pseudothrombocytopenia. It is seen in blood samples collected with EDTA as the anticoagulant. EDTA causes a reduction in the calcium content of the collected blood sample. This triggers in vitro platelet clumping and agglutination by antibodies (usually IgG), as shown below: When a low platelet count is obtained with an EDTA sample, the peripheral blood smear should be evaluated. The platelet count must also be determined in blood collected in sodium citrate or heparin collection tubes or fresh fingerstick blood sample.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is false regarding patients with Bernard-Soulier syndrome?
options: Platelet aggregation tests with epinephrine and ADP are normal
explanation: The ristocetin aggregation test is abnormal (no aggregation) in patients with Bernard-Soulier (BS) syndrome. It is an inherited disorder of platelet function or qualitative platelet disorder due to deficiency of the Gp Ib-IX receptor. This is the platelet membrane receptor for the von Willebrand factor (vWF). The binding of the vWF to the GpIb-IX-V complex on the platelet membrane is essential for platelet adhesion to the vessel wall. This condition presents with mild thrombocytopenia and peripheral smear shows large platelets. Platelet aggregation tests are performed to measure platelet activation and aggregation in vitro. Various platelet agonists like ADP, epinephrine, collagen, and ristocetin can be used to perform these tests. In Bernard-Soulier syndrome, the following responses are seen: With ristocetin - No response/no aggregation, as ristocetin specifically binds to the platelet membrane via the Gp Ib-IXa receptor With ADP or epinephrine - Normal response, as Gp IIb-IIIa receptor is not involved in this process
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is the most common inherited bleeding disorder?
explanation: Von Willebrand disease (vWD) is the most common inherited bleeding disorder. vWD occurs due to deficient or abnormal von Willebrand factor (vWF). vWF is synthesized by endothelial cells and megakaryocytes (gene located on chromosome 12p). It is then stored in endothelial storage vesicles, Weibel-Palade bodies. Metalloprotease ADAMTS13 cleaves ultra-large multimers of VWF which are responsible for platelet adhesion. The functions of vWF and the corresponding symptoms include: Adhesion of the platelets to the exposed subendothelium - symptoms of both platelet and bleeding disorders Prolongs the half-life of factor VIII by binding to it in circulation - hemophilia A like symptoms (rare)
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is called autosomal hemophilia?
explanation: Autosomal hemophilia is also called type 2N von Willebrand disease (vWD), as the clinical presentation is similar to hemophilia. The types of vWD are: In pseudo vWD, the vWF is normal. However, platelets have an increased affinity for vWF. It presents similar to vWD 2B with thrombocytopenia. Type Inheritan ce Mechanism Important characteristics 1 AD Partial quantitative deficienc y of VWF Most commontype 3 AR Complete quantitative deficie ncy Most severe VWD 2A AD Loss of VWF multimers (incr eased cleavage by ADAMS13) Platelet adhesion defect 2B AD Increased binding of VWF to platelets causing VWF-platele t complex destruction Thrombocytopenia 2M AD Decreased affinity of VWF to platelets Platelet adhesion defect, very rare 2N AR Decreased affinity of VWF to Factor VIII Autosomal hemophilia
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following patients has Heyde's syndrome?
options: A man with aortic stenosis with gastrointestinal bleeding
A woman with aortic stenosis with intracranial bleed
A man with aortic regurgitation with gastrointestinal bleeding
A woman with aortic regurgitation with intracranial bleed
explanation: Heyde’s syndrome is aortic stenosis with gastrointestinal bleeding, due to angiodysplasia of the gastrointestinal tract. The shear stress on blood passing through the stenotic aortic valve produces a change in the von Willebrand factor making it susceptible to serum proteases. Hence, large multimer forms are lost, leading to an acquired type 2 von Willebrand disease (vWD). The condition is reversed with the replacement of the aortic valve. Other causes of acquired vWD include: Multiple myeloma Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma Polycythemia vera Systemic lupus erythematosus
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following laboratory findings is seen in a patient with von Willebrand's disease?
explanation: Bleeding time is increased in von Willebrand disease (vWD). It is a combination of a platelet adhesion defect with factor VIII deficiency. The laboratory findings in vWD include: Platelet count is normal (except type 2B) Bleeding time is prolonged Ristocetin aggregation is abnormal Other platelet aggregation tests are normal Prothrombin time (PT) is normal aPTT is prolonged VWF activity is decreased Factor VIII activity is decreased
subject: Medicine

question_text:
A 28-year-old woman is being evaluated for prolonged bleeding following a tooth extraction. She also reports heavy bleeding during menses and recurrent gum bleeds. Labs show increased aPTT, normal PT, and increased bleeding time. Which of the following is the
first-line treatment for this patient?
explanation: This clinical scenario is suggestive of von Willebrand's disease. The preferred first-line treatment is desmopressin (DDAVP). This drug acts on endothelial V2 receptors causing the release of VWF and factor VIII from endothelial stores. DDAVP can be given intravenously or by an intranasal spray. The side effects include tachyphylaxis and hyponatremia. VWF concentrate and factor VIII concentrate are reserved for patients with severe disease or prior to major procedures. Antifibrinolytic therapy (tranexamic acid or -aminocaproic acid) may be used for the prevention and treatment of mucosal bleeding.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following features is not seen in patients with Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia?
options: Abnormal platelet aggregation on adding ADP
explanation: Thrombocytopenia is not seen in Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia. Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia is a primary defect of platelet function (aggregation). It occurs due to congenital absence of the GpIIb/IIIa receptor. It presents as superficial mucocutaneous bleeding with normal platelet count and single isolated platelets without clumping on peripheral smear. The levels of vWF are normal. Normally, release of ADP causes platelets to change shape and bind to fibrinogen through the GpIIb/IIIa receptor. In Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia, absence of the receptor causes abnormal aggregation (absent or reduced) on adding ADP. However, aggregation in response to ristocetin is normal, as it is dependent on GpIb and vWF. Secondary platelet dysfunction can be seen in the following conditions: Uremia Paraproteinemia Myeloproliferative disorders
subject: Medicine

question_text: A physician decides to start a patient with stroke on antiplatelet medication. All of the following drugs would be effective except:
explanation: Pagoclone is an anxiolytic medication. It is not an antiplatelet drug. The thienopyridine drugs are ADP receptor or P2Y12 antagonists that inhibit ADP mediated platelet aggregation. They include the following drugs: Clopidogrel - commonly used Ticagrelor - reversible drug with a shorter t1/2, does not require activation, may cause mild, self-limited dyspnea Prasugrel - 10 times more potent than clopidogrel, rapid onset of action, better absorption, more predictable Ticlopidine Clopidogrel and prasugrel are prodrugs that require activation by cytochrome P450 enzymes. CYP2C19 polymorphisms can cause reduced platelet inhibition with clopidogrel and increased risk of cardiovascular events.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 24-year-old woman underwent evaluation for bleeding manifestations and severe anemia. Investigations revealed combined autoimmune hemolytic anemia and idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: Combined autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA) and idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) is called Evans syndrome. Options B and C: May-Hegglin anomaly and Fechtner syndrome are autosomal dominant hereditary conditions presenting with bleeding, sensorineural hearing loss, glomerulonephritis, and/or eye abnormalities. The severity of the bleeding symptoms is out of proportion to the moderately decreased platelet count. Option D: Rosenthal syndrome or hemophilia C refers to factor XI deficiency.
subject: Medicine

question_text: What is the most common side effect experienced by patients taking enteric-coated aspirin?
explanation: The most common side effect of aspirin is gastrointestinal symptoms. The use of enteric-coated aspirin does not reduce these side effects. Aspirin irreversibly acetylates and inhibits platelet cyclooxygenase (COX)-1, which causes reduced synthesis of thromboxane A2. At high doses, it also inhibits COX-2, which results in the anti-inflammatory effects of aspirin. The major GI side effects include dyspepsia, erosive gastritis, peptic ulcers with bleeding and perforation. The overall risk of major bleeding with aspirin is 1–3% per year, which increases 2-3 fold if there is concurrent use of other antiplatelet drugs or anticoagulants. The risk of bleeding can be reduced by eradication of Helicobacter pylori infection and giving proton pump inhibitors (PPIs). Aspirin sensitivity refers to bronchospasm or urticaria/angioedema seen immediately after administration of aspirin. It is also called Samter's triad (asthma, recurrent nasal polyps, aspirin sensitivity). In patients with aspirin resistance, there is failure of aspirin to produce its normal platelet inhibitory functions.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is incorrect about the mechanism of action of dipyridamole?
options: Increases levels of cyclic AMP in platelets
explanation: Dipyridamole increases extracellular adenosine levels. It is an antiplatelet drug that increases levels of cyclic AMP (cAMP) in platelets by: Blocking the reuptake of adenosine and increasing extracellular adenosine levels Inhibiting phosphodiesterase-mediated cAMP degradation This increase in cyclic AMP reduces intracellular levels of calcium. This inhibits platelet activation and aggregation. Dipyridamole is a weak antiplatelet used in combination with aspirin for the prevention of stroke in patients with TIA. Side effects include gastrointestinal and vasodilatory complaints (headache, flushing, dizziness, hypotension). Due to it's vasodilatory effects, it is contraindicated in patients with symptomatic coronary artery disease.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 62-year-old man diagnosed with myocardial infarction is planned for percutaneous intervention. He was diagnosed with diabetic nephropathy 2 months ago. The cardiologist decides to start him on aspirin and an additional antiplatelet drug. Which of the following can be used for this patient?
explanation: Abciximab is safe in patients with renal impairment. It belongs to the group of GpIIb-IIIa receptor antagonists. These are parenteral drugs that are used in the management of patients with acute coronary syndrome. There are three important drugs in this group: Immune-mediated thrombocytopenia and bleeding are the most common side effects. Thrombocytopenia can occur within 24 hours of initiation.
