subject: Medicine

question_text: Plasmapheresis is the mainstay of treatment in patients with which of the following?
explanation: Plasmapheresis is the mainstay of the treatment of patients with thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP). The best response to this therapy is seen in patients with ADAMTS13 autoantibodies. Plasmapheresis is continued until the resolution of platelet count and signs of hemolysis for at least 2 days. Option A: The first line of treatment of autoimmune hemolytic anemia is glucocorticoids. The second line includes rituximab and splenectomy. Option B: Treatment of disseminated intravascular coagulation is primarily supportive with measures to treat the underlying cause. Option D: Treatment of HUS is primarily supportive. Dialysis is usually required. In some varients of HUS plasma infusion/exchange can be effective by replasing the complement-regulatory proteins.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is not seen in patients with thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura?
explanation: Large vessel arterial or venous thromboemboli are not seen in thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP). This condition is associated with microvascular thrombosis. TTP occurs due to deficiency or autoantibodies against the metalloprotease ADAMTS13, which normally cleaves multimers of vWF. In this condition, the vWF molecules persist causing pathogenic platelet adhesion and aggregation. This causes localized platelet thrombi and fibrin deposits at various sites. It presents with the following pentad of clinical features: Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia - mechanical shearing of RBCs as they pass through platelet rich-microthrombi Thrombocytopenia - deposition of platelets in microthrombi Renal failure - microthrombi in the renal vasculature Neurologic findings - headache, confusion, transient focal neurologic deficits Fever
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding patients with thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura?
options: Clinical features overlap with hemolytic uremic syndrome
It is common in patients with HIV infection
It can be associated with use of quinine
explanation: In patients with thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP), the PT and aPTT are normal, as consumptive coagulopathy is not seen. TTP and HUS are thrombotic microangiopathies with overlapping clinical features. TTP can be primary (ADAMTS13 deficiency) or secondary (associated with infections like HIV and drugs like quinine). Note: In disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), thrombocytopenia and microangiopathy are seen. It is associated with consumption of clotting factors and fibrinogen resulting in prolonged PT and aPTT.
subject: Medicine

question_text: What is the most common genetic abnormality seen in patients with recurrent history of venous thrombosis?
explanation: Factor V Leiden mutation is the most common inherited cause of venous thrombosis. Venous thrombosis typically manifests as deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary thromboembolism. Hypercoagulable states or thrombophilias can be inherited or acquired: Inherited causes in decreasing order of prevalence are as follows: Factor V Leiden mutation Prothrombin mutation Protein C deficiency Protein S deficiency Antithrombin III deficiency Acquired causes include: Surgery Malignancy Antiphospholipid syndrome Trauma Pregnancy Long-haul travel Obesity Oral contraceptives/hormone replacement Myeloproliferative disorders Polycythemia vera
subject: Medicine

question_text:
Which of the following qualitative platelet disorders are inherited as autosomal dominant?
Glanzman thrombasthenia
explanation: Platelet storage pool disease (SPD) is an example of an autosomal dominant qualitative platelet disorder. It refers to a group of disorders characterized by a deficiency of platelet granules causing secretion defects. Bernard Soulier syndrome, Glanzman thrombasthenia, and Chediak-Higashi syndrome are inherited as autosomal recessive traits. Acute Leukemia
subject: Medicine

question_text: What is the most common type of leukemia in adults?
explanation: Chronic lymphoid leukemia (CLL) is the most common type of leukemia in adults. The common types of leukemia in various age groups is as follows: Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) - most common acute leukemia in adults Acute lymphoid leukemia (ALL) - most common cancer in childhood. The most common subtype f ALL is B-cell ALL Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma (NHL) - most common lymphoid malignancy in adults
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is not a risk factor for acute myeloid leukemia?
explanation: Evan's syndrome does not predispose to acute myeloid leukemia (AML). The following conditions predispose to AML: Genetic conditions: Down's syndrome: Young children <4 years Typically of the acute megakaryocytic subtype and associated with GATA1 mutations Excellent clinical outcomes Defective DNA repair in conditions like ataxia telangiectasia, Fanconi anemia, and Bloom syndrome Environmental factors: Drugs: Alkylating agents - cyclophosphamide, melphalan, dacarbazine, platinum compounds, after 4-6 years of exposure Topoisomerase II inhibitors - etoposide, after 1-3 years of exposure. Radiation - high dose radiation, therapeutic radiation in patients exposed to alkylating agents Chemicals - benzene, petroleum products, pesticide Hematological disorders with increased risk of AML: Myeloproliferative disorders Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria Aplastic anemia Myelodysplastic syndrome Multiple myeloma
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 2-year-old girl was referred with recurrent bacterial infections. Parents report that their first child also had similar features and died at the age of 18 months from myeloid leukemia. Investigations revealed markedly reduced absolute neutrophil count. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: This clinical scenario of congenital neutropenia is suggestive of Kostmann syndrome. It is associated with an increased risk of acute myeloid leukemia (AML). Kostmann syndrome occurs due to mutations in the G-CSF receptor and neutrophil elastase. This causes bone marrow failure specifically in the myeloid lineage. It presents in young children as recurrent bacterial infections (such as otitis media, cellulitis) and oral ulcers. Option A: Bloom syndrome occurs due to defects in DNA repair. It is not associated with neutropenia but has a higher risk of AML. Option C: Diamond-Blackfan syndrome refers to congenital erythroid aplasia. It is also associated with a higher risk of AML. Option D: Chediak-Higashi syndrome is due to defective phagolysosome formation. It is not associated with neutropenia.
subject: Medicine

question_text:
A 60-year-old man is being evaluated for suspected acute myeloid leukemia. He reports a fast-growing swelling in his mouth for the past 1 week. On examination, there is a greenish
gingival mass with a necrotic surface. This presentation is likely associated with which of the following?
explanation: This clinical scenario is suggestive of a chloroma. It is commonly associated with the M2 subtype of acute myeloid leukemia, also called AML with maturation. Chloroma is also called myeloid sarcoma, extramedullary myeloid tumor, or granulocytic sarcoma. It is an extramedullary tumor mass consisting of myeloid blasts, with or without maturation. It is called chloroma due to the peculiar green color, caused by myeloperoxidase. The sites affected include orbit (most common), skull, oral cavity, paranasal sinuses, sternum, ribs, vertebrae, and pelvis.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Patients suffering from which type of AML are more prone to develop disseminated intravascular coagulation?
explanation: Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) is commonly seen in patients with acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL).
subject: Medicine

question_text: Oral cavity examination of a 56-year-old man with suspected leukemia revealed the following. What subtype of AML is he likely to be suffering from?
explanation: The given image shows swollen and spongy gums, indicating gum infiltration. This is a characteristic feature of acute monocytic leukemia (AML-M5). Infiltration of the gingivae, skin, soft tissues or meninges with leukemic blasts is characteristic of the monocytic subtypes and those with 11q23 chromosomal abnormalities. Less commonly, infiltration is also seen in acute myelomonocytic leukemia (AML-M4).
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following would be seen on flow cytometry of a patient with acute megakaryoblastic leukemia?
explanation: On flow cytometry, the immunophenotype of acute megakaryoblastic leukemia is CD41 and/or CD61 positive (platelet-specific antigens). Flow cytometry is useful in establishing the different subtypes of AML: Phenotype CD markers Myeloblastic CD11b,13,33,117 Promyelocytic(M3) CD13,33 Myelomonocytic(M 4) CD11b,13,14,33 Monocytic(M5) CD11b,11c,13,14,33 Erythroid(M6) Glycophorin,spectri n Megakaryoblastic( M7) CD41,61 Basophilic CD11,13,33,123 Mast cell CD13,33,117
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is true about the WHO classification of acute myeloid leukemia?
options: The clinical features are not considered to define the subtype
The cutoff value of blast cells for diagnosis is 20%
It is only based on morphological features of myeloid precursors
Chromosomal translocations along with > 20% blasts are needed for diagnosis
explanation: The cutoff value of blast cells for the diagnosis of AML is 20% according to the WHO classification. This classification is based on the clinical features, cytogenetic and molecular abnormalities in addition to morphology. This is in contrast to the previously used French-American-British (FAB) classification which was based on only morphology of myeloid precursors. The major changes in the WHO classification in contrast to FAB classification are: Blast cutoff for diagnosis of AML is 20% (30% in FAB classification) Specific chromosomal rearrangements such as t (8;21), inv(16), t(16;16) and t (15;17) can define AML even with < 20% blasts Immunophenotyping (flow cytometry) is used to differentiate AML from ALL and to identify some subtypes of AML Myeloid dysplasia with blasts between 20-30% can benefit from therapy for myelodysplastic syndrome (decitabine, 5-azacytidine, cedazuridine)
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 50-year-old man is referred for evaluation of severe anemia, persistent fever, and recurrent epistaxis. Lab investigations are given below. What is the diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute myeloblastic leukemia (AML). According to the WHO criteria, the diagnosis of AML requires any one of the following: Blast cell count 20% either in the peripheral blood or bone marrow Presence of any one of the following cytogenetic abnormalities: t(15;17) t(8;21) Inversion 16 or t(16;16) t(9;22) NPM1 mutation (Nucleophosmin mutation) CEBPA mutation FLT3-ITD
subject: Medicine

question_text: Patients with all of the following are classified as AML with recurrent cytogenetic abnormalities except:
explanation: The chromosomal translocation t(9,22) is called the Philadelphia chromosome. It is seen in patients with CML. AML with recurrent genetic abnormalities includes the following chromosomal aberrations: t(15;17) t(8;21) Inversion 16 or t(16;16) Two gene mutations have been added to the criteria of AML with recurrent genetic abnormalities in addition to chromosomal aberrations. Both gene mutations are associated with a good prognosis. NPM1 mutation: Nucleophosmin mutation CEBPA mutation
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following cytogenetic abnormalities is seen in patients with acute promyelocytic leukemia?
explanation: t(15,17) is associated with acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL).
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 65-year-old woman presented with fatigue and fever for the past 2 months. Investigations revealed pancytopenia and the following peripheral smear findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario and peripheral smear showing blast cells with peroxidase granules are suggestive of acute myeloid leukemia (AML). Peroxidase granules are dark blue-stained granules seen in the cytoplasm on peroxidase staining. Myeloperoxidase cytochemical activity is negative in chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) and blast crisis.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following patients with AML has a better prognosis than the others?
options: A 48-year-old man newly diagnosed with AML with a family history of lymphoma
A 60-year-old woman who developed AML following chemotherapy for ovarian cancer
A 71-year-old man with a longstanding history of myelodysplastic syndrome
A 67-year-old woman evaluated with a 4-month history of pancytopenia prior to diagnosis
explanation: Young age of onset is associated with a good prognosis in patients with AML. Family history does not affect the prognosis. P r prognosis is seen in the following cases: Advancing age (usually defined as > 60 years) Previous hematologic disorders - myeloproliferative neoplasms and myelodysplastic syndrome Longstanding cytopenias >3 months before diagnosis Therapy-related AML (chemotherapy for other cancers) Chromosomal aberrations with poor outcomes
subject: Medicine

question_text: A pathologist is examining the peripheral smear of a patient with suspected leukemia. All of the following features are suggestive of a myeloblast except:
explanation: Pelger-Huet anomaly is not a feature of myeloblasts. Auer rods and Phi bodies are considered pathognomonic of AML. Myeloblasts have the following characteristics as shown in the following image: Large, uniform population of cells Prominent nucleoli (yellow arrow in the image) Primary cytoplasmic granules Auer rods - needle-shaped azurophilic intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies formed by fusion of lysosomes (black arrow) Phi-bodies - fusiform or spindle-shaped rods similar to Auer rods that require special stains for hydroperoxidases Pseudo-Chediak-Higashi syndrome - Giant lysosomes forming intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies Pelger-Huet anomaly refers to neutrophils with bilobed nuclei that occur as a benign, inherited condition. Pseudo-Pelger-Huet anomaly refers to an acquired defect seen in CML, myelodysplastic syndrome. Note: Chediak-Higashi syndrome is a rare autosomal recessive disorder with abnormal lysosomal trafficking (LYST gene). Presents with oculocutaneous albinism and immunodeficiency.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A patient presents to the ER with a sudden-onset fever and the following painful rash over her face and upper limbs. CBC reveals neutrophilia. This presentation is associated with all of the following conditions except:
explanation: This clinical presentation with painful edematous plaques is suggestive of febrile neutrophilic dermatosis or Sweet syndrome. It is not associated with aplastic anemia. It is associated with the following conditions: Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) - most common Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) Solid malignancies of the genitourinary tract Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) Drugs - all-trans-retinoic acid, granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF) Idiopathic Sweet syndrome - common in women following respiratory tract infection This condition presents with the following triad: Fever Neutrophilia Dense dermal infiltrate of neutrophils: Pinkish-red to reddish-brown edematous painful plaques Occur over the head, neck, extremities
subject: Medicine

question_text: What is the most commonly used complete remission induction regimen in patients with AML?
explanation: The most commonly used complete remission induction regimen in patients with AML is cytarabine and an anthracycline (e.g., daunorubicin, idarubicin). The treatment of AML is as follows: Induction chemotherapy with a 7+3 regimen: Cytarabine - continuous intravenous infusion for 7 days IV daunorubicin on days 1,2,3 Side effects include neutropenia, sepsis Post-remission therapy: High dose cytarabine Allogenic hematopoeitic stem cell transplant Novel agents include gemtuzumab ozogamicin, a CD33 monoclonal antibody.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 60-year-old man came with generalized bone pain, and easy bruisability for the past 6 months. His WBC count was 60,000 cu. mm and bone marrow aspiration revealed the following. Immunohistochemistry was positive for MPO and cytogenetic studies showed presence of t(15:17). What is the preferred treatment regimen?
options: Arsenic trioxide and all transretinoic acid
explanation: The presence of blast cells with numerous Auer rods, MPO (myeloperoxidase) positive cells, and t(15:17) is diagnostic of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL). The preferred treatment regimen is arsenic trioxide and all-trans-retinoic acid (ATRA). APL is characterized by t(15; 17) translocation resulting in the PML-RAR-alpha fusion gene (promyelocyte-retinoic acid receptor alpha). It is a highly curable subtype of leukemia. The treatment is as follows: Induction therapy: ATRA + anthracycline (daunorubicin or idarubicin) or cytarabine (OR) ATRA + arsenic trioxide Consolidation therapy: Post remission anthracycline-based chemotherapy
subject: Medicine

question_text: An 18-year-old girl with the diagnosis of acute promyelocytic leukemia was treated medically. She developed fever and tachypnea and a chest X-ray showed pulmonary infiltrates. What drug should she be given next?
explanation: The clinical scenario describes a patient of APL (acute promyelocytic leukemia) developing fever, tachypnea, and pulmonary infiltrates while on medical treatment. This is suggestive of APL differentiation syndrome, an adverse effect of all-trans-retinoic acid (ATRA). The management involves glucocorticoids like dexamethasone. Along with glucocorticoids, the other management of APL differentiation syndrome includes chemotherapy for cytoreduction and supportive measures. In severe cases, temporary discontinuation of ATRA is necessary. ATRA is an oral drug that induces the differentiation of leukemic cells bearing the t(15;17) chromosomal translocation. While ATRA reduces the incidence of DIC associated with cytarabine and daunorubicin used earlier in APL, it can cause APL differentiation syndrome due to the adhesion of differentiated neoplastic cells to the pulmonary vasculature endothelium. In low-risk APL patients with a low leukocyte count at presentation, a combination of ATRA and arsenic trioxide (ATO) has been found to be superior and is the current standard of care.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 47-year-old man with a diagnosis of acute myeloid leukemia with a blood type O negative blood group presents to the transplant clinic to discuss proceeding with an allogeneic stem cell transplant. Which of the following would be an optimal donor?
options: His HLA identical 50-year-old brother who is otherwise healthy and is blood type O+
An HLA identical matched unrelated donor who is blood type O–
explanation: In the case of acute myeloid leukemia (AML), allogeneic stem cell transplants are the treatment of choice. His HLA identical 50-year-old brother who is blood type O positive would be the best choice. Other options: Option A: An identical twin brother would not be the donor of choice. The therapeutic benefit of stem cell transplant in hematological malignancies is due to the graft-versus-leukemia (GvL). Donor T lymphocytes attack malignant hematopoietic stem cells of the recipient that remain after high-dose chemotherapy. Despite having a low rate of graft versus host disease (GvHD), stem cells from an identical twin do not have a desirable degree of GvL effect, leading to higher rates of recurrence post-transplant. Option B: Autologous (umbilical cord transplant) is not recommended as higher rates of relapse have been reported. Option D: An HLA identical sibling is preferred over an unrelated HLA identical donor because there is a greater chance of matching for minor histocompatibility complex (mHC). This reduces the risk of GvHD. ABO compatibility is also important to consider, but a minor ABO mismatch (Rh mismatch) doesn't have any impact on hemolysis, graft-versus-host disease, or survival.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Individuals in which age group have the highest incidence of T-cell acute lymphoblastic lymphoma?
explanation: The highest incidence of T-ALL (T-cell acute lymphoblastic lymphoma) is at 10-19 years (adolescence) when the thymus reaches the maximum size. On the other hand, B-ALL which is more common has a peak incidence at 3 years (1-10 years). At this age, the number of normal bone marrow pre-B cells (the cell of origin) is at its greatest.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Children with Down's syndrome are at an increased risk of developing all of the following except:
explanation: Down's syndrome is not associated with myelodysplastic disorder. These patients are at increased risk of developing the following conditions: Acute lymphoid leukemia (ALL) - most commonly B-cell ALL Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) - most commonly M7/megakaryoblastic subtype Transient myeloproliferative disorder: Associated with GATA1 mutations. Seen in 10% of neonates, resolves in first 3 months of life Require close follow-up as 20-30% may develop AML by 3 years of life
subject: Medicine

question_text: An 8-year-old boy was brought with fever, weight loss, and easy bruisability. Initial examination revealed severe pallor and significant lymphadenopathy. Peripheral smear revealed the following cells, which were also seen on bone marrow studies. Further investigations revealed CD10+ cells. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: This clinical scenario and image showing blast cells in a young child are suggestive of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). The presence of CD10 is diagnostic of pre-B-cell ALL. CD10 is also called the common ALL antigen (CALLA). It is the specific immunohistochemical marker for pre-B cell ALL. This is the most common type of ALL and is associated with a good prognosis. However, CD10 is negative in infantile leukemia, which is associated with translocation (4;11). The immunohistochemistry of ALL is as follows: Other abnormalities in ALL include: Type CD marker pro-B cell CD34,CD19, CD79a pre- B cell CD19, CD79a,CD10, Tdt, Cyt oplasmic Ig Mature B c ell CD19, CD79a,CD20, CD21,C D22, Surface IgM and D T cell CD 2,3,4,5,6,7 Good prognosis Bad prognosis Cytoge nic t(12,21) t(9,22), t(4,11)Burkitt lympho ma-associated ALL / ALL-L3 - t(2,8) , t(8,14), t(8,22) Molecu lar HyperdiploidyHOXNOTCH 1 mutations Hypodiploidy
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following indicate a good prognosis in children diagnosed with acute lymphoblastic leukemia?
explanation: In children with ALL, a good prognosis is indicated by low WBC count, female sex, and hyperdiploidy. Other abnormalities in ALL include: Good prognosis Bad prognosis Cytoge nic t(12,21) t(9,22), t(4,11)Burkitt lympho ma-associated ALL / ALL-L3 - t(2,8) , t(8,14), t(8,22) Molecu lar HyperdiploidyNOTCH 1HOX Hypodiploidy
subject: Medicine

question_text:
A 3-year-old boy with Down's syndrome was brought with recurrent infections and bruising over his legs. Further workup was diagnostic of acute lymphoblastic leukemia and he was started on chemotherapy. Which of the following must be added on to prevent metastases to the central nervous system?
L-Asparginase
explanation: Intrathecal methotrexate is used for CNS prophylaxis in acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). It is essential in this condition as nearly 1/3 of patients develop CNS involvement at relapse without prophylactic therapy. The treatment of ALL is as follows: Induction (4 weeks): L-Asparaginase: Single-dose Side effects - pancreatitis, thrombosis Vincristine: Weekly Side effects - neuropathy, SIADH Prednisolone Consolidation: Intrathecal methotrexate Maintenance (24-36 months): 6-Mercaptopurine Methotrexate Plasma Cell Disorders
subject: Medicine

question_text: What is the most common symptom seen in patients with multiple myeloma?
explanation: Bone pain is the most common symptom in multiple myeloma. Multiple myeloma is a plasma cell malignancy in which there is an increased proliferation of monoclonal plasma cells. There is an increased production of monoclonal paraprotein (M protein). Clinical features of multiple myeloma: Bone pain (most common): Due to proliferation of tumor cells, activation of osteoclasts that destroy bone, and suppression f osteoblasts that form new bone. Persistent localized pain in a patient with myeloma usually signifies a pathological fracture. Fever due to recurrent bacterial infections (second most common) Acute kidney injury due to: Hypercalcemia (most common) Amyloid deposits Hyperuricemia Recurrent infections Infiltration of the kidney by myeloma cells Normocytic-normochromic anemia due to: Replacement of normal marrow by expanding tumor cells Inhibition of hematopoiesis by factors made by the tumor Reduced production of erythropoietin by the kidney Myeloma defining events (MDE) include the presence of one or more features such as hypercalcemia, renal failure, anemia and lytic bone lesions.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is true about multiple myeloma?
options: Increased monoclonal IgG1 causes hyperviscosity syndrome
Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance mostly progresses to multiple myeloma
Radioisotope bone scanning can be used for diagnosis
explanation: There is decreased anion gap in multiple myeloma due to the M protein. Anion gap in the serum is calculated as Na■ – (Cl– +HCO3–). The M protein is cationic, resulting in the retention of chloride causing decreased anion gap. Only 1% of patients with monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS) go on to develop multiple myeloma. Hyperviscosity symptoms in multiple myeloma occurs due to excessive production of M proteins, usually of IgG3 or IgA subtype. Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia (IgM myeloma) is the most common cause for hyperviscosity syndrome due to excess IgM paraprotein in these cases. Radioisotopic bone scanning is less useful in diagnosis because the bone lesions are lytic in nature and are rarely associated with osteoblastic new bone formation.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 72-year-old man presented with complaints of fatiguability and chronic lower back pain. Laboratory findings are as follows. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: In this scenario, the patient has increased M protein (>30g/l), bone marrow clonal plasma cells >10%, and evidence of end-organ damage (fatiguability and back pain). The most likely diagnosis is multiple myeloma. Diagnostic criteria for plasma cell disorders: Note: Solitary plasmacytoma of bone has only a single area of bone destruction due to clonal plasma cells, no M protein, bone marrow appears normal, and no end-organ damage. Plasma cell leukemia is an aggressive plasma cell proliferative disorder with >20% abnormal plasma cells in the peripheral blood. Criteria Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significa nce (MGUS) Smoldering multiple myel oma (asymptomatic myelo ma) Multiple mye loma Non-secretory my eloma M protein (>30g/l) No Yes Yes No Bone marrow plasma cells (>10%) No Yes Yes Yes End organ damage(CRAB) S.Calcium >11 mg/dlRenal, S. Creatinine >2 mg/dlAn emia, Hemoglobin <10g/d lLyticbone lesions No No Yes Yes
subject: Medicine

question_text: What is the most common cause of renal failure in patients with multiple myeloma?
explanation: Hypercalcemia is the most common cause of renal failure in multiple myeloma. The second most common cause of renal failure in multiple myeloma is light chain cast nephropathy. The most common type of myeloma causing renal failure is light chain myeloma. Mechanisms involved in acute kidney injury are: Hypercalcemia Amyloid deposits Hyperuricemia Recurrent infections Infiltration of the kidney by myeloma cells Tubular damage by excretion of light chains (Fanconi's syndrome)
subject: Medicine

question_text: A patient was brought to the hospital with dehydration and generalised weakness. He was diagnosed with multiple myeloma 2 years ago. Investigations revealed metabolic acidosis and hypokalemia. Urine analysis showed a pH of 5.1, glycosuria, and proteinuria. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: In this patient with hypokalemia and urine pH of 5.1, type 2 renal tubular acidosis (adult Fanconi’s syndrome) is the likely diagnosis. It is commonly associated with multiple myeloma. Normally, light chains are filtered, reabsorbed in the proximal tubules, and catabolized. In multiple myeloma, there is an increased amount of light chains and the tubular cells are overloaded. This leads to proximal tubular damage either directly from light chain toxic effects or indirectly from the release of intracellular lysosomal enzymes. Clinical features of renal tubular acidosis type 2: Metabolic acidosis Urine pH <5.3 Proteinuria (only light chains) Glycosuria Aminoaciduria Alport's syndrome is characterised by hematuria, hearing loss and eye abnormalities.
subject: Medicine

question_text: What is the immunophenotype of tumor cells in multiple myeloma?
explanation: The immunophenotype of tumor cells in multiple myeloma is CD38 and CD138. Multiple myeloma is derived from plasma cells in which B cell markers (CD19, CD20) are lost. Immunophenotype of tumor cells in lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma / Waldenstrom's macroglobulinemia is CD19, CD20, surface IgM+, CD38. A lymphoplasmacytic cell retains B cell markers and carries plasma cell markers.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 45-year-old patient presented with multiple fractures and bone pain. Serum electrophoresis revealed elevated serum M protein. What does it most likely to constitute?
explanation: In the above clinical scenario, the patient most likely has multiple myeloma as there are pathological fractures and elevated M protein. Serum M protein is likely to constitute IgG. The serum M component is IgG in 53% of patients, IgA in 25%, and IgD in 1%. Serum IgM is elevated in Waldenstrom's macroglobulinemia (lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma).
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 60-year-old man presented with fatigue and back pain since 3 months. Investigations were done and are as follows. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: In the given clinical scenario, the patient has normal SPEP and clonal plasmacytosis. The most likely diagnosis is non-secretory myeloma. Non-secretory myeloma is characterised by the absence of M protein in the serum or urine. Bone marrow clonal plasmacytosis > 10% and myeloma defining symptoms. Option A: In multiple myeloma, SPEP demonstrates a sharp peak (church spire or M band) in the gamma globulin region, as shown below. Option B: Lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma (Waldenstrom's macroglobulinemia) also demonstrates a localized peak (M band) in the gamma globulin region. Immunofixation is required to identify the type of immunoglobulin. Option C: Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS) does not present with myeloma-defining symptoms. Clonal bone marrow cells will be less than 10%
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 69-year-old business tycoon is diagnosed with multiple myeloma. He is worried about his business empire and asks you how long he will survive. Which of the following is the best predictor for this?
explanation: Serum 2-microglobulin levels are the best modality to predict the median survival period. Albumin levels alone cannot be used to predict the median survival period. It is used in combination with 2-microglobulin for risk stratification. Patients with 2-microglobulin levels <3.5 mg/L and albumin levels > 3.5 g/dl have a median survival period of 5 years. Those with levels >3.5 mg/L and albumin < 3.5 g/dl have a survival period of fewer than 2 years. Durie-Salmon staging is unable to predict outcomes with newer agents. Hence it is no longer used. Factors associated with poor prognosis: Plasma cell labeling index Chromosomal aberrations Circulating plasma cells Performance status Highly elevated LDH Extramedullary disease De novo plasma cell leukemia
subject: Medicine

question_text: In patients with multiple myeloma, the presence of which of the following is associated with a poor prognosis?
explanation: 17p deletion is associated with a poor prognosis in multiple myeloma. Chromosomal abnormalities in multiple myeloma are classified as follows: Standard risk (6-7 years survival): t(11;14) (most common) t(6;14) 13q deletion High risk (2-3 years survival): 17p deletion t(4;14) t(14;16) t(14;20)
subject: Medicine

question_text: An X-ray skull of a patient with marked hypercalcemia is shown below. Which of the following laboratory parameters is consistent with his diagnosis?
options: High alkaline phosphatase and normal ESR
High alkaline phosphatase and elevated ESR
Normal alkaline phosphatase and normal ESR
Normal alkaline phosphatase and elevated ESR
explanation: In the above clinical scenario, hypercalcemia along with the skull demonstrating typical 'punched out' lesions is characteristic of multiple myeloma. Normal alkaline phosphatase and elevated ESR are consistent with multiple myeloma. Multiple myeloma is a malignant plasma cell dyscrasia with the proliferation of plasma cells derived from a single clone. It is associated with an increased osteoclast activity with suppression of osteoblast activity, causing punched-out lytic lesions in the bone and hypercalcemia. Signs and symptoms: Bone pain is the most common symptom Pathologic fractures Recurrent bacterial infections Renal failure Normocytic normochromic anemia, elevated ESR, hypercalcemia, normal ALP (ALP is a marker f bone growth and hence is not increased in multiple myeloma) Radiography: Punched-out lytic lesions on X-ray. The lesions are purely osteolytic with little or no osteoblastic activity. Hence alkaline phosphatase (ALP) is normal. The most common site of lytic lesion in multiple myeloma is the vertebral column. Electrophoresis: M spikes Urinalysis: Bence Jones proteinuria Bone marrow biopsy: Plasma cells
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 68-year-old male patient presented with multiple fractures. He has been suffering from recurrent infections for the past 6 months. Bone marrow biopsy showed the following. What is the treatment of choice in this condition?
explanation: In the above clinical scenario, the symptoms and bone marrow biopsy are characteristic of multiple myeloma. Lenalidomide + bortezomib + dexamethasone is the treatment of choice in this condition. This combination achieves close to a 100% response. Hence it is one of the preferred induction regimens in transplant-eligible multiple myeloma patients. Other pharmacological agents are used as second-line and have a 90% response rate. Chemotherapy followed by autologous stem cell transplantation prolongs overall survival. The image below shows a bone marrow biopsy with an increased number of plasma cells.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is a proteasome inhibitor?
explanation: Bortezomib is a proteasome inhibitor. It has a rapid response and is effective in poor-prognosis myeloma. Side effects include neuropathy (both peripheral and autonomic). Subcutaneous and weekly administration can reduce neuropathic side effects. Other proteasome inhibitors include carfilzomib (second-generation) and ixazomib, an oral proteasome inhibitor, used in relapsed disease. Option A: Lenalidomide is an immunomodulatory analogue of thalidomide. Option B: Rituximab is an anti-CD-20 monoclonal antibody. Option C: Cyclophosphamide is an alkylating chemotherapeutic agent.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 64-year-old male patient is admitted with complaints of weakness of the extremities, blurry vision, and nose-bleeds. On examination, there is lymphadenopathy and dilatation of the retinal veins. Peripheral smear is given below. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?
explanation: In the above clinical scenario, the hyperviscosity symptoms and rouleaux formation on peripherals smear point to a diagnosis of Waldenstrom's macroglobulinemia. It does not cause lytic bone lesions. Waldenstrom's macroglöbulinemia is a B-cell malignancy affecting lymphoplasmacytoid and plasma cells. It is characterized by high levels of circulating IgM antibodies. Clinical features include: Hyperviscosity symptoms Recurrent infections Epistaxis Visual disturbances Peripheral neuropathy - due to myelin-associated glycoprotein causing demyelination. Lymphadenopathy Hepatosplenomegaly Ophthalmoscopic examination may reveal vascular segmentation and dilation of the retinal veins. Investigations: Bone marrow shows >10% infiltration with lymphoplasmacytic cells Serum M component is >30 g/L (3 g/dL). The size of the IgM paraprotein results in little renal excretion, and only 20% of patients excrete light chains. The image below shows rouleaux formation.
subject: Medicine

question_text:
A 19-year-old boy presented with progressive shortness of breath, and easy fatiguability for 3 years. His older brother died of cardiac arrest during a football match a few years ago.
Further evaluation revealed hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Biopsy and staining of subcutaneous fat showed the following. What mutation is likely in this patient?
explanation: The biopsy showing amyloid deposits stained by congo red, along with family history points to a diagnosis of familial amyloidosis (AF). It is most commonly due to the mutation of the transthyretin gene (TTR). Amyloidosis is a group of protein misfolding disorders characterized by the accumulation of abnormal proteins called amyloid fibrils in various organs.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 60-year-old man presented with progressive weight loss, generalized edema. On evaluation, he had nephrotic range proteinuria, macroglossia, and raccoon eyes. What is the most probable diagnosis?
explanation: The patient has non-specific symptoms, which along with macroglossia and raccoon eyes are suggestive of amyloidosis. Clinical features include: Fatigue Weight loss Nephrotic range proteinuria due to renal amyloidosis and is associated with hypoalbuminemia Cutaneous ecchymoses around the eyes are called the 'raccoon-eye' sign. Due to easy bruising as a result of amyloid deposits or deficiency of clotting factor X.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is the most commonly involved organ in amyloidosis?
explanation: The kidneys are the most frequently involved organ in amyloidosis and are affected in 70–80% of patients. The heart is the second most commonly affected organ (50–60% of patients). The spleen is frequently involved, and there may be functional hyposplenism in the absence of significant splenomegaly. Liver involvement causes cholestasis. Macroglossia, a pathognomonic sign of AL amyloidosis is seen in only 10% of patients.
subject: Medicine

question_text:
What is the leading cause of death in patients with primary amyloidosis?
Renal failure
explanation: Cardiac disease is the leading cause of death from primary amyloidosis. Chronic Myeloid Leukemia and Chronic Lymphoid Leukemia
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following patients are at risk of developing chronic myeloid leukemia?
options: A middle-aged man whose mother died of chronic myeloid leukemia
An oil-refinery worker with occupational benzene exposure for 20 years
A woman who underwent radiotherapy for carcinoma cervix
An elderly man who received chemotherapy for Hodgkin's lymphoma
explanation: Exposure to a high dose of ionizing radiation is the only known risk factor for developing chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). This may be in the form of radiation therapy for malignancy or other conditions and nuclear accidents. It is dose-dependent and low-dose radiation exposure is not a risk factor. There are no familial associations, infections, or toxins associated with the development of CML.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is true about the Philadelphia chromosome?
options: Unbalanced translocation between short arm of chromosomes 9 and 22
Unbalanced translocation between long arm of chromosomes 9 and 22
Balanced translocation between short arm of chromosomes 9 and 22
Balanced translocation between long arm of chromosomes 9 and 22
explanation: Philadelphia chromosome is a balanced translocation between the long arm of chromosomes 9 and 22. It is present in the majority of patients with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). In a balanced translocation, a part of one chromosome is shifted to another chromosome and vice versa. In this case, the ABL gene present in chromosome 9 is translocated next to the BCR gene (breakpoint cluster region) on chromosome 22. It leads to the formation of shortened chromosome 22, which has been named the Philadelphia chromosome after the place of discovery.
subject: Medicine

question_text: What is the most common sign in patients with chronic myeloid leukemia?
explanation: Splenomegaly is the most common physical examination finding in patients with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). The majority of the patients with CML are asymptomatic. They are often incidentally diagnosed during routine blood tests when they have elevated white blood cells count. In later stages, the following clinical features develop: Anemia - easy fatigability, exercise intolerance Increased number of WBCs and platelets - hyperviscosity, leading to MI and stroke Increased cell metabolism - night sweats, weight loss, and hyperuricemia (gout) Splenomegaly - abdominal pain, early satiety Hepatomegaly, lymphadenopathy, skin or subcutaneous lesions
subject: Medicine

question_text: Leukocyte alkaline phosphatase score is decreased in patients with all of the following except:
explanation: Leukocyte alkaline phosphatase (LAP) score is increased in polycythemia vera and leukemoid reactions. The biochemical abnormalities in CML include: Low LAP score High levels of: Vitamin B12 Uric acid Lactic dehydrogenase Lysozyme Note: Leukemoid reaction refers to extreme elevations in WBC > 50,000/mm3 due to reactive causes outside the marrow. This includes severe infection, trauma, Down's syndrome.
subject: Medicine

question_text: In patients with chronic myeloid leukemia, which of the following are predominantly elevated in the peripheral smear?
explanation: Myelocytes will be predominantly elevated in the peripheral smear of the patients with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). The clinical hallmark of CML is the uncontrolled production of mature and maturing granulocytes. All of the stages of development of granulocytes can be noted on the peripheral smear in varying numbers: Myeloblast - large cells with a round or oval nucleus, cytoplasm is dark and has no granules Myelocyte - nucleus is oval and is eccentrically placed. Metamyelocyte - nucleus is like a kidney bean-shaped Band forms - nucleus is in the shape of C or U. Segmented neutrophils- nucleus has 2-5 lobes. All the cells except the myeloblast have a granular cytoplasm. Due to the varied appearance of the cells, it is called garden party appearance or college girl's appearance.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 55-year-old man is found to have the following findings on a routine CBC. A subsequent peripheral smear is performed as shown below. A bone marrow aspiration study is planned for this patient. All of the following are likely to be seen on bone marrow except:
explanation: The image shows a left-shift with a predominance of segmented neutrophils, myelocytes, metamyelocytes that is suggestive of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). Marrow blasts are usually < 5% in the majority of CML patients. In CML, the following bone marrow findings are noted: Markedly hypercellularity - due to increased granulocytic precursors Myeloid: erythroid ratio (M/E ratio) is significantly increased Megakaryocytes - normal or increased Erythroid precursors - usually decreased Sea blue histiocytes - macrophages with abundant wrinkled, green-blue cytoplasm. Bone marrow fibrosis may occur due to the deposition of reticulin. Pseudo-Gaucher cells - macrophages with wrinkled tissue paper appearance, as shown below. Due to the increased turnover of the cells, there is an increased accumulation of glucocerebroside within the macrophages.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 48-year-old man presents to the clinic with easy fatiguability and weight loss. After a detailed workup, he is diagnosed with chronic myeloid leukemia. What is the initial treatment of choice?
explanation: The initial treatment of choice in patients with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) is tyrosine kinase inhibitors. These include imatinib, nilotinib, dasatinib, bosutinib, and ponatinib. Allogeneic stem cell transplant is considered in patients who are negative for Philadelphia chromosome, or who are non-responsive to the tyrosine kinase inhibitors.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 61-year-old with CML failed to respond to imatinib therapy. Further evaluation revealed a T315I mutation. What drug should he be started on?
explanation: Ponatinib is effective in patients with CML with T315I mutations. It is a third-generation tyrosine kinase inhibitor. The T315I mutation in BCR-ABL clones is specifically resistant to therapy with imatinib, dasatinib, nilotinib, and bosutinib but is sensitive to the third-generation agent ponatinib. It is also used in the treatment of accelerated and blast phases.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following can be used to assess the prognosis in patients with chronic myeloid leukemia?
explanation: Hasford scoring system can be used to assess prognosis in patients with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). The prognosis of CML can be assessed by: Sokal score which is based on: Age Spleen size Platelet count Percentage of blast cells in the blood Hasford score - Similar to Sokal score, but additionally uses the percentage of eosinophils and basophils in the blood Option A: Rai and Binet staging system is used for staging chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL). Option B: Ann Arbor staging system is used in Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas. Option D: Matutes scoring system is used for the diagnosis of CLL by flow cytometry.
subject: Medicine

question_text: All of the following patients with chronic myeloid leukemia are in the accelerated phase except:
explanation: A blast count  20% in peripheral blood is indicative of a blast crisis, not the accelerated phase of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). CML can be divided into three phases: Chronic stable phase - Blasts < 10% in peripheral blood and bone marrow Accelerated phase - any of the following: Blasts comprising 10-19% of white blood cells (WBCs) in peripheral blood and/or bone marrow Peripheral blood basophils 20% Thrombocytopenia or thrombocytosis not responsive to therapy Additional cytogenetic abnormalities in Philadelphia chromosome cells Blast crisis: Blasts  20% of peripheral blood WBCs or bone marrow Extramedullary blast proliferation Majority of the patients present in the chronic stable phase. Without effective treatment, CML in the chronic phase will eventually move into an accelerated phase at first and then into the blast phase.
subject: Medicine

question_text: What is the classical immunophenotypic picture seen in patients with chronic lymphocytic leukemia?
explanation: The classical immunophenotypic feature seen in patients with chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) is CD19+, CD20+, CD21+,CD22+, CD23+, CD5+. It is significant for coexpression of the B cell marker CD19 with the T cell marker CD5. Mantle cell lymphoma has the same immunophenotype but with absent CD23. question_text: A 68-year-old man with fever is found to have a WBC count of 1,50,000/cu.mm. His peripheral smear study is given below. Which of the following is true about this condition?
options: It arises from the myeloid lineage
Radiation exposure is a risk factor
It arises from the T lymphocytes
Patient may have autoimmune hemolytic anemia
explanation: The smear shows small round lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm and the presence of a smudge cell. The most probable diagnosis is chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL). Patients with CLL may have autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA). Chronic lymphocytic leukemia/ small lymphocytic lymphoma refers to the monoclonal proliferation of mature B lymphocytes. It is more common in men than women. Increasing age and family history are important risk factors. CLL is one of the few leukemias not linked to radiation exposure. The majority of the patients are asymptomatic and are diagnosed during routine blood tests. Some patients may have painless lymphadenopathy and splenomegaly. Increased B cells may produce autoantibodies leading to autoimmune complications like autoimmune hemolytic anemia and immune thrombocytopenia (ITP).
subject: Medicine

question_text: What is the treatment of choice for a 71-year-old asymptomatic woman diagnosed with chronic lymphocytic leukemia?
explanation: Expectant management is the treatment of choice for asymptomatic patients with chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL). This is because there is no clear survival benefit with chemotherapy in asymptomatic patients. Chemotherapy and monoclonal antibodies are used in the presence of the following features: Progressive marrow failure - worsening anemia, thrombocytopenia Progressive splenomegaly Progressive lymphadenopathy Presence of constitutional symptoms like weight loss, fever, night sweats Important drugs used in the management of CLL are fludarabine, cyclophosphamide, bendamustine, and rituximab.
subject: Medicine

question_text:
Which of the following is true about Richter syndrome?
Lymphadenopathy is absent
explanation: Richter's syndrome is the transformation of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) to aggressive lymphoma, most commonly diffuse large B cell lymphoma (DLBCL). It has a poor prognosis. Patients develop the following features: Fever, and weight loss Rapidly enlarging lymph nodes Elevated serum lactate dehydrogenase Lymphomas
subject: Medicine

question_text: What is the most common non-Hodgkin lymphoma in India?
explanation: Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) is the most common form of non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) in adults and children over the age of 15 years, worldwide, and in India. Burkitt's lymphoma is the most common NHL in children under the age of 15 years.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is not caused by the Epstein-Barr virus?
options: Primary diffuse large B cell lymphoma of the CNS
explanation: Human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8) is the etiological factor for primary effusion lymphoma, not Epstein-Barr virus. Lymphoid malignancies associated with Epstein-Barr virus include: Burkitt's lymphoma Post-organ transplant lymphoma Primary diffuse large B cell lymphoma of the CNS Hodgkin's disease Extranodal NK/T cell lymphoma, nasal type Primary effusion lymphoma is a variant of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma that presents with pleural effusions, usually without apparent tumor mass lesions. It is most common in the setting of immune deficiency disease, especially AIDS.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following types of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma and its corresponding grade are correctly matched?
options: Diffuse large B cell lymphoma - Low grade
explanation: Burkitt lymphoma is a fast-growing, high-grade type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL). NHL was earlier classified on the basis of its morphology and clinical behaviour. However, this classification is not currently used. Based on the clinical behavior, NHL is classified as: Low grade - CLL/SLL (small lymphocytic lymphoma), follicular lymphoma Intermediate grade - mantle cell and marginal cell lymphoma High grade - diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL), Burkitt's lymphoma The most aggressive NHL is DLBCL, whereas the most rapidly progressive tumor is Burkitt's lymphoma. Most pediatric NHLs are high-grade and aggressive.
subject: Medicine

question_text: What is the most common extranodal site of involvement in patients with non-Hodgkin's lymphoma?
explanation: The gastrointestinal tract is the most common extranodal site in patients with non-Hodgkin's lymphoma (NHL). The stomach is most commonly involved, followed by the small intestine. The skin is the second-most common site. Mycosis fungoides is a mature T-cell (CD4+) NHL with skin involvement with eventual visceral and nodal spread. When malignant T-cells in the skin enter circulation, it is called Sezary syndrome. It presents as erythroderma (diffuse erythema and scaling). Histologically, there are Sézary-Lutzner cells (with cerebriform nuclei) and Pautrier microabscesses in epidermis. CNS is the most common extranodal site in patients with HIV infection. Primary CNS lymphoma (histologically, DLBCL) is one of the AIDS-defining malignancies.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is used to assess the prognosis in patients with non-Hodgkin's lymphoma?
explanation: The prognosis of patients with non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma is best assessed using the international Prognostic Index (IPI). It consists of 5 clinical risk factors for poor prognosis: Age >60 years Elevated levels of serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) Performance status  2 (ECOG) or 70 (Karnofsky) Ann Arbor stage III or IV >1 site of extranodal involvement Option A: Ann Arbor staging is used for anatomic staging to develop a treatment plan for Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. Option B: Rai and Binet score is used for staging of CLL. Option D: Hasford scoring is used to assess the prognosis of CML.
subject: Medicine

question_text:
A 63-year-old man presented with a 2-month history of fatigue, fever, and night sweats. On examination, generalized painless lymphadenopathy and splenomegaly were noted.
Investigations revealed the following. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The clinical scenario is suggestive of mantle cell lymphoma. It is diagnosed by its characteristic immunophenotype - CD19+, CD20+, CD21+, CD22+, CD23(-), CD 5+. Comparison between mantle cell lymphoma and chronic lymphocytic leukemia/small lymphocytic lymphoma (CLL/SLL): Mantle cell lympho ma CLL/ SLL CD5 P sitive P siti ve CD23 Negative P siti ve Cyclin D 1 P sitive Negat ive FMC7 P sitive Negat ive CD10, B CL6 Negative Negat ive
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is incorrectly matched?
explanation: Translocations seen in Burkitt's lymphoma are t (8;14), t (2;8) and t (8;22).
subject: Medicine

question_text:
A 59-year-old came to the OPD after noticing a swelling on her neck. On examination, painless lymphadenopathy was noted in the cervical, axillary and inguinal regions with no
hepatosplenomegaly. CBC was normal. Lymph node biopsy showed effacement of nodal architecture with centrocytes and centroblasts. Which of the following immunophenotypic panels will confirm this diagnosis?
options: CD 19, CD79a, CD 20, CD10, CD 23, Bcl-2
explanation: This clinical scenario and the presence of centrocytes and centroblasts on biopsy are suggestive of follicular lymphoma. Immunophenotyping will be positive for CD19, CD79a, CD20, CD10, CD23, Bcl-2. Follicular lymphoma presents at a median age of 59 years with no sex predilection. The patients most commonly develop painless generalized lymphadenopathy. Systemic symptoms are absent. A lymph node biopsy is usually adequate for the diagnosis of follicular lymphoma. Characteristic features following lymph node biopsy include: The normal nodal architecture is effaced by nodular expansions of tumour cells Centrocytes - small lymphocytes with cleaved nuclei Centroblasts - larger cells with vesicular chromatin and prominent nucleoli
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following statements is false about diffuse large B-cell lymphoma?
options: It is a high-grade aggressive lymphoma
It is commonly associated with BCL-6 chromosomal rearrangements
It is associated with CNS lymphoma and intravascular lymphoma
It does not present with extranodal involvement
explanation: Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) commonly (>50%) presents with extranodal involvement at diagnosis, with the most common sites being the GI tract and bone marrow. DLBCL is the most common non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. It is a high-grade aggressive tumour. It is associated with BCL-6 chromosomal rearrangements and t(14;18). It is commonly associated with CNS lymphoma, pleural effusion lymphoma, and intravascular lymphoma. It is considered an AIDS-defining malignancy. AIDS-defining malignancies include: Kaposi sarcoma Primary central nervous system lymphoma (DLBCL) Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma Invasive cervical cancer
subject: Medicine

question_text: A physician is in Africa, working with the Doctors Without Borders group. He encounters a 7-year-old boy with the following finding. His parents say that he had a jaw swelling for 2 months that failed to resolve with antibiotics. A biopsy of the swelling reveals a starry sky appearance. Which of the following statements is true about this patient's condition?
options: It is associated with n-myc dysregulation
Expectant management is the treatment of choice
It is associated with HIV infection
explanation: This clinical scenario is suggestive of the endemic type of Burkitt's lymphoma. In this condition, the tumor cells are CD21+. Burkitt's lymphoma is an aggressive condition and is the most common NHL in children. This condition is endemic in African countries and is associated with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection. It is associated with c-myc dysregulation, especially in cases in bone marrow involvement. Patients require aggressive management with high-dose chemotherapy.
subject: Medicine

question_text: The lymph node biopsy of a patient with lymphoma is given below. It shows two different cell populations labeled as A and B. Which of the following statements is false?
options: Cells labelled A will test positive for CD14, CD40, CD11b & CD64
The fraction of cells with positive Ki67 staining is 100%
Cells labelled B will test positive for CD19, CD10, BCL-6 & CD43
Cells labelled B represent the stars in starry sky appearance
explanation: The given image shows the characteristic starry sky appearance of Burkitt's lymphoma. The reactive macrophages (labelled as A) represent the stars in starry sky appearance. On the other hand, the homogenous tumour cells (labelled as B) represent the sky. The neoplastic cells are homogeneous, medium-sized B cells with a high growth fraction. These cells are positive for CD19, CD10, BCL-6 & CD43. Reactive macrophages are scattered throughout the tumour. Their pale cytoplasm in a background of blue-staining tumour cells gives the tumor a so-called starry sky appearance. Reactive leukocytes and macrophages are not stained by special stains. They are positive for CD14, CD40, CD11b & CD64. The growth fraction of these lymphomas is very high, with frequent mitotic figures. The fraction of Ki-67+ (MIB-1+) stained cells is nearly 100%.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Patients with which of the following conditions are at risk of developing salivary gland MALToma?
explanation: Sjogren's syndrome is implicated in salivary gland MALToma. MALT lymphomas are commonly associated with an underlying autoimmune or inflammatory process such as: Sjogren’s syndrome - salivary gland Hashimoto’s thyroiditis - thyroid Helicobacter pylori gastritis - gastric (most common) Celiac disease - small intestine The most common translocation associated with MALToma is (11,18). It has a good prognosis.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is not a T-cell lymphoma?
explanation: Hairy cell leukemia arises from a late, activated memory B cell exhibiting post-germinal center features. Mycosis fungoides and anaplastic large cell lymphoma (also called null cell lymphoma) are both T-cell lymphomas.
subject: Medicine

question_text: The peripheral smear of a patient who presented with generalized lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given peripheral smear shows tumor cells with multilobulated nuclei called cloverleaf or flower cells. This is characteristic of adult T-Cell leukemia/lymphoma. This condition occurs in adults infected by human T-cell leukemia retrovirus type 1 (HTLV-1). It is a rapidly progressive disease that is fatal within months to one year following diagnosis. It is characterized by the following clinical features: Skin lesions Generalized lymphadenopathy Hepatosplenomegaly Peripheral blood lymphocytosis, Hypercalcemia
subject: Medicine

question_text:
A 55-year-old man presented with fatigue and dragging sensation in the left upper abdomen. Physical examination revealed massive splenomegaly and no lymphadenopathy. CBC revealed
pancytopenia. Bone marrow aspirate yielded a dry tap. Immunohistochemical staining of the tumor cells tested positive for CD19, CD22, CD11c, CD25, CD103 and CD123. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: This clinical scenario is suggestive of hairy cell leukemia (HCL). In this condition, most patients present with symptoms related to cytopenias or splenomegaly. On bone marrow aspiration, a dry tap is obtained due to HCL-induced marrow fibrosis and the interlocking cell borders of hairy cells (distinct from myelofibrosis). Tumor cells share certain characteristics of memory B cells. CD11c, CD25, CD103, CD123 is the characteristic immunophenotype diagnostic of this condition. Pan-B markers such as CD19, CD20, and CD22 may also be positive. Note: Splenic marginal zone lymphoma involves both white and red pulp of the spleen, whereas hairy cell leukemia is limited to the red pulp. All non-Hodgkin's lymphomas involve white pulp of spleen except: Hairy cell leukemia Hepatosplenic lymphoma
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following best distinguishes hairy cell leukemia from other B cell malignancies?
options: Hairy cells on a Wright-stained peripheral blood smear
Annexin A1 on bone marrow specimens
Intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies called ribosome-lamellar complexes
explanation: Annexin A1 on immunophenotyping of bone marrow specimens is the best method to differentiate hairy cell leukemia from other B-cell malignancies. It has 100% sensitivity and specificity. Hairy cells on Wright-stained peripheral blood smear are an important diagnostic finding. Typical hairy cells are mononuclear cells with abundant pale blue-grey agranular cytoplasm with elongated (hairy) projections. Intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies called ribosome-lamellar complexes can also be seen in 50% of cases. However, these can be seen in other B-cell disorders also. Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP) stain is an important tool and is positive in 95% of cases of hairy cell leukemia. However, it is not pathognomonic. The following pattern of bone marrow involvement is near to pathognomonic for hairy cell leukemia (>99%): Diffuse infiltration of tumor cells with honeycomb appearance. Individual cells have a fried egg appearance such that the nucleus of each hairy cell is surrounded by a halo of cytoplasm, as shown below.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Patients with hairy-cell leukemia are at a higher risk of infection with which of the following?
explanation: Hairy cell leukemia is associated with infections of Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare. This is possibly related to frequent unexplained monocytopenia. Among them, infection with Mycobacterium kansasii is common.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 45-year-old man presented with progressive fatigue and weight loss for 3 months. CBC showed pancytopenia. On peripheral smear, the following cells were seen, which also showed positive staining with TRAP. What is the drug of choice for this patient?
explanation: The given image shows mononuclear cells with abundant pale blue-grey agranular cytoplasm with elongated (hairy) projections, which are TRAP-positive. This clinical scenario is suggestive of hairy cell leukemia. The drug of choice is cladribine. Hairy cell leukemia is responsive to chemotherapy with interferon , pentostatin, and cladribine. However, cladribine is the preferred drug of choice due to complete remission in the majority of patients, and higher rates of long-term disease-free survival. It is administered daily for 7 days by continuous intravenous infusion. Chemotherapy-refractory patients have responded to vemurafenib, a BRAF inhibitor. Splenectomy is often associated with prolonged remission.
subject: Medicine

question_text: What subtype of Hodgkin's lymphoma is most commonly seen in India?
explanation: The most common subtype of Hodgkin's lymphoma in India is the mixed cellularity classical Hodgkin's lymphoma. In contrast, nodular sclerosis is most commonly seen in western countries. The most common subtype of Hodgkin's lymphoma in: Developed/ western countries - nodular sclerosing Children - mixed cellularity Females - nodular sclerosis (but Hodgkin's lymphoma is more common in males overall) HIV-associated - mixed cellularity EBV-associated - lymphocyte-depleted
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is not a classical form of Hodgkin lymphoma?
explanation: Nodular lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin's lymphoma (HL) is a distinct clinicopathological entity from classical Hodgkin lymphoma as per the WHO classification. The following image shows the Reed-Sternberg cell in classic HL. question_text: What is the most commonly observed clinical presentation in patients with Hodgkin's lymphoma?
explanation: Supraclavicular or cervical lymphadenopathy is the most common clinical presentation of Hodgkin's lymphoma. The clinical features of Hodgkin's lymphoma are as follows: Asymptomatic lymphadenopathy (non-tender with a rubbery consistency) is the most common presentation. Most common - cervical or supraclavicular Second-most common presentation - mediastinal mass Hepatosplenomegaly in some cases Pel-Ebstein fever: Refers to recurrent febrile and afebrile intervals, each phase lasting for days to weeks More common in older patients with mixed-cellularity Hodgkin’s lymphoma in an abdominal site Alcohol-induced pain is a rare, unusual presentation
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 29-year-old man with a 3-week history of fever is found to have multiple rubbery, enlarged lymph nodes. A biopsy reveals abnormal cells with bilobed nuclei that are positive for CD15 and CD30. Which of the following is associated with this man's condition?
explanation: This clinical scenario is suggestive of Hodgkin's lymphoma. The paraneoplastic syndrome associated with this condition is subacute cerebellar degeneration. Other paraneoplastic syndromes associated with Hodgkin's lymphoma include: Minimal change disease (nephrotic syndrome) Vanishing bile duct syndrome Cholangitis Alcohol-induced pain - pain typically occurs within a few minutes after the ingestion of even a small amount of alcohol and is localized to areas involved by HL Option A: Syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion is associated with small cell lung carcinoma of the lungs. Option B: Lambert-Eaton syndrome is associated with small cell lung carcinoma of the lungs. Option D: Migratory superficial thrombophlebitis (Trousseau syndrome) is associated with adenocarcinoma of the pancreas and lungs.
subject: Medicine

question_text: The lymph node biopsy of a 49-year-old woman with painless lymphadenopathy revealed the following finding. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given image shows a lacunar Reed-Sternberg (RS) cell. It is identified by a folded or multilobed nucleus surrounded by an open space, which is an artifact created by disruption of the cytoplasm during tissue sectioning. It is seen in nodular sclerosis classical Hodgkin's disease (CHL). The histological subtypes of classical Hodgkin's disease are as follows: Subtype Histopathology Clinical correlation Nodular sclerosis Lacunar RS cellNecrosis with inflammatory infiltrate (eosi nophils, macrophages, plasm a cells)Fibrous bands dividin g cellular areas into nodules Mediastinal lymphadenopath y and superior vena cava syn dromeExcellent prognosis Mixed cellularity RS cells with rich inflammato ry infiltrate Biphasic: Children and elderl yB symptomsAssociated with EBV (and HIV)Very good pr ognosis Lymphocyte-rich Background infiltrate richin T-cells - Lymphocyte- deplet ed Reticular variant, paucity of background reactive cells Associated with HIV (and EB V)Poor prognosis
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following statements is true about Hodgkin's lymphoma?
options: Reed-Sternberg cell is specific for Hodgkin's disease
Classical Hodgkin's lymphoma is associated with CD20 positive cells
Central nervous system is the most common site of extranodal disease
PET-CT is the most reliable technique for staging Hodgkin's lymphoma
explanation: PET-CT is the most reliable technique for staging Hodgkin's lymphoma. Reed-Sternberg cells on histology, point to a clinical diagnosis of Hodgkin's lymphoma. However, they are not specific for Hodgkin's lymphoma. Reed-Sternberg cells can also be seen in the following conditions: Infectious mononucleosis Solid tissue cancers Large cell non-Hodgkin's lymphomas (most common in immunoblastic type) Classical Hodgkin's lymphoma is associated with positive test results for CD15 and CD30. Nodular lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin's lymphoma is associated with CD20 positive cells. The central nervous system (CNS) is an uncommon site of extranodal disease in Hodgkin's lymphoma. Lung, liver, bone, and bone marrow are the most common extranodal sites for the disease.

question_text: A 49-year-old man is diagnosed with stage IIIB Hodgkin's lymphoma. Lab investigations reveal a hemoglobin of 10.8 g/dl, WBC count of 14,000/ µL, and an absolute lymphocyte count of 450/ µL. Which of the following are poor prognostic factors in this patient?
explanation: In this patient with advanced-stage Hodgkin's lymphoma, his age, gender, and absolute lymphocyte count all indicate poor prognosis. Unfavourable or poor prognostic factors for advanced-stage HL (stages III and IV) include: Age > 45 years Male gender Haemoglobin (Hb) < 10.5 g/dL Serum albumin <4 g/dL White blood cell (WBC) count 15,000/ µL Absolute lymphocyte count (ALC) < 600/ µL Unfavourable or poor prognostic factors for early Hodgkin's lymphoma (stages I and II) include: Large mediastinal lymphadenopathy Involvement of 4 or more sites Age >45 ESR > 30 mm/hr B symptoms - unexplained fever, night sweats or unexplained weight loss The selection of initial treatment for Hodgkin's lymphoma is usually based on presenting stage and prognostic factors.

question_text: A 48-year-old man with fever, night sweats, and weight loss is diagnosed with stage IIB Hodgkin's lymphoma. What is the treatment of choice for this patient?
explanation: The patient's age (> 45 years) and presence of B symptoms indicate an unfavourable prognosis. The treatment of choice in early-stage Hodgkin's lymphoma (stage I and II) with an unfavourable prognosis is ABVD regimen along with field radiation. ABVD is a combination of doxorubicin (adriamycin), bleomycin, vinblastine, and dacarbazine. It is composed of rituximab + cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin, vincristine (oncovin) and prednisone.

question_text: The most common bleeding manifestation seen in severe hemophilia is:
explanation: Recurrent hemarthrosis is the most common bleeding manifestation of severe hemophilia. Hemophilia is said to be severe when the residual activity of factor VIII is <1%. H mophilia is an X-linked recessive hemorrhagic disorder and is caused by mutations in either the F8 gene (hemophilia A or classic hemophilia) or the F9 gene (hemophilia B). Clinically, it is impossible to distinguish between hemophilia A and hemophilia B as they present with similar symptoms. It can be classified based on residual activity of FVIII or FIX as severe (<1%), moderate (1–5%), or mild (6–30% ) H mophilia presents early in life- bleeding after circumcision or when beginning to walk or crawl. Clinical features: Acute hemarthrosis: Local pain, swelling Erythema Muscle contractures due to fixed positioning. Chronic hemarthrosis: Synovial thickening Synovitis (due to intraarticular blood) The most common joint affected is the knee. One joint is affected more than the other. This is called the target joint. Muscle hematomas can lead to compartment syndromes. H maturia is common but self-limited. Life-threatening bleeds such as bleeding into oropharyngeal spaces, CNS, and retroperitoneum can occur. Treatment: Without treatment, severe hemophilia may limit life expectancy. Factor replacement for hemophilia has been the mainstay of therapy. FVIII dose (IU) = Target FVIII levels – FVIII baseline levels × body weight (kg) × 0.5 unit/kg . FIX dose (IU) = Target FIX levels – FIX baseline levels × body weight (kg) × 1 unit/kg The FVIII half-life of 8–12 h requires injections twice a day to maintain therapeutic levels, whereas the FIX half-life is longer, ~24 h so that once-a-day injection is sufficient.

question_text: A teenager with hemophilia A presented with multiple spontaneous bleeds. He has been receiving prophylactic factor VIII infusion on a regular basis. Investigations revealed low factor VIII levels and abnormal plasma mixing study. Which of the following can be used to confirm the diagnosis?
explanation: Bethesda assay is the best test for the confirmation of factor VIII inhibitors. The formation of inhibitor/ alloantibodies to FVIII or FIX is the major complication of hemophilia treatment. When this happens, patients do not respond to factor replacement at therapeutic doses. aPTT measurement is done on a mixed sample. It is used to determine the presence of factor VIII inhibitors. aPTT is estimated using a 1:1 mix of patient's plasma and normal plasma. It is interpreted as: In hemophilia, aPTT is corrected with a 1:1 mix. In patients with inhibitors, aPTT with 1:1 mix is abnormally prolonged (inhibitor neutralizes th normal factors). Bethesda assay is based on the same principle but is superior because it helps to quantify the type and specificity of the inhibitor. question_text: Which among the following is wrong about DIC?
explanation: In disseminated intravascular coagulopathy (DIC), fibrinogen levels are decreased due to increased bleeding. Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) is an acquired syndrome characterized by the widespread activation of blood clotting factors within blood vessels, resulting in a loss of clotting control. The primary mechanism of DIC involves the uncontrolled generation of thrombin through multiple pathways which leads to sustained coagulation activation, the formation of fibrin, and the consumption of clotting factors and platelets. Infections are the most frequent cause of DIC. Laboratory investigations in DIC: Decreased platelet count Prolonged PT/TT Prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) Decreased fibrinogen Elevated fibrin degradation products (D-dimers) Peripheral smear: microangiopathic hemolytic anemia in DIC with schistocytes (fragmented red blood cells) The treatment involves platelet transfusion when platelet counts are below 10,000-20,000/L. Replacement of fibrinogen and coagulation factors is with fresh frozen plasma (FFP) along with cryoprecipitate or fibrinogen concentrate. In cases of low-grade DIC associated with solid tumors or acute promyelocytic leukemia low doses of continuous-infusion heparin has been effective.

question_text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the emergency with petechiae, bruising, and abdominal distension. Examination revealed an abdominal mass. Investigations revealed schistocytes and thrombocytopenia. What is the most probable cause of the mass?
explanation: This patient presents with petechiae, and abdominal distension with schistocytes and thrombocytopenia. This in child most likely has Kasabach-Merritt syndrome (secondary DIC). His abdominal mass is likely to be a hepatic hemangioma. Kasabach-Merritt syndrome is a life-threatening complication that occurs in patients with giant hemangiomas. It is most commonly seen in infants. Clinical features: Enlarged abdomen Hepatomegaly or jaundic Petechiae, bruising, and frank bleeding Painful lesions Anemia It is characterized by profound thrombocytopenia and consumptive coagulopathy leading to a DIC-like picture. Other options: Option A: Neuroblastomas are tumors of the sympathetic ganglia and adrenal medulla that are derived from primordial neural crest cells. It is the most common extracranial solid tumor of childhood and the most frequently diagnosed tumor in infancy. Brain tumors are the most common solid tumors in childhood. They present as a flank mass that crosses the midline. Option B: Hepatoblastoma is the most common childhood liver tumor. Histologically it is composed of small polygonal embryonal cells forming trabeculae, acini, or papillary structures in the developing liver. Option C: Wilms tumor is the most common primary malignant renal tumor in children and is the second most common malignant abdominal tumor in children. The clinical presentation usually involves an asymptomatic unilateral abdominal mass, hypertension, abdominal pain, and gross painless hematuria. Constitutional symptoms of fever, anorexia, and weight loss can also be present at the time of diagnosis.

question_text: Patients with protein C deficiency are at an increased risk of developing all of the following except:

question_text: A patient presented with bleeding gums and skin discoloration. She was given heparin for DVT prophylaxis 5 days ago. Investigations showed thrombocytopenia. Which of the following is the most specific test to diagnose this condition?
explanation: Serotonin release assay is the most specific test for the diagnosis of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT). Serotonin release assay is performed by quantifying serotonin release. Platelets loaded with labeled serotonin are exposed to patient serum in the absence or presence of varying concentrations of heparin. If the patient serum contains the HIT antibody, heparin addition induces platelet activation and serotonin release. question_text: A patient on warfarin develops severe gastrointestinal bleeding. What is the treatment of choice?
explanation: Patients on warfarin who present with severe bleeding are treated with both IV infusion of vitamin K and fresh frozen plasma regardless of the INR. Warfarin is an oral anticoagulant that blocks the enzyme vitamin K epoxide reductase. This inhibits factors II, VII, IX, and X, proteins C and S. This can cause an initial procoagulant state. Since the anticoagulant action of warfarin takes 2-3 days, patients require concomitant treatment (bridging therapy) with a rapidly acting parenteral anticoagulant (heparin, LMWH or fondaparinux) for at least 5 days. Warfarin has a narrow therapeutic window, hence all patients on warfarin should have their INR determined every 3–4 weeks. The most common side effect of warfarin is bleeding. Severe or life-threatening bleed includes: Hematuria Gastrointestinal bleeding Intracranial hemorrhag Intramuscular or intra-abdominal bleed Management of supratherapeutic INR: INR Bleeding Management 3.5-1 No Hold warfarin until INR is th 0 erapeutic >10 No Oral vitamin K 2.5-5 mg INR Bleeding Management Any Serious or life-threatening 10 mg vitamin K slow IV infu sion + fresh frozen plasma/pr othrombin complex concentr ate
