question_text: A man presents to the flu clinic with complaints of fever and sore throat for the past 4 days. COVID-19 is suspected and a paper-based test kit as shown below is used for testing. Identify the test.
explanation: The paper-based Covid-19 test kit developed by CSIR and IGIB and approved by the Drugs Controller General of India (DCGI) is named FELUDA. FELUDA is an acronym for FNCAS9 Editor Linked Uniform Detection Assay. The name is inspired by a fictitious detective character in novels written by Satyajit Ray. FELUDA uses CRISPR-Cas9 technology (CRISPR = Clustered Regularly Interspaced Short Palindromic Repeats). The CRISPR technology uses a highly specific CAS9 protein to find and bind to the target Covid signature. This is then coupled with paper-strip chemistry to elicit a visual readout on a paper strip. It is a very affordable, sensitive (96%), and specific (98%) strip test which can detect viral genetic material within 45 minutes.
subject: Medicine

question_text: What is the name of the COVID-19 IgG antibody detection ELISA test kit developed by ICMR and NIV?
explanation: COVID Kavach ELISA is an indigenous ELISA test kit for COVID-19 antibody detection developed by ICMR Delhi and NIV Pune. It is reported to have a 98.7% sensitivity and 100% specificity and testing is possible even at the district level. As the ELISA kit has an inactivated virus, only minimal biosafety and biosecurity requirements as compared to the real-time RT-PCR test. IgG antibodies usually start appearing after two weeks of the onset of infection. Therefore, the IgG test is not useful for detecting acute infection. IgG based antibody tests are used in sero-surveillance of the population.
subject: Medicine

question_text: What is least likely to be seen in a patient suspected of COVID-19?
explanation: Lymphocytosis is least likely to be seen in a patient with COVID-19. On the contrary, lymphopenia is likely to be seen. Common laboratory abnormalities seen in COVID-19 are: Lymphopenia Mild thrombocytopenia Elevated aminotransaminase levels Elevated lactate dehydrogenase levels Elevated inflammatory markers - eg, ferritin, C-reactive protein, and erythrocyte sedimentation rat Markers of a hypercoagulable state - high fibrinogen, high D-dimer levels, increased fibrin degradation products, prolonged prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) The degree of these abnormalities tends to correlate with disease severity.
subject: Medicine

question_text: What is the most commonly seen pattern in chest CT of patients affected with COVID-19?
explanation: Ground glass opacity (GGO) is the most commonly seen pattern in chest CT of patients with COVID-19. Some of the typical features seen in the CT scans of COVID-19 patients include: Ground glass opacities Consolidation Air bronchograms Interlobular septal thickenings Visible intralobular lines (crazy-paving pattern) Reversed halo sign The image below shows an axial CT scan with multiple patchy areas of pure ground-glass opacities. GGO are hazy areas with slightly increased density in the lungs without obscuration of underlying bronchial and vascular margins. The image given below shows a CT scan with bilateral GGO in the lower lobe and an air bronchogram (arrow) in the left subpleural area. Air bronchograms appear like air-filled bronchi within a highly attenuated parenchymal background. These are dilated bronchi filled with mucus plugs and do not truly contain air. The image given below shows a CT scan with multiple consolidation areas and interlobular septal thickening (arrows) in both lungs. The pulmonary interstitial structures such as interlobular septa and intralobular lines can thicken and manifest as small linear opacities. The image given below shows a CT scan with crazy-paving pattern (circled area). It is defined as the presence of GGOs with superimposed interlobular septal thickening giving the appearance of irregular paving stones. The image given below shows a CT scan with multiple lesions with reversed halo sign (arrows). The reversed halo sign or atoll sign is the presence of a ring-like area of consolidation with a superimposed rounded GGO.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Increased concentrations of all of the following are poor prognostic markers in a COVID-19 patient except:
explanation: Glycosylated ferritin is decreased in severe COVID-19 illness and hence, it is not a poor prognostic marker. Interestingly, in contrast to ferritin which is actually elevated in individuals with COVID 19, the glycosylated ferritin is decreased. It is a potentially sensitive biomarker that can better discriminate severe COVID than ferritin alone. Increased levels of the following laboratory markers is associated with poorer outcomes: D-dimer C-reactive protein Lactate dehydrogenas Cardiac troponin Ferritin Creatinine phosphokinas
subject: Medicine

question_text:
Which inflammatory marker is of prognostic significance in COVID-19 patients?
IL-6
explanation: Elevated pro-inflammatory cytokines like interleukin-6 (IL-6) are associated with critical and fatal COVID-19. It is specifically useful in predicting prognosis of such patients. Increased levels of the following laboratory markers are associated with poorer outcomes: D-dimer C-reactive protein Lactate dehydrogenas Cardiac troponin Ferritin Creatinine phosphokinas Options B, C and D: Inflammatory markers associated with increased severity of COVID-19 are: PCT (procalcitonin test) ESR WBC LMR (lymphocyte/mean platelet volume ratio) HsCRP (high-sensitivity C-reactive protein) NLR (neutrophil to lymphocyte ratio) COVID 19 - Treatment
subject: Medicine

question_text: The airport authority sent a COVID-19 suspect patient to the designated district hospital for a consultation. He came positive on RT-PCR testing. As the duty doctor, you observe that he has mild symptoms that can be treated on an outpatient basis. What will be your recommendation?
options: Home isolation for 7 days from testing positive
Home quarantine for 10 days from testing positive
Home isolation for 10 days from testing positive
Home quarantine for 7 days from testing positive
explanation: The given scenario is a mild case of COVID-19 who can be recommended home isolation for a duration of 7 days from testing positive. Isolation is the separation and restriction of movements or activities of persons who are sick, to prevent the transmission of disease. Eligibility for home isolation: Clinically assigned as a mild or asymptomatic case Facility at their residence for self-isolation and for quarantining the family contacts Availability of a caregiver Must monitor his health regularly and inform his health status to the district surveillance officer The patient can end home isolation after 7 days from testing positive and no fever for 3 successive days. There is no need for testing after the home isolation period is over. The patient should seek medical help if he/she develops: Unresolved High-grade fever (more than 100° F for more than 3 days) Difficulty in breathing, Dip in oxygen saturation (SpO2  93% on room air at least 3 readings within 1 hour) or respiratory rate >24/ min Persistent pain/pressure in the ches Mental confusion or inability to arouse Severe fatigue and myalgia Quarantine separates and restricts the movement of people who were exposed to a contagious disease to see if they become sick.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A COVID-19 positive man is rushed to the casualty due to severe breathlessness. Examination findings are suggestive of pneumonia and his vitals are- PR: 90/min, BP: 134/88 mmHg, RR: 22/min and SpO2: 86%. What will you advise this patient?
explanation: The patient is suffering from severe COVID-19 and hence has to be admitted to ICU. The disease is said to be severe when there is RR>30/min, breathlessness OR SpO2<90% on room air.
subject: Medicine

question_text:
A man presents with fever and cough for 2 days. His wife recently tested positive for
COVID-19 and has been under home isolation. Examination findings are given below. What is not recommended in his management?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of moderate COVID-19 (SpO2 <94%, RR24). Awake proning should be avoided in patients with hemodynamic instability. Awake proning in moderate COVID disease is recommended for any patient with severe respiratory distress. It improves oxygenation by keeping the alveolar units open. Timely proning of patients with SpO2 < 94% can help reduce mortality. Steps for self-proning: 1 pillow below the neck 1 or 2 pillows below the chest through upper thighs 2 pillows below the shins Keep alternating between proning, laying on your right, sitting up, and laying on your left, in a lying position, ideally for not more than 30 minutes in each position with an upper limit of 2 hours. One may prone up to 16 hours a day, in multiple cycles, if tolerable. Avoid proning: Hemodynamic instability For 1 hour after meals DVT, cardiac conditions Fractures of spine, femur, or pelvis
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 42-year-old COVID-19 positive man under home isolation develops breathing difficulty. SpO2 is 86%. He is administered oxygen via a face mask with a reservoir bag with a flow rate of 10 L/min. After a trial of one hour, his SpO2 is 88%. What is the next step?
explanation: This patient has persistent hypoxia after an adequate trial of standard oxygen therapy and should be started on high-flow nasal cannula oxygen therapy. When respiratory distress and/or hypoxemia of the patient cannot be alleviated after receiving standard oxygen therapy, high–flow nasal cannula oxygen therapy (HFNO), or non–invasive ventilation can be considered. Compared to standard oxygen therapy, HFNO reduces the need for intubation. Patients on HFNO should be closely monitored, and endotracheal intubation should be done if the patient acutely deteriorates or does not improve after a short trial (about 1 hr). Contraindications to HFNO includes patients with: Hypercapnia (exacerbation of COPD) Hemodynamic instability Multi-organ failure Abnormal mental status Note: If an high flow nasal cannula (HFNC) or simple nasal cannula is used to administer O2, an N95 mask should be applied over it.
subject: Medicine

question_text: An 84-year-old man is being treated in the ICU for sepsis induced respiratory failure secondary to COVID-19. What is the maximum tidal volume setting permissible for his mechanical ventilation? (PBW-predicted body weight)
explanation: A maximum tidal volume of up to 8 ml/kg PBW is allowed in a patient with ARDS who is being mechanically ventilated. In patients with ARDS, mechanical ventilation should be implemented using lower tidal volumes (4–8 ml/kg PBW) and lower inspiratory pressures (plateau pressure <30 cmH2O). In patients with moderate or severe ARDS, a higher PEEP is suggested. PEEP titration requires consideration of benefits (improving alveolar recruitment) vs. risks (end-inspiratory over distension leading to lung injury). Lung protective ventilation strategy by ARDS net protocol recommendations: Parameters Values Tidal volume 6ml/kg RR 15-35/m in PEEP 5-15cm H2O Target plateau pressur e < 30cm H2O Target SpO2 88-95% Parameters Values Parameters Values Target PaO2 55-80m mHg
subject: Medicine

question_text: An elderly diabetic man with COVID-19 is desaturating on non-invasive ventilation. You intubate him and place him on a mechanical ventilator. He improves briefly but the SpO2 suddenly drops. You suspect a tubal block and perform closed suctioning. Despite this, he goes into cardiac arrest and you start CPR. You would not expect aerosol generation in:
explanation: Open suctioning of the respiratory tract is associated with significant amounts of aerosol generation and not closed suctioning. Commonly performed aerosol-generating procedures are: Open suctioning of the respiratory trac Bronchoscopy Cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) Non-invasive ventilation (e.g., BiPAP, CPAP) Endotracheal intubation and extubation Manual ventilation It is recommended that healthcare providers should be protected with PPE while performing these procedures. It must be performed in an adequately ventilated single room with a minimum of 12 air changes/hour.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 67-year-old patient with end-stage renal disease is tested positive for COVID-19. Which anticoagulation agent would you recommended for him?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of COVID-19 in a patient with end-stage renal disease. Unfractionated heparin is recommended for use in such patients. Prophylactic anticoagulation is used in the management of moderate and severe COVID cases. A prophylactic dose of low molecular weight heparin or unfractionated heparin is used to prevent thromboembolism. In a COVID patient with end-stage renal disease, unfractionated heparin is the preferred agent.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which case scenarios along with the drugs prescribed are inappropriate?
explanation: The correct answer is 1, 2, 3, and 4. Tocilizumab is contraindicated in HIV-positive patients and those with active bacterial or fungal infection. Bamlanivimab is not authorized for patients with mild COVID-19 pneumonia who are not at a high risk for hospitalization. Remedisivir is contraindicated in postnatal lactating women. Convalescent plasma therapy is no longer recommended in the management of COVID patients. Tocilizumab acts by IL-6 inhibition. It may be considered in moderate-severe COVID patients with progressively increasing oxygen requirements and mechanically ventilated patients not improving despite the use of steroids. Patients should be carefully monitored for secondary infections and neutropenia after treatment with tocilizumab. It is contraindicated in: HIV Active infections (systemic bacterial/fungal) Tuberculosis Active hepatitis Absolute neutrophil count < 2000/mm3 Platelet count < 1,00,000/mm3 Bamlanivimab is a monoclonal antibody directed against the spike protein of SARS-CoV-2. The FDA has issued an emergency use authorization for bamlanivimab for the treatment of adult and pediatric mild to moderate COVID patients (12 years of age and older weighing at least 40 kilograms) who are at high risk for progressing to severe COVID-19 and/or hospitalization. Possible side effects include anaphylaxis and infusion-related reactions, nausea, diarrhea, dizziness, headache, itching, and vomiting. There is no specific contraindication for this drug. Remdesivir is an antiviral drug that works by inhibiting RNA-dependent RNA polymerase. It may be considered in moderate and severe hospitalized COVID patients requiring supplemental oxygen/oxygen delivery through a high flow device/ noninvasive ventilation/ invasive mechanical ventilation/ ECMO. It is contraindicated in: AST/ALT > 5 times upper limit of normal Severe renal impairment (i.e., eGFR < 30ml/min/m2 or need for hemodialysis) Pregnancy or lactating females Children <12 years of age Convalescent plasma therapy is no longer recommended in the management of COVID patients, as per the revised guidelines. Dexamethasone is generally given to all patients of moderate and severe COVID-19. Patients with severe COVID-19 can develop a systemic inflammatory response that can lead to lung injury and multisystem organ dysfunction.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A G2P1 woman presents to the clinic at 36 weeks of gestation. Her husband was COVID positive and now she has also been tested positive. What is true regarding her management?
options: C-section is the preferred mode of delivery
Aim to keep oxygen saturation more than 94% during labour
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of COVID-19 disease in a pregnant patient. The management should include an aim to keep oxygen saturation above 94% during labour in this patient. In such cases, maternal observations and assessment during labour should be continued as per standard practice, with the addition of hourly oxygen saturation. Option A: There is currently no evidence to favour one mode of birth over another. Mode of birth should not be influenced by the presence of COVID-19, unless the woman’s respiratory condition demands urgent intervention for birth. Option B: Awake proning is recommended. Although evidence is limited, there are reports that this is feasible with appropriate padding up to at least 28 weeks of gestation. Option C: CT scan is relatively contraindicated. Pregnant women with abdominal shielding should not be excluded from chest CT if clinically recommended.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which of the following is a criterion for discharge in a patient with mild COVID-19 infection?
options: Discharge after 10 days from testing positive & no fever for 3 days
Discharge after 7 days from testing positive & no fever for 3 days
Discharge if SpO2>98% on room air for 3 consecutive days
Discharge if repeat RT-PCR testing is negative
explanation: COVID-19 cases that are mild/very mild/presymptomatic can be discharged from home isolation after 7 days of testing positive and no fever for 3 successive days. There is no need for testing after the end of home isolation. Criteria to diagnose asymptomatic COVID-19: Laboratory confirmed case with no symptoms with a saturation of more than 93% in room air. Criteria to diagnose mild COVID-19: Laboratory confirmed case with upper respiratory tract symptoms with/without fever, without shortness of breath, and saturation of more than 93% in room air. Patients are advised to isolate from other family members and monitor themselves at home, under proper medical guidance. Patients >60 years with co-morbidities, and immunocompromised patients are allowed to isolate only after receiving clearance from the designated medical officer. Immediate medical attention is required if the patient experiences the following: A 100 ºF fever persists for >3 days and does not resolve on medication. Difficulty in breathing Oxygen saturation 93% (at least 3 readings within 1 hour) Respiratory rate >24/min Persistent chest pain or pressure Mental confusion Severe fatigue or myalgia
subject: Medicine

question_text:
A 33-year-old delivery boy tested COVID-19 positive. He started experiencing worsening breathlessness and cough and rushed to the hospital when his pulse oximeter reading was
87%. Following treatment, he showed signs of improvement. What is correct before discharging him?
options: Discharge after 7 days from symptom onset & no fever for 3 days
Discharge if repeat RT-PCR testing is negative after recovery
Discharge if SpO2>98% on room air for 3 consecutive days
Discharge at the discretion of the treating medical officer
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of severe COVID-19 disease. Severe cases of COVID-19 (and immunocompromised patients) are discharged based on their clinical recovery at the discretion of the treating medical officer. Note: Mild and moderate cases do not need an RT-PCR test before discharge. But, at the time of discharge, they are advised to self-monitor and continue wearing masks for a duration of 7 days.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 10-year-old boy with COVID-19 presents with sore throat, rhinorrhea and cough. He does not have fast breathing. What is recommended for this child?
explanation: The presence of sore throat, rhinorrhea, cough with no fast breathing are suggestive of mild COVID-19 disease. Hence, home isolation along with supportive care is recommended in this child.
subject: Medicine

question_text:
FDA has recently sanctioned emergency use authorization to the first oral antiviral drug combination for the treatment of COVID-19. This drug combination contains:
Nirmatrelvir and Ritonavir
explanation: FDA recently sanctioned emergency use authorization to a combination of nirmatrelvir and ritonavir tablets (Paxlovid) for the treatment of mild-to-moderate COVID-19. It is the first oral antiviral for the treatment of COVID-19. Nirmatrelvir is a peptidomimetic inhibitor of the SARS-CoV-2 main protease (Mpro). Inhibition of this enzyme makes the virus incapable of processing polyprotein precursors and thus prevents viral replication. Ritonavir is an HIV-1 protease inhibitor. It inhibits the CYP3A-mediated metabolism of nirmatrelvir which results in increased plasma concentrations of nirmatrelvir. It is not active against SARS-CoV-2 Mpro. Patients who tested positive with direct SARS-CoV-2 test can be administered this drug combination, provided they are: 12 years of age and older Weighing at least 40 kgs At high risk for progression to severe COVID-19. Contraindications include hypersensitivity reactions to the active ingredients or any other components, co-administration with drugs highly dependent on CYP3A for clearance, co-administration with potent CYP3A inducers. Adverse reactions include dysgeusia, diarrhea, hypertension, and myalgia. COVID 19 - Prophylaxis and Complications
subject: Medicine

question_text:
Your worried friend calls you for advice after attending a family function. He informs you that his aunt, who also travelled to the function in the same car, tested positive for COVID-19.
What is your advice for your friend?
explanation: Home quarantine for 14 days is advised when a person comes in contact with a COVID-19 positive patient. The home quarantined person: Should stay in a well ventilated single room and stay away from high-risk individuals Should not attend any religious or social gatherings Must wash hands often Must change mask every 6-8 hrs Their surroundings must be disinfected with 1% sodium hypochlorite solution In case the person being quarantined becomes symptomatic, all his contacts should be home quarantined for 14 days and followed up for another 14 days or till the report turns out negative on lab testing. Isolation is the separation and restriction of movements or activities of persons who are sick, to prevent the transmission of disease. Quarantine is the separation and restriction of movements or activities of persons who are not ill but are believed to have been exposed to infection, for the purpose of preventing transmission of diseases.
subject: Medicine

question_text: A 50-year-old man recovering from COVID-19 presents as follows. His medical and personal histories are insignificant with no exposure to cold. What would you suspect?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of COVID toes. The image shows pernio-like lesions caused due to COVID-19. Pernio / chilblains are skin lesions on the acral surfaces of the body characterised by the development of erythematous-violaceous or purpuric macules. They may be accompanied by edema and pruritus. It is usually due to cold exposure or underlying hematological disorders but has also been reported in patients with COVID-19 disease. The underlying mechanism is thought to be an inflammatory process. The lesions appear late (postviral phase) with the patients exhibiting positive IgM/ IgG antibodies for SARS-CoV-2 and negative RT-PCR. However, pernio like lesions can also be seen in early stages of the disease when the patients are still infective. There are no treatment guidelines but high-potency topical corticosteroids may be helpful if the lesions are causing discomfort. Other cutaneous manifestations include exanthematous rash, livedo reticularis, urticaria, MIS-C etc.
subject: Medicine

question_text: While donning a set of PPE, what is the order that you will follow?
explanation: The correct sequence of donning a PPE is first pair of gloves  coverall  Shoe cover  N-95 mask. Preparation for donning the PPE: To be performed only in the designated area The health care worker must be prepared for the shift duty by Taking a meal Using the washroom Drinking water prior to entering the donning area Remove all accessories, jewelry Change into clean hospital scrubs and closed washable footwear Perform hand hygiene with soap and water Steps of donning/putting on the PPE: Hand hygiene Wear the first pair of gloves Sterile or unsterile Make sure the cuff of the gloves goes as far as possible Examine and wear coverall Examine the coverall for any damage Start by wearing the leg sleeves and then the arm sleeves Zip up and cover the zip with the flap attached Wear shoe cover Sit on the clean chair and wear shoe cover Pull them up till your calves Wear N-95 mask and wear hood Hold the mask like a cup in the hand with both the straps hanging out in the front Place the mask on the face, pull and wear the lower strap first placing it below the ears Then pull and wear the upper strap placing above the ears The air leakage should be minimum around the mask when forcibly exhaling Wear the hood covering the forehead and the cheeks Wear face shield/eye goggles over the hood and ensure the fit Wear the second pair of gloves - pull the gloves to cover the sleeve cuff and forearm as much as possible
subject: Medicine

question_text: While doffing, what is the first component of the PPE that you would remove?
explanation: The component of the PPE kit to be removed first is the shoe covers. Preparation for doffing the PPE: To be performed only in the designated area Check for any leak or soiling Doffing room should have two chairs, dirty and clean All the PPE must be discarded in the red bin Hand hygiene must be performed after every step Steps of doffing the PPE: Engage the observer and ask him to check the PPE - observer should check for any leak, tear, or contamination of PPE. If contaminated, then it should be disinfected with alcohol-based wipes. Disinfect the gloves Remove and discard shoe covers Sit on the dirty chair with legs apart Remove the shoe covers by slowly pulling the outer surface starting from the top and then pull rom the toes end. Discard them Disinfect and remove outer pair of gloves While removing the outer gloves, inner gloves should not be torn or contaminated Pinch the first glove on the outer surface at the wrist and pull it inside out Hold this glove in the other hand like a ball Slide the thumb inside the other glove and remove inside out balling around the previous glove, making it into a single bag. Then discard it. Disinfect inner gloves Remove face shield/eye goggle - loosen the screw and remove the face shield by holding it from the back handle. Discard it. Disinfect inner gloves again Remove hood and coverall Slide back the hood by holding it from the top Separate the zip flap and unzip the coverall suit Holding the suit at the arms, slide it off the shoulder slightly, then pull the suit from the side o the waist Roll the arms out one by one By touching the inner surface of the suit carefully roll out each leg. Discard it Disinfect and remove inner gloves as previously described Perform hand hygiene and wear a new pair of gloves Remove and discard N-95 mask Do not touch the exposed surface of the mask Stoop forward and first remove the lower strap Then pull out the upper strap and remove the mask Disinfect gloves Sit on the clean chair and disinfect shoes using alcohol wipes Disinfect and remove gloves Perform hand hygiene Wipe the shoes on sodium hypochlorite soaked doormat at exit Exit the doffing area and take a shower
subject: Medicine

question_text: You are a medical officer at the designated COVID hospital in your city and are required to don PPE every day at work. Which area of the PPE should you not touch while doffing?
explanation: The front of the face shield is considered to be a contaminated area of the personal protective equipment (PPE). Hence, it should not be touched while doffing. The areas that are considered clean are the parts that will be touched while removing a PPE: Inside the gloves Inside and back of the gown including the ties Ties or earpieces of the mask, goggles, and face shields The areas that are considered contaminated are: Outside front and sleeves of the isolation gown Front of goggles, mask, respirator, and face shield Outside of the gloves
subject: Medicine

question_text: After your COVID ICU shift, where would you dispose your face shield?
explanation: The face shield used by a healthcare worker during COVID-19 pandemic is disposed in the red bin.

question_text: What is recommended for cleaning and disinfecting a healthcare facility against COVID-19?
explanation: 1% sodium hypochlorite is recommended for cleaning and disinfection against COVID-19. The sodium hypochlorite solution should be prepared fresh. Leaving the solution for a contact time of at least 10 minutes is recommended. Note: Alcohol (e.g. isopropyl 70% or ethyl alcohol 70%) can be used to wipe down surfaces where the use of bleach is not suitable, e.g. metals.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Identify the wrong match regarding COVID-19 vaccines:
explanation: The Moderna COVID-19 vaccine is also an mRNA-based vaccine. Vaccines Mechanism Pfizer/BioNtech (Comirnaty) mRNA based vaccine Moderna mRNA based vaccine Oxford University/ Astra Zen eca/ Serum Institute of India (Covishield) Non-replicating viral vector Gamaleya (Sputnik V)/ Dr.Re ddys Non-replicating viral vector Johnson and Johnson (Janss en Ad26.CoV2.S) Non-replicating viral vector Bharat biotech/NIV (Covaxin) Inactivated vaccine Zydus Cadila (ZyCoV-D) Plasmid DNA vaccine Novavax Protein subunit The Drugs Controller General of India (DCGI) has granted permission for restricted emergency use of the following vaccines against COVID-19: Covaxin (Bharat biotech/NIV) Covishield (Oxford University/ AstraZeneca/ Serum Institute of India) Sputnik V (Gamaleya Research Institute/ Dr. Reddy's Laboratories) ZyCoV-D (Zydus Cadila) The FDA has issued an emergency use authorization for the following vaccines against COVID-19: Pfizer/BioNtech Moderna Johnson and Johnson According to the new vaccine guidelines by NEGVAC (National Expert Group on Vaccine Administration for COVID-19): Vaccination is to be deferred by 3 months in the following persons: Individuals (proven positive) recovered from the disease. Recipients of monoclonal antibodies or convalescent plasma. 2nd dose is to be deferred by 3 months if infected with COVID after 1st dose. 4-8 weeks gap, after recovery of patients with other serious illnesses requiring hospitalization/ICU care. Blood donation: Wait for 14 days after receiving the vaccine/testing RT-PCR negative. No screening is required by rapid antigen test (RAT) prior to vaccination. Recommended for all lactating women. COVID-19 vaccination during pregnancy: MoHFW has recently approved the vaccination of pregnant women against COVID-19. COVID-19 vaccine can be taken anytime during pregnancy and should be taken at the earliest. If any woman has been infected with COVID-19 during pregnancy, she should be vaccinated soon after delivery. COVID-19 vaccine is safe in pregnancy.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Four days after being extubated, an elderly diabetic man with COVID-19 developed rhinosinusitis. The tissue obtained from the sinuses showed the following. The physician wanted to start the patient on amphotericin B. However, it was not available. Which other drug can be given to this patient?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of mucormycosis. Intravenous administration o amphotericin B is the first line treatment. Other drugs which are approved for its management include isavuconazole and posaconazole. Surgical debridement is the last line management. Immunocompromised states are important risk factors including diabetes mellitus and glucocorticoid treatment as well as patients on ventilation. Diagnosis can be made by culturing the organisms from sterile sites like needle aspirate, pleural fluid, or a tissue biopsy specimen. The biopsy is most sensitive. It reveals characteristic wide, thick-walled, ribbon-like, aseptate hyphal elements that branch at right angles. It can present as: Rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis - (most common) the initial symptoms are nonspecific and include eye or facial pain and facial numbness followed by the onset of conjunctival suffusion and blurry vision. If untreated it can spread from the sinuses to the orbit, and then to the frontal lobe. Pulmonary mucormycosis - (second most common) Cutaneous mucormycosis - usually results after trauma Gastrointestinal mucormycosis - primarily occurs in premature neonates who have disseminated disease or necrotizing enterocolitis Disseminated mucormycosis
subject: Medicine

question_text: A young girl, who recently recovered from COVID-19, presents with fever, abdominal pain and rashes for 4 days. On examination, strawberry tongue is observed and cervical nodes are found to be enlarged bilaterally. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: This is a case of multisystem inflammatory syndrome in children (MIS-C), associated with COVID-19 infection. Diagnostic criteria for MIS-C: Children and adolescents 0–18 years of age with fever 3 days AND two of these: Rash or bilateral non-purulent conjunctivitis or mucocutaneous inflammation signs (palmoplantar erythema, lip hyperemia, periorbital erythema and edema, strawberry tongue, and malar erythema) Hypotension or shock. Features of myocardial dysfunction, pericarditis, valvulitis, or coronary abnormalities (including ECHO findings or elevated Troponin/NT-proBNP) Evidence of coagulopathy (PT, PTT, elevated D-Dimers) Acute gastrointestinal problems (diarrhoea, vomiting, or abdominal pain) AND Elevated ESR(>40 mm), C-reactive protein (>5 mg/L), or procalcitonin. AND No other obvious microbial cause of inflammation including bacterial sepsis, staphylococcal or streptococcal shock syndromes. AND Evidence of COVID-19 (RT-PCR, antigen test, or serology positive), or likely contact with patients with COVID-19. Types of MIS-C: MIS-C with shock/multi-organ dysfunction Kawasaki phenotype MIS-C without shock MIS-C is treated with IV methylprednisolone. The dose can be increased in patients with shock. If the condition does not improve for 48-72 hours, specialists can be consulted for the addition of biologicals to the treatment regimen.
subject: Medicine

question_text: Which gene increases the risk of collapsing glomerulopathy in COVID-19 patients?
explanation: APOL1 gene increases the risk of collapsing nephropathy in patients infected with COVID-19. Glomerular lesions are reported in a minority of COVID-19 patients. They are associated with collapsing focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) and are called COVID-associated nephropathy (COVAN). Such patients present with nephrotic-range proteinuria and acute kidney injury (AKI). It specifically affects individuals of African ancestry who are carriers of this gene variant. Thrombotic microangiopathy is another uncommon finding among these patients. Histopathology is similar to those seen in other forms of collapsing glomerulopathy. But, tubulointerstitial lesions including microcystic tubular dilatation and tubular injury are typically associated with APOL1- related disease.
subject: Medicine

question_text: As a healthcare worker working in a COVID hospital, you receive the following vaccine. Which of the following is not an adverse event related to this vaccine?
explanation: Demyelinating disorders are rare adverse events following Covishield, not Covaxin. explanation: The 51-year-old man should receive COVID-19 vaccination at least 3 months after hematopoietic cell transplantation (and not 5 weeks) to maximize vaccine efficacy. Graft-versus-host disease and immunosuppressive regimens like systemic corticosteroids can blunt the immune responses to vaccination. Delay of vaccination until immunosuppressive therapy is reduced can be considered. Consider additional risk factors linked to adverse COVID-19 complications including, but not limited to: Patients with advanced age (eg, 65 years of age) Patients with comorbidities (eg, chronic pulmonary, cardiovascular, or renal disease) Social and demographic factors COVID-19 vaccines should be prioritized over other vaccines. A gap of 14 days is recommended between COVID-19 vaccines and any other vaccine. If COVID vaccine has been given first, then TT vaccine can be given on the same day. A 24-year-old boy who had SARS CoV-2 infection 3 months back came with complaints of fatigue and shortness of breath for 3 days. The minimum duration of these symptoms to define it as post-Covid-19 condition according to WHO is
2 months
explanation: The minimum duration of symptoms such as fatigue, shortness of breath to define it as post Covid-19 condition according to WHO is 2 months. WHO clinical case definition of post Covid-19 - Post Covid-19 condition occurs in individuals with a history of probable or confirmed SARS CoV-2 infection, usually 3 months from the onset of Covid-19, with symptoms that last for at least 2 months and cannot be explained by an alternative diagnosis. Common symptoms include Fatigue Shortness of breath Cognitive dysfunction.
